headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    * Chase Manhattan Corp. is issuing $175 million, up from $150 million, of 12-year floating rate Euronotes through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers International. Interest is set at 1/4 of a percentage point above the three-month London interbank offered rate, with a maximum 13 1/4 percent coupon after four years.    * Citicorp is issuing $350 million of 50-year floating rate Euronotes through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. Interest is set at 22 1/2 basis points above the one-month London interbank bid rate. The notes, which have a minimum 5 percent coupon, are callable after three years.

headline: DIGITAL PLANS I.B.M. LINKAGE
abstract: The Digital Equipment Corporation said yesterday that it plans to introduce an I.B.M.-compatible personal computer, leaving Apple Computer Inc. as the sole American computer maker that has not adopted the I.B.M. architecture.   Digital's chief executive, Kenneth H. Olsen, confirmed the company's plan at the company's annual meeting in Boston.

headline: Japanese Bank Plans To Issue Bonds in U.S.
abstract: In another effort to raise the value of the yen, the Government-owned Japan Development Bank today announced that it would issue $200 million of seven-year  bonds in New York next month.         By converting the bond proceeds into yen, the financing could help to strengthen the yen. But economists in Tokyo said that more institutions would have to follow suit to guarantee any substantial appreciation in the yen.

headline: AFRIKANER MINISTER TELLS OF HIS LONG ROAD OF CONVERSION FROM APARTHEID
abstract: He was 4 years old, the Rev. Nico Smith said, when he learned his first lesson of apartheid: You talk to blacks, his mother told him, only when you have an order to give to them, a command to impart.   The lesson, he says now with a rueful smile, seemed to take root and blossom.   When the Afrikaner National Party came to power in 1948 on a platform of racial separation, he recalls with the same smile, he rejoiced.   He studied in Pretoria and joined the Dutch Reformed Church, which found scriptural justification for apartheid. He was called into the ranks of the secretive and powerful Afrikaner fellowship called the Broederbond. He became a professor in the theology department at the University of Stellenbosch in the Cape, a cradle of Afrikanerdom. In terms of the orthodoxy of his forebears, he had arrived.

headline: AFGHAN REBELS REPORT CAPTURE OF ARMY BASE
abstract: Moslem rebels fighting the Soviet-backed regime in Afghanistan have captured an army headquarters base and a Government official, rebel spokesmen in Peshawar said today.

headline: Yankee Publishing Buys Alaska Magazine
abstract: The Yankee Publishing Company of Dublin, N.H., already the home of six publications, has just reached an agreement to acquire its seventh. And it has taken quite a reach.

headline: BONN SAYS IT SEEKS 'STAR WARS' ROLE
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's center-right coalition announced today that it would negotiate with the United States over a role for West German industry in the so-called ''Star Wars'' missile defense program.   A statement said Economics Minister Martin Bangemann would go to Washington next month to negotiate the agreement on the program, officially known as the Strategic Defense Initiative.   At its last meeting before the Christmas break, the Cabinet agreed on a mandate for Mr. Bangemann that amounted to a compromise between Mr. Kohl, who supports the American defense program, and Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, who is known to have serious doubts about it.   A Government statement said Mr. Bangemann, who is the chairman of the small Free Democratic Party, would negotiate ''an improvement in the general conditions for the mutual transfer of the results of scientific research and technological information.''

headline: Abbas Called 'Surprised'
abstract: An Italian official said today that Mohammed Abbas, the P.L.O. official, had  told him ''he was surprised when he learned of the ship's hijacking.''         The official, Antonio Badini, said he talked to Mr. Abbas as they flew from Sicily to Rome last week aboard the Egyptian airliner that had been intercepted earlier by American fighter planes. Along with Mr. Abbas and an aide, it had been carrying the four hijackers from Egypt to what they thought would be sanctuary.

headline: Bomb Blast on Train In India Kills 2 Hindus
abstract: A bomb exploded Friday night on a train packed with Hindu workers entering Punjab state, killing 2 passengers and wounding 18 others, the police said today.

headline: UNITED NATIONS CALENDAR
abstract: ANNUAL RECEPTION - Diplomats will gather tonight at the annual reception for the chairmen of delegations to the General Assembly, which will be held 6:30-8:30 P.M. in the Delegates' Lounge. The sponsors of the gathering, which is expected to attract several hundred people, are Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar and Jaime de Pinies, President of the General Assembly.   SLOWING DOWN - Only six speakers, the smallest number in the 14 days of general debate, are scheduled to address the General Assembly today. Leading the schedule is the Acting Foreign Minister of the Philippines, Pacifico A. Castro. He will followed by representatives of the Comoro Islands, a nation off the coast of Mozambique, and Qatar. The Foreign Minister of Bangladesh, Humayun R. Choudhury, is the last speaker scheduled this morning. He is expected to be the president of the Assembly next year. In the afternoon, delegates will hear from representatives of Cameroon and Malta.

headline: Assad Meets Leaders Of Lebanese Factions
abstract: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria met today with leaders of three Lebanese factions and offered assurances that Syria would help carry out an agreement designed to end Lebanon's 10-year-old civil war.   The Lebanese leaders - Nabih Berri of the Shiite movement Amal, Walid Jumblat of the Progressive Socialist Party, a mostly Druse group, and Elie Hobeika, commander of the Christian militia known as the Lebanese Forces - signed the agreement on Saturday in Damascus, Syria.

headline: CLASH OVER KELLY ROLE AT BEATRICE
abstract: Top executives of the Beatrice Companies offered to support a $4.9 billion takeover if Donald P. Kelly, the Chicago businessman, was excluded from the deal, insiders said yesterday.         But the investment house leading the offering group - Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company -refused to leave Mr. Kelly out, these sources said. Beatrice  executives then refused to negotiate, the sources said, and subsequently, on Sunday, Beatrice directors decided that they preferred for the company to remain independent.

headline: CHIP MAKER POSTS A LOSS
abstract: Advanced Micro Devices, a leading semiconductor maker based in Sunnyvale, Calif., reported a loss of $15.3 million for its second fiscal quarter ended in September, in contrast to a profit of $42.1 million, or 72 cents a share, a year earlier.   Sales of $128 million in the quarter were only half the $257 million recorded in the 1984 period.

headline: Southern Bell
abstract: The Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Company is offering $300 million of 10 3/4 percent debentures, due in 2025, at a price of 99.05 to yield 10.885 percent, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company. The yield on the debentures, which are callable after five years and rated Aa-3 by Moody's and AA+ by S.&P., was about seven-tenths of a percetage point higher than for Treasury bonds due in 2012. Proceeds will be used to finance the redemption of $300 million of 12 7/8 percent debentures due in 2020.

headline: SPEECHES BY TWO IN OSLO
abstract: Following are the speeches here today by Dr. Yevgeny I. Chazov and Dr. Bernard Lown, accepting the 1985 Nobel Peace Prize on behalf of International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War:    Chazov Address Ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues, I am convinced that today is a great and exciting day not only for the members of our international movement but also for all physicians on our planet, regardless of their political and religious beliefs. For the first time in history, their selfless service for the cause of maintaining life on earth is marked by the high Nobel Prize.   True to the Hippocratic oath, we cannot keep silent knowing what can the final epidemic - nuclear war -bring to the humankind. The bell of Hiroshima rings in our hearts not as funeral knell but as an alarm bell calling out to actions to protect life on our planet.   We were among the first to demolish the nuclear illusions that existed and to unveil the true face of nuclear weapons - the weapons of genocide. We warned the peoples and governments that medicine would be helpless to offer even minimal relief to the hundreds of millions of victims in nuclear war.

headline: Philippine-I.M.F. Pact
abstract: The Philippine Government announced International Monetary Fund approval of further draw-downs from a standby credit of 615 million special drawing rights.

headline: Dirty Money' Curbs Asked
abstract: Administration officials urged Congress today to make ''money laundering'' a  Federal offense and to stiffen penalties against banks that do not report large  cash transactions.  Assistant Attorney General Stephen Trott told the Senate Judiciary Committee that organized crime uses banks and other businesses to make billions of dollars obtained from drug trafficking and other illegal activities look as though it came from legal sources. The law now requires banks to report cash transactions over $10,000 but ''contains no sanctions for washing dirty money,'' he said.  David Queen, Acting Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, said the present law is not strong enough.  The officials urged Congress to raise the minimum penalty for not reporting large cash transactions  to $25,000, from $10,000.

headline: SOVIET LEADING BID TO DISMISS UNESCO'S AMERICANS
abstract: The second day of a Unesco conference here was dominated today by a Soviet-led effort to dismiss all American nationals working for the agency, from which the United States resigned in protest at the end of last year.   The Soviet effort, supported by Algeria, India and Cameroon, could also lead to the closing of the observer mission that the United States still keeps at Unesco as well as to a decision to prosecute the United States before the International Court of Justice for nonpayment of its share of this year's budget.   The Soviet Union demanded that the General Conference, Unesco's supreme decision-making body, should itself quickly debate and decide the organization's future relationship with the United States. The Reagan Administration said it quit the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization because it regarded the agency as unduly politicized and hostile to Western values.

headline: COPING WITH COLLEGE COSTS
abstract: AT Duquesne University in Pittsburgh, alumni can pay for the entire tuition cost of their children who may enter Duquesne up to 18 years from now, with a single, fixed lump sum.   At Washington University in St. Louis, parents of entering undergraduates can make a single payment for the full four years' tuition at the rate in effect during the freshman year.   And at the University of Southern California, a tuition installment plan lets families avoid large payments twice a year, by financing the annual tuition bill over a number of months at below-market interest rates.   These are just a few of the ways that families who do not qualify for government-subsidized loans are attempting to meet the escalating expenses of higher education. And with the annual cost of attending college expected to rise an average of 7 percent during the current academic year alone - following increases of 10 to 11 percent in the early 1980's - more parents are taking advantage of such financial devices to handle what might otherwise be an unmanageable expense.

headline: EX-HOSTAGES TELL HOUSE PANEL OF HIJACKING
abstract: With two of the former hostages from the Achille Lauro seated at the witness table before them, members of a Congressional committee argued today over whether there was anything the United States could do to force foreign cruise lines to impose tighter security.   The former hostages, Viola and Seymour Meskin of Union, N.J., testified that before the Achille Lauro was seized by terrorists, they had seen no evidence of any security precautions.   Mr. Meskin said their bags were never searched or examined. Mrs Meskin recalled that when the cruise ship was at berth in Alexandria, Egyptian merchants selling jewelry and other wares were allowed on board.

headline: JARUZELSKI VISITING LIBYA
abstract: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, flew to Libya today on the first stop of a three-country tour of North Africa. He will also visit Algeria and Tunisia.

headline: SERVICE STOCKS STAR IN 6-WEEK ADVANCE
abstract: When the Dow Jones industrial average moved above 1,400 last week and held its ground, the new high dramatized a broad rally that began in late September to give the bull market new life. Among the 30 Dow stocks, the star performers included Exxon, American Can, Du Pont and Woolworth, along with McDonald's, a newcomer.         The groups that did best in the period were tied mainly to consumer spending  and the service segment of the economy. Most portfolio managers believe these same areas will continue to prosper in the stock market in coming months, while  many industrial companies struggle to improve their profitability.

headline: FED TO CURB BANKS' FUNDS TRANSFERS
abstract: Concerned about the electronic payment systems that banks use to send money around the nation, the Federal Reserve Board is moving to introduce a sweeping change in how the systems are operated.   The Fed has asked the banks to set limits voluntarily on how much they may overdraw their accounts at the Fed when using Fedwire, a system of computers and Telex connections operated by the central bank. Fedwire is the principal means by which banks exchange funds in transactions other than those involving checks.   The self-determined limits on overdrafts, which have been criticized by Wall Street analysts, are due at the Fed tomorrow and are scheduled to take effect in March. Each bank's limit will also apply to the negative balances it builds up in other wire-transfer systems, such as the Clearing House Interbank Payments System, or Chips, the primary means by which banks exchange money internationally.

headline: B.B.D.O. Wins Line Of Polaroid
abstract: BATTEN, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, which has been doing direct marketing work for Polaroid, has now won the corporation's entire domestic consumer account, which covers both its amateur photographic equipment and half-inch videotape.   Tom Clark, president of the agency, got the good news at home on Christmas Day from Peter Eichorn, Polaroid's head of advertising and sales promotion for consumer products.   ''It made my Christmas instantly happy,'' Mr. Clark said.

headline: Treasury Closes Year With Bill Sale
abstract: The United States Treasury will close its 1985 regular bill auctions today with the sale of $5.2 billion of 90- and 180-day bills, and will start its 1986 funding program by auctioning $6.5 billion of seven-year notes on Thursday.   The holiday-season calendar of new fixed-income offerings will otherwise remain light and confined to tax-exempt issues.

headline: STOCK OFFER BY MURDOCH MAY BE USED IN TV BID
abstract: Rupert Murdoch told the Federal Communications Commission today that the company he has created to purchase a group of television stations from Metromedia Inc. may offer stock to the public to help raise funds to finance the $1.4 billion takeover.   It would be the first public offering in the United States of stock in a company controlled by the international publisher, although some bonds held by his 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation are publicly held.   The possibility of a public stock sale was among the general details of a capitalization plan for Mr. Murdoch's company, News America Television Inc., which has proposed to purchase seven and retain six television outlets that reach 22 percent of the nation's viewing audience. The stations include those in major markets such as New York City, Washington, Chicago, Dallas and Los Angeles.

headline: NEW YORK-JERSEY COSTS RISE 0.8%
abstract: Consumer prices in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area jumped eight-tenths of 1 percent in November, the largest monthly increase since January 1984, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.  The regional commissioner of the bureau, Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, attributed the increase to higher costs for housing, energy, meats and transportation. The January 1984 increase was 1 percent.

headline: BREADTH OF PROBLEMS STIRS CALLS FOR ANOTHER SYNOD
abstract: Joseph Cardinal Malula of Zaire, one of the presidents of the extraordinary Synod of Bishops called to examine the results of the Second Vatican Council, said today that another meeting might be required to adequately examine the problems facing the church.   ''The limited amount of time available to discuss all the problems in the church doesn't enable us to deliberate in much depth,'' he said. ''I see no real problem having another synod in five years.''   Cardinal Malula's comments reflected a general view among the church leaders assembled here that they have been overwhelmed by the sheer breadth of the problems they have had to discuss.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 14, 1985
abstract: International    The Senate voted for stringent quotas on textile imports from 12 countries, most of them in Asia. The vote was 60 to 39. A similar version was passed last month by the House, and now a conference will have to reconcile the two measures. Senator Evans of Washington forecast a Presidential veto, but supporters of the bill said Mr. Reagan would sign it for political reasons. [Page D1.]    The President's trade advisers want him to file complaints against Japan and Taiwan. The charges would involve ''dumping'' of computer chips by the Japanese below their fair value and Taiwan's failure to protect copyrights and trademarks. [D2.]

headline: NEW ZEALAND SEIZES ARMS ON SHIP
abstract: Customs officials raided a French freighter tonight and confiscated 25 packages of automatic weapons and ammunition, the authorities said.   It was not known for whom the weapons were intended, but there was speculation that the arms may have been destined for right-wing French settlers who are battling an independence movement in New Caledonia, a French territory in the Pacific.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Arizona Bancwest Corp., Phoenix, said its shareholders had approved the merger into Security Pacific Corp. for $45 a share, or a total of about $480 million.    * Chicago Pacific Corp. said it had begun buying shares tendered in its offer for the Hoover Co.

headline: U.S.-SOVIET PACT ON CHEMICAL ARMS IS SAID TO BE NEAR
abstract: The United States and the Soviet Union are poised to announce at the Geneva summit meeting that they have agreed to combine efforts to halt the spread of chemical weapons, Reagan Administration officials said today.   American Government officials also said the two countries had concluded a new cultural exchange agreement, which the Administration hopes will lead to a significant increase in the number of young people visiting and studying in the two countries. Mr. Reagan is expected to discuss the cultural accord in a nationally broadcast speech at 8 o'clock Thursday night. [Page A12.]  The officials said that Moscow had agreed to the accord on chemical weapons and that the Administration had agreed in principle, although they said the Pentagon was continuing to resist giving final approval. Details on how to put the pledge into effect have not been worked out, the officials said.      Announcement at End of Talks    Officials said the pledge on chemical weapons was one of several arms-control statements that the two sides have prepared for announcement at the end of the meetings next week between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Arthur Young, the accounting and consulting firm, has appointed Guy C. Jackson to the newly created position of national director of strategic planning.    * Emerson Electric Co. has appointed Harry R. Baker president of its U.S. Electrical Motors division.

headline: Church's to Close 100 Restaurants
abstract: Church's Fried Chicken Inc. said that it was closing about 100 of its fried-chicken restaurants in a move that would reduce first-quarter earnings between 11 cents and 15 cents a share. J. David Bamberger, chairman and chief executive, said that most of the restaurants are geographically remote and difficult to market.

headline: Meritor Financial Names a New Chief
abstract: The Meritor Financial Group, which will serve as a holding company for seven financial service companies, including PSFS of Philadelphia, the nation's oldest and largest savings bank, announced that Frederick S. Hammer had been named chairman and chief executive officer.   Mr. Hammer, who is 49 years old, joined PSFS on Jan. 1, 1985 as president and chief operating officer after serving as executive vice president in charge of worldwide consumer banking at the Chase Manhattan Bank.   He succeeds M. Todd Cooke, 65, who has been chairman and chief executive since 1979. The Meritor board said on Friday that Mr. Cooke had been elected vice chairman, a position he will hold until April 1987, when he is scheduled to retire.

headline: MARKET REACTION STRONG AMID DOUBTS ON OPEC
abstract: The threat by OPEC oil ministers to wage a price war to protect a fixed share of the world market reverberated through the commodity and stock exchanges yesterday.   Prices of crude oil and petroleum products fell sharply in worldwide trading. The stocks of oil companies also slumped on the New York Stock Exchange.   Investor optimism that a decline in crude oil prices would lead to lower inflation led to strong advances elsewhere in the stock market and in the bond market. Conversely, prices of gold and silver, which are both traded as hedges against inflation, fell noticeably. And the dollar rose against most currencies, while the pound, which is very sensitive to oil-price fluctuations because of Britain's North Sea holdings, declined.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: * Blount Inc., Montgomery, Ala., which provides construction and engineering services, has elected to its board Robert M. Adams, senior vice president of the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Co.    * Bostrom Corp., a trade association management company based in Chicago, has named James S. Nicol senior vice president and account executive.

headline: Dial Drive Stresses Education
abstract: THE newest new management of the five-year-old Dial magazine thinks it has found the way to go as far as drawing advertisers to the 1.2-million-circulation publication that offers public televison programming. Education. ''It was the one demographic that just jumped off the page,'' explained Jeffrey S. Butler, chairman of the East/West Network, publisher of 10 in-flight magazines for airlines, which has added Dial to its responsibilities.   So on Monday the publication, which is distributed by 14 leading public television stations, will start a new trade campaign emphasizing the educational attainment of its readership. Monday will also mark the beginning of National Education Week, noted a pleased Estelle Ellis, president of Business Image, the agency that created the campaign.   The lead-off ad will be headed ''The Demo That Makes the Difference,'' followed by ''Education'' printed four times using each of the colors - blue, red, green and yellow - that since April have been part of the magazine's logotype. In the redesign of the magazine, created by Bob Cato, the magazine's name is boxed in with daubs of those colors and a single daub of one of those colors is used to emphasize the title of each article.

headline: Fairfield Communities Is Losing Its President
abstract: Fairfield Communities Inc., a leading developer of retirement and recreational resort communities in the Sun Belt, announced that George F. Donovan, its president and chief operating officer, has resigned.   Mr. Donovan, who has held his posts since January 1981, is leaving for personal reasons and to pursue other business interests, the company said.

headline: Russians Are Angola Target
abstract: A rebel group said today that at least 12 Russians were killed when bombs planted by its forces exploded in Soviet officers' quarters in Huambo several days ago. The group, the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, also said that its guerrillas killed 17 Angolan Government soldiers in an attack last Thursday on the town of Que in southern Huila Province.

headline: STOCKS COOL OFF ON PROFIT TAKING
abstract: The stock market retreated in orderly fashion yesterday as investors, laden with gains from the two previous sessions, took profits.   ''We don't have any of the get-me-out-at-any-price type of selling,'' said Martin Krouner, managing director of L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin. The mildness of yesterday's selloff was evident in the volume figures. Only 109.7 million shares were traded, down sharply from the 170.8 million on Tuesday, when Wall Street experienced its seventh-busiest session ever.

headline: Advertising;   Lincoln-Mercury Gets Minority Agency
abstract: Unlike the Ford division, its sister operation in the Ford Motor Company, Lincoln-Mercury has not had an independent specialty agency to do advertising for minority markets.

headline: U.S. Contractor 'Espionage' Charged
abstract: A former Defense Department investigator charged today that as many as 25 military contractors have illegally obtained Pentagon documents to help them bid on Government contracts.   The investigator, Robert L. Segal, said in prepared testimony that a Government investigation had uncovered evidence that many of the companies have set up ''espionage units'' to steal the material. He said some of those involved were ''household names,'' but he did not identify any.   ''Classified documents which are prohibited from ever leaving'' the Defense Department ''are regularly trafficked among private consultants, companies in the procurement industry and military and civilian employees of the government,'' Mr. Segal said in testimony prepared for a Senate subcommittee.

headline: Advertising;   HCM/New York
abstract: Patrick Hillman, 37, has been promoted to managing director of HCM/New York, from senior vice president and director of overall planning for the entire company. The agency is a joint venture of Young & Rubicam and Havas Conseil of France. Mr. Hillman was formerly with Scali, McCabe, Sloves and Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver.

headline: 12 ARGENTINES ORDERED SEIZED
abstract: President Raul Alfonsin invoked special executive powers early today and ordered the immediate arrest of six military officers and six civilians suspected of participating in a recent wave of right-wing violence.   The arrest decree said the Government had ''detected the existence of a group of persons acting in a coordinated way with the common objective of using violence against democratic institutions and people.''   Those listed in the decree, which did not list specific charges, included a cashiered general who has been a fugitive since last year, three active military officers, a military cadet, two journalists and two civilians who held posts in former military Governments. It was unclear if there was any connection between the suspects.

headline: Acme Head Promoted By American Stores
abstract: The American Stores Company, the nation's third-largest supermarket chain, yesterday named Thomas W. King, the head of its Acme supermarket division, president and chief operating officer, effective next Feb. 2.   Mr. King, 54, fills posts that had been vacant since Thomas W. Field Jr. resigned last year to become president of the McKesson Corporation. American Stores's chairman and chief executive, S. L. Skaggs, 62, had performed some of the duties of president, while others were filled by a three-man office of the president, which was made up of three senior vice presidents and will now be eliminated.

headline: LEADERS OF SIX NATIONS TELL OF THEIR HOPES AND WORRIES
abstract: SRI LANKA Ranasinghe Premadasa Prime Minister 'A New Global Pact' Between the Haves And the Have-Nots The Prime Minister of Sri Lanka appealed to the General Assembly to approve an emergency resolution asking the United States and the Soviet Union to reduce their military expenditures by 40 percent over the next five years.   The Prime Minister, Ranasinghe Premadasa, said a significant part of the money saved under the plan should go toward reducing the foreign debts of developing nations.   ''What we offer is the beginning of a new global pact between those who have resources and those who represent the political and commercial marketplaces of the future,'' Mr. Premadasa said. ''What we demand is an end to a system where the security of the many is hostage to the amibtions of a few.''

headline: Puerto Rico Sewer Unit Sets $320 Million Sale
abstract: The Puerto Rico Aqueduct and Sewer Authority is offering $320 million of revenue and refunding revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 9 percent for securities due in 2009 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.   For shorter maturities, investors were tentatively offered yields ranging from 5 1/2 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 6 3/4 percent in 1990, 8 percent in 1995 and 8 3/4 percent in 2000.

headline: 2 Concerns Move To Bar Takeovers
abstract: The Weyerhaeuser Company, the giant paper concern based in Tacoma, Wash., said today that its shareholders had approved antitakeover measures, including a provision that important transactions be approved by 80 percent of shareholders or a majority of continuing directors.

headline: Boesky Increases Stake in Harris
abstract: The New York investor Ivan F. Boesky said he had increased his stake in Harris Graphics Inc. to 8.4 percent of the common shares outstanding.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    * Chase Manhattan Corp. is issuing $175 million, up from $150 million, of 12-year floating rate Euronotes through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers International. Interest is set at 1/4 of a percentage point above the three-month London interbank offered rate, with a maximum 13 1/4 percent coupon after four years.    * Citicorp is issuing $350 million of 50-year floating rate Euronotes through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. Interest is set at 22 1/2 basis points above the one-month London interbank bid rate. The notes, which have a minimum 5 percent coupon, are callable after three years.

headline: DIGITAL PLANS I.B.M. LINKAGE
abstract: The Digital Equipment Corporation said yesterday that it plans to introduce an I.B.M.-compatible personal computer, leaving Apple Computer Inc. as the sole American computer maker that has not adopted the I.B.M. architecture.   Digital's chief executive, Kenneth H. Olsen, confirmed the company's plan at the company's annual meeting in Boston.

abstract: In another effort to raise the value of the yen, the Government-owned Japan Development Bank today announced that it would issue $200 million of seven-year  bonds in New York next month.         By converting the bond proceeds into yen, the financing could help to strengthen the yen. But economists in Tokyo said that more institutions would have to follow suit to guarantee any substantial appreciation in the yen.

abstract: Moslem rebels fighting the Soviet-backed regime in Afghanistan have captured an army headquarters base and a Government official, rebel spokesmen in Peshawar said today.

headline: Yankee Publishing Buys Alaska Magazine
abstract: The Yankee Publishing Company of Dublin, N.H., already the home of six publications, has just reached an agreement to acquire its seventh. And it has taken quite a reach.
