Leading the schedule is the Acting Foreign Minister of the Philippines, Pacifico A. Castro. He will followed by representatives of the Comoro Islands, a nation off the coast of Mozambique, and Qatar. The Foreign Minister of Bangladesh, Humayun R. Choudhury, is the last speaker scheduled this morning. He is expected to be the president of the Assembly next year. In the afternoon, delegates will hear from representatives of Cameroon and Malta.

headline: Advertising;   Mandelbaum-Remco
abstract: Mandelbaum, Wolf, Wiskowski, which deserted New York for a reconditioned warehouse on the water in Jersey City, has been doing the creative work for Remco Toys, a subsidairy of the Azrak-Hamway Company, while the Botway/Libov Associates, has been planning and buying the media. Yesterday, Mandelbaum, Wolf announced that it had been given the additional responsibility for the media.

headline: CARBIDE REJECTS BID FROM GAF
abstract: The Union Carbide Corporation, calling a $68-a-share bid by the GAF Corporation ''grossly inadequate and unfair,'' said last night that its board had rejected that offer and had authorized a program to repurchase 35 percent of its stock for a package of cash and notes that it valued at $85 a share.   Warren M. Anderson, Carbide's chairman, said the giant chemical company would, as a further defensive manuever, repurchase an additional 35 percent of its shares if GAF's holdings of Carbide exceeded 30 percent. GAF owns 10 percent of Carbide's stock.   In an interview last night, Mr. Anderson, who called the GAF offer ''a boot-strap, junk-bond, bust-up deal,'' said that, under the repurchase program, each shareholder could exchange a share of GAF stock for $20 in cash and $65 in ''intermediate and long-term notes.'' Carbide said its investment banker, Morgan Stanley & Company, valued the stock repurchases at $2 billion each.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: LOWER NET AT AIRLINES IS FORECAST
abstract: The airline industry is gearing up for heavy traffic during the Thanksgiving and Christmas holidays, but there is great concern that traffic will weaken and fare wars will widen early next year. That is causing some analysts and executives to predict a sharp drop in earnings in the first quarter.   ''It's going to be a tough year,'' Richard J. Ferris, chairman of United Airlines, told a group of analysts last week.   Many carriers are also scheduled to add capacity next year with the delivery of new planes ordered some time ago, putting further pressure on fares if traffic levels remain soft.

headline: PARIS BLASTS LAID TO AN INDIVIDUAL
abstract: Crude incendiary devices are believed to have caused the explosions at two Paris department stores that wounded 39 people, a spokesman for the Interior Ministry said today.   The spokesman said the explosions on Saturday night were caused not by sophisticated bombs of the kind often used by terrorist groups, but by incendiary devices with a timing system linked to a small explosive, perhaps a firecracker, connected to a drum containing a flammable substance.   Several groups have claimed responsibility for the blasts, but the police were treating the claims with skepticism. The type of explosive used led the police investigating the explosions to speculate that the blasts were the work of an individual, rather than of an organized political group.

headline: G.M. OFFERS NEW SALES INCENTIVE
abstract: The General Motors Corporation today announced a limited sales incentive plan, offering 8.5 percent financing on one line of compact cars.   The action by G.M. comes a week after the Chrysler Corporation offered 8.6 percent financing or rebates of up to $1,000 on the smaller half of its product lineup. There has been no action as yet from the Ford Motor Company, and a Ford official said no announcement was planned for today.

headline: Burlington To Bid for Southland
abstract: Burlington Northern Inc., the giant railroad company, said yesterday that it  intends to begin a tender offer for all the shares of the Southland Royalty Company, a major independent developer and producer of crude oil and natural gas, for $17 a share, or about $695 million.         Burlington's announcement came hours after Southland said that its board had  approved a plan to reorganize the company into a new limited partnership.

headline: American Honda Increases Prices
abstract: The American Honda Motor Company said that it was increasing the price of its 1986 automobiles by 4 percent, or an average of $403 a car, as a result of the falling value of the dollar.

headline: Washington Watch;A Banking Bill And Squabble
abstract: WASHINGTON         WITH friends like you . . . ? That's what the House Banking Committee's chairman, Fernand J. St Germain, is saying as he makes preparations to get the panel to approve on Wednesday the strongest piece of consumer banking legislation of the year.

headline: BERMUDA FAULTS PRETORIA
abstract: Bermuda adopted economic sanctions against South Africa today and called for the elimination of apartheid. Prime Minister John Swan announced the sanctions after months of protests by local anti-apartheid groups that had urged the Government of this British colony to sever all links with South Africa. The sanctions banned all commercial imports from South Africa including the sale of gold krugerrands. Mr. Swan also reiterated Bermuda's policy of not investing in South African companies.

headline: LATIN MEDIATORS REPORTED GLOOMY ON CENTRAL AMERICA PEACE EFFORT
abstract: The Contadora Group nations today struggled to keep alive their three-year-old peace effort among signs of a deepening rift between Nicaragua and three other Central American nations.   One well-placed Latin American official said the foreign ministers of the four mediating nations - Mexico, Colombia, Venezuela and Panama -were very pessimistic about their chances of moving forward.   Adding to their gloom, Nicaragua's Deputy Foreign Minister, Nora Astorga, unexpectedly boycotted a breakfast meeting here this morning with ministers from the Contadora Group and other Central American nations.

headline: MAKING SIZE 22 POSH AND PROFITABLE
abstract: IT is midday at the Forgotten Woman shop on New York's Upper East Side.   Large shoppers whirled around Nancy Radmin, its owner, who is large herself. There wasn't anyone close to a petite in sight.   ''Here's how it all happened,'' Mrs. Radmin said. ''Eight years ago, I was a size 6 and I had a son and I gained 80 pounds. I went out looking for clothes in size 16 to 18. There was nothing. There were no gabardine wool pants. No cashmere sweaters. I got so mad.''

headline: Press in Italy Reports New Hijacking Arrest
abstract: The Rome police have arrested another Palestinian who may have been involved in the hijacking of the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro, Italian news agencies reported today.   The news agency ANSA said the unidentified man was arrested several days ago and was being held for interrogation by magistrates in Genoa, where the Achille Lauro cruise began.

headline: MAN THE HIJACKERS WANT
abstract: The hijackers of the Achille Lauro were said to have mentioned only one name in demanding the release of 50 Palestinian guerrillas held here in Israel. He is Samir al-Qantari, whom they describe as ''a hero of Operation Nahariya.''

headline: Bert Lance Suit Survives
abstract: A judge has denied the Government's request to dismiss a lawsuit by the former Federal budget director, Bert Lance, that accuses bank regulators of violating his right to privacy by leaking a report on the bank he heads. In a ruling disclosed today, Federal District Judge Harold L. Murphy said the Government's motion to dismiss the case was invalid.

headline: Swift in Talks About Buyout
abstract: The Swift Independent Corporation, the nation's largest full-line meatpacking company, said today that it is ''engaged in preliminary discussions with a potential purchaser of the company'' for cash and securities valued at about $26 a share, or a total of $130 million.   The Chicago-based company, which reported sales of $700.9 million in its most recent quarter, also said that its potential purchaser ''is engaged in discussions with Beatrice Companies,'' which owns 35 percent of Swift's common stock.

headline: TRW Acquires Circle
abstract: TRW Inc. has announced it has acquired Circle Computer Services Inc., an Illinois company that provides technical services to leasing companies and users of International Business Machines Corporation computer equipment.

headline: Merrill Seeks Buyout Respect
abstract: A FEW weeks ago, in the middle of Merrill Lynch & Company's struggle to keep a leveraged buyout deal with the SCM Corporation alive, whispers started coming out of the investment firm's camp that it was determined not to let this one slip away.   The reason for the stubborness was simple. Other Merrill Lynch deals, including a proposed multibillion acquisition earlier this year of Storer Communications Inc. in a joint bid with the Comcast Corporation, had been shunned, and the brokerage firm's determination in the leveraged buyout arena was being questioned by the professionals on Wall Street.   ''They wanted to demonstrate two things'' with their firm stand on SCM, according to a source close to Merrill Lynch. ''Their resolve, and that they were a serious player in the L.B.O. business.''

headline: CHECKING BRAIN'S STATUS DURING HEART SURGERY
abstract: Erwin R. John, director of brain research laboratories at the New York University Medical Center, was granted a patent this week for a system that, during open-heart surgery, detects brain waves, observes the blood flow and temperature, and displays the information to the surgical team.

headline: PRETORIA PARTY WILL MEET REBELS
abstract: A delegation from South Africa's official white opposition party has arrived in Lusaka for discussions with the outlawed African National Congress, diplomats in the Zambian capital said today.   The meeting, expected to take place Saturday, comes after discussions in Zambia last month between leading white South African businessmen and a delegation led by Oliver Tambo, the Congress's exiled leader.   Unlike that encounter, however, the discussions with the Progressive Federal Party seem much more low-key. President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia has not publicly supported the meeting and Mr. Tambo, who has previously condemned the Progressive Federal Party, is not expected to attend.

headline: PANEL URGES LIMIT ON ARMS IN SPACE
abstract: A bipartisan group of experts has recommended that the Reagan Administration seek to negotiate limits on the American and Soviet ability to destroy satellites that travel in a high orbit.   The recommendation is being made at a time when the Administration has been criticized by some members of Congress for not seeking to negotiate limits on anti-satellite weapons.   The United States did not make specific proposals for limiting anti-satellite weapons in the round of the Geneva arms talks that ended last week, Administration officials said. Nor has the Administration said whether it plans to raise the issue of anti-satellite weapons at the coming summit meeting.

headline: EXCHANGE SEATS WON IN TOKYO
abstract: The Tokyo Stock Exchange today chose three American and three British securities firms as members, marking the first time foreign firms will be allowed to join the 107-year-old exchange.   The change, Wall Street executives say, is another step in the internationalization of capital markets, a process that increasingly over the last five years has seen investors from all parts of the globe providing funds to corporations and governments beyond their home country's borders.   It follows the announcement early this week that the London Stock Exchange and the National Association of Securities Dealers in the United States will swap price information on British and American stocks.   The American firms selected are Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, Goldman, Sachs & Company and Morgan Stanley & Company. The British firms are Jardine Fleming Securities Ltd., Vickers da Costa & Company, the international stockbroking subsidiary of Citicorp, and S.G. Warburg & Company. They will each pay about $5 million for a seat on the Tokyo exchange, more than 10 times the price of a seat on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: New Editor Is Named At Times of London
abstract: Charles Wilson, deputy editor of The Times of London, was appointed editor today, succeeding Charles Douglas-Home, who died of cancer last week.   Mr. Wilson, a 50-year-old Scot who started his career as a copy boy at the age of 16, held several executive posts on British national newspapers before joining The Times in 1982.   He was appointed joint deputy editor last year and was recently chosen by The Times's owner, Rupert Murdoch, the Australian-born publisher, to coordinate the start of a new London evening newspaper next spring.

headline: MIXED REVIEWS FOR WYMAN
abstract: It has been a tough year for Thomas H. Wyman, the chairman of CBS Inc. No sooner had he fought off a takeover bid by Ted Turner, the Atlanta-based entrepreneur, than he felt compelled to ask another potential bidder, Laurence A. Tisch, the chairman of the Loews Corporation, to join the CBS board.   Now with Mr. Tisch, who can buy up to 25 percent of CBS's stock, watching over his shoulder, Mr. Wyman must grapple with the major challenge of improving CBS's performance. Its core businesses - broadcasting, records and publishing - are facing problems. The company must divest itself of a handful of assets to meet its increased debt. And to complicate matters, a number of Wall Street analysts are skeptical that Mr. Wyman's demonstrated managerial skills can solve those problems.   ''I would give Tom Wyman a B so far,'' said Edward Attorino, an analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. ''Although his cost-cutting strategy seems to be working, some of it was forced on CBS by the Turner deal and the deterioration in the broadcast business. Secondly, some of the company's diversification moves have not worked out. There had been a belief that CBS would successfully broaden its base, but so far it has not developed a diversification strategy that works.''

headline: PATENTS;  Transmitting Data In Computer Network
abstract: A data communications system to provide transmission between a number of local computer networks was patented this week for the Ford Motor Company. Patent 4,550,402 was granted to Melvin G. Gable and two other research scientists on the company's staff.  The invention was described by a spokesman as a very high-speed data communications system for facilitating the switching of small packs of data between or among local area networks, through a single transfer device made of a number of parallel conductors. It was developed in a project undertaken for Ford Aerospace and Communications Inc.

headline: HIJACKERS LINKED TO PALESTIAN FACTION
abstract: The gunmen who hijacked an Egyptian airliner to Malta were pro-Libyan followers of Abu Nidal, a Palestinian known for his strong opposition to Yasir Arafat, according to sources close to the Palestinians here.   The sources speculated that Abu Nidal's motive in ordering the hijacking was to deal a double blow to Mr. Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization leader, and to President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt.   The hijacking of the Egyptian plane ended violently Sunday night when Egyptian commandos stormed the aircraft and the hijackers detonated grenades. In all, 60 people were reported killed in the hijacking, including all but one of the hijackers.

headline: DOW JUMPS 15.94 POINTS TO RECORD
abstract: A sharp rise in stock prices yesterday, in heavy trading volume, sent the Dow Jones industrial average crashing through its previous record set earlier in the week.   Hopes for lower interest rates were credited with pushing the blue-chip indicator up 15.94 points to its best-ever level of 1,390.25. For the week, the Dow rose 33.73 points, its best five-day advance since mid-January.   Market analysts say a weeklong rally in the bond market has helped to fuel the interest in stocks. But Newton Zinder of E. F. Hutton & Company said the resiliency of the equities market is also a major factor.

headline: Singapore Stock Market
abstract: Singapore says plans to tighten control over its stock market, delayed after initial resistance from brokers, will go ahead soon following a financial crisis sparked by a major firm's debt problems.   Finance Minister Richard Hu said today that wide-ranging changes in laws governing the securities industry would be introduced in Parliament next year.

headline: $60.3 Million Issue For Hospital
abstract: The New York State Medical Care Facilities Finance Agency is offering $60.3 million of bonds on behalf of St. Mary's Hospital in Rochester.   The public offering of tax-exempt securities included serial bonds that were tentatively priced to yield from 5 1/4 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 6 1/2 percent in 1990, 7 1/2 percent in 1995 and 8.20 percent in 2000.

headline: BUTING SECURITIES THAT THE 'ARBS' DUMP
abstract: THE heated pace of mergers, acquisitions and leveraged buyouts has contributed to this year's record number of bonds, convertible bonds, preferred stock and other fixed-income instruments, many of which were issued to finance such deals. And at least one money manager is taking advantage of the ''inefficient market'' that often emerges when risk arbitragers establish spread positions using some of the new securities.   Robert M. Wallace, a vice president at Fort Hill Investors in San Jose, Calif., invests almost $150 million of his clients' portfolios in the debt securities that ''arbs'' sell short to set up the low end of their spreads.   In many deals, the acquiring company often uses preferred stock or bonds as part of the purchase package. For instance, when Baxter Travenol recently took over American Hospital Supply, it offered cash and a package of Baxter common stock, adjustable-rate preferred stock and preferred stock that is convertible to common.

headline: FRENCH ARTICLE SETS OFF FUROR ON IMMIGRANTS
abstract: The publication of an article asserting that French identity and culture are threatened by the growing immigrant population has touched off a political furor in France.   The debate has been getting louder in the last week since Le Figaro Magazine, a weekend supplement to the conservative daily newspaper, published a cover article asking: ''Will France still be French in 2015?'' The cover featured a picture of Marianne, symbol of France, wearing an Arab woman's veil with a rosette in red, white and blue, the colors of the French flag.   The article, by Jean Raspail, a prominent French writer, and Gerard Francois Dumont, a demographer who is head of the Institute of Political Demography, asserts that the proportion of France's non-European immigrant population will grow to endanger the ''survival'' of traditional French culture, values and identity.   Three senior French officials condemned the article as false, provocative and racist. Prime Minister Laurent Fabius, in a speech to Parliament, said the article drew a dangerous link between social insecurity and immigrants.

headline: WEST GERMAN BACKS PARTICIPATION IN 'STAR WARS'
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's national security adviser called today for a governmental agreement with the United States to coordinate the participation of West German industry in the Reagan Administration's research program for an antimissile shield.   The security adviser, Horst Teltschik, said it was ''a vital interest'' for the Federal Republic to take part in the American research effort, and he said a decision to strike a government-to-government accord could reached by the end of this year or early next year.   Mr. Teltschik's endorsement of West German participation in the strategic defense initiative, often called the ''Star Wars'' program, was the Kohl Government's first public statement on the issue since Mr. Teltschik returned from an 11-day fact-finding mission in the United States earlier this month.

headline: MORE AIR FARES CUT AS RIVALRY GROWS
abstract: As traffic slows in November and early December, airlines have traditionally cut fares to such vacation markets as Florida. But this year reductions are being offered in fares to many other markets as well because of a growing rivalry between two low-cost carriers: People Express and Continental Airlines.   The rivalry has already led to a fare war that has drawn in one major carrier, United Airlines, which matched some of the lower fares to remain competitive.   Analysts, however, believe that the struggle will not lead to the wide fare wars the industry experienced several years ago, and that the responses by other major carriers will remain limited.

headline: BLEAK REPORT ON BRITISH INDUSTRY DRAWS FIRE FROM CABINET
abstract: A gloomy assessment of Britain's industrial prospects by some prominent industrialists and bankers in the House of Lords has drawn an unusually defensive and caustic response from members of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Cabinet.   In blunt language, the Lords noted in a report this week that Britain was the only advanced industrial nation that had experienced an absolute decline in manufacturing output in the last decade. The industrial decline, they warned, poses ''a grave threat to the standard of living and to the economic and political stability of the nation.''

headline: People
abstract: * R. Patrick McCarthy has been appointed senior vice president, director of communications and human resources, at D'Arcy MacManus Masius/Bloomfield Hills, Mich.

headline: Long-Term Bond Prices Up
abstract: A late spurt of buying pushed prices of long-term Treasury bonds into the plus column yesterday. But the gains did not extend to the intermediate two- to five-year maturities or the bill market, both of which closed largely unchanged on the day.   Some dealers attributed the late buying to a misinterpretation of the House's passage of a ''continuous resolution'' on the budget. Others cited the strong surge of buying near the close of the Treasury bond futures market in Chicago.

headline: Rumania Ousts Head Of Its Defense Ministry
abstract: The Rumanian Defense Minister, Col. Gen. Constantin Olteanu, has been relieved of his duties, the official Rumanian press agency said today.

headline: PHILIPPINE ELECTIONS GET SUPREME COURT APRROVAL
abstract: The Supreme Court ruled today that a presidential election set for Feb. 7 should go ahead despite doubts about its constitutionality. But opposition politicians said they still believed President Ferdinand E. Marcos had several other options for stopping the election should he fear he might lose.   The split decision by the court was widely believed to reflect the will of Mr. Marcos. He said today that he welcomed the opportunity to proceed with elections that would lay to rest doubts raised by the ''libelous propaganda'' of his opponents about his own mandate and the popularity of his Government's programs.

headline: SALVADOR REPORTS PLEDGE BY REBELS
abstract: Senior Government and church officials said today that leftist rebelshad pledged they would no longer kidnap relatives of political or military leaders.   The officials said the pledge was one of several private accords reached this week in Panama in talks that led to the release of the kidnapped daughter of President Jose Napoleon Duarte, Ines Guadalupe Duarte.   The commitment by the rebels was considered vital by the Salvadoran military command, officials said, and by President Duarte, who recently sent eight of his relatives out of the country.   The officials said the pledge removed the last stumbling block in the long talks that finally led to a complex exchange involving 143 people. It was the largest prisoner exchange in El Salvador's civil war.

headline: Mexico Death Toll Is Raised to 5,526
abstract: The official death toll from the two earthquakes last month rose to 5,526 today, and the United States said its rescue workers were ending the search.   The Government commission established to take over the rescue operations and arrange the demolition of damaged structures announced today that no new construction would be allowed on lots where buildings collapsed.   Factories damaged in the quake will be relocated outside the metropolitan area and ''parks, monuments, sports centers and libraries will be built on all cleared lots,'' the commission statement said.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    * Citicorp plans to sell $100 million of floating-rate notes due in 1992 through underwriters led by Paine Webber; the rate, which may float between 8 1/4 percent and 12 percent, will be adjusted quarterly to 1 3/8 points above the bond-equivalent yield of three-month Treasury bills.    * Indiana Gas Co. filed $35 million of 25-year first-mortgage bonds through Goldman, Sachs.    * Parker Hannifin Corp. filed $60 million of debentures due in 2015 through Kidder, Peabody.

headline: A Novel Feature For Citicorp Notes
abstract: A novel issue of 12-year Citicorp notes totaling $100 million was offered in the Eurobond market yesterday through underwriters led by S.G. Warburg & Company.  The notes were offered at a price of 100 5/8 with an initial coupon of 9 5/8 percent.

headline: Advertising;   Fisher Award For Newhouse
abstract: S. I. Newhouse Jr., the second-generation publisher who this year added The New Yorker to his holdings, has been named ''publisher of the year'' by the Magazine Publishers Association.

headline: The U.N. Today; Nov. 8, 1985
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Political and Security Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Special Political Committee -10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Economic and Financial Committee - 3 P.M.   Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Decolonization Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Legal Committee - 3 P.M.

headline: Auto Sales Fell 10.1% In Early October Period
abstract: New-car sales fell 10.1 percent in the first 10 days of October, the nation's major manufacturers reported here today. The decline followed the end of a highly successful round of incentive programs that pushed sales to record levels in September and cleaned out dealer stocks.   During September, most domestic manufacturers offered 7.5 or 7.7 percent financing on virtually all of their remaining 1985-model cars. Sales soared and inventories fell to a 13-year low. Those programs expired on or before Oct. 5.

headline: Fannie Mae Certificates Priced to Yield 11.25%
abstract: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, is offering $200 million of 11 percent mortgage-backed securities at a price of 97 22/32 to yield 11.25 percent through various securities dealers.   The securities are a kind of morgage pass-through certificate backed by a pool of fixed-rate, long-term home mortgages.

headline: ON ARMS CONTROL AND THE FUTURE OF THE U.N., STATESMEN SPEAK OUT <
abstract: uf1> AFGHANISTAN Shah Mohammad Dost Foreign Minister It is regrettable that we are celebrating the 40th anniversary of the establishment of this organization when, as a result of the policy of all-out confrontation and unbridled arms race pursued by imperialism, the world is precariously tottering on the edge of the abyss of a nuclear catastrophe, which threatens not only the entire civilization but also the very existence of any form of life on earth. Nothing could be more distant from the dreams and ideals of the authors and signatories of the United Nations Charter.   From Southeast to Southwest Asia and the whole Indian Ocean, from Palestine and the Middle East to South Africa and Namibia and from Central America to the whole of Latin America, imperialist policies, aided and abetted in certain parts of the world by hegemonism and local stooges, have not only brought about bloodshed and destruction but have also impaired the ability of the United Nations to adopt, on behalf of the international community, effective measures aimed at putting an end to aggression and occupation and correcting the injustice done. NORWAY Svenn Stray Foreign Minister My Government together with other Nordic governments submitted several proposals and ideas for strengthening the organization. Our attention has first and foremost been focused on the Security Council and the office of the Secretary General in order to make the United Nations a more effective instrument for the maintenance of international peace and security.

headline: ISRAELIS PRAISE U.S. ACT AS BIG ANTITERROR STEP
abstract: Israelis from all walks of life today hailed the swift capture by the United States of the hijackers of the Italian cruise ship.   ''What the Americans did was great,'' said a policeman on Hillel Street here who would not give his name. ''The world has finally begun to feel what Israel has felt all along.''   Using phrases like ''courageous decision,'' ''flawless implementation'' and ''decisive action,'' Prime Minister Shimon Peres told President Reagan in a letter that ''your action is a landmark in the fight to eradicate terrorism, and a shining example of your resolve.''

headline: Advertising;   Chesebrough-Pond's Moves Media Buying
abstract: You can bet there is weeping and gnashing of teeth these days at Ogilvy & Mather, the William Esty Company and Waring & LaRosa. And for good reason.

headline: Advertising;   Zale Fills Post
abstract: The Dallas-based Zale Corporation, which has changed from a manufacturing to a marketing thrust, has appointed Michael C. Barlerin, formerly of Doyle Dane Bernbach, New York, to be senior vice president, corporate marketing. Zale has 1,450 retail jewelry outlets and a $60 million promotion budget. The Bloom Agency does its advertising.

headline: WIFE OF SOVIET AIDE IS DEAD IN CANADA LINK TO SPY DENIED
abstract: The wife of a Soviet trade representative stationed in Toronto has died under circumstances that were not immediately disclosed, the External Affairs Ministry reported today.   The identity of the woman was not disclosed.

headline: Occidental To Sell Stake
abstract: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said it intends to sell its 20 percent stake in the Dallas-based Southland Corporation, the world's largest convenience-store operator, in a deal valued at about $394 million.   Occidental said it was selling the Southland stock to concentrate on its core businesses of oil and gas exploration, chemicals and coal.

headline: CLEARING THE AIR: A FIRST FOR MOSCOW SINCE '80
abstract: The cessation of Soviet jamming on three radio frequencies during President Reagan's speech to the Soviet Union marked the first time since 1980 that there had been no interference with a broadcast of the Voice of America, Administration officials say.   Voice of America officials, speaking at a news conference Thursday, said jamming was halted on two frequencies audible in Moscow and one in Leningrad, and was resumed after Mr. Reagan's 10-minute speech.   During a speech by Mr. Reagan to the Soviet Union in September 1983, jamming continued as usual. The Soviet Union has been jamming Western radio broadcasts on and off for years, the latest period beginning in 1980, when the Solidarity free trade union movement arose in Poland.

headline: Leucadia to Raise Stake in Minstar
abstract: The Leucadia National Corporation, an investment company that specializes in takeovers, said it plans to increase its stake in Minstar Inc. to 11 percent, from 9.2 percent. It was not immediately clear, however, if Minstar, which is controlled by Irwin L. Jacobs, will become the object of a takeover bid itself.

headline: Consumers Power
abstract: The Consumers Power Company said it could refund $46.4 million to its 1.1 million gas customers on their December bills.

headline: Red Cross Worker Is Killed
abstract: A Swiss delegate of the International Committee of the Red Cross was shot dead near Lobito, Angola, on Monday night, the organization said today. The group, with headquarters here, said in a statement that the victim, Marc Blaser, 21 years old, went to Angola last October as a radio operator.

headline: THE CITY RETAILERS' CHARITY CHRISTMAS
abstract: THE flurry of excitement that usually accompanies the Christmas shopping season was not as evident this year. But the shopping period has not been without some suspense.

headline: Court Refuses to Review Movie Antitrust Ruling
abstract: The Supreme Court today declined to review a lower court's ruling that barred theater owners from agreeing not to compete for particular films.   The effect of the action is to leave intact the ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, in Chicago, which was based on antitrust laws. The movie industry has been extremely interested in the case.

headline: Fluor May Sell Oil, Gas Units
abstract: The Fluor Corporation, in another step of its financial restructuring, has signed a letter of intent to sell its remaining onshore and offshore oil and gas operations to Primary Fuels Inc., a subsidiary of Houston Industries, for about $190 million.   The construction, engineering and natural resources company, which is based in Irvine, Calif., said that the planned net profit of $170 million from the sale would be used to pay off debt and related production costs.

headline: EASING OF TRUST RULES IS PROPOSED TO REAGAN
abstract: The level of imports would become a statutory factor in determining whether a merger is unlawfully anti-competitive under a revamping of antitrust law that President Reagan's Cabinet has just recommended.   A joint meeting of the Domestic Policy Council, under Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, and the Economic Policy Council, under Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d, submitted the recommendations to the President yesterday, Administration officials said today.   The proposals, sponsored chiefly by Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige, would, if enacted, amount to the most sweeping changes in antitrust laws since the Clayton Act was enacted in 1914. Mr. Baldrige has argued that antitrust law should be relaxed to make American industry more competitive.

headline: Market Place;   OPEC's Impact On Stocks
abstract: WALL STREET is taking a a positive view of the latest meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Ending three days of talks in Geneva, OPEC ministers vowed yesterday to defend their share of the world oil market.   It remains to be seen whether or not this decision by the organization, whose influence has eroded steadily in recent years in the face of the rising output of crude oil in other parts of the world, will result ultimately in a price war.   But the implications are clear, according to Earl L. Lester, oil analyst for Standard & Poor's. ''It means that the 13 OPEC nations have decided to stop wrangling among themselves and to carry the fight to non-OPEC producers such as Britain, Norway, Mexico and even Russia,'' he said. ''OPEC's new philosophy seems to be, 'Let them taste the sword,' even if that means lower prices.''

headline: Lewis Federal Merger
abstract: The $54 million Lewis Federal Savings and Loan Association of Chehalis, Wash., today acquired the financially troubled Sterling Savings Association of Spokane, Wash. The Federal Home Loan Bank Board assisted the merger with a $1.75 million cash infusion and by agreeing to indemnify Sterling, which had $118 million in assets, against litigation and any undisclosed liabilities.

headline: Comments From Soviet
abstract: The Soviet Union today called the kidnapping of the Soviet diplomats a ''heinous crime'' out by ''bandits'' from an ''arch-reactionary ultra-right-wing'' organization.   The comment, broadcast on Soviet television news this evening and published by the Tass press agency, was Moscow's first public response to the kidnappings.

headline: RENAISSANCE
abstract: To the Editor:   I read with great interest your article ''High Tech Blossoms Along The Potomac,'' (Sept. 15). However, I would like to correct a misimpression of Charles Gulledge, chairman of the Fairfax County Economic Development Authority.

headline: Soviet Protest to Britain
abstract: The Soviet Foreign Ministry today protested the British Government's decision to join in research for the United States space-based missile defense program known as ''Star Wars.'' Britain signed a memorandum with the United States on Dec. 6 agreeing to join in the research.

headline: JAIL IS ASKED FOR ARGENTINA'S EX-LEADERS
abstract: The prosecution asked a military court today to strip three former Argentine rulers of their rank and to sentence them to 12 to 8 years in prison for ''negligence'' in conducting the country's 1982 war with Britain, according to the Defense Ministry.   Brig. Gen. Hector Canale, the prosecutor, began his summation today in the closed-door proceedings against 16 officers, including the three former junta members. The court-martial began two years ago and a verdict is expected by the end of the year.

headline: DOW GAINS 11.87 AS STOCKS RALLY
abstract: Economic news propelled stocks strongly ahead yesterday, providing an upbeat conclusion to a lethargic trading week.   Government reports that producer prices fell six-tenths of 1 percent in September, while retail sales rose 2.7 percent, cheered investors who had been cautiously awaiting clues to the course of the economy.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which hovered about 8 points on the upside throughout much of the trading session, ended 11.87 points ahead, at 1,339.94, after spurting near the close on the strength of a couple of institutional buy programs.

headline: SINAI SLAYINGS: DETAILS PROMISED
abstract: Prime Minister Shimon Peres told the Cabinet today that he had received a message from President Hosni Mubarak promising all the facts surrounding the killing of seven Israelis at a Sinai resort Oct. 5 by an Egyptian policeman or soldier.   According to Mr. Peres, the message said Egypt's concern about the incident is no less serious than that of Israel.   At the time of the shootings, Egyptian authorities said the man had gone berserk. But Israeli intelligence sources said he was a Moslem fundamentalist who was a follower of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the Iranian leader, and that he had a history of aggression against Israelis.

headline: 10 REBELS KILLED IN CLASH SRI LANKA REPORTS
abstract: Ten Tamil separatist guerrillas were killed today in a battle with troops in Mannar District, the Defense Ministry said.   A spokesman said the battle broke out when troops encountered the guerrillas, who were traveling in a van.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: *    * Burmah Specialty Chemicals Ltd., London, a subsidiary of Burmah Oil P.L.C, said it would not continue with its $25 million acquisition of Advance Process Supply Co. after failure to reach agreement with the American company.    * Cannon Group Inc., Hollywood, said it had completed an agreement with a consortium of four banks, led by the First National Bank of Boston, for a $65 million revolving line of credit.

headline: COLOMBIA SIEGE SURVIVORS ARE BITTER
abstract: The 12 judges who survived a 28-hour siege at the Palace of Justice here last week boycotted an elaborate memorial service today for the scores of people who  died. The judges, who said they stayed away to protest the Government's handling of the crisis, were joined in the boycott by most of the relatives of 11 slain justices.         In a brief address at the memorial, held in Colombia's main cathedral and attended by hundreds of Government officials and scores of foreign diplomats, President Belisario Betancur sought to explain his decision not to negotiate with the leftist rebels who seized the justice building shortly before noon on Wednesday. The rebels were members of a group known as M-19.

headline: REAGAN CHOICE FOR POST IN PEKING IS BLOCKED
abstract: The nomination of Winston Lord as Ambassador to China has been stalled in the Senate, a Republican leadership aide said.

headline: MOSCOW OFFERS MORE MODEST PLAN FOR ACHIEVING TRUE COMMUNISM
abstract: In a major departure from its traditional goals, the Soviet Communist Party today published a new draft program that abandons predictions of quickly overtaking the West or of soon achieving a true communist society.   The central pledge of the last program, adopted under Nikita S. Khrushchev in 1961, that ''the present generation of Soviet people shall live in communism'' has been dropped. Instead, the new draft asserts that attempts to move too fast in introducing communism, ''without due account taken of the level of material and spiritual maturity of society, are, as experience shows, doomed to failure.''      'Maneuvering' of Capitalism    And where Khrushchev's program exuded certainty about the imminent demise of capitalism, pledging to leave the United States ''far behind'' in industrial output and labor productivity by 1980, the new draft states that capitalism, although still doomed, ''is constantly maneuvering to adjust itself to the changing situation.''

headline: THE RUSSIANS' LOT IN AFGHAN HANDS
abstract: ''The Holy Koran,'' a rebel commander said, ''says if you capture a prisoner during fighting you should not kill him but you should teach him about Islam. If he becomes a Moslem, you should treat him as a brother.''   The insurgent leader was speaking of the options available to the rebel forces - and the problems they face - when Russian soldiers are taken alive: the rebels can convert the Russians to Islam, kill them, send them to Pakistan or exchange them for captured rebels.   His statement also underscored another aspect of the conflict here, one that foreign diplomats based in Pakistan, medical volunteers and others who have traveled in Afghanistan agree is one of the most vital yet least-understood elements of the long war: what they call ''the Islamic factor.''   The goal of the insurgents, these sources say, is not only to drive out the Russians and end the rule of Afghan Communists, but also to establish a society based on the social and ethical values of the Koran.

headline: ZOOLOGIST IS SLAIN IN CENTRAL AFRICA
abstract: Dian Fossey, an American zoologist who studied Rwanda's rare mountain gorillas for 18 years, has been killed by unknown assailants at her forest camp in this central African country, the police said today.   Dr. Fossey, who was 53 years old, was a fierce defender of the mountain gorilla, which she feared would become extinct by the end of the century.   ''She was far more at home with wildlife than with humans,'' an acquaintance in Nairobi, Kenya, said.   The police said that Dr. Fossey's body was found Thursday at the Karisoke Research Institute, which she founded, and that her killers appeared to know the area well. [The Rwanda radio said that there had been no arrests and that an investigation was continuing, The Associated Press reported.]  Friends Suspect Poachers In Nairobi, friends of Dr. Fossey speculated that she might have been killed by the poachers she fought against for so long.

headline: Dow Off, but Week Is Best in 9 Months
abstract: Stock prices slipped yesterday but ended their best weekly performance since January, as the market remained transfixed by potentially profitable takeovers.   The best gainer was Litton Industries, for the second consecutive day. It rose 11 points, to 89, on consolidated volume of 2.1 million shares. But it was a 2 7/8-point gain, to 60 1/4, in Union Carbide, a component of the Dow Jones industrial average, that kept the blue-chip index out of serious trouble.

headline: Worker Drug Test Law Set
abstract: Mayor Dianne Feinstein will allow a city ordinance prohibiting random drug testing of workers by employers doing business in San Francisco to become law without her signature.   The Mayor has refused to sign the ordinance, which was passed by the Board of Supervisors on Nov. 15 by a 9-to-1 vote, because she believes it gives a protected status to being under the influence of drugs while on the job.

headline: REVLON LOSES A TAKEOVER RULING
abstract: In a court decision expected to have major repercussions in all takeover battles, the Delaware Chancery Court ruled yesterday that directors of Revlon Inc. had breached their fiduciary duty by giving a New York investment house the right to buy two key operations.   The court also found illegal an arrangement whereby the investment house - Forstmann Little & Company - had exacted a promise that Revlon would not use the Forstmann Little offer to shop around for a better price.   A Delaware lawyer who asked not to be named said that under the ruling the concept of the so-called poison pill, making takeovers extremely expensive, ''may be on the way out.'' He explained that if directors issued such pills, they assumed greater duties than before and thus must negotiate with all parties trying to buy their company.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Beneficial Corp., Wilmington, Del., finished selling its Western Auto Supply Co. subsidiary to Wesray Automotive Inc., an affiliate of Wesray Capital Corp., for more than $300 million.    * Central Maine Power Co., Augusta, Me., said it had asked the Maine Public Utilities Commission for a rate increase of $39 million, or 7.1 percent, in 1986 and $20 million, or 3.7 percent, in 1987, related to the beginning of operations at the Millstone Three nuclear power plant.

headline: Administration And Clausen
abstract: THE president of the World Bank, A. W. Clausen, was never brought in on the big plans for the bank that Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d disclosed in Seoul, South Korea. His staff got a whiff of them months ago, and he learned more of the details from newspaper reports leading up to Mr. Baker's speech.

headline: CRACKING DOWN HARD, TEXAS STYLE
abstract: HOUSTON is not a comfortable place for an auto salvage dealer these days. At midnight on Dec. 31, the licenses of every one of the 150 yards expires. And there is a good chance that city officials will put yard owners through the wringer before those licenses will be renewed.

headline: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 22, 1985
abstract: Markets    Stock prices vaulted higher, climbing far into record territory. The Dow Jones industrial average bettered its previous record by more than 22 points, closing at 1,462.27, up 23.05 points for the day. Standard & Poor's 500 index, a much broader gauge, also rose sharply. Big Board volume expanded to a brisk 150.3 million shares. [Page D1.]  Short interest on the Big Board soared 18.4 percent in the month ended Nov. 15, to a record 262.8 million shares. [D24.]    The Treasury market continued to digest a heavy supply of new issues at the lowest yields in more than five years, but dealers said investors seemed dissatisfied with the returns. Prices fell modestly after an auction of $7 billion of new 10-year notes. [D17.]

headline: Brazil Bank In U.S. Move
abstract: The New York office of the Government-owned Banco do Brazil S.A. said yesterday that it had taken over the New York operations of two failed Brazilian banks.   Ilza Paolini, supervisor of the Banco do Brazil's operations in New York, said, ''We have taken on all the responsibilities and the liabilities of the offices of these banks.''

headline: Belgian King Asks Martens to Stay in Office
abstract: Prime Minister Wilfried Martens today appeared certain to be asked to form another center-right coalition Government committed to economic austerity and the deployment of United States cruise missiles.   Mr. Martens resigned early today, but King Baudouin asked him to stay on in a caretaker capacity.

headline: Media General Names Officers
abstract: Media General Inc., a newspaper and broadcasting company based in Richmond, yesterday named J. Stewart Bryan and James A. Linen 4th executive vice presidents.   In the new positions, Mr. Linen, 47 years old, will be responsible for the company's newsprint, broadcast, magazine and community newspaper operations. Mr. Bryan, also 47, will take responsibility for daily newspapers and cable television. Mr. Bryan will remain publisher of The Richmond Times-Dispatch and News Leader, and Mr. Linen will continue as chairman of Media General Broadcast Services.

headline: A TEXACO DEAL HALTED BY NIPPON
abstract: The Nippon Oil Company said yesterday that it would delay a planned exploration of some of Texaco Inc.'s United States oilfields until Texaco's legal battle with the Pennzoil Company was resolved.   The decision by the Japanese oil company, while not considered terribly significant by itself, came in an atmosphere of extreme concern and wariness among Texaco's lenders, suppliers and joint venture partners about Texaco's ability to weather a long battle with Pennzoil. On Tuesday, a Texas state judge upheld an award of $10.53 billion, plus interest, against Texaco.

headline: C.F.T.C., EXCHANGES FIGHT IT OUT
abstract: The commodities industry is digging in its heels for a battle with its regulator, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, over tough new capital rules the commission has proposed.   On Tuesday, the directors of the Chicago Board of Trade, the country's largest futures exchange, decided at a long meeting to set aside $1 million for a legal defense fund. And a number of other commodities exchanges and large commodities brokers, including Merrill Lynch Futures, Cargill Investor Services and Goldman, Sachs & Company, are lobbying against the proposed rules.   At stake, industry officials say, is the survival of many commodities brokerage firms. The New York Commodity Exchange, for instance, contended that 30 percent of its member firms could not now meet the proposed new capital rules, and thus would have to find more capital or go out of business. Both the Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange have contended that up to 40 percent of their firms would not have the capital.

headline: THE PSYCHOLOGICAL ROUTE TO CUTTING COSTS
abstract: Bill Thompson was in bad shape. He had no appetite, could not sleep, and had lost interest in sex. His lower back pain had gotten so bad that he was missing work frequently. Finally he could not go to work at all.   After 18 months of disability, Mr. Thompson was considering surgery to sever nerves in his back. As a last resort, he went to a psychotherapist, and the truth came out.   Mr. Thompson was the controller of the Acme Company, a family-run business that had not changed chiefs in the 23 years he had worked for it. But when the owner's son took over and started to computerize the operations, Mr. Thompson, at age 54, had to face a whole new world. That idea so frightened him that he literally made himself sick.

headline: WHY PEOPLE MAKE FUN OF ECONOMISTS
abstract: EVERY year, between Christmas and New Year's Day, the American Economic Association holds its annual convention. For three days, several thousand economists, mostly university teachers but with a substantial number of people who work for governments, banks and other corporations and consulting firms, hang around a hotel lobby listening to each other talk. Or at least talking. The official program for this year's meeting, now under way in New York, includes hundreds of formal presentations, most with prepared discussions, and there will be hours of informal conversation.   This year's convention is special in one respect. It marks the 100th anniversary of the founding of the American Economic Association. The assembled economists will poke fun at themselves, the way confident professionals often do. They will, in fact, feel pretty good about themselves. The truth is: they have quite a lot to feel good about. In contrast with other academic fields, there are still teaching jobs in economics for new Ph.D.'s. To a profession that tends to take the market seriously, that is itself a very good sign.

headline: Cogenic Energy Shifts To Replace Co-founder
abstract: Cogenic Energy Systems Inc., the nation's leading manufacturer of modular cogeneration systems, said yesterday that Richard H. Nelson, president and chief executive, had been named chairman.   Mr. Nelson succeeds Warren W. Nissley, 62, who is retiring. The company said that Mr. Nissley, who founded Cogenic Energy in 1980 along with Mr. Nelson, would remain a director.

headline: Advertising;   Mullen's New Client
abstract: Mullen Advertising and Public Relations, one of the bigger agencies in Beverly Farms, Mass., has been tagged to do advertising for Analog Devices, a Norwood, Mass., manufacturer of linear integrated circuits and testing, measurement and control equipment for industry. The billings, previously handled by Giardini/Russell, will be about $1.5 million.

headline: G.M. Price Rises
abstract: The General Motors Corporation said that some models in its newest line of 1986 cars would cost nearly $4,000 more than the 1985 versions. The sports-luxury cars, sharing the same basic body and platforms, are the Cadillac Seville, with a suggested retail price of $26,756, 15 percent over the 1985 price; the Cadillac Eldorado, $24,251, up nearly 16 percent; the Oldsmobile Toronado, $19,418, up 15.6 percent, and the Buick Riviera, $19,831, up 18.7 percent. Clifford Merriott, a GM spokesman, said the increases were justified because the company redesigned the cars ''from roof to road and from front to back.''

headline: 'Alternative Maximum Tax'
abstract: If President Reagan's effort to overhaul the income tax system runs aground in Congress, Senator William L. Armstrong, a member of the Finance Committee, plans to offer a plan that would satisfy both those yearning for a simpler tax system and those who like things just the way they are now.   Under his plan, called the ''alternative maximum tax,'' taxpayers who voluntarily elected to give up virtually all tax benefits would be able to have their taxes computed on a much lower rate schedule than those who continue to take advantage of the variety of tax deductions, credits and exemptions available under current law.

headline: HIS PITCH LURES 'INSTANT INSIDERS'
abstract: GERALD GUTERMAN barely pauses for breath before beginning his spiel. ''You can invest and make a cash profit, or you can give your money to Uncle,'' he says. ''You don't have a choice - you do have to write a check.''   Mr. Guterman is a supersalesman of one of the unlikelier commodities in New York: renter-occupied cooperatives and condominiums. In the last several years, with the widespread conversion of apartment buildings to co-ops and condominiums, an active market has sprung up in the sale to outsiders of units that remain occupied, but unbought, by tenants.

headline: 5 REPORTED DEAD IN A LEBANON RAID
abstract: Three men with explosives strapped to their bodies caused extensive damage to a radio station run by American missionaries in the Israeli-controlled part of southern Lebanon today, Lebanese authorities said. At least five people were reported killed, including the attackers.   The Soviet-oriented Lebanese Communist Party later said it was responsible for the attack on the station, known as ''Voice of Hope.'' There were no reports of American casualties. The radio was put off the air for several hours.

headline: 3 Philippine Convicts Slain
abstract: Three prisoners were shot dead and eight escaped in two jailbreaks in the Philippines today, the police said. The three were shot by policemen after they fled at dawn from a jail in Manila's suburban district of Quezon City, a spokeman said. Eight men escaped in a dawn jailbreak in Baguio, 125 miles north of Manila, by drilling a hole in a bathroom wall, the Philippine News Agency said.

headline: NORTHWEST
abstract: THE Pacific Northwest's economy has undergone euphoric turns in recent months in the major cities and technology corridors. But out in the hinterlands of Washington and Oregon, where traditional industries such as forestry products, aluminum and agriculture are depressed and more plant closings are expected, the outlook is somber. Overall, the unemployment rate hovers nearly a point and a half above the national average in Washington, at 8.3 percent, and is worse in Oregon, where the 9.9 percent jobless rate is expected to climb above l0 percent next year.

headline: LATIN PEACE MEETINGS SUSPENDED
abstract: The Contadora group has suspended negotiations on a peace agreement for Central America for five months at Nicaragua's request, Colombia's Foreign Minister says.   Nicaragua officially proposed the suspension on the ground that new governments taking office in Guatemala and Honduras in January and in Costa Rica in April could change policy on the negotiations, the Foreign Minister, Augusto Ramirez Ocampo, said Saturday.

headline: REAGAN MAY BOYCOTT FETE AT U.N. IF ARAFAT SHOWS UP
abstract: President Reagan may boycott ceremonies marking the 40th anniversary of the United Nations if Yasir Arafat, head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, takes part, a spokesman at the United States Mission said today.   If the General Assembly votes to invite Mr. Arafat, the United States will ''re-evaluate the level and extent of its participation,'' said the spokesman, who asked not to be identified.   ''Anything is a possibility,'' the spokesman added. ''We're hoping not to have to make this decision.''

headline: Unesco Head Refuses To Decide on New Term
abstract: As a Unesco meeting ended here, the organization's Director General, who has been criticized by Western countries for his handling of the agency, refused today to say whether he would seek re-election.   ''The choice of Director General is not made in newspaper columns,'' said the Director General, Amadou-Mahtar M'Bow of Senegal, at a news conference after the 23d general conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

headline: Military Export Rules
abstract: The Defense Department must improve its export control system to stop the Soviet Union from acquiring Western military technology, Stephen Bryen, Deputy Under Secretary of Defense, said today. Mr. Bryen told a House panel that the Soviet Union was making a big effort to steal Western technology, and said a recent Defense Department study found more than 5,000 Soviet military research projects have benefited significantly each year since 1980 from the acquisition of Western technology. He suggested that controls on technology include a fully integrated automated data processing system for all agencies involved in export control and compilation of a single list of controlled technology.

headline: U.S. PLANS INQUIRY ON JAPANESE CHIPS
abstract: President Reagan has initiated an unfair trade complaint against the Japanese semiconductor industry, ordering an investigation into whether the Japanese have sold high-capacity memory chips, used in sophisticated computers and other electronic devices, in this country at prices below the cost of production.   The President's action was announced today by Secretary of commerce Malcolm Baldrige, who is chairman of an interagency strike force set up by the President in late September as part of a more aggressive policy to combat unfair trade.   Mr. Baldrige told a news conference that the complaint involved 256,000-kilobit random access memory chips, known as 256K RAM's, He said the chips may have been sold in this country at ''substantially below'' their present production cost, a practice known as ''dumping.''      Higher Duties Might Be Imposed    Should the investigation find that dumping has occurred and should the International Trade Commission find that the American industry has been injured by it, higher duties could be imposed on Japanese chips, raising their price in the United States.

headline: Israeli Reporter Is Convicted For Making a Visit to Jordan
abstract: An Israeli journalist who visited Jordan was convicted here today of violating laws prohibiting Israelis from visiting countries at war with Israel.

headline: At Stop & Shop, Wife Is Husband's Successor
abstract: The Stop & Shop Companies, a multibillion-dollar retailing concern, said yesterday that Carol R. Goldberg had been named president.   Mrs. Goldberg, most recently executive vice president and chief operating officer, succeeds her husband, Avram J. Goldberg, as president. Last week, Mr. Goldberg, who is also chief executive, was named chairman.

headline: Profits Scoreboard
abstract: Net Income        Percent                                                                Change

headline: RESCUERS IN MEXICO TUNNEL TOWARD BOY
abstract: Rescue workers today continued to tunnel in the rubble of an apartment building destroyed by the earthquake last month, seeking a 9-year-old boy they think has been trapped alive for 16 days.   ''The workers in the tunnel consider themselves to be very close to the boy because they hear sounds that in accordance with their experience as rescuers makes them think the sounds are coming from the boy inside,'' said Col. J. D. Ramirez Garrido of the Mexico City police. Rescuers have identified the boy as Luis Ramon Nafarrate, who was in the apartment with his grandfather when the earthquake struck Mexico City Sept. 19.

headline: Bethlehem Steel
abstract: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said it had revised its retirement security program, effective Jan. 1, for nonunion salaried employees, and it expects to save at least $30 million annually. Bethlehem said the program will freeze pension benefit amounts of current salaried employees as of Dec. 31 and initiate a new defined contribution plan.

headline: TO HOSTAGE FAMILIES, WAITING BACK HOME IS ALSO A NIGHTMARE
abstract: There are 11 of them in the group, devoted friends from New York and New Jersey who for many years have spent weekends together at the Jersey shore.   ''We call them the beach people,'' said 34-year-old Lisa Klinghoffer, whose parents, Marilyn and Leon Klinghoffer of Manhattan, are members of the group and now hostages aboard a cruise ship in the Mediterranean.   This fall the Klinghoffers and their friends - men and women in their 60's and 70's, several of them in frail health - booked a cruise aboard the Italian ship Achille Lauro.   But through a quirk of fate involving a simple decision to take a sightseeing excursion in Egypt or to remain on board, the 11 have been separated. Five are safe in Cairo. Six, including the Klinghoffers, are among the 413 people estimated to be held by Palestinian hijackers aboard the Achille Lauro.

headline: BRITISH M.P.'S APPROVE ULSTER ACCORD, 473 TO 47
abstract: The House of Commons gave its overwhelming approval tonight to Britain's agreement with the Irish Republic that allows Dublin a consultative role and official presence in Northern Ireland.   Despite pleas made by Government and opposition spokesmen alike, the 473-to-47 vote in favor of the British-Irish accord appeared certain to lead to a mass resignation from the House by the 15 representatives of the province's Protestant majority.   The Unionists, as they are known on account of their commitment to the idea that the province must remain forever British, condemned the accord as a fatal concession to the nationalist cause of ending Ireland's partition.   The goal of the mass resignation, said to be the first of its kind in Parliament's history, would be to force a series of by-elections in Northern Ireland that could be interpreted as a referendum on the agreement that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher signed 12 days ago with her Irish counterpart, Garret FitzGerald.

headline: Urban Guerrilla Suspects Are Captured in Belgium
abstract: Four people were arrested today in a major breakthrough against urban guerrillas, Justice Minister Jean Gol said.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: Unpredictable Consumers ''Never before have economists been so uncertain,'' says Robert J. Eggert. When his forecasting concern, Eggert Economic Enterprises of Sedona, Ariz., polled 51 leading economists this month, the average forecast for the third quarter was a 3.1 percent rise in real gross national product at an annual rate. But the average hides an unusually wide range.   Pessimists expect the period to register a sluggish 2.5 percent annual growth rate, close to the 2.8 percent ''flash'' estimate recently announced by the Government. Optimists put the quarter's growth at a more robust 4.4 percent annual rate. The Government will help resolve the issue Friday when official - albeit, preliminary - figures are due out.

headline: Soviet Calls 'Star Wars' Weak
abstract: A Soviet military specialist outlined possible countersteps Monday that he said would convert into ''useless junk'' the kind of space-based missile defense envisioned by President Reagan.   The comments were in an article by Col. Vasily Morozov, retired, that was distributed by the official feature syndicate Novosti.

headline: WORLD BANK URGES CHINA POLICY SHIFTS
abstract: China's leaders have a ''good chance'' of fulfilling their ambitious economic goals for the next 15 years, but should consider a shift in emphasis away from crude output targets toward a strategy allowing for faster growth in personal income and services, a World Bank report has concluded.   The report, one of the most thorough independent studies ever made of the Chinese economy, offers a strong endorsement of the pragmatic policies of Deng Xiaoping, the 81-year-old Communist Party leader who has been in control since 1978. One of the report's central themes is a call for still greater play for market forces, decentralization and foreign investment, the cornerstones of Mr. Deng's approach. The report urged greater use of the marketplace to ''stimulate innovation and efficiency'' through cost cutting and quality control.   At the same time, the 183-page document, which was released late last week, strikes a cautionary note on a number of issues, including Mr. Deng's goal of catching up with the economic standards of the leading Western nations by the middle of the 21st century. The report states that this will require annual growth in per capita income - currently at about $300, on a par with Haiti - of as much as 6.5 percent. According to the report, only two relatively small nations, Greece and South Korea, have approximated such rapid growth since 1960.

headline: Teheran Car Bomb Kills 2
abstract: A car bomb exploded in front of a hospital in northern Teheran today, killing 2 people and wounding 18, officials and residents said. Iran's national press agency blamed ''agents of imperialism,'' an official term for opponents of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

headline: AT LAST, THE DEBUT OF I.B.M.'S NETWORK
abstract: After several years' delay that created confusion throughout the computer industry, the International Business Machines Corporation yesterday introduced the key elements of its long-awaited local area network, a high-speed communications system intended to link hundreds of independent computers.   I.B.M. officials and industry experts expressed hope that the network, intended primarily for use by a company or a business department, would finally bring order to a morass of computer communications problems, which many believe forced the nation's largest computer users to temporarily halt their buying. ''We've cleared a lot of smoke away today,'' said Stephen B. Schwartz, the I.B.M. vice president who directs the company's fledgling telecommunications efforts. ''We have given the industry a far better view of where we are going.''

headline: Mary Kay Deal
abstract: Mary Kay Cosmetics Inc. said it is now a private company.

headline: New Caledonia Amnesty Is Announced By France
abstract: France announced a partial amnesty today in its Pacific territory of New Caledonia and a package of steps aimed at helping the economy and resolving rival land claims by European settlers and Melanesians.

headline: West German Cities Hit By Bomb Blasts
abstract: Bombs exploded today at a car dealership and a botanical research station in Cologne and a fire bomb went off in a store in Hamburg, the police said. There were no injuries in the attacks.

headline: P.L.O. AIDE BIDS U.S. PRODUCE EVIDENCE ON HIJACKING LINK
abstract: Mohammed Abbas, the Palestinian official sought by the United States in connection with the hijacking of the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro, challenged Washington today to produce evidence showing that he was involved in the seizure.   His statement came in a telephone interview from Belgrade, Yugoslavia, shortly before associates here said that he had left by air for Southern Yemen.   In the interview, Mr. Abbas called on the United States to produce tape recordings that American officials contend include conversations of him coordinating the hijacking.

headline: SOUTH AFRICA ENDS A CASE AGAINST 12
abstract: Charges of treason against 12 prominent opponents of the South African Government were dropped today by the prosecution. Four others still face charges in the case.   Last week the state's key witness admitted in court that he did not know the ideological differences separating various political groups and had made ''fundamental mistakes'' in his testimony that could have misled the court.   The 12 against whom charges were dropped are leaders of the United Democratic Front. The front, a multiracial group that says it has more than 600 affiliates and at least 1.5 million members, is the country's largest nonparliamentary opposition movement.

headline: New Job ReportedFor Andropov's Son
abstract: The son of Yuri V. Andropov, the former Soviet leader, has been appointed an ambassador at large and will work with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, a ministry official said.   The appointment of Igor Y. Andropov, a 44-year-old career diplomat and former Ambassador to Greece, was made several weeks ago, the Foreign Ministry official said Thursday.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

headline: SOVIET REAFFRIMS ITS LINKS TO ARABS
abstract: The Soviet Union has begun a campaign to reassure the Arabs that Mikhail S. Gorbachev will not conclude a deal with President Reagan at Arab expense.   An article by the Soviet press agency Novosti, distributed here in Arabic Monday night, dismissed as ''fabrications'' and ''lies'' claims that Arab interests would be compromised at Geneva. The Soviet Union, it said, is ''fully committed'' to safeguarding ''the interests of its Arab friends.''

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    * Allied Signal Inc. is issuing 20 billion yen of 6 3/4 percent Eurobonds due in 1993 at 101 through Nomura International Ltd.    * Belgium is expected to offer $400 million of floating-rate notes in two issues, each at a price of 100.10. One issue of $150 million is due in 1995 and pays interest equal to the six-month London interbank offered rate, while a $250 million 25-year issue pays three basis points above the six-month rate.    * Chesebrough-Pond's Finance Corp. is offering $100 million of 10 5/8 percent senior debentures due in 1995 at 99.85 to yield 10.65 percent through Shearson Lehman Brothers.

headline: INDONESIANS HOPE TO SETTLE DISPUTES IN TIMOR AND IRIAN JAYA
abstract: Forty years after their country declared its independence from the Dutch, Indonesians say they are making progress in defusing two ''time bombs'' left behind by colonial powers.   One of the trouble spots is the former Dutch territory of West Irian, which shares the island of New Guinea with the independent nation of Papua New Guinea, and which has been the Indonesian province of Irian Jaya since 1963. The other is East Timor, a former Portuguese territory invaded and incorporated by Indonesia in 1975-1976.

headline: New York-Jersey Costs Up by 0.4%
abstract: Consumer prices in New York and northeastern New Jersey rose four-tenths of 1 percent in September, returning to the moderate inflationary pattern that has characterized the year so far, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.   The September increase, which followed a jump of seven-tenths of 1 percent the preceding month, indicated that the August rise was ''only a temporary break'' from the moderate increases that have produced a 3.3 percent inflation rate over the last 12 months, according to the regional commissioner of labor statistics, Samuel M. Ehrenhalt.   Nationwide, consumer prices rose two-tenths of 1 percent, after seasonal adjustment. Consumer prices in the region over the last nine months rose by three-tenths of 1 percent. For all of 1984, the regional increase was 4.8 percent. The regional index is not adjusted for seasonal variations.

headline: UNITED NATIONS CALENDAR
abstract: NATIONAL BIRTHDAYS - Today is the national day of three countries - China, Cyprus and Nigeria. The Chinese will mark the 36th anniversary of their nation with the second reception in two days at their mission on West 66th Street. The food promises to be one of the highlights of the circuit. The Nigerians had planned an early celebration on Friday, but the party was canceled, a mission spokesman said, when ''Gloria came to town.'' In keeping with past years and in light of continuing political troubles in Cyprus, that nation's mission plans no special celebration, a spokesman said.

headline: Ex-Cell-O Plant
abstract: The Ex-Cell-O Corporation, a large and diversified maker of automotive components and industrial equipment, said it had failed to find a buyer for its London, Ontario, plant and intends to close it on Nov. 29. The move affects nearly 200 people who make milling machines, machining centers and transfer lines. Ex-Cell-O cited a ''severely depressed market'' and Japanese competition for the closing.

headline: REBELS REPORT FOILING ATTACK
abstract: A spokesman for the African National Congress said today that a suspected South African agent was shot dead as he tried to kidnap a member of the group last weekend.   Two other agents fled, leaving a truck behind in the raid early Saturday morning, he added.   The shooting was the second violent incident in Lusaka this month involving the Congress, which has its headquarters here and is banned in South Africa.

headline: BRAZILIANS ELECTING MAYORS IN 201 CITIES
abstract: In the first elections since civilian government returned here last March, about 18 million Brazilians voted today in elections to pick the mayors of 201 cities, including all state capitals and urban centers.   The elections, which were hotly disputed - the Army was called in to patrol five cities - will measure the strength of the 5 old and the 25 new parties that are scrambling to fill the political vacuum left by the end of two decades of military rule.   The Brazilian Democratic Movement Party, the dominant partner in the governing coalition, is expected to win in most of Brazil's 23 state capitals.

headline: Conrail Urges Delay of Sale
abstract: Officials of the Consolidated Rail Corporation urged senators today to delay action on the proposed sale of the Government-owned railroad to the Norfolk Southern Corporation until the Justice Department finishes an antitrust analysis of the merger.   The Justice Department has given preliminary approval to the plan pending a more detailed examination.

headline: Beatrice Is Sued By 2 Shareholders
abstract: Two shareholders of the Beatrice Companies filed suit in state court today seeking an injunction to block the agreed upon sale of Beatrice to Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company for $50 a share or a total of $6.2 billion.   In their lawsuit, Louis Klein and Robert A. Weiss charge Beatrice's directors with, ''a lack of full efforts'' to find other bidders.

headline: DUTCH AFFIRM A DECISION TO DROP 2 NATO NUCLEAR COMBAT TASKS
abstract: The Dutch Defense Minister said today that despite opposition from other NATO members, his Government planned to stick to a decision to end its obligation to carry out two specific tasks in the event of war.   The Dutch decision to give up fighter-bomber and antisubmarine combat roles was criticized by Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger and other defense ministers here for a meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The meeting ended here today, one day ahead of schedule.

headline: THE BIG PAYOFF IN PAY PHONES
abstract: WITH visions of quarters jangling in their heads, corner delicatessens and corporate giants alike are buying pay telephones. The lure: Owners of pay phones need not pay commissions to telephone companies.   Federal restrictions on private ownership of pay phones were lifted earlier this year, and 30 states, including New York, now allow it. Marc Ostrofsky, editor of Private PayPhone News, estimates that more than 15,000 pay phones, made by 55 manufacturers, have been sold so far.

headline: PENSION PLANS
abstract: To the Editor:   ''Raking in Billions From the Company Pension Plan'' (Nov. 3), as well as proposals in Congress, reflect a lack of perspective on plan funding. They also demonstrate little appreciation for the rights and obligations of employers who establish and maintain voluntary retirement plans for their employees.   Defined benefit plans provide for the most secure retirement for workers. They are unquestionably the most expensive for an employer to maintain; the employer assumes all the risks of investment losses and adverse mortality and employment experience. The employer funds the plan based on actuarial assumptions which can result in excess plan assets at termination, or in underfunding, for which the employer may be liable in whole or in part at plan termination. The more conservative the assumptions, and the more responsible the funding, the greater the chance of excess assets at termination.

headline: Hong Kong Bank Loss
abstract: A Hong Kong bank that was saved from collapse by the Government in June said today that it lost $385 million in the year to June and predicted further deficits in the future.

headline: STATES' DRIVE ON PRICE FIXING
abstract: Calling the Reagan Administration's antitrust policy a ''betrayal of the consumer,'' the nation's 50 state attorneys general - Republicans and Democrats - today announced a drive to combat restraints on discounting and other ''vertical'' price fixing imposed by manufacturers and wholesalers on retailers.   The drive was announced by the National Association of Attorneys General. Robert Abrams, Democrat of New York, chairman of the association's antitrust committee, said the group was trying to set a uniform standard for state enforcement of Federal and local antitrust laws.   Mr. Abrams contrasted the association's policy statement with what he portrayed as lax enforcement by the Reagan Administration of vertical price restraints.

headline: WASHINGTON PONDERS YURCHENKO: A TROUBLED SPY OR AN ACTOR?
abstract: Vitaly S. Yurchenko's voice was breaking and he appeared to be brushing tears from his eyes this week as he described for reporters what he said were his experiences during three months in the hands of the Central Intelligence Agency.   ''When I was sleeping, they prohibited me even to close the door,'' he said. ''Door should be closed, and next room was sitting such fat, quiet, stupid - excuse me - unemotional person who is following the order. Only following the order.''   Mr. Yurchenko's rambling performance at the news conference this week may have been the finale in a elaborate play staged from the start by Soviet intelligence.
