Or it was a remarkable public display of the inner turmoil of a middle-aged man, a spy spurned by his lover and torn by guilt over betraying his homeland.

headline: A New Rule on Terminating Pensions
abstract: Companies terminating pension plans to siphon off excess cash will be able to report the excess immediately as profit under a new accounting rule issued yesterday. The rule changes the longstanding practice under which companies had to amortize, or spread, the profit over many years.   The rule, Statement 88 of the Financial Accounting Standards Board, the principal maker of accounting regulations, will apply not only to pensions terminated in the future but also retroactively to past terminations.

headline: AMERICAN IS REPORTED HELD BY RIGHTISTS IN BEIRUT
abstract: A British writer, reported yesterday to have been abducted in Beirut by a Christian rightist group, turned up last night in London saying that he had been released but that an American associate was still being held by the armed group.   The writer, Anthony Haden-Guest, identified the American as Steven Donahue of Hollywood, Fla. He said they were collaborating on a book about the narcotics trade in Lebanon and its political implications and linked their difficulties to the project.   Mrs. Donahue's wife, Joanna, said yesterday that she had known for some time that her husband was being held against his will but had only yesterday been given clearance by the State Department to make the case public.

headline: Merck Reports Profit Up 12.6%
abstract: Merck & Company, one of the nation's largest pharmaceutical companies, said yesterday that it earned $136.1 million, or $1.91 a share, in the third quarter, up 12.6 percent from $120.9 million, or $1.65 a share, a year ago. Revenues slipped to $855.8 million, from $857.9 million.

headline: WITH FOES OF MARCOS DIVIDED, EX-SENATOR REGISTERS TO RUN
abstract: Salvador H. Laurel registered today as a candidate for president of the Philippines, rejecting a last-minute offer from Corazon Aquino for a compromise that might have allowed them to run on a joint ticket.   Though Mrs. Aquino said she had not closed the door to a last-minute reconciliation, one of her aides said, ''It looks pretty hopeless.''   Attempts to form a unified ticket broke down Sunday, with the two candidates disagreeing over Mr. Laurel's insistence that his party, the United Nationalistic Democratic Organization, be their sole standard.

headline: THE RECESSIONS WEREN'T WORTH IT
abstract: IF THERE is a conventional wisdom about the disinflation experience of the first half of the 1980's, it is that the back-to-back recessions of 1980 and 1981 and 1982 (and the falling oil and commodities prices and strong dollar that accompanied them) were the unpalatable but indispensable medicine that purged the economy of double-digit inflation.   My own conclusion, after an examination of a full cycle of recession and recovery, is a bit different. While I do not dispute the general disinflationary effects of high unemploymentrates, falling materials prices and a rising dollar, I do believe the contribution of these factors to disinflation has been vastly overstated. In particular, I found that the mere stabilization of the dollar at its 1980 value and of oil and farm prices at historically high levels would have been enough to bring inflation down substantially.

headline: CHILL IN BUCHAREST BRINGS A WHIFF OF HARDER TIMES
abstract: The first chestnuts have fallen from the trees in Europe's greenest capital, nights have become nippy and Rumanians' thoughts are turning fearfully to winter.   Last winter lingers in memories as the worst time this country has experienced since World War II. To this day, Rumanians talk as though they feel in the marrow of their bones the record colds, aggravated by a critical shortage of fuel.   Men, women and children returned from cold and dimly lighted places of work or study to unheated homes, where they were told to light no more than one room, with a single bulb of low wattage.

headline: PROPOSAL ON FAILED BROKERAGE
abstract: The Commodity Exchange said yesterday that it would try to end a complicated legal wrangle by agreeing to provide $4.1 million to repay customers of the Volume Investors Corporation, a small brokerage firm whose accounts at the Comex were frozen last March when it went into receivership.   The situation has been a ticklish one for the Comex. ''I'm sure that they feel they don't want to be an insurer of people's accounts,'' John F.X. Peloso, the court-appointed receiver for Volume, said of the Comex. ''On the other hand, if commodity trading markets are to have stability and the confidence of investors, you have to have something to keep this from happening.''

headline: BRANDT, ON VISIT, ASKS ARMS FREEZE
abstract: Former Chancellor Willy Brandt urged the United States and the Soviet Union today to learn from ''the arms control disaster of the last decade'' and agree to a sweeping freeze of nuclear weapons while they negotiate for actual arms reductions.   Mr. Brandt, leader of West Germany's opposition Social Democratic Party, also called for a freeze on the development, testing and production of all space weapons.   He made his comments after receiving the Albert Einstein Peace Prize in Washington today. His speech dealt mainly with the summit meeting in Geneva between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev next week, which Mr. Brandt said was awaited by the world with a mixture of ''hope and fear.''

headline: Detroit Convention Center Expansion
abstract: Among the projects being undertaken to revive the downtown area of Detroit is the expansion of the Cobo Hall Convention Center. To finance the project, the city is selling $180 million of tax-exempt convention facility limited tax revenue bonds.

headline: Pepperell Gets New President
abstract: West Point-Pepperell Inc., the Georgia-based textile manufacturer, has named Donald J. Keller as president and chief operating officer, effective Jan. 15.

headline: Corpocracy
abstract: To the Editor:   That the points scored in ''Taming the Corpocracy'' (Forum, Oct. 13) have to be periodically ''rediscovered'' by detached observers like Messrs.

headline: THE SUMMIT: A PROLOGUE?
abstract: Soviet officials here, apparently in a policy shift, are now talking about the summit meeting more as an occasion to begin a dialogue with the United States than as an event to score a breakthrough in arms control.   For months, Soviet leaders have been saying that the meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev must be judged by whether they can agree on principles for breaking the negotiating deadlock in the Geneva arms talks, specifically whether Mr. Reagan is prepared to abandon his space-based missile defense program.   Now, presumably after assessing that this approach would fail, the Russians are saying that the conference must be seen more ''in overall terms'' and as part of a process. The hopes for a breakthrough on arms still flavor Soviet comments, but the pressure seems to be off.

headline: NEW TARGET, NEW WORRIES FOR HIJACKERS
abstract: Psychologists and other specialists have written many volumes on the human aspects of hijackings, hostage-takings and related events, but they have devoted little attention to the specific environment of ships.   In analyzing the seizure Monday of an Italian cruise liner in the Eastern Mediterranean Sea, authorities on terrorism offered these views:    * To the extent that large ships are a new and unexpected ''container of hostages,'' they plainly suit the needs of some political groups for new stages for attracting world attention.    * A large ship also appears to present hijackers with special problems, such as a greater difficulty in efforts to intimidate and control hundreds of widely dispersed captives.

headline: Bell Atlantic
abstract: The Bell Atlantic Corporation said it planned to spend up to $200 million to buy back stock on the open market between now and Dec. 31, 1986. The company, one of the seven operating companies spun off from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, said it has 99.9 million shares outstanding. At yesterday's close of $98.875, Bell's buyback would total about 2 million shares.

headline: OIL GROUP EXPECTED TO ASSAIL TAX PLAN
abstract: A change in tax policies, oil exploration in the Great Lakes and offshore California and the poor prognosis for oil prices next spring, as well as the short-term natural gas outlook, are expected to be discussed widely at the annual meeting of the American Petroluem Institute that begins Monday in San Francisco.   The 2,500 people gathering for the industry's largest annual conference - from the chief executives of the nation's leading major and independent oil companies to one-rig wildcatters - are expected to reiterate urgently that the tax-revision plans put forth by both the White House and the House Ways and Means Committee would discourage capital investment in the industry, and quickly stifle most exploration activity.   The industry was dismayed by the plan advanced by the Treasury Department last winter - which proposed eliminating many of the oil industry's tax incentives, including write-offs of intangible drilling costs - and was only somewhat mollified when the White House later revised the proposal to reinstitute the most valued of those breaks, such as the intangible drilling cost exemption.      Proposals Sharply Revised    But now the bill drafted by the Ways and Means Committee, which sharply revises the White House proposals for the oil industry, has provoked calls for scuttling the attempt to revise the tax code altogether.

headline: Prices Paid Farmers Dip
abstract: Prices that farmers get for raw products fell eight-tenths of 1 percent in September and now stand 13 percent below the level of a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.   September's drop, the seventh consecutive monthly decline, followed a fall in August even sharper than initially reported - 3.9 percent instead of the 3.2 percent estimate.

headline: Advertising;Lawson Joins Laurence Shop
abstract: Thomas F. Lawson, who left Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson early last week, is joining Laurence, Charles & Free as president and is bringing $35 million in McDonald's billings and 50 R.S.&L. employees with him, according to an agency source who requested anonymity.

headline: Advertising;   Magazine On Black Culture
abstract: ''AMERICAN VISIONS: The Magazine of Afro-American Culture'' is the brainchild of a black historian that will make its official debut on a most historic occasion, Jan. 15, the first national holiday marking the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Through the good offices of the Washington-based Martin Luther King Federal Holiday Commission, which will pay for production, the magazine will be mailed free to at least 1.5 million people, mostly upscale blacks. And that is the group that Gary Puckrein, 31-year-old publisher and editor in chief, would like to see making up most of his permanent subscriber list. So, in effect, the January mailing will be a giant sampling.   American Visions is being published by the Visions Foundation, and is benefiting from the cooperation and financial support of the Smithsonian Institution, the Philip Graham Fund of the Washington Post Company and Rutgers University, where Dr. Puckrein is on the history faculty. And it will have a six-a-year frequency. For its second issue, March-April, it will be dropping back to the start-up rate base it originally planned to have, 100,000, a respectable circulation for a newborn ''thought'' magazine, especially if they have a median household income of $30,000 to $32,000.

headline: People
abstract: Irwin Warren has been elected executive vice president and to the board of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn.    * E. Michael Roche has joined Kothe, Howard & Roche, Charlotte, N.C., as executive vice president and director of account services.    * Peter Hochstein and Anestos Tritchonis have joined Muller Jordan Weiss as senior vice presidents and creative directors.

headline: New Eminent Domain Issues
abstract: WHEN New York City rezoned some land in midtown Manhattan recently, the owners of the land sued the city. They asserted that the rezoning reduced the value of their property and therefore was equivalent to condemning it. When a government takes private property, according to the Constitution, it must compensate the owner.   The owners in this case lost. The court ruled that, as long as the property had other viable uses, ''downzoning'' was not equivalent to condemnation. This case is another example of the changes that have occurred since the concept of condemnation, or eminent domain, was developed centuries ago. The terms refer to the right of a government body to acquire a private individual's land for a public purpose, as long as it makes an appropriate payment.

headline: LEFTISTS IN HAMBURG CLASH WITH THE POLICE
abstract: Hundreds of leftists protesting a two-day meeting of a rightist group clashed with the police today.

headline: Profit Up 45% At Genentech
abstract: Genentech Inc., a leading biotechnology company, reported today that its third-quarter net income rose 45 percent, to $1.6 million, or 10 cents a share, from $1.1 million, or 8 cents a share, a year earlier.

headline: 2 Boating Magazines Make Advertising Offer
abstract: Ten-month-old Power and Motoryacht magazine, sent free monthly to 116,000 big spenders among boat owners, is teaming up in a joint buy with Cruising World magazine, which has catered to the needs and desires of cruising sailboat owners for 11 years. Together, the two magazines offer the marketers of upscale consumer goods 241,000 households with an average annual income of $115,000.

headline: PRICES TO FARMERS RISE
abstract: Prices farmers get for raw products rose 2.4 percent in the latest monthly reporting period, the second consecutive such increase, the Agriculture Department said today.   But even with the back-to-back increases, farm commodity prices in mid-November were 7.4 percent below the level of a year ago. Department economists said no significant recovery was in sight and that the farm economy would remain sluggish at least through the first half of 1986.

headline: RIGHTISTS MARCH IN MADRID TO HONOR FRANCO
abstract: Tens of thousands of right-wing Spaniards marched through Madrid today singing fascist songs in a celebration marking the death 10 years ago of Francisco Franco.   Led by Franco's daughter, Carmen, blue-shirted marchers waved the Falangist red and yellow Spanish flag as an old Franco saying, ''The enemies of Spain and of Christian civilization are alert,'' was repeated over loudspeakers.   The march crowned a series of events since the anniversary Wednesday of Franco's death and was one of the largest far-right demonstrations this country has seen in recent years. Authorities estimated that some 50,000 people marched, while organizers put the number higher.

headline: SPAIN INSISTS U.S. CUT TROOPS THERE
abstract: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez affirmed today that Spain would continue to press for a reduction in the number of American troops stationed here.   The issue, which has figured in talks between Madrid and Washington, has grown more sensitive recently as Spanish and American officials have given different accounts of the talks. They also disagree on whether the talks constitute formal negotiations.   Mr. Gonzalez, speaking in an hourlong interview here, suggested that American officials might not be clear about Spain's determination to seek the troop cuts.

headline: Daimler Set to Buy Big Stake in AEG
abstract: The auto maker Daimler-Benz A.G. said today that it plans to buy a majority stake in AEG A.G., an electronics maker, in a deal that would make Daimler-Benz the largest industrial concern in West Germany. The price and size of the proposed stake were not disclosed.   Daimler, perhaps best known for its Mercedes cars and trucks, has embarked this year on a diversification program that has already taken it into aerospace and aircraft engines.

headline: A.T.&T. Unit Gets Union Complaint
abstract: The Communications Workers of America filed an unfair-labor-practice charge against AT&T Information Systems in an effort to stop the American Telephone and Telegraph Company subsidiary from laying off some 24,000 employees. The union's president, Morton Bahr, said the formal complaint, filed with the National Labor Relations Board regional office in Newark, sought an injunction blocking the layoffs.

headline: JAPAN'S MAVERICKS SHUN LADDER FOR PEACE CORPS
abstract: The last thing Toshio Ogawa wanted out of life was the great Japanese dream.   For young men in this country, the dream usually means graduating from a good college, joining a prestigious corporation, working one's way up the ladder and waiting for retirement.   Not for Mr. Ogawa. He wanted to raise cattle after graduation, and perhaps travel. For two years, until last spring, he combined both ambitions by living in Ghana, teaching techniques in animal husbandry to farmers.

headline: General Shale To Study Offers
abstract: The General Shale Products Corporation, a leading producer of brick for residential and commercial construction, said that it had agreed to evaluate any serious inquiries from parties interested in acquiring the company. George C. Sells, the company's chairman and chief executive, said General Shale had been approached by ''seven or eight interested parties,'' none of whom had made an official offer.

headline: Anderson, Clayton Move
abstract: T. J. Barlow, who has been taking a gradual leave from the top management of Anderson, Clayton & Company, the Houston-based food products concern, will take early retirement at the start of the new year, the company has announced. However, it said he would continue as chairman ''on an interim basis'' until a successor was named.

headline: TERROR IN 1985: BRUTAL ATTACKS, TOUGH RESPONSE
abstract: As a year of hijackings, kidnappings, car bombings and murder draws to a close, reports from correspondents of The New York Times around the world indicate that governments have hardened their attitudes and toughened security measures against a growing plague of terrorism.   Across Europe and the Middle East, where terrorists in 1985 struck more often and more brutally than in years past, governments have adopted new laws, ordered tighter defenses and forged new links of international cooperation to exchange information, catch and prosecute terrorists, and isolate nations that support them.   Even Italy and Austria, which have long been sympathetic to Palestinian and Arab causes, on Friday found their airports the targets of men with links to Palestinians, and officials' responses showed they were embarrassed.      Britain's Tough Measures    Britain, which uses tough measures to suppress Northern Ireland violence that have led to more violence, agreed last fall to give the Irish Republic a voice in the affairs of Northern Ireland.   France, where violence by leftist radicals has sharply increased in the past year, has made little progress in trying to track terrorists and is considering a range of tougher measures -including more police powers to infiltrate terrorist groups, even if these encroach upon traditional freedoms.

headline: GENETIC SYSTEMS GETS BRISTOL BID
abstract: The Bristol-Myers Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Genetic Systems Corporation, a biotechnology company based in Seattle, for $10.50 a share, or a total of $294 million in Bristol-Myers stock.   The deal would give Bristol-Myers access to Genetic Systems' expertise in monoclonal antibodies, which identify disease organisms in the body and are considered a key to developing cures for cancer and other diseases.

headline: VOLCANO RESCUE APPEARS TO END
abstract: Officially, the search for survivors of the eruption of the Nevado del Ruiz volcano here is still under way. But except for intensified efforts by two small teams of French and British rescue workers, the operation, which from the beginning had been fragmented, small and poorly equipped, had all the signs of being over.   A few helicopters made low passes over the mud plain covering this ruined town, but most of the aircraft in the area were hauling food and other supplies to refugees camped on the surrounding hills.   Journalists and construction workers who have been going into Armero daily said that the number of helicopters and volunteer rescue workers had dwindled to the lowest point since the search started.

headline: U.S. DECLARES KAHANE IS NO LONGER A CITIZEN
abstract: The State Department said today that it had deprived Rabbi Meir Kahane, the Israeli political leader, of his United States citizenship.   The action came after Rabbi Kahane took a seat in the Israeli Parliament last year, and after he told a National Press Club audience last month that he retained his American citizenship only as a matter of convenience.   The State Department concluded that both actions had signaled Rabbi Kahane's intention to relinquish his United States citizenship, according to James P. Callahan, a spokesman for the agency. Rabbi Kahane, 54 years old, had held dual citizenship.

headline: CONQUERING A SOFTWARE LAN
abstract: THE promise of the new zero-slot LAN's, or local area networks, is economy.   These software-based LAN's, as they are also known, tie two or more computers together so that peripherals, such as printers, can be shared and files can be transferred electronically from one user's screen to another's, without any hardware adjustments other than plugging a cord into each computer gaining access to the network.   On the average, zero-slot LAN's range from $100 to $300 per computer. A standard hardware-based LAN, on the other hand, requires the addition of a zero to the end of each of those numbers. The question such a difference is likely to pose in the potential buyer's mind is what one gives up in the process of obtaining that kind of savings.

headline: CBS STOCK UP SHARPLY FOR 3D DAY
abstract: Capping three days of hectic trading, CBS stock rose $4.75 a share yesterday, to $123.25, in heavy volume. Fueled by a variety of takeover rumors, CBS stock has soared $14.50 a share in the past three days, rising $5 on Thurday and $4.75 the previous day.   Wall Street traders said they had heard that Fisher Bros., a major New York real estate firm headed by Larry and Zachary Fisher, were planning a bid for the company, or that the General Electric Company might be interested.

headline: DISPUTES BOG DOWN HEARING ON HOLDINGS SAID TO BE MARCOSES'
abstract: A House subcommittee looking at purported holdings in the United States of President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines and his wife, Imelda, bogged down today amid partisan disputes and conflicting statements during public and closed sessions.   Representative Stephen J. Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn, and chairman of the subcommittee on Asian and Pacific Affairs of the House Foreign Affairs Committee clashed with a subcommittee member Representative Gerald B. H. Solomon, Republican of upstate New York, over whether the committee's investigation was interfering with elections set for Feb. 7 in the Philippines.

headline: C.G.E. Talks Stop
abstract: The French Government has called off talks between one of its state-owned companies and the Swedish company L. M. Ericsson until it decides whether to go ahead with a deal involving the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the Industry and Trade Minister, Edith Cresson, said. Speaking to reporters, the minister said the Government had given ''the green light'' to state-owned Compagnie Generale d'Electricite to negotiate further with A.T.&T. and repeated her desire to see the initial deal improved.

headline: Asian Wall Street Journal Apologizes to Singapore
abstract: The Asian Wall Street Journal and its editor apologized to Singapore's High Court today for committing contempt of court in an editorial published in The Journal last month.   The newspaper and its editor accepted responsibility for what Attorney General Tan Boon Teik called ''a scandalous article'' in The Journal's Oct. 17 issue.

headline: I.R.A. ALLY DERIDES PARLEY ON IRELAND
abstract: Gerry Adams, the head of Sinn Fein, the political arm of the Irish Republican Army, today characterized the negotiations between the British and Irish Governments on Northern Ireland as an effort ''to put a diplomatic veneer on British rule'' and to make it more stable in the long term.   The outcry by Unionists, who want the talks stopped, will be used by both Governments, he told his party's annual conference at the Mansion House in Dublin, to ''exaggerate the substance of whatever concessions are produced.'' The Unionists want Northern Ireland to remain a part of Britain.   The agreement, still not reached but considered possible in the next few weeks, is expected to give the Dublin Government an advisory role in affairs north of the border. Sinn Fein leaders said this weekend that, while they welcomed anything that would improve life for nationalists in the north, they rejected any settlement that would fortify the political status quo.

headline: U.S., JOINING JORDAN, FAVORS A SYRIAN ROLE IN PEACE TALKS
abstract: The United States said today that it hoped Syria would join with Jordan and Israel in reviving Middle East peace talks.   In a conciliatory statement toward Syria, Bernard Kalb, the State Department spokesman, said:   ''We continue to hope that all parties in the dispute, including Syria, will recognize the opportunities inherent in the current peace process and elect to participate constructively.''   For the last six months, the United States has been trying to arrange direct negotiations between Israel and a joint Jordanian-Palestinian group. But the effort has run into problems.

headline: Fed Bank on Coast Names President
abstract: Robert T. Parry, chief economist with the Security Pacific Corporation, will succeed John Balles as president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, upon Mr. Balles's retirement in February.   For Mr. Parry, who is 46 years old, the job will offer what he described as a number of challenges and opportunities. ''As a professional economist, I've had a long interest in monetary policy and I look forward to having discussions on monetary policy from the inside,'' he said in a telephone interview from his office in Los Angeles. ''I look at that as an opportunity.''

headline: S.E.C. Upheld On Bank Rule
abstract: A Federal District Court today upheld the Securities and Exchange Commission's authority to require banks that offer brokerage services to register with the commission as securities brokers.   In July, the commission decided to require, effective Jan. 1, that a bank that publicly solicits brokerage business, makes a profit on execution of orders or underwrites securities must comply with the regulations that govern brokers.   The new rule does allow a bank to transfer its brokerage activities to a subsidiary and only the subsidiary would have to make the required disclosures.

headline: WHITE HOUSE, IN SHIFT, SAYS RAID BY ISRAEL 'CANNOT BE CONDONED'
abstract: The White House backed away today from its firm support of the Israeli air strike on Tuesday at the headquarters of the Palestine Liberation Organization in Tunisia.   A carefully phrased White House statement called the raid ''understandable as an expression of self-defense'' but said the bombing ''cannot be condoned.'' In its initial statements Tuesday, the White House had called the Israeli action ''a legitimate response'' to ''terrorist attacks.''   The P.L.O. said 67 people were killed in the bombing. Israel said it attacked the P.L.O. headquarters in retaliation for the slaying of three Israeli civilians in Larnaca, Cyprus, last week. P.L.O. officials in Cyprus denied at the time that they or any group affiliated with the P.L.O. were responsible, although an anonymous caller took responsibility on behalf of a Palestinian commando unit.

headline: CHINA REPORTED TO HAVE GOTTEN TOP U.S. SECRETS
abstract: A former Central Intelligence Agency analyst is thought to have given China many of the C.I.A.'s top-secret reports on the Far East over the last 20 years, an Administration official said today.   According to the official, the Government believes that the analyst, Larry Wu-Tai Chin, 63 years old, had access to nearly all these documents. The official, who is knowledgeable about the case, said Mr. Chin was one of the agency's most experienced Chinese-language translators and was involved in distributing C.I.A. reports to the White House and Federal agencies.   Another Administration official said Mr. Chin might have provided China with detailed information about American policymaking in the Vietnam War. According to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Mr. Chin has confessed spying for the Chinese since at least 1952.

headline: IN MOSCOW, KEEN INTEREST IN REAGAN ARTICLE
abstract: President Reagan's interview with Soviet journalists, published in today's issue of the Government newspaper Izvestia, was not exactly the talk of the town, but it did attract considerable attention.   Muscovites seemed not only aware of Mr. Reagan's comments but keenly interested in them.   The interview was the first by an American President with Soviet journalists in more than two decades. Izvestia published a full page of Mr. Reagan's remarks but deleted some of them, including some of his criticism of the Soviet role in Afghanistan. The newspaper's version of the interview was accompanied by a full-page critique by the four Soviet reporters who interviewed the President at the White House last week.

headline: FROM SOVIET, SYMPATHY AND A BARB FOR THE U.S.
abstract: The official Soviet press agency Tass today described America's anger at the killing of an American by Palestinian hijackers as ''understandable and just,'' but then pointedly recalled that two Soviet hijackers had been given refuge in the United States.   The first Soviet report about the American operation to divert an Egyptian jetliner and capture the Palestinian hijackers was published in the newspaper Izvestia without commentary.   A later Tass dispatch said, ''The crimes of terrorists, no matter where they are committed, must be punished most severely, and such severity must be shown unfailingly to all perpetrators of such crimes.''

headline: POPE EMPHASIZES ROLE OF VATICAN
abstract: Pope John Paul II opened a special meeting of the College of Cardinals today with a strong assertion of papal authority and a defense of the Roman Curia.   The Pope's address was a prelude to nearly three weeks of crucial meetings here that will be dominated by a special Synod of Bishops.   The synod, which begins with another papal address on Sunday, will discuss the effect of the Second Vatican Council on the Roman Catholic Church. The council, which closed 20 years ago, had a revolutionary impact on Catholicism and marked a greater openness to the modern world.

headline: Market Place;   Analysts' View Of Bell Issues
abstract: WALL STREET houses are renewing their praises of the seven regional Bell companies that were divested from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company at the start of 1984. Salomon Brothers expects shares of the Baby Bells to exceed the performance of Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and other telephone issues over the next 6 to 12 months.   ''We estimate that the shares will provide investors with an annual return of about 15 percent,'' said Neil Yelsey, who follows telecommunications services for the firm. He cited the ''reliable earnings growth, low price/earnings ratios, high yield and solid fundamentals'' of the regionals.

headline: Real Estate;   Catering To Small Offices
abstract: IN a city of skyscrapers, where talk of putting up the world's tallest building is taken seriously, almost no one pays attention to small buildings and the tenants who occupy them.   But one man's surplus is often another man's need and several developers now say there is a market - albeit limited - for quality office space on a comparatively small scale. They say that such space is being sought by foreign companies that want to establish a classy New York office, or domestic companies with headquarters in another state that still need to do business in the city on a regular basis but do not want to be jammed into one corner of a large floor with other small users.   Several developers have tried to meet this need. Most re-use existing buildings that are not being held to assemble land for a new office tower. But on Fifth Avenue, a Brazilian development company is beginning construction on a narrow, 18-story building that will contain just 85,000 square feet of space.

headline: BUOYANT CAPITAL HAILS THE ACTION
abstract: Reagan Administration officials and legislators reacted exuberantly tonight to the news that American warplanes had seized the four hijackers who apparently killed an elderly American aboard an Italian cruise ship.   ''Thank God we've won one,'' said Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York.   The comment summed up the mood in this startled capital after years of witnessing the Carter and Reagan administrations struggling in vain to cope with Middle East terrorism and attacks against the United States.      Iran Crisis Recalled    Officials pointed out that it was nearly six years ago that Iranian revolutionaries seized the United States Embassy in Teheran and virtually made a hostage of the Carter Administration. Mr. Carter found himself unable to fulfill his threats against terrorists and, in the case of a military raid to rescue the Americans held hostage in Iran, failed in a humiliating manner.

headline: Connecticut Issue
abstract: The Connecticut Resources Recovery Authority is offering $91.7 million of bonds for a solid waste disposal and energy generating project with a maximum yield of 8.702 percent for bonds due in 2004 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. For shorter maturities, yields ranged from 7 percent for bonds due in 1990 to 7.90 percent in 1995 and 8.40 percent in 2001. The bonds are rated A by Moody's and Standard & Poor's.

headline: Advertising;   Magazine to Welcome People to New Homes
abstract: Beginning next June, families moving into new homes in 25 major markets will receive a handy magazine and guide from a local utility that will inform them about the area and coming events. A quarterly, it will appropriately be named Changing Homes. The people behind it are expecting to distribute 6.2 million copies the first year and add 10 markets the second.

headline: Lowered Ratings For General Foods
abstract: The General Foods Corporation's debt rating and those of its subsidiaries was lowered to A-1, from Aa-2, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday.

headline: Market Place;   Award's Effect On Pennzoil
abstract: IN the wake of the Pennzoil Company's record damages award, Wall Street analysts are trying to handicap the value of Pennzoil's shares.   A quick sampling, taken two days after Pennzoil's $10.53 billion jury award in its case against Texaco Inc., indicates the analysts are betting that Pennzoil will take home at least $500 million before taxes.   ''It's really very, very subjective at this point, but almost everyone among the lawyers we've talked to close to the case thinks Texaco is in a box,'' said Thomas E. Hassen, an oil analyst with Morgan Stanley & Company. He estimated that Texaco would have to pay at least $1 billion.

headline: REAGAN SAID TO PROMISE A POST-GENEVA BRIEFING
abstract: President Reagan has agreed to meet with European leaders after his conference next month with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, according to Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany.   In a long conversation with West German journalists in New York on Thursday night, Mr. Kohl said that he and several other European politicians had pressed the President at dinner that evening to agree to such a meeting, and that Mr. Reagan had agreed. Mr. Kohl said the meeting would probably be held in Brussels on Nov. 21, immediately after the Reagan-Gorbachev talks in Geneva.   A ranking Administration official said the President was ''working on the notion.''

headline: Eritrea Rebels Report Halting Offensive by Ethiopia Troops
abstract: A rebel group, the Eritrean People's Liberation Front, said today that it had killed or wounded nearly 5,000 Ethiopian troops in halting a Government offensive against strongholds in the Eritrean heartland in northern Ethiopia.   A representative of the rebels in the United Arab Emirates, Othman Mohammed Omer, said in a news statement that Ethiopian forces had suffered 4,800 dead or wounded in an offensive that began on Nov. 9.

headline: Chrysler Canada Layoff
abstract: Chrysler Canada Ltd. said today that it was temporarily laying off more than a third of its work force at its plant in Ajax, Ontario, because of an inventory buildup resulting from a strike of Chrysler plants by American workers. That strike was settled Wednesday. There are 2,000 employees at the Ajax plant, which makes trim parts.

headline: ARMCO'S CHAIRMAN PLANS TO STEP DOWN
abstract: Armco Inc., which is trying to climb back to profitability after three successive years of huge losses, said today that Harry Holiday Jr., its chairman since 1982, would retire next Jan. 31. Mr. Holiday, who is 62 years old, will be succeeded by Dr. Robert E. Boni, 57, who will remain president and chief executive.   Armco, which is based in Middletown, Ohio, also reported earnings for the third quarter of $48.6 million. But over the last three years, Armco has lost a total of more than $1 billion.

headline: GUYANA PRESIDENT SAYS HE IS VICTOR
abstract: President Desmond Hoyte claimed an ''overwhelming'' victory today in the elections here and said he was ''catagorically denying'' widespread charges of fraud and voter interference.   In a news conference this afternoon, the 56-year-old Mr. Hoyte said he was satisfied that the elections held on Monday in this South American nation were ''above board and regular.''   Mr. Hoyte dismissed accusations issued today by seven church, labor and human rights organization as well as the Guyana Bar Association that the elections had been a ''sordid catalogue of widespread disenfranchisement.''

headline: Palestinian Thanks Rome
abstract: Mohammed Abbas expressed thanks to Italy today for allowing him and a bodyguard to leave Rome for Belgrade.   Mr. Abbas, who heads a faction of the Palestine Liberation Front, was aboard an Egyptian airliner carrying the four hijackers that was diverted to Sicily early Friday morning.   Italy allowed Mr. Abbas to leave despite an American request for his extradition. The United States has formally protested to the Government of Prime Minister Bettino Craxi.

headline: Trade Stirs Concern In Quebec
abstract: Robert Bourassa, the Premier-elect of Quebec, said Wednesday that he is nervous about a Canadian free trade pact with the United States.   In a wide-ranging interview, Mr. Bourassa said the talks that Prime Minister Brian Mulroney had proposed to President Reagan could eventually lead to the United States politically swallowing up Canada. United States-Canadian trade is bigger by far than between any other two nations.

headline: Mexican's Body Recovered
abstract: Rescue workers today found the body of a 55-year-old man in the rubble of a building destroyed by last month's earthquakes. But there was no sign of his 9-year-old grandson, who had been believed alive but was given up for dead.

headline: Computer Company Loss
abstract: The Computervision Corporation said today that it had lost $20.7 million in the third quarter, in contrast to a net income of $4.7 million, or 16 cents a share, in the 1984 period.   Revenues dropped about 23 percent, to $105.8 million from $137.1 million a year ago.

headline: G.N.P. GROWTH
abstract: To the Editor:   Critical to the argument in ''Lower Rates Will Kick Off a Boom'' (Forum, Sept. 30) was the assertion that quarterly G.N.P. growth rates ''are bimodal, with one cluster centering on the 6 to 8 percent range, the other on the 1 to 3 percent range.''   The facts are different.

headline: MOROCCAN HARDENS POSITION ON TALKS WITH ISRAEL
abstract: King Hassan II elaborated today on terms for holding peace talks with Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel, saying that such negotiations could not take place until Israel made it clear it was willing to discuss giving up occupied territories and granting Palestinians self-determination.   The King's statement came a day after he said he was prepared to receive Mr. Peres for talks in Rabat ''if he has some serious proposal to make.''   In a television interview Monday, King Hassan said that Mr. Peres had asked to be invited to Morocco to talk with the King, who is chairman of the 21-nation Arab League and acted as intermediary in the Egypt-Israel negotiations.

headline: TRAILBLAZER AND TEAM PLAYER
abstract: The choice of Franco Modigliani as winner of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science is a popular one among economists, a tribe often given to highly refined and sometimes vocal dispute. Yesterday congratulatory telephone calls and laudatory telegrams poured in to his office at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.   ''Economists all over the world are students, admirers and friends of Franco Modigliani,'' said Paul A. Samuelson of M.I.T., himself a Nobel laureate, Like previous winners of the award, Professor Modigliani (pronounced ''mo-deel-YAH-nee'') is considered a consummate academic and an intellectual pathfinder. But unlike some others, whose work was either obscure or accessible only to specialists, his ideas have shaped generations of students.   ''If you took finance at business school, if you studied economics, or if you studied corporations in law school, chances are you will have heard of Franco's propositions,'' said Eugene Flood, professor of finance at the Stanford Business School. He studied in graduate school under Professor Modigliani.

headline: Zimbabwe Leader Signs Accords With Moscow
abstract: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe reached agreement Tuesday with Soviet leaders on two accords aimed at improving relations, the official press agency tass said today.   Tass said Mr. Mugabe, in his first offical visit to Moscow, and Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, the Soviet Prime Minister, signed an agreement to increase economic and technological cooperation and a protocol to expand political ties.

headline: MORAL RIGHT'FERVOR LAPS AT NEW ZEALAND SHORE
abstract: It was the biggest petition effort in the history of New Zealand, bigger even than the drive a decade ago to save the white birch trees of the South Island.         The subject reflected the changing times in this nation where urbanization and modern values are challenging traditional ways of life: homosexual rights.

headline: New Patent Office Chief
abstract: Donald J. Quigg took office today as Commissioner of Patents and Trademarks. The Senate had approved his nomination on Thursday. Mr. Quigg, who had been deputy commissioner, joined the staff in 1981. Before that, he had been patent counsel for the Phillips Petroleum Company.

headline: GORBACHEV CALLS REAGAN MEETINGS A 'POSITIVE' START
abstract: Mikhail S. Gorbachev said in a speech today that his discussions with President Reagan had been a success and that preparations for the next summit meeting, in 1986, should start now.   Mr. Gorbachev's televised 80-minute speech to the Supreme Soviet, or parliament, marked his first effort since a news conference in Geneva to report on the summit meeting to the Soviet public.   Reading from a prepared text, he explained why he had decided to meet with Mr. Reagan and why he regarded the results as encouraging despite the absence of progress in arms control.      Test Freeze a Topic in Geneva   Mr. Gorbachev called on Mr. Reagan again to join in a halt of nuclear testing to strengthen trust. Moscow announced a freeze in July but said it would expire Jan. 1 unless Washington joined in. The Americans have refused on the ground that they need further tests to catch up with the Russians.

headline: President of Mattel Resigns the Position
abstract: Mattel Inc., the toy and game company, has announced that Glenn Hastings, its president, has resigned.   Mattel said that Mr. Hastings, who is 58 years old, ''has been obliged for personal reasons not to continue'' in his role as president, a post he has held since June 1984.   Mattel would not elaborate beyond that statement, but industry analysts and sources close to the company said that Mr. Hastings was in ill health.

headline: G.M.A.C. Issue Biggest of Kind
abstract: Officials at the First Boston Corporation said yesterday that they expected to offer later this week a $524 million issue of bonds for the General Motors Acceptance Corporation backed by automobile loan receivables. The financing exceeds the total amount of all previous bonds backed by automobile and lease receivables and marks the first such financing by an automobile finance company.

headline: 2 VISIT GUATEMALA TO SEEK BROTHER
abstract: Two brothers of an American journalist who has been missing in Guatemala for seven months asserted this week that neither the Guatemalan Government nor the American Embassy here had done as much as it could to learn the missing man's fate.   Nick Blake, 27 years old, and a companion, Griffin Davis, also an American citizen, disappeared in the rugged Guatemalan highlands in March. Soldiers, guerrillas, armed civil defense patrols and bandits are known to roam the region.   ''After seven months, we can assume they're dead,'' Sam Blake, 23, said here in an interview here Sunday night. ''We'd like to know by whom.'' ''We don't believe we've had the full cooperation of both Governments,'' he said. ''We have not had the full cooperation of our embassy.'' Sam and his brother, Randy, came to Guatemala last week for a brief visit.

headline: U.S. and Soviet Open Talks on Airline Link
abstract: The United States and the Soviet Union opened talks here today on resuming a direct airline connection.   The aim is to reach an agreement before President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, meet in Geneva on Nov. 19 and 20.

headline: Tate & Lyle Official Appointed Chairman
abstract: Neil Shaw has been appointed chairman and chief executive of Tate & Lyle P.L.C., the British sugar company. He succeeds Sir Robert Haslam, who became deputy chairman of the National Coal Board Nov. 1 and is scheduled to become chairman next March.   Mr. Shaw, 56, was elected director of Tate & Lyle in 1975 and became group managing director in 1980.

headline: AT OLD BAILEY, POWDER PUFFS VS. HOBNAILS
abstract: When a rowdy soccer fan named Kevin Whitton was sentenced to life imprisonment the other day, Members of Parliament and editorial writers outdid one another in praise for the judge. When a former philosophy student named Nicholas Boyce got six years in jail, no one bothered to comment on the sentence.   Yet by the standards of most societies, including Britain's, Mr. Boyce's crime far exceeded Mr. Whitton's in its consequences and gruesomeness.   The details might almost be characterized as unmentionable, except that they were reported in even the most highbrow newspapers in grisly detail. Having strangled his wife, Mr. Boyce hacked her body into small pieces, some of which he cooked, in order, it was explained to the jury, to make them look like leftovers from ''a Sunday lunch.'' The remains were then distributed at various points around London.

headline: JAILED PALESTINIANS: HUNDREDS HELD
abstract: Despite the release of 1,150 convicted Palestinian guerrillas and other prisoners by Israel in May as part of an exchange for three Israeli prisoners of war captured in Lebanon, hundreds of Palestinians remain in Israeli jails.   Although guerrilla leaders wanted to virtually empty the Israeli prisons of Palestinians, the Israeli authorities managed to limit the number freed in the exchange to 1,150, of whom 600 were allowed to return to their homes in Israel, the occupied West Bank or the Gaza Strip.   Those released included some of the most notorious Palestinian terrorists - 79 had been directly involved in killing Israelis, and 380 were serving life sentences - as well as political activists serving lesser terms.   The Palestinians remaining in Israeli prisons have been imprisoned for a variety of crimes. These include the murder of Jews, the planting of explosives in Jewish neighborhoods, stone throwing, advocating Palestine Liberation Organization causes, and membership in Palestinian guerrilla organizations.

headline: Walton Heads List Of Richest in U. S.
abstract: For Sam M. Walton, this has been a very good year. For Gordon Peter Getty it has been comparatively poorer, but all things considered he still has little to complain about.   Mr. Walton, the chairman of the Wal-Mart Corporation, this year became the richest man in the country, with a total net worth of $2.8 billion, according to a special issue of Forbes magazine. Last year, Mr. Walton was ranked No. 2.

headline: CHEWY COOKIE MARKET FALTERS
abstract: Stan Livingston of McFarland, Wis., tried those chewy home-style cookies that the likes of Procter & Gamble, Nabisco, Frito-Lay and Keebler have been touting. But Dr. Livingston, a 32-year-old physician and a longtime connoisseur of the homemade chocolate chip cookie, was not impressed.   ''They really don't taste that good, to tell you the truth,'' he said.   The problem for cookie companies is that millions of cookie munchers apparently agree. They just do not seem to believe that the cookies are as good as the ones mom makes - or those sold fresh-baked by specialized chains such as David's Cookies and Mrs. Fields.

headline: RIOTS CONTINUE IN BRITISH CITIES
abstract: Youths in Liverpool attacked policemen with stones today as violence flared for a second straight day after a night of violence in that city and in Peckham, an area of south London.   The officers came under attack by a crowd of about 20 youths as they watched the demolition of a shop burned during violence Tuesday night in the Toxteth area of Liverpool.   Eighteen people were injured and 13 arrested in violence that was touched off Tuesday after a crowd gathered to disrupt proceedings in Liverpool Magistrates' Court, where four men were appearing on charges of being involved in a brawl. Crowds stoned the police station and set cars afire.

headline: Iranian Gunboats Seize Kuwaiti Cargo Vessel
abstract: Iranian gunboats have seized a Kuwait-registered cargo ship with a 43-man crew in the Gulf of Oman, the ship's owners said today.

headline: U.S. AIDES FIND HOPE AS SOVIET URGES TEST BAN
abstract: Although the Reagan Administration has publicly rejected the Soviet Union's proposal for a moratorium on nuclear testing, some Administration officials say they still see the Soviet move as a potentially positive development.   In a Dec. 5 letter to President Reagan, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, proposed that the United States join Moscow's current unilateral moratorium on the underground testing of nuclear weapons, the only tests now permitted. He said that under the moratorium, observers could visit each side's territory to investigate ''ambiguous phenomena'' and resolve ''possible doubts'' about compliance.   Mr. Gorbachev also proposed resuming talks with the United States and Britain on a comprehensive ban on underground nuclear tests. Negotiations on such an agreement were carried out during the Carter Administration, but the Reagan Administration has not sought to resume them.

headline: CRAXI IS POSITIVE ON U.S. RELATIONS
abstract: Bettino Craxi, the caretaker Prime Minister of Italy, says he does not blame the Reagan Administration for the collapse of his Government in the aftermath of the hijacking of the cruise ship Achille Lauro.   In an interview after he arrived in New York City on Wednesday night, Mr. Craxi said relations between the two countries were not permanently damaged because of actions taken by the United States after the hijacking ended.   In addition, he said the United States should realize that the recent Israeli bombing of the Palestine Liberation Organization headquarters in Tunisia was a ''political bombing,'' with even more serious consequences than the Achille Lauro affair and should have been recognized as such by the United States.   ''The Government crisis was the fruit of the garden of Italian political life, and not the fault of the Americans,'' Mr. Craxi said. He called the tension between the two Governments last week that led to the collapse of his five-party coalition Government ''a little incident, a little incomprehensible turn of events that has been set right.''

headline: Man Is Fined $1,500 In Niagara Falls Stunt
abstract: A Canadian mechanic who plunged over Niagara Falls in a barrel was fined the maximum $1,500 today, and the police said he promised not to try the stunt again.   The mechanic, John David Munday, 48 years old, said in Provincial Court today that the ride over the Horseshoe Falls on Oct. 5 was ''a terrifying experience'' that he had no desire to repeat. By making that pledge, Munday avoided a possible 30-day jail sentence.

headline: MARYLAND ADOPTS CHASE PLAN
abstract: Maryland's General Assembly today approved a plan to let the Chase Manhattan Corporation enter the Maryland banking market by purchasing three ailing thrift institutions.   The approval came after six grueling days of negotiations and an impassioned plea from Gov. Harry R. Hughes. The deal will free about $500 million in frozen deposits and relieve the state of millions of dollars in potential losses it would face if it had to liquidate the savings and loan associations.

headline: SOME ANALYSTS SAY BID FOR SEA-LAND IS 'FAIR'
abstract: Harold C. Simmons' unsolicited $25-a-share offer for the Sea-Land Corporation, which goes before the container company's board today, may be too good to turn down, analysts say, even though management has previously indicated that a takeover is undesirable.   ''From a shareholder's point of view, I think that $25 a share is a good price in today's market,'' said T. Richard Holt, a vice president at Wheat, First Securities Inc. of Richmond. The company, he said, ''isn't going to have the greatest results'' this year and next, adding that ''the opportunity costs of holding the stock at recent prices could add up.''   Another analyst, who asked not to be identified, said the offer was ''fair, even generous,'' given Sea-Land's recent performance and the outlook for the shipping industry.

headline: PAPANDREOU WARNS CABINET OF THREAT OF 'CHAOS'
abstract: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou has warned his Cabinet that the conjunction of labor unrest and a bomb explosion on an Athens bus on Thursday raised the threat of ''insecurity and chaos'' comparable to the situation that led to a coup and military dictatorship in 1967.   Mr. Papandreou said Friday, in a talk whose full text was made public today, that the armed forces, although loyal to democracy and the Constitution, still contained seeds from the seven years of military dictatorship and would continue to for many years.   He also warned of unspecified foreign forces that might create tension for their own advantage, saying:   ''We must not forget but must always bear in mind that the forces of reaction, which were deeply disappointed by the results of the June 2 elections - such forces exist inside and outside Greece - might be in a position to create step by step, and at the same time take advantage of, an extended atmosphere of insecurity and chaos like that of 1965-66.''   Labor unions have held a continuing wave of strikes to protest austerity measures put into effect last month. They include a curtailment of automatic wage increases tied to rises in the cost of living. The unrest has presented Mr. Papandreou with the most serious internal challenge since his election in 1981 and re-election last June. It has led to defections of labor leaders from the Socialist Party's position and their expulsion from the party.

headline: Otis in Bid for Saxby
abstract: The Otis Elevator Company of the United States, which already owns 81.35 percent of Saxby, the French handling equipment company, has proposed making a public offer for the remaining shares, the Stockbrokers' Association said today. The association gave no details of the offer but said it was open until Jan. 27.

headline: Tennessee Bonds
abstract: The metropolitan government of Nashville and Davidson County, Tenn., is offering $163.5 million of general obligation bonds with yields ranging from 5 1/4 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 8 1/4 percent in 1995, 9.30 percent in 2005 and 9.40 percent in 2010 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. The bonds are rated Aa by Moody's and AA by Standard & Poor's.

headline: BELGIANS AND DUTCH ANGRY WITH REAGAN
abstract: Belgium and the Netherlands are angry that they were not among the nations invited by by President Reagan to a meeting for consultations before his summit talks with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and they called today for a special North Atlantic Treaty Organization Foreign Ministers' meeting.   It was the latest sign of dissatisfaction with Mr. Reagan's planned meeting of the seven major industrial democracies, which Administration officials intended as a display of unity.   The nations invited by Mr. Reagan to the meeting, scheduled in New York on Oct. 23-24, were Britain, France, West Germany, Canada, Italy and Japan. Mr. Reagan will be in New York at that time to attend observances marking the 40th anniversary of the founding of the United Nations.   On Tuesday, a spokesman for President Francois Mitterrand said Mr. Mitterrand was turning down Mr. Reagan's invitation. Mr. Mitterrand was widely believed to have been angered by Mr. Reagan's decision to announce the meeting and its date before the French leader had agreed to atttend.

headline: Indian Tax Crackdown
abstract: A crackdown on India's tax-dodging black economy today caught one of the country's top textile millionaires. Kapal Mehra, a prominent figure in Indian business circles, was remanded in custody until Friday on charges of avoiding duty of $1.3 million on goods bought from C. Itoh & Company of Japan in 1982 and 1983.

headline: Prices, Wages Spurt in China
abstract: China today announced a record increase in retail prices because of a relaxation of state controls, but said that wages were growing at a faster rate.   The State Statistical Bureau said that retail prices rose 7.7 percent in the first eight months of 1985 from a year earlier, with prices in big cities rising 11.1 percent.

headline: People
abstract: * Diane Flynn has been promoted to senior vice president at Young & Rubicam, New York.

headline: IN CRUMBLING ZANZIBAR, THE SPICE OF LIFE IS GONE
abstract: There was a time, Hashim Siddique remembers, when everything seemed possible here. Fortune seekers and Arab traders, fresh from white-hulled steamers and peeling wooden dhows, hurried down deeply shadowed streets to trade in gold and ivory, cloves and cinnamon and nutmeg.   ''I had a ship hawker's license,'' recalled Mr. Saddique, his chair creaking from age as he bent forward. ''I was allowed to go on board ships and sell my items - antique silver and carvings. I was dealing in coins also. With these antique things, you could go anywhere, to any country in the world and earn your grub.

headline: GENCORP PLANS STOCK BUYBACK
abstract: Gencorp Inc., which was once known as the General Tire and Rubber Company, said yesterday that it would ask its board to authorize the buyback of ''a significant'' portion of its stock, using some $700 million in pretax proceeds, principally from the sale of two television stations.   RKO General Inc., a division of Gencorp, has agreed to sell KHJ-TV, a Los Angeles independent television station, to the Westinghouse Electric Corporation for $310 million, Gencorp said.   RKO is also exploring the sale of WOR-TV, the New Jersey-based station that covers the New York market. That station, which Westinghouse is also interested in buying, could sell for $300 million to $400 million. The company has additional funds coming from its agreement last month to sell its stake in Frontier Holdings Inc., an airline holding company, to People Express for $300 million.

headline: CRAXI EXPECTED TO TRY TO FORM CABINET
abstract: Politically strengthened by a warm letter of conciliation from President Reagan, Italy's caretaker Prime Minister, Bettino Craxi, today seemed virtually certain of being asked to form a new government.   Politicians in the old Government's five-party coalition welcomed Mr. Reagan's letter expressing confidence in Mr. Craxi and in Italian-American friendship, seeing it as a way of ending the fierce polemics between Italy and the United States over the last week.   The arguments, as well as the fall of Mr. Craxi's Government, were brought about by Italy's decision to free a Palestinian leader accused by Washington of ''masterminding'' the hijacking of the Achille Lauro cruise ship.   After consulting with all the party leaders, the Italian President, Francesco Cossiga, was expected to announce his choice for a new government leader on Monday.

headline: Fidelity Group Sees Profitable Victory
abstract: Twenty years ago, William G. Simon set up a company, made up of California investors, to challenge RKO General Inc.'s license to operate station KHJ-TV in Los Angeles, on the ground that hometown owners could better manage a broadcast outlet than an absentee corporation.   Now, Mr. Simon, a 72-year-old lawyer and former head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's Los Angeles office, has given up that goal. But he and other shareholders of Fidelity Television Inc., the closely held company he heads, appear to have won a sweet victory all the same.

headline: Regency-Wilshire
abstract: The owners of the Beverly Wilshire Hotel, one of the city's best-known luxury hotels, have agreed to sell the 57-year-old establishment to Regency International Hotels for $125 million, the companies said. The sale is expected to close by Dec. 31. Regency International, based in Hong Kong, owns or manages a dozen resort properties around the world, including the Dorchester Hotel in London, the Regent Hotel in Hong Kong and the Mayfair Regency Hotel in New York.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: Burlington Northern Inc., Seattle, has appointed Christopher T. Bayley president and chief executive of the Glacier Park Co., which manages its U.S. real estate operations.    * Coast Federal Savings and Loan Association, Sarasota, Fla., has elected to its board Jack D. Cason, president of the Florida Coca-Cola Bottling Co.

headline: Business Leaders Urge Talks in South Africa
abstract: South African business leaders today urged negotiations between the Government and black leaders to prevent an intensification of violence.   At a news conference, speakers representing black and white industrial and commercial bodies said only a clear Government commitment to end apartheid would relieve domestic and international pressure.

headline: NOBEL PRIZE OUTCRY: PANEL SURPRISED
abstract: The room, quiet and green in tone, contains an oval wooden table, six upholstered chairs and a crystal chandelier. On the discreetly flowered walls are 69 small framed black and white photographs of the men and women who have won the Nobel Peace Prize since it was first awarded in 1901.   A visitor to the Nobel Institute here can enter the hallowed chamber where every year the five-member Nobel Prize Committee chooses the winner of the prestigious award.   It was here in the course of meetings this year that the select group of Norwegians decided to give the 1985 prize to International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War, an organization that joins American, Soviet and other doctors who have publicized the medical dangers of nuclear war.

headline: Advertising;   Forbes Will Rerun Ad Twitting Competitors
abstract: Forbes ran a five-column ad on the back page of the Oct. 30 issue of The New York Times that tweaked its competitors, Business Week and Fortune, for rewarding subscribers with expensive premiums. The ad, prepared by Doremus & Company, had an illustration of a grand Rolls-Royce under the headline ''What premiums will Fortune and Business Week resort to next?''

headline: PERES REPORTS FRENCH OFFER TO FLY SOVIET JEWS TO ISRAEL
abstract: Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel said today that France had offered to to help Jews emigrate from the Soviet Union by flying them directly to Israel if Moscow agreed to permit expanded emigration and such flights.   Mr. Peres disclosed the French offer at a news conference after a luncheon meeting this afternoon with President Francois Mitterrand, under whose Government relations between Israel and France have significantly improved.   Mr. Peres's decision to discuss the offer publicly at this time tended to support reports circulating in diplomatic circles that the Soviet Union had signaled that it might be prepared to countenance such flights - and increases in Jewish emigration - after the summit meeting in November between President Reagan and the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev.   Diplomats here and in Washington said that Moscow might also be prepared to permit an exchange of interest sections between the Soviet Union and Israel.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Altos Computer Systems, San Jose, Calif., said its board had authorized the repurchase of up to 2 million of the company's 14.6 million common shares outstanding.

headline: Agency Gets Thrift Proposal
abstract: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today it had received an application, as expected, from the thrift industry to establish an institution that would acquire the troubled assets of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation and liquidate them over time.   Under the proposal, the so-called Federal Savings and Loan Asset Management Association would sell $500 million in common stock to the F.S.L.I.C., and the new association would receive an equivalent amount of troubled assets.

headline: Benazir Bhutto Asks To Go to France
abstract: The opposition leader Benazir Bhutto asked to be freed from house detention today in order to travel to France and attend an inquest into the death of her younger brother, officials said.   Police officials said Miss Bhutto sent the request after receiving a summons from a French court.

headline: Geneva Rightist Party Gains No Council Seat
abstract: An attempt by the rightist political party Vigilance to gain a seat in the Geneva cantonal government has failed in an election marked by a higher-than-usual turnout.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: Subduing the Dollar Will the attack on the dollar, mounted a month ago by the Group of Five industrial nations, bring down the currency's value enough to stimulate exports and ease the Congressional pressure for protectionism? So far, that achievement is not in sight. At best, the steps taken amount to a quick and temporary fix, says Edward Yardeni, chief economist for Prudential-Bache Securities Inc.   True, the currency is down about 18 percent, on a trade weighted basis, from its February peak, with most of the slide coming since Sept. 22, when the United States, Japan, France, Britain and West Germany announced they would intervene by selling dollars in international markets to lower the currency's value.   And the group's agreement did slow Congress's drive for protectionist legislation - a delay that ''temporarily reduced the downside risks for the economy,'' said Mr. Yardeni. Like many economists, he fears that fallout from such laws - inflation and retaliation on the part of trading partners, for example - could produce an economic slowdown in the United States.

headline: NOBEL PEACE PRIZE GIVEN TO DOCTORS OPPOSED TO WAR
abstract: The 1985 Nobel Peace Prize was awarded today to the International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War, a five-year-old Boston-based group that was jointly founded by American and Soviet doctors.   The physicians group has a membership of 135,000 people in 41 countries. One of its co-founders, Dr. Yevgeny I. Chazov, has been the personal physician of the top Soviet leadership and a member of the Communist Party Central Committee since 1982. He has also been a Deputy Minister of Health since 1968.   After learning of the award today, Dr. Bernard Lown, the American co-founder of the group, immediately urged President Reagan to stop all nuclear testing.

headline: Careers;   Need Seen For Quake Engineers
abstract: THE devastating earthquake in Mexico and recent tremors in the New York-New Jersey area have put a new emphasis on an old subject - earthquake engineering.   Dr. Jacobo Bielak, a professor of civil engineering at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh who specializes in earthquakes, says the disaster in Mexico shows the need for more engineers in the specialty.   Earthquakes have been studied for generations but the engineering aspects of buildings, highways and other structures that might be affected have constituted a specialty for perhaps only 30 years.   ''It really took off as a profession in the 1950's,'' Dr. Bielak said last week. ''There is much more to it than developing and following building codes. We use computers to analyze. When the public looks at earthquake engineering it does not appear to be a high-tech industry but it is.''

headline: Latin Peace Effort Halted, Official Says
abstract: The Contadora group has suspended negotiations on a peace agreement for Central America for five months at Nicaragua's request, Colombia's Foreign Minister, Augusto Ramirez Ocampo, said today.   Nicaragua officially proposed the suspension on the grounds that new Governments that take office in Guatemala and Honduras in January and in Costa Rica in April could change policy toward the talks, Mr. Ramirez said at a meeting of the General Assembly of the Organization of American States.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    * AMCA Overseas Finance Corp. is issuing 150 million marks of 7 3/8 percent, seven-year Eurobonds at 99 1/2 through underwriters led by Deutsche Bank A.G.    * Chrysler Financial Corp. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for up to $1 billion of debt securities through Salomon Brothers.    * Colt Industries has filed for up to $300 million of debt securities.    * Student Loan Marketing Association is issuing 20 billion yen of 8 percent dual currency Eurobonds due 1995 at 101 1/2 through Yamaichi International (Europe) Ltd. The bonds will be redeemable in U.S. dollars at a rate of 181 yen to the dollar. Common Stock

headline: U.S. AND ISRAEL FAIL TO ISSUE STATEMENT ON SPY CASE
abstract: A last-minute hitch late Thursday night prevented American investigators and Israeli officials from issuing a joint communique effectively closing the Washington spy scandal case and expressing the United States' full satisfaction with Israeli cooperation, senior Israeli Government sources said today.   The communique was to have been issued at the close of six days of questioning by a team of American law enforcement and State Department officials of Israeli diplomats and intelligence officers involved in Washington with Jonathon J. Pollard, a United States Navy intelligence analyst accused of spying for Israel.      'Something Went Wrong'    However, after 13 hours of negotiation over a proposed joint statement that would have been released in Washington Thursday night, the two sides failed to reach a mutually satisfactory understanding, the sources said. Most of the American team, which was led by State Department legal adviser, Abraham D. Sofaer, was reported to have left early Friday morning, without the anticipated joint statement.

headline: Avon Debt Rating Cut
abstract: The rating on Avon Products Inc. senior long-term debt and that of its Avon Capital and Avon International Finance subsidiaries has been lowered to A-2 from A-1, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday. About $410 million of debt securities are affected.

headline: RUSSIANS IN AFGHANISTAN: CHANGES IN TACTICS
abstract: The continued, elusive resistance of the rebels in Afghanistan, mounting casualties and poor performance by conscripts are forcing the Soviet Union to review and revise its tactics and command system in Afghanistan, according to United States and British intelligence sources familiar with the war.   Superficially the war, which will enter its sixth year in December, has gone well for the Russians. They hold the cities and principal towns. Seven major air bases, all within a bomber's flight of the Persian Gulf, have been expanded. Afghanistan's Government in Kabul is amenable to Soviet direction.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: More Volatile Dow Expected
abstract: THE inclusion yesterday of two new components - the Philip Morris Companies and the McDonald's Corporation - in the Dow Jones industrial average will make this closely watched indicator of stock prices slightly more volatile, according to market experts.   Spurred by a decline in interest rates, the index of 30 industrials rose 6.84 points yesterday, to a new closing high of 1,375.57. The former record of 1,369.29 was set just two weeks ago.   The inclusion of the two new companies in the index of 30 companies is the result of the removal of two others. The General Foods Corporation was dropped because of its acquisition by Philip Morris, the nation's largest cigarette maker and a leading producer of beer and soft drinks. McDonald's, the dominant force in the fast-food industry, was substituted for American Brands Inc., in part to avoid overweighting the Dow with tobacco-oriented companies. These moves are intended to reflect more accurately price trends in the broader stock market.

headline: NEW TAKEOVER BILL STIRS LIVELY DEBATE
abstract: The Cuomo administration's proposed legislation to curb hostile corporate takeovers could have a major chilling effect on takeover activity in New York State, according to lawyers and investment bankers who specialize in mergers and acquisitions.   In interviews, some takeover experts also said the proposed measure, announced last week, might be unconstitutional. They said companies would almost surely challenge it in court or try to circumvent it.   While some investment professionals said the new proposal marks an improvement over an earlier bill vetoed by Governor Cuomo last summer, others complained that it would still restrict freedom of the marketplace and thus harm shareholders.

headline: London Stock Changes Set
abstract: The London Stock Exchange said today that it would allow outsiders such as banks to own outright member firms from March as part of its program to modernize centuries-old trading systems.   The move to allow non-member firms to take over wholesale and retail sales of stocks precedes another major change in the stock exchange due in October when fixed commission rates on share deals regulated by the exchange will be abolished.

headline: F.D.I.C. Delay on Moves
abstract: Regulatory officials expect the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to approve a six-month delay today of a rule requiring that the agency disclose disciplinary actions that it takes against banks.

headline: Phillips Sells Some Assets
abstract: The Phillips Petroleum Company, continuing its efforts to pare its debt, said yesterday that it had sold or agreed to sell properties worth $500 million.   The company said that the agreements bring its assets sales to more than $1 billion for the year.

headline: SHIP HIJACKER TO BE TRIED AS MINOR
abstract: One of four Palestinians accused of hijacking the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro will have to be tried separately by a juvenile court because it has been learned he is 17 years old, legal officials said today.   A six-year, seven-month sentence given the youth this week on hijacking-related weapons charges will also have to be annulled, the officials said.

headline: 2 Bombs Go Off in Chile
abstract: Two bombs exploded here today, causing panic but no casualties, shortly before President Augusto Pinochet visited this copper mining community, the police said.

headline: Advertising;   Advertising to Women Quits Second Account
abstract: Advertising to Women, which announced last Thursday that it had resigned the Charles of the Ritz account, made a similar announcement Friday concerning the Wella Corporation. And the reason the agency gave was the same: It wanted to free itself for advertising assignments of an entrepreneurial nature that would let it share in the profits from sales.

headline: TUNISIAN DISSATISFIED WITH U.S. STAND ON ATTACK
abstract: The Foreign Minister of Tunisia said today that his country was not satisfied with the American response to a proposed draft resolution in the Security Council condemning Israel's bombing of the Palestine Liberation Organization headquarters.   The official, Beji Caid Essebsi, said before the council met this afternoon that the Tunisians and the Americans were not in agreement on the resolution, which in its current form calls for a condemnation of Israeli aggression.   ''Up to now, we are still discussing preliminary matters,'' Mr. Essebsi said. ''But up to now, the Tunisians are not satisfied with the American response.'' Tunisia, considered friendly to the United States, was encouraged by the Reagan Administration to give the P.L.O. sanctuary after the Palestinians were forced out of Beirut.

headline: Genex Layoffs
abstract: The Genex Corporation, suffering from the loss of a contract to its biggest customer, said it would lay off about 40 percent of the 146 employees at its Rockville, Md., headquarters and that several top executives, including its president and chief operating officer, V. M. Esposito, had resigned. Genex has been reeling from the loss of its contract with G. D. Searle & Company to provide a key ingredient for Searle's artificial sweetener, aspartame. The contract with Searle represented 88 percent of Genex's revenues, and Genex had shut down its Paducah, Ky., plant, laying off the 70 workers there.

headline: Mitel Picks Leader And Shifts Officers
abstract: The Mitel Corporation, a major Canadian maker of telecommunications equipment that has been experiencing severe financial difficulties, has announced sweeping changes in its top management.   The company, which is based in Kanata, Ontario, said that Anthony Griffiths, a 55-year-old financial and management consultant, had been named president and chief executive officer.   Mr. Griffiths, whose appointment is effective immediately, succeeds Terrence Matthews. Mitel said that Mr. Matthews, 42, will become chairman, replacing Michael C. J. Cowpland. Mr. Cowpland, a co-founder of Mitel, will continue with the company as a member of the board. Mitel said he would provide ''specific direction to the development of strategic technologies.''

headline: No Comment on Talks
abstract: The American Embassy and Israeli Government spokesmen refused today to give any details on the interviews of Israelis in the Pollard case, the nature of the discussions or the Israeli individuals involved.
