Israeli Government sources said Israeli intelligence has exerted heavy pressure to insure that all discussions between the Israelis and the Americans be kept secret, since they touch on the highly sensitive fabric of Israel's worldwide intelligence-gathering.

headline: BRITISH TIME OF VIOLENCE
abstract: Early this year, the Princess of Wales ventured from her apartment in Kensington Palace to dedicate a youth center in a housing project in Tottenham, a racially mixed working-class area of north London.      Just before dawn on   Monday, scores of police officers in riot gear smashed their way into that same youth center, hoping to find some of the rioters responsible for the worst inner-city disorders Britain has seen.   The shattering of the center's windows was a relatively minor incident in a night of violence in which 54 constables were taken to hospital emergency rooms and one was brutally knifed to death. But it showed how deeply the cancer of racial suspicion has eaten into a society that is still reluctant to come to grips with the fact that it is now permanently multiracial.

headline: Thrift Ruling Appealed
abstract: A court order preventing the identification of thrift institutions that lent money to bankrupt real estate partnerships established by the Equity Programs Investment Corporation has been appealed by The New York Times and The Washington Post. Last week a bankruptcy judge in Alexandria, Va., refused to rescind his order sealing financial information submitted by the bankrupt partnerships, because attorneys representing them had said the disclosure could trigger runs among their depositors. Lawyers for the newspapers said the order violates provisions of the bankruptcy code permitting public access to court documents, and also violates First Amendment guarantees of freedom of the press.

headline: Taiwan Mine Cave-In Kills 2
abstract: Two miners were killed today and 11 injured in a cave-in at a coal mine about 12 miles north of Taipei, the police said. They said the accident occurred at the Fu Chi coal mine at Chitu when a mine car ran out of control and hit steel arch supports, causing a cave-in and killing a 50-year-old worker. Ong Chang-chun, vice president of Fu Chi, said a second worker died on his way to a hospital.

headline: AID SEEN FOR BANK IN CANADA
abstract: Canada's big six banks are quietly aiding the Mercantile Bank of Canada, in an effort to avoid a repeat of the federal Government's forced closings of two small Alberta banks last month.   The result could be the merger of Canada's eighth-largest bank with another bank, or the apportioning of its assets among a group of banks, analysts suggest. Another possibility would be to merge the bank with a trust or insurance company, as would be possible if proposed changes in Canada's financial laws take effect.

headline: SEARS TRADE UNIT SHIFTS FOCUS
abstract: When Sears, Roebuck & Company set up Sears World Trade more than three years ago, officials at the new trading subsidiary boasted that they would go so far as to help Indonesia tap its timber resources and help China develop its pulp industry.   But now, after continual losses, Sears World Trade Inc. has sharply narrowed its grand design in order to focus on Sears' traditional strong point - consumer goods.   The trading operation, which is based here, is importing running shoes, venetian blinds, wooden tables, stereo equipment and computer peripherals. These items are not for Sears' own stores but instead go to other companies that need a middleman to help them with the intricacies of importing, exporting and locating products overseas.   Sears World Trade also is shipping Japanese-made microwave ovens to Britain. And in a pilot project, it is importing food - tuna from Thailand and tomato paste from Portugal. It is shifting away from grand projects, toward consumer goods.

headline: CAPE TOWN DAY: JUST A SAMPLE OF A NATION'S PAIN
abstract: The armored truck drew to a halt in the midst of the crowd and the men inside opened fire with pump-action shotguns on youths who had thrown rocks at them.   Seven minutes later, when the truck drove on, its human cargo had been increased by one - a 19-year-old student wounded in the leg and chest by birdshot had been placed aboard by the uniformed whites. And the hostility and bitterness of the people who saw the shooting, which occurred Wednesday, had been raised by a corresponding notch in the scale of South Africa's racial and other animosities.   ''Give me back my son,'' the mother of the wounded youth, identified by friends as Faizel Jinnah, pleaded of the men in the truck.

headline: IT'S GERMANY'S TURN TO TAKE THE LEAD
abstract: WEST GERMANY must take a more active role in expanding the global economy. Confronted with slower growth in the United States, and continued unwillingness on the part of Japan and other European nations to take up the slack, the world is waiting for Bonn to adopt more stimulative economic policies.   But is West Germany prepared to adopt more expansive policies on behalf of the worldwide recovery? The signals from Germany's ruling conservative coalition are decidedly mixed. Since last spring, Finance Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg has been sending the same message: ''The risks of such action would be likely to outweigh the prospective benefits.'' Apparently, Bonn will ignore the calls for more expansive economic policies and concentrate on budget-cutting and price stability.

headline: SPECIAL THRIFT FUND IS URGED
abstract: The chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board today proposed raising $8.5 billion from the savings and loan industry to shore up the beleaguered thrift institution insurance fund.   Testifying before a House Banking subcommittee, the bank board chairman, Edwin J. Gray, warned of the pressing need to bolster the resources of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation in order to provide assistance to the large number of ailing thrift institutions.   During three hours of testimony, Mr. Gray said the insurance fund now had only $3.2 billion in usable assets to handle future obligations, and could dip to as low as $1.5 billion in six months if no action was taken.      Predictions of Failures    When pressed to estimate the magnitude of the problem, Mr. Gray predicted that about 300 thrift institutions would eventually fail and that the insurance fund could be required to cover losses of between $14 billion and $15 billion ''over time.'' He said about 900 thrift units are classified as problem institutions.

headline: PRETORIA RELEASES 5 FROM DETENTION
abstract: South African authorities have freed from detention the only four whites held under the state of emergency that was declared almost four months ago, the parents of one of those released said tonight.   A fifth detainee, Ram Salojee, who is of Indian descent, was also said to have been freed.   The motive for the release remained unclear. According to figures published last week, more than 1,100 persons, the bulk of them black, are still being held under the emergency decree, now in force in 38 magisterial districts, while 392 out of 1,633 people held apart from the provisions of the emergency under the nation's wide-ranging security legislation are still in detention.

headline: CITIBANK SAYS DATA STOLEN
abstract: Four former Citibank employees and the brokerage firm of Bear, Stearns & Company have been charged by Citibank with having stolen proprietary information and trade secrets from the bank.   The action was filed in New York State Supreme Court on Dec. 18.

headline: DUARTE SAYS NICARGUA HELPS TERRORISTS
abstract: President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador said today that Nicaragua was serving as a ''sanctuary'' for a new stage of terrorism under way in his country.   Accompanied by his 35-year-old daughter, who was held captive for 44 days by Salvadoran guerrillas, Mr. Duarte met this morning with President Reagan at the White House.   He later delivered an emotional speech to the National Press Club, in which he stressed that there was a link between Nicaragua's Marxist Government and terrorist activities in El Salvador.   ''In Central America, in my own country,'' he said, ''countless persons from all walks of life, and in the case of my family, my daughter, Ines Guadalupe, would not have been victims of the merciless violence of the terrorists if terrorists did not have the support, direction, approval and timely protection of the terrorist dictatorship in Nicaragua.''

headline: U.S.-Soviet Agreement On Terror Pact Reported
abstract: The United States and the Soviet Union have agreed for the first time on a comprehensive resolution condemning the taking of hostages, high-level diplomatic sources said today.   The resolution calls for the release of all hostages and urges nations to prosecute and punish offenders, sources said.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: FIGHTING NATURAL AND MAN-MADE LAWS
abstract: NOT every fish is easily cultivated. Cod and haddock are too big and voracious to be reared economically. Sturgeon require fresh water at some parts of their life, salt water at others. Immature lobsters have the inconvenient habit of eating each other. And surf clams are highly vulnerable to predators on the bay bottom.

headline: THE BIG MAC GOES TO MEXICO
abstract: The McDonald's Big Mac came to Mexico this week, causing traffic jams as hundreds of Mexicans lined up to buy hamburgers, but with chili sauce instead of ketchup.   Police were on hand to manage traffic, and customers were lined up 15 deep at the counter and waiting upward of an hour outside on the first day of business for the first McDonald's in Mexico.   More than three years of planning went into this inaugural, including the creation of a supply system based entirely in Mexico that provides everything from russet potatoes for the french fries to chocolate chip cookies.   This opening comes at a time when the granddaddy of fast-food chains has so insinuated itself into the American landscape that it is increasingly looking to other countries for growth.

headline: FOR NIGERIAN DOCTORS, THE HEALING IS THE EASY PART
abstract: Dodging a battered yellow bus hurtling up Obalende Road past his clinic, Dr. Doyin Okupe hurried across the stretch of pavement, past women crouched in the shadow of a concrete underpass selling oranges.   He rushed down a small passageway, sending tiny lizards scurrying, and bounded up two flights of crumbling cement stairs, their banisters careening at odd angles where the masonry was giving way.   ''Our operating room is still not with the main clinic,'' the 33-year-old physician said. Along a narrow hallway, its walls painted white, doors opened into a small ward of beds here, into a cramped operating room there. He looked into a ward with two beds.

headline: Advertising;   Reaching The Rich in Magazine
abstract: THE frequent attempts and frequent failures of magazine publishers to come up with a product that will appeal to the wealthy is almost laughable. Especially when those products look so much alike - the super-glossy heavy stock paper and the articles chosen to attract the right kind of free-spending advertisers. Travel. Art. Arty collectibles. Fine cars. Cover the logotypes and you wouldn't know which magazine you were reading.   Except for the magazines that are doing the job right.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: Allegheny and Western Energy Corp., Charleston, W.Va., an oil and gas company, has named Anthony Altmann president and chief executive officer.

headline: Coast Transit Bond Yields Set
abstract: The San Francisco Bay Area Rapid Transit District, known as BART, is offering $145 million of sales tax revenue bonds through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.   Investors are offered yields ranging from 6 3/4 percent for bonds due in 1990 to 7.80 percent in 1995 and 8.20 percent in 1997.

headline: BOEING GETS $3.1 BILLION UNITED ORDER
abstract: United Airlines said today that it had ordered as many as 116 new planes, worth about $3.1 billion, from the Boeing Company. The agreement, involving the nation's largest airline and largest commercial aircraft manufacturer, was said by Boeing to be the largest single order in aviation history.   United said it plans to purchase up to 110 737-300 twinjets, a small plane with 122 seats used mainly for shorter flights, and up to six long-range 747-200B jumbo jets, which it will use on the new Pacific routes it is purchasing from Pan American World Airways. The Department of Transportation gave final approval today for that purchase.

headline: MALTESE AGREE ON A HARD ISSUE, NOT ON A SOFT DRINK
abstract: On this sunny speck of an island in the Mediterranean, the color a Maltese wears and the beverage he drinks betray more than esthetic preferences: they are political statements.   Supporters of the ruling socialist Labor Party wear red; members of the conservative opposition Nationalist Party wear blue. Labor Party members drink Coca Cola; Nationalist Party people sip Pepsi.   Most towns and villages - no matter how small - have two ceremonial bands: Labor and Nationalist.

headline: CIGARETTE TAX RISE REJECTED
abstract: The Senate voted, 66 to 30, today against raising the cigarette tax to 24 cents a pack from 16 cents.   The vote came as the Senate began debate on a package of spending cuts and revenue increases that would bring total savings of $85 billion over three years. That would be a major portion of the $276 billion, three-year deficit reduction plan approved in this year's Congressional budget resolution. Debate is expected to continue Thursday and Friday.

headline: DIPLOMATS CITE GROWING SIGNS OF CEAUSESCU ILLNESS
abstract: President Nicolae Ceausescu's frail appearance in recent months and signs that official photographs of him have been altered have reinforced speculation that he is seriously ill, according to Western diplomats and others here.   They say Mr. Ceausescu, Rumania's leader for the last 20 years, may be grooming a member of his immediate family to succeed him.   The diplomats say they have been struck by a marked deterioration in Mr. Ceausescu's appearance, noting that his face has become thin and worn and that he looks increasingly frail.

headline: S.E.C. Asks Position Limits
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission asked five stock exchanges and the National Association of Securites Dealers today to consider voluntarily ''telescoping'' their existing limits on the number of stock index option contracts that can be held by a single trader as the contracts near their expiration.   The agency said a voluntary agreement to gradually lower position limits ''might serve to reduce some of the price volatility in the stock market at or near the expiration of an index without unduly inhibiting the use of arbitrage trading strategies.''

headline: British Committee Backs Tunnel Plan for Channel
abstract: Members of Parliament recommended tonight that Britain and France choose a tunnel rather than a bridge to link their countries across the English Channel.   Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and President Francois Mitterrand are due to sign a treaty early next year realizing a centuries-old dream of connecting Britain to the Continent over the 21-mile waterway.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

headline: BLAST IN DURBAN WOUNDS 8 PEOPLE
abstract: A bomb exploded today at a post office in Durban, wounding eight people, three of them children.   The explosion, which the police said was caused by a limpet mine, shattered the post office's windows and caused part of its exterior wall to collapse. Six people, including the children, were hit by flying glass as they sat in their car.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: W.R. Grace & Co. has appointed Harvey G. Knell chairman and Sean F. Lee president and chief executive officer of Grace Home Centers West.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

headline: Taiwan Rewards 2 Who Stole Chinese Boat and Weapons
abstract: A doctor and a soldier who commandeered a Chinese fishing boat and forced the crew to sail to Taiwan at gunpoint have been granted political asylum by the Nationalist Government, a spokesman said today.   The pair crossed the narrow Taiwan Strait separating the Nationalist island from the China mainland after kidnapping the four crew members of the boat Aug. 18, a military spokesman said.

headline: IN MICRONESIA, A GNAWING DOUBT AMID THE PALMS
abstract: A few years back the Municipal Assembly banned all alcohol sales on this craggy island in the western Pacific.   Prohibition has worked about as well as it did in the United States 60 years ago. Now people break the law to drink.   Moen's police chief decided he would not even pretend to enforce the rules. His defiance so upset Mayor Fichita Bossy that he opened his own jail for liquor violators. Unfortunately for the Mayor, Truk state officials closed down his operation for sanitation-code infractions.

headline: XEROX RESHAPES CRUM & FORSTER
abstract: The Xerox Corporation took steps yesterday to reposition its Crum & Forster insurance subsidiary, a move that will have an adverse impact of $160 million after taxes on third-quarter earnings.   Xerox last year earned $81.3 million in the third quarter, and analysts said the charge for the insurance moves would result in a loss for the third quarter this year.   Still, analysts described the move positively, as wiping the slate clean and getting the unit's problems resolved. It does mean, however, a major drop in this year's earnings, raising the issue of a cut in the dividend, analysts said. But Xerox noted that the quarterly payout of 75 cents was declared on Monday, with knowledge of the insurance moves it announced yesterday.

headline: Technology Exports to China
abstract: The Western allies and Japan have agreed to a major relaxation of the rules under which they export high-technology products to China. Such sales totaled $6 billion in the year ended Sept. 30, up from $1 billion in the fiscal year 1984.   The move to expand and expedite exports will add new categories of goods eligible for transfer to the Chinese, who have long chafed under rules that have been applied without distinction to Eastern Europe, the Soviet Union and China.

headline: BHOPAL IS IN MIDST OF GRIM RECOVERY A YEAR AFTER LEAK
abstract: One year after a poison gas leak at the Union Carbide factory here, a major relief effort is reaching thousands of people while thousands more continue to have trouble breathing and working.   Misery and rehabilitation can be seen side by side in the crowded and dusty slum abutting the plant, where death was almost instantaneous for hundreds of people when poison gas leaked from a storage tank late in the night of Dec. 2, 1984, and spread through the city in the early hours of Dec. 3.   In interviews this week, slum-dwellers said that their health had not improved and that they feared they would not be able to earn a living. Every day, 3,000 people receive treatment from 20 medical dispensaries that have been built in this central Indian city in the year since the leak killed at least 2,000 people and injured 200,000 others.      Mud Shanties and New Roads    The crumbling shanties of mud and splintering wooden slats are still there, but so are newly built drainage systems, roads and a nearby hospital with 30 beds and examination rooms.

headline: Japan Banks Cut Rate
abstract: Japan's long-term credit bank and trust banks said today that they have decided to lower the long-term prime lending rate to 7.2 percent, from 7.5 percent, effective Saturday.

headline: 6 YEARS OF AFGHAN WAR: RUSSIANS AND FOES MIRED
abstract: Six years to the day after Soviet forces swept into Afghanistan, more than 100,000 Soviet soldiers and airmen confront a stubborn and elusive guerrilla army in a war with no end in sight.   The fighting has fallen into a pattern and the war is deadlocked, according to rebel commanders and fighters interviewed in Afghanistan in five and a half months of travel through the country with rebel convoys. The Soviet-backed leaders of Afghanistan have not permitted visits by Western reporters to the Government side of the front.   The Russians have said repeatedly that they will negotiate with the existing Communist Government in Kabul on a withdrawal of Soviet troops only after Western and other aid to the rebels is cut off.   Rebel leaders are unanimous in saying that the Russians, estimated at 118,000 troops, must withdraw to the last man and tank and that they will not accept any formula that would keep the Communist Government in place. The rebels say that if any attempt is made to impose a diplomatic solution on them, they will fight on alone. They say they believe a long struggle lies ahead.

headline: LAND MINE KILLS 6 IN SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: The South African Army reported tonight that six people were killed and five people seriously wounded when a light truck set off a land mine close to the border with Zimbabwe.   An army spokesman in Pretoria said those killed were members of two families, including a mother and two children. The incident occurred at about 6:50 P.M. at the Chatsworth game farm, about 19 miles from the border town of Messina.   The incident brings to seven the number of land-mine explosions in less than three weeks near Messina. A black farm laborer was killed and six people, four of them soldiers, were wounded in explosions late last month. A soldier was slightly wounded on Thursday when an army troop carrier set off a land mine during security operations being carried out because of the series of explosions.

headline: Sale of Phillips Unit
abstract: Freeport-McMoran Inc. said it had agreed to buy the Phillips Petroleum Company's Geysers Geothermal unit and other geothermal properties for $215 million. Freeport-McMoran said Friday that the acquisition strengthens its commitment to the natural resources industry. Geysers Geothermal produces geothermal steam air for electric power generation.

headline: 2 Die in Shootings in India
abstract: Gunmen killed two people in separate attacks in Punjab State, where an increase in Sikh violence has caused Indian authorities to increase security, an Indian new agency reported today.

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN EDUCATIONAL TOYS;  A POST-SPUTNIK SCIENCE REVIVAL
abstract: TIME was when children thought that building a radio from a kit or staring at the stars through a telescope was the height of fun. But in the last two decades, interest in science toys waned badly. ''Things like computers and video games pretty much blitzed it,'' said Pete Fox, sales manager at Tedco Inc., a maker of toy gyroscopes and prisms.

headline: UNITED NATIONS CALENDAR
abstract: NINTH DAY OF DEBATE - The Foreign Ministers of Libya and Iran are scheduled to speak during the ninth day of debate in the General Assembly this morning. Other nations scheduled to speak include Laos, Honduras, Ghana, Morocco, Guatemala and Barbados.   AROUND AFRICA - After meeting for more than three hours Wednesday to consider a resolution condemning Monday's raid by Israel on the Palestine Liberation Organizaton headquarters in Tunisia, the Security Council moves to the other end of Africa this morning. The Council will take up a request by Angola for condemnation of a South African raid on its territory earlier this week, and then probably conclude its consideration of the Tunisian resolution in the afternoon. A request by India, representing the nations espousing nonalignment, for a meeting on the general situation in the Middle East, is still pending.

headline: MILITARY CONTRACTS
abstract: The Defense Department ended its fiscal year today by awarding 132 contracts worth almost $1.1 billion, including $104 million it would have lost had it not been obligated. Most of the awards were for fairly small amounts and less than 10 percent of the money obligated would have actually lapsed had it not been dispensed. The biggest single contract announced today was an Army contract for $70. million, which went to the Lycoming division of the Avco Corporation for 143 gas turbine engines.

headline: POPE BIDS U.N. ACT ON THE DEBT CRISIS
abstract: Pope John Paul II today described the global debt crisis as an ''ethical and humanitarian'' issue and called on the United Nations to play a ''front line'' role in the effort to find solutions.   In a strongly worded message read to the General Assembly by the Vatican Secretary of State, Agostino Cardinal Casaroli, the Pope singled out the indebtedness problem for attention.   The problem, he said, has brought ''whole countries to the brink of breakdown.''   Neither debtor nor creditor nations ''have anything to gain from the development of situations of despair that would be uncontrollable'' because of the debt, he added.

headline: BAKER'S DEBT PLAN GETS LATIN SCRUTINY
abstract: Latin America's leading debtor nations are expected to renew their campaign for lower interest payments when they meet Monday in Montevideo, Uruguay, to analyze the Baker Plan.   According to officials involved in preparing the conference, the consensus in the region is that the Reagan Administration's new initiative to ease the three-year-old debt crisis is ''positive but insufficient.''   They said foreign ministers and finance ministers from the 11-nation Cartagena Group would therefore ''build on'' proposals made by Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d at the October meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank in Seoul, South Korea.   The Baker Plan calls for structural economic adjustments by 15 heavily indebted nations, including 10 in Latin America, in exchange for $9 billion in extra loans from the World Bank and $20 billion in ''new money'' from commercial banks over three years.

headline: Mice Leap to Death On the Golan Heights
abstract: Hundreds of field mice are killing themselves by jumping from cliffs on the Golan Heights in what Israeli scientists say is the rodents' instinctive way of solving an overpopulation problem.   Scientists said they had observed mass jumps into two streams and counted the remains of 150 mice at the bottom of one cliff. They estimate some 250 million mice inhabit the sparsely populated Israeli-Syrian cease-fire line.

headline: TERRORISM: A DEADLY YEAR
abstract: The attacks on the Rome and Vienna airports yesterday were among a total of about 690 terrorist attacks so far this year, according to State Department figures. Here are some of the major terrorist attacks this year: March 8 - Car bomb explodes outside an apartment building in Beirut, killing 80 people. Reports in Washington say later that the bombing was the work of people who had been hired by a Lebanese counterterrorist team that had been working with the C.I.A. June 14 - Trans World Airlines Flight 847, carrying 145 passengers and 8 crew members, is commandeered by Shiite Moslem hijackers after it takes off from Athens. It is forced to fly to Beirut after several flights across the Mediterranean. One passenger, an American Navy diver, is slain. The rest of the captives are released in stages, with the last group, all Americans, freed June 30.

headline: BOGATA REBELS KILL 2 ON BUS
abstract: Leftist guerrillas hurled grenades and fired into an army bus in Bogota early today, killing two soldiers and wounding eight others, witnesses said. A joint command of several guerrilla groups took responsibilty for the attack in calls to local radio stations, saying the raid was in response to the killing two weeks ago of a rebel political chief.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Coastal Savings Bank, Portland, Me., said it received an unsolicited offer from Norstar Bancorp to acquire all of its common stock outstanding for $30 a share, or a total of about $29 million.    * First Union Corp., Charlotte, N.C., and Atlantic Bancorp said the Federal Reserve Board has approved the acquisition of Atlantic by First Union.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt    * Continental Information Systems Corp. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $25 million of 20-year convertible subordinated debentures through Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Common Stock    * Numerica Financial Corp. has filed for a proposed offering of one million common shares through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.    * United States Video Vending Corp., Winooski, Vt., has filed for an initial public offering of one million units through L. C. Wegard & Co. Each unit consist of two common shares and two warrants.

headline: De Havilland Sale Reported
abstract: The Canadian Government will announce today that it will sell the state-owned de Havilland Aircraft of Canada Ltd. to the Boeing Company, the world's largest commercial aircraft manufacturer, Canadian Government sources said yesterday. The Government is expected to announce, in a news conference in Ottawa this afternoon, that it will sell the company for around $200 million (Canadian).

headline: KELLY'S ESMARK CORPS RE-ENLISTS FOR BEATRICE
abstract: By all accounts, the top executives at Esmark Inc. before it was bought by Beatrice last year formed a formidable management corps, remarkable both for their business success and their operating style.   Now, Donald P. Kelly is aiming to harness that talent and energy again when he takes the helm of the Beatrice Companies early next year, and reassembles the team he had in place when he was chairman of Esmark.   ''It's an all-pro lineup, a winning ball team with good esprit de corps,'' said Roger W. Spencer, an analyst with Paine Webber Inc. ''There was an unusual camaraderie among the top Esmark people that was sort of like Camelot.''   The 63-year-old Mr. Kelly had three top lieutenants at Esmark.

headline: EXPERTS ASSAIL PLAN FOR F.H.A.
abstract: Economists, mortgage bankers and other housing industry analysts yesterday sharply criticized the Reagan Administration's plan to sell the Federal Housing Administration to private bidders by the end of 1989.   ''If you're going to sell the F.H.A., you're effectively selling the American homebuyer down the river,'' said Warren Lasko, executive vice president of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America.   Created by the National Housing Act of 1934 to combat the effects of the Depression, the F.H.A. has provided mortgage insurance to more than 51 million homeowners, enabling many to receive mortgages they otherwise would not have been able to obtain. The agency made a profit of $9.4 million last year.

headline: Third World's Debt Burden
abstract: IF the upsurge of confidence in the securities markets, founded on a belief in the stability of the American and world economy, is to be validated, the greatest threat to the financial system still needs to be solved. That threat remains the huge and still growing debt crisis confronting the developing countries and banks in the United States and elsewhere in the industrial world.   The World Bank has raised its estimate of the total external liabilities of the developing countries to $920 billion, from $895 billion, as of the end of 1984. Of that $920 billion total, $630 billion is owed to private banks.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    * Circle K Corp. is offering $125 million of 12 3/4 percent senior subordinated debentures due 1997 at a price of 99 1/2 through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.    * Fairfield Communities Inc. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $40 million of senior subordinated notes due 1992 through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.    * Lehigh Valley Industries Inc. is offering $35 million of 14 7/8 percent subordinated debentures due 1995 at a price of 98.856 to yield 15.10 percent through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. Proceeds from the sale will be used to finance its acquisition of Nico Inc.    * Montreal is issuing $60 million (Canadian) of 11 percent, 10-year Eurobonds at a price of 100 through underwriters led by STE Generale de Banque.    * Scott Paper Co. is issuing 217 million Swiss francs of 5 3/8 percent, 15-year bonds at a price of 100 through Swiss Bank Corp.    * Tenneco Corp. is issuing $100 million of 10 percent, 4-year Eurobonds at par, and $100 million of 11 percent, 10-year Eurobonds at 100 1/2, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley International. Common Stock    * Birmingham Steel Corp. has filed for an initial public offering of 2 million common shares.

headline: U.N. HIGH COMMISSIONER JOB: THE RACE IS ON
abstract: At the height of the General Assembly, when the flesh-pressing and maneuvering in the corridors was broken only by marathon speeches, the most active diplomats were not lobbying for resolutions on disarmament or apartheid. They were looking for a job. The job being sought is the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, and the campaign to fill that post has brought out a level of politicking not seen at the United Nations since the last time the organization elected a Secretary General.   Campaigning by the five leading candidates - a Dutchman, an Egyptian, a Norwegian, a Swede and a Swiss - has become so intense that even those accustomed to such lobbying are surprised.

headline: U.S. Experts in Vietnam To Excavate Crash Site
abstract: A team of American experts and a plane filled with heavy equipment arrived in Hanoi today to begin the first joint excavation of an American warplane crash site in Vietnam.   With hundreds of people watching, the American team drove a 21,000-pound excavator along a narrow dirt road to the crash site at Yen Thuong village, 9 miles north of Hanoi, where they hope to uncover the remains of at least four American men still listed as missing in action.   The excavation is scheduled to begin Tuesday and to take at least 10 days.

headline: 2 ISRAELI SAILORS REPORTED KILLED IN BARCELONA
abstract: Two bodies believed to be those of missing Israeli sailors have been found in this Mediterranean port, and today an anonymous telephone caller said they had been killed by a Palestinian group.   The caller told a Western news agency that two ''Zionist sailors from the Zionist ship California'' were killed last Saturday by the Palestinian unit known as Force 17.   Officials believe that two badly decomposed bodies found in a Barcelona apartment late Wednesday are those of the sailors. Zim Israel Navigation Company, the national shipping company, identified the seamen as Yaakov Abu, 32 years old, and Zion Abu, 33, both of Haifa, Israel.

headline: BRITAIN FINDS SIGNS OF HOPE
abstract: Polls show Britons losing patience with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's economic policies, and there is a widespread belief that the prospects are bleak. Britain's industrial imports exceeded exports last year for the first time since the nation gave birth to the Industrial Revolution. Unemployment is at record levels and rising. Manufacturing costs are increasing faster than in other major industrial countries. North Sea oil output is peaking. Amid all this, however, there have been some less noted developments that could lead to a brighter future. Most important, perhaps, has been a revival of interest in economic self-help, reflected in a booming venture capital market and the creation of new businesses at a record rate.

headline: A CABLE FROM U.S. REPORTEDLY WARNED OF HIJACKING THREAT
abstract: Several days before the Egyptair hijacking, the Transportation Department warned that terrorists trained in Iran might be planning to seize an airliner, according to a source familiar with a cable sent to United States airlines and international aviation authorities.   The cable noted that the department could not say where or when such a hijacking might take place, the source said.   According to the source, the cable said American authorities had obtained information that Iran was training several hundred people of various Middle Eastern nationalities in hijacking and terrorist activities and that these people could be expected to use ''stolen or forged'' passports from several nations to make a hijacking possible.

headline: CRAXI'S COMMENTS IMPERIL NEW CABINET
abstract: A political storm that erupted over a statement on the Middle East by Prime Minister Bettino Craxi intensified today, threatening his revived coalition Government.   On Wednesday, Mr. Craxi defended the legitimacy of armed struggle by the Palestine Liberation Organization, provoking shouts and catcalls by rightist and other members of the Chamber of Deputies. He went on to win a vote of confidence by a comfortable margin.   But today, during a debate in the Senate, Mr. Craxi's remarks were subjected to sharp criticism from those who are, theoretically, his political allies. Party leaders spent the day in intensive negotiations.

headline: SENATORS SEE MODIFIED BILL, HARD FIGHT
abstract: The Senate is likely to adopt a tax-revision measure of its own next year, but it will probably be more favorable to business than the bill passed by the House tonight, and it could well raise additional revenues to help reduce the Federal deficit, Senate leaders said tonight.   House Republicans provided the key votes to pass a tax measure after they received assurances from President Reagan that he would only sign a bill that differed markedly from the House measure. Consequently, the Republican House members as well as the White House are looking to the Senate to fashion a bill more to their liking.   Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, said tonight that he had not been consulted about the promises made by the White House to the House Republicans, but the Senate seems headed for a long and difficult debate.

headline: FOUNDER OF AVIS WANTS IT BACK
abstract: Warren E. Avis, who founded Avis Rent-a-Car in 1947 with a $10,000 investment and sold it in 1955 for $8 million, wants to buy the company back again. The price tag on the company now is several hundred million.   Mr. Avis said that he and a group of investors from the United States, Europe and the Middle East are offering to buy Avis Inc. from the Beatrice Companies, which has put it up for sale.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 30, 1985
abstract: Companies

headline: Court Gives Revlon a Stay
abstract: The Delaware Supreme Court yesterday delayed a preliminary injunction that had been granted by a lower court to prevent Revlon Inc. from giving Forstmann Little & Company the right to buy two key businesses.   The Supreme Court granted the stay so Revlon could appeal the lower court's finding that its directors had breached their fiduciary duty to stockholders by giving Forstmann Little special rights as part of a Revlon-backed plan to buy the company.

headline: DOW UP 3.47 AFTER LATE RALLY
abstract: Stock prices closed mixed yesterday on Wall Street after blue chip issues salvaged the session with a final hour rally instigated by oil and high-technology issues.   Noticeably absent from the session was the swarm of takeover rumors that engulfed the market during the previous two weeks. Investors, in fact, seemed genuinely concerned about some of the more speculative issues. ''I think people are starting to look at the takeover world with a greater sense of reality,'' said James Meyer of the Janney Montgomery Scott brokerage firm in Philadelphia.

headline: PENTAGON REASSESSES SOVIET BOMBER
abstract: The Defense Intelligence Agency has significantly lowered its estimate of the range of a Soviet bomber that has figured in the Geneva arms talks, Reagan Administration officials said today.   Administration experts said the new estimate reinforced the contention by some arms-control proponents that the bomber, known in the West as the Backfire, was designed to attack ships and targets in Europe and Asia, not in the United States.   The new, lower intelligence agency estimate of the bomber's range raises questions about the Administration's decision to treat the Backfire as part of Moscow's long-range nuclear arsenal in the Geneva talks.   But some Administration officials said they expected the United States to keep to its position that the Backfire should be limited by any future arms control agreement because the Soviet Union could add to the bomber's refueling capabilities.

headline: FILIPINO CALLS RULING 'BIG LIE'
abstract: A woman who testified in a recent trial in the Philippines that she saw Benigno S. Aquino Jr. shot by a man in uniform repeated her charge at a news conference in New York yesterday and said she had been threatened and offered bribes to keep her from telling her story.   The witness, Rebecca Quijano, was appearing at a news conference organized by the Brooklyn-based Ninoy Aquino Movement to protest the Philippine court's ruling yesterday that cleared General Fabian C. Ver, the Philippines Chief of Staff, and 25 other defendants of complicity in the 1983 assassination and appeared to endorse President Ferdinand E. Marcos's assertion that Mr. Aquino, the Philippines' most prominent opposition leader, was murdered by a lone civilian named Rolando Galman.   Congressman Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, also appeared at the news conference, which was held at the United Nations Church Center at 777 United Nations Plaza.

headline: Dollar's Rise Continues Despite Intervention
abstract: The dollar fluctuated widely yesterday and finished generally stronger, despite efforts by several central banks to weaken it both by words and financial muscle.   Yesterday's upturn continued the dollar's swing upward of Monday and Tuesday, which followed a broad descent in the previous two weeks. It presents the most severe test yet of the ability of five industrial nations to engineer a weaker dollar, as they decided to do Sept. 22.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Boeing Commercial Airplane Co., Seattle, a unit of Boeing Co., said three airplane companies had ordered a total of five Boeing 747's with a combined value of more than $490 million. The airplanes are scheduled for delivery in September 1986.

headline: U.S. SAYS SOVIET COMPLIES ON SOME ARMS ISSUES
abstract: The Soviet Union has quietly taken steps to reduce some American concerns over purported arms-control violations, according to Administration officials.   The Soviet moves involve the cutting up of bombers and, according to intelligence reports, the possible removal of SS-16 missiles from a test center at Plesetsk in northern Russia.   The moves are of political importance because the United States has taken the position that it will not undercut the 1979 strategic arms treaty as long as the Soviet Union does not.   The 1979 treaty issue was not pursued at the Geneva summit meeting, officials said today. Nor was the question of Soviet violations dealt with in detail.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corp., Pittsburgh, said it had ended merger talks with Gibbs Wire and Steel Co.    * Allied Stores Corp. said that it had agreed to acquire Jerry Leonard Inc., a chain of 26 apparel stores located in the Middle west and Southwest. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: YOUNGEST CHESS CHAMPION: GARY KASPAROV
abstract: Even in chess, a game in which every great player was once a child prodigy, few champions have swept to the top as swiftly or relentlessly as Gary Kasparov.   He began playing at the age of 6, and by the time he was 10 and a pupil at Baku Middle School 151, he had already attracted the attention of the chess world by taking first place in a young hopefuls tournament.   He never looked back. By 13 he was the Soviet youth champion, at 15 he was competing in the Soviet championship, and at 16, in 1979, he swept through his first major international tournament, in Banja Luka, Yugoslavia. Competing against great grandmasters like Tigran Petrosian and Ulf Andersson, the dark-haired teen-ager gained eight victories and finished a full 2 points ahead of the next highest contender.

headline: Sudan Denies It's Unsafe For American Travelers
abstract: Prime Minister al-Gazouly Dafallah today denied a State Department assertion that Khartoum was unsafe for Americans, the official Sudan News Agency reported.   In a meeting with Ambassador Hume Alexander Horan, Mr. Dafallah asked for an explanation of the State Department warning, the press agency said.

headline: EGYPTIAN OFFICER IS GIVEN LIFE TERM
abstract: An Egyptian border policeman who ran amok in Sinai, shooting and killing seven Israeli tourists, four of them children, was sentenced to life imprisonment with hard labor today.   Later, an administrative court rejected an appeal by lawyers for the policeman, Suliman Khater, that the trial should have taken place in a civilian court and upheld the sentence.

headline: Bergerac Quit Deal to End Criticism, Insider Says
abstract: Michel C. Bergerac, chairman and chief executive of Revlon Inc., decided not to put any money into a group trying to buy the company, an insider said yesterday, ''to put an end to criticism in the media'' that the executive was ''having his cake and eating it, too.''   The source, who is close to Revlon, said the company's legal advisers had told it that it was ''perfectly O.K.'' for Mr. Bergerac and his executives to take their golden parachutes, cash in their stock options and then invest in the company.   Revlon's lawyers, the source said, told Mr. Bergerac that no one would incur any liability if he or his executives decided to invest in the company but that he could stop the criticism by dropping out.

headline: I.C.C.'s Next Chairman
abstract: Heather Gradison, one of Washington's most aggressive deregulators, seems likely to be the next chairman of the faction-ridden Interstate Commerce Commission.   The 98-year old I.C.C., grandfather of the Federal regulatory agencies, loses two of its seven commissionerships on Jan. 1.

headline: CALLER IN BEIRUT MENACES RUSSIANS
abstract: An anonymous caller told a radio station here today that unless the Soviet Union closed its embassy in Beirut, three kidnapped Soviet diplomats would be killed within 30 minutes of the call and the embassy destroyed.   The Christian radio known as the Voice of Lebanon said the same man had called Sunday and said the Soviet Union had 48 hours to close the embassy before the hostages were killed. By tonight, the radio had not heard again from the caller.

headline: CONCERN OVER CHARGES ON CREDIT CARDS GROWS
abstract: The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company's action on Tuesday to lower the interest it charges on its Visa and Mastercard accounts comes amid growing concern in Congress and among consumer groups about those charges.   Members of Congress and consumer leaders are pressing banks to lower the interest they charge credit card users, contending that these rates have stayed high while most others, notably the prime rate on commercial loans, have come down substantially in the last four years.   ''I believe in the free market, but there are times when the free market does not work, said Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, noting that some Congressional sentiment in this matter is contrary to the anti-regulatory atmosphere in Washington. ''In this case, I have a feeling that everybody looks at each other, winks and doesn't reduce the rates,''

headline: New President At CBS/Fox
abstract: The CBS/Fox Company, the leading producer and marketer of pre-recorded video cassettes, said yesterday that James G. Fifield, an executive at General Mills Inc., had been named president and chief executive.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: U.N.'S CHIEF URGES JOB EQUITY FOR ITS WOMEN
abstract: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 15 -Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar has announced that he is committed to correct what he called ''severe disparities in women's representation'' on the professional level at the United Nations.   On Thursday, in his first official report on the status of women in the United Nations, Mr. Perez de Cuellar blamed ''the institutional and attitudinal climate within the organization'' and the shifting of responsiblity ''from one party to the next'' for the slow movement of women up the United Nations ladder.   The report was sensitive, and it went through 14 versions before it was finally acceptable, United Nations officials involved in its drafting said.   The Secretary General ordered each department to set up new targets for the recruitment and promotion of professional women for 1986 and announced a review system that would make department heads accountable if the goals were not met.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 19, 1985
abstract: The Economy    All interest payments on mortgages for second homes would remain tax deductible under a decision by a working group of the House Ways and Means Committee, which rejected an Administration proposal to limit the deduction. The group also rejected the President's proposal to limit real estate investors' deductions to the amount they actually invest and the amount of mortgages they are personally required to repay. The full committee is likely to adopt the group's recommendations. [Page D1.]    The operating rate at factories, mines and utilities fell for the fifth month of the last six, with continued foreign competition cited. Industry operated at 80.2 percent of capacity. [D27.]

headline: Pepperell Chief Plans Flexibility With Cluett
abstract: As the fourth generation of his family to head West Point-Pepperell Inc., Joseph L. Lanier Jr. knows a thing or two about the textile business. And one thing he knows all too well is how badly the apparel fabrics segment of that business has been hurt by competition from imports: his company's net income fell 49 percent last year, largely because of soft performance in apparel fabrics.   So when West Point announced on Monday that it had agreed to buy Cluett, Peabody & Company, the apparel company that makes Arrow shirts and Gold Toe socks, for about $375 million, some people wondered what Mr. Lanier had in mind. Did he plan to buck the industry trend by increasing West-Point's apparel fabrics production to supply his new subsidiary?

headline: OPEC Head Sees No Shift
abstract: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has not changed its policy on oil prices, but new practices may be considered at future meetings, OPEC's president said.

headline: BUSINESS ECONOMISTS FACE A BLEAKET OUTLOOK
abstract: For business economists, one area of the economy that may appear the bleakest is their own profession.   Major corporations, leading banks and the Federal Government have been eliminating, de-emphasizing or reassigning their once-elite staffs of Ph.D. economists. Some companies are now buying whatever analysis they need from economic consulting firms.   Although economists have often come under fire for their forecasts, business has generally valued their insights and their number had continued to grow. But for the past couple of years, severe pressures on corporate profits have led many chief executives to reassess the role of economists in their organizations, and some have concluded that such staffs are a luxury.

headline: U.N. Reports Progress On Rights in Salvador
abstract: Although Government and rebel forces in El Salvador continue to kill civilians and commit widespread human rights violations, the Government's human rights policies are improving, according to a United Nations report made public today.   The report, prepared for the United Nations Commission on Human Rights, says Government agents continue to engage in or tolerate summary executions of civilians and use ''severe psychological pressure'' in interrogations of political prisoners.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Air One, St. Louis, said it had completed its plan of reorganization and has emerged from protection under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy laws.    * American Telephone and Telegraph has agreed to buy a domestic satellite earth station and to lease two additional earth stations for limited periods from the GTE Corporation for about $2.5 million.    * Abiibi-Price Inc., Toronto, which makes newsprint and kraft pulp, said that its board of directors had recommended that shareholders accept Gulf Canada Ltd.'s offer of $21 (Canadian) a share for the publicly held common shares of the company.

headline: EGYPT SAYS LIBYA WAS BEHIND HIJACKING
abstract: Egyptian officials accused Libya today of responsibility for the hijacking of an Egyptian airliner on which 59 people were killed.   ''The connection is very clear,'' President Hosni Mubarak said at a news conference.   The hijacking ended violently Sunday when Egyptian forces stormed the plane in Malta in a rescue attempt. The hijackers responded by detonating grenades. In all, 59 people died, including 57 during the rescue attempt.

headline: Washington Watch;   Volcker Trip, Martin Denial
abstract: The Federal Reserve Board's chairman, Paul A. Volcker, left town Thursday for an unusually long overseas trip that will keep him away from his office until next Monday. He flew to debt-strapped Argentina and might stop in Venezuela on the way back, an aide said.

headline: G.M.A.C. Tests Financing Plan
abstract: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation, the financial subsidiary of the giant auto maker, today introduced a pilot financing program that is intended to lower a new-car buyer's monthly payment with a balloon payment at the end of the contract. Initially, the plan will be offered in southeastern Michigan only.

headline: UNITED NATIONS CALENDAR
abstract: END OF GENERAL DEBATE -The third and final week of the general debate begins today with speeches by eight nations. Prime Minister Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe was originally scheduled to lead-off the session, but he has postponed his visit to New York until later this month, a spokesman said Friday. Foreign Minister Witness Mangwende will substitute for Mr. Mugabe. The morning lineup also includes the Foreign Ministers of Mongolia, Bahrain and the Dominican Republic. In the afternoon, delegates will hear speeches by representatives of Angola, Southern Yemen, Benin and Sao Tome and Principe.

headline: HEWLETT BETS THE STORE ON SPECTRUM
abstract: LIKE most of its Silicon Valley neighbors, the Hewlett-Packard Company is in the grip of an austerity program. Since July, its factories have been shut down two days a month, paychecks of most of the company's 85,000 employees have been reduced and hiring any new employee requires highest-level approval.   But in a new, low-slung building in Cupertino, Calif., more than 800 people have been working full weeks and even on Saturdays and actively hiring new workers. They are racing against the clock to come out with an entirely new line of computers, code-named Spectrum, that could change the way computers are designed and almost certainly will change Hewlett-Packard's fortunes.   For Hewlett-Packard, one of the premier companies in the electronics industry and the company that founded Silicon Valley, is engaged in the biggest gamble of its 46-year history. ''If Spectrum doesn't make it, it's devastating,'' said Rich Edwards, a former Hewlett-Packard strategic planner who is now an analyst with Robertson, Colman and Stephens in San Francisco.

headline: DENG SKEPTICAL ON SOVIET OFFER
abstract: The Chinese leader, Deng Xiaoping, said today that Mr. Gorbachev's proposal that the United States and the Soviet Union cut their nuclear arsenals by half did not mean substantial change, officials in a West German delegation said.   They said Mr. Deng told Franz Josef Strauss, the visiting Bavarian Premier, that as long as the two superpowers had the nuclear arms potential to destroy the world, ''a 50 percent reduction does not mean any substantial change.''

headline: U.N. UNANIMOUSLY CONDEMNS HOSTAGE-TAKING
abstract: The Security Council adopted a resolution today that condemns ''all acts of hostage-taking and abduction'' and calls for the immediate, safe release of all hostages and abducted people.   Vernon A. Walters, the American delegate, said in a statement after the meeting that ''this is a historic step, almost without precedent in the entire 40 years of the United Nations.''   The resolution, initiated by the United States and drafted in closed-door sessions, was endorsed unanimously by all 15 members. It is binding on all countries in the United Nations.

headline: JACOBS GROUP LIFTS INTERNORTH STAKE
abstract: Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis financier, said he had increased his investment group's stake in HNG-Internorth Inc. to 9.1 percent, from 7.9 percent, of the company's 44 million shares.

headline: Argentine Debt Talks
abstract: David Mulford, an Assistant Treasury Secretary, will fly to Argentina Tuesday for talks on the United States debt strategy with President Raul Alfonsin and Finance Ministry officials, a Treasury spokesman said today.

headline: THE PERIL BEHIND THE TAKEOVER BOOM
abstract: THE biggest wave of corporate acquisitions and buyouts in American history is beginning to cause widespread alarm. The merger mania has sent stock prices to levels no one ever envisioned for 1985. But in the process, American business has gone heavily into debt to pay for its multi-billion dollar takeovers. And this boom in corporate debt, particularly with its use of high-yielding, less-than-investment grade ''junk bonds,'' is bringing warnings even from those involved in financing the megadeals.   ''I'm worried about what this leveraging up will do,'' said Thomas S. Johnson, president of the Chemical Bank, which despite Mr. Johnson's concern participates in takeover lending. ''I'm worried that the aggregate of all these things, including leveraged buy-outs, is simply Some of the players in 1985's deals, Page 7 a perverse result of greed and not a logical, rational thing. I don't know how all this debt will be serviced.''   The situation has so troubled Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, that he now wants to restrict the use of junk bonds, a step that would thwart many highly-leveraged takeovers.

headline: SHULTZ BACKS AID TO FOES OF SOVIET
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that members of the Atlantic alliance should not shrink from using all kinds of aid, including covert assistance, to advance their diplomatic goals.   In a major speech to the Pilgrims Society, a British-American group here, Mr. Shultz seemed bent on persuading Washington's European allies to support the approach being followed by Washington in such areas as Afghanistan, Nicaragua, Cambodia, and now Angola. Both secret and open aid is being supplied to anti-Communist rebels there in the absence of diplomatic solutions.      Aid to Angolan Rebels    He said that the United States and its ''European friends'' have had ''tactical differences'' over the correct mix of ''power and diplomacy.''

headline: Economic Scene;   Trying to Deal With Deflation
abstract: ECONOMIC policy makers, like generals, have a tendency to fight the last war, and their last war was against inflation. But the actual battle now confronting the United States and other industrial countries is against deflation.   World oil prices have fallen 25 percent since their 1981 peak, and commodity prices have been falling since the start of the 1980's. But the December issue of World Financial Markets, published by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, shows that oil prices are still high in historical terms relative to world prices of manufactured goods.

headline: Hungarian Leader in London
abstract: Janos Kadar, the Hungarian Communist Party leader, arrived here today for a three-day official visit that will include talks with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. British officials say the visit is part of Mrs. Thatcher's effort to encourage discussions with the Eastern bloc nations.

headline: TAKEOVER ISSUES CLIMB
abstract: The stock market ended mostly higher yesterday, bolstered by sharp gains in some rumored takeover targets.   The session came on the heels of Wednesday's record-setting performance that saw the Dow Jones industrial average end above 1,500 for the first time. And although the Dow dipped 0.46 point yesterday, at 1,511.24, advances exceeded declines by 920 to 721.

headline: HOW YURCHENKO BADE ADIEU TO C.I.A.
abstract: Vitaly Yurchenko's dramatic return to Moscow began last Saturday at a fern-decorated restaurant a few blocks from the Soviet Union's embassy compound, according to intelligence sources.   These sources said Mr. Yurchenko arrived at the 24-hour Continental restaurant Au Pied de Cochon in the company of a single C.I.A. officer.

headline: Khomeini Meets Cabinet Of New Prime Minister
abstract: Iran's spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, told the country's new Cabinet today not to ''nationalize everything'' and suggested that its members should minimize their ideological differences.   ''Give the committed merchants -those who want to serve the country -a free hand to serve, and don't nationalize everything,'' he said.   At his home in Teheran, Ayatollah Khomeini received President Hojatolislam Ali Khamenei, Prime Minister Mir Hussein Moussavi and 22 ministers of the Cabinet approved by Parliament on Monday.

headline: SIHANOUK, AT U.N., SAYS REBELS AREN'T LOSING
abstract: Prince Norodom Sihanouk told the General Assembly today that his rebel forces were holding their own against the Hanoi-backed Government in Phnom Penh.   The Prince, who is recognized by the United Nations as the legitimate head of state of Cambodia, asserted in a speech that forces of the opposition coalition he leads had recently made inroads into regions near the Cambodian capital, causing ''serious concern'' for the Vietnamese. The rebel alliance consists of two non-Communist groups and the Khmer Rouge, which is Communist.

headline: A TALE OF TWO CITRUS BELTS
abstract: Oranges by the million swirl through the Redland Heights Citrus Company, from rooms of ethylene gas that give the oranges color to conveyer belts where each fruit is waxed to shine like a new car.   These days, the same shine marks the entire California citrus industry, which continues to thrive despite the general farming downturn. Prices are good for lemons as well as oranges, and the navel orange harvest now under way seems likely to be very profitable.   ''It is one of the true bright spots in American agriculture today,'' said John R. Norton 3d, the Deputy Secretary of Agriculture.

headline: A NEW ACT TAKES OVER AT POLYGRAM
abstract: AT Polygram Records Inc., there are 33Y revolutions per minute. At least, that is how it has looked in the last few years. Polygram has redrawn its organization chart countless times. It has been in and out of myriad new ventures. It has tried in vain to merge with other record companies. And in the process, it has marched presidents in and out its doors. ''At Polygram,'' said one former employee, ''by the time you learn to pronounce their names, they're gone.''  The company has gone through agonies trying to follow its own act. One of the six largest record companies in the United States, Polygram, the American arm of a worldwide complex of record companies owned by Dutch electronics giant N. V. Philips, once seemed earmarked for stardom. In 1978 it broke industry sales records with the soundtrack albums of ''Saturday Night Fever'' and ''Grease,'' and hopes ran high throughout Philips that its American subsidiary was on the way to becoming the industry's pacesetter.

headline: MALAYSIAN SECRETS LAW IS USED AS A NEWS CURB
abstract: Malaysia, citing the Official Secrets Act, has begun to prosecute journalists who gain access to unpublished Government reports.   On Friday the Malaysian police arrested a 27-year-old reporter for the country's leading English-language daily, The New Straits Times. He had written in January about Government plans to acquire Airborne Warning and Control System planes from the United States.

headline: PACT IN INDIA ASSURES SOME, INFLAMES OTHERS
abstract: Last August Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi triumphantly announced a settlement in a bitter ethnic dispute that had cost thousands of lives in the northeastern state of Assam.   But now the carrying out of that accord is creating new bitterness and fears of violence in this remote region of India. What had been hailed as a victory for national unity has instead produced sharp new antagonisms between Hindus and Moslems.   The focus for the renewed friction is a state election scheduled for Dec. 16.

headline: HONDURANS VOTE FOR A PRESIDENT TODAY
abstract: Hondurans will vote for a new president on Sunday, but as of this afternoon it continued to appear that they would do so without knowing how their next leader will finally be selected.   The main problem is a continuing dispute over a new electoral law that has left two legally viable methods for selecting the winner of the presidency. Under the electoral law, the leading candidate of the party that gets the most votes will win. But under the Constitution, whichever candidate wins a majority of the vote becomes president.

headline: Anti-Takeover Plan by Busch
abstract: In an anti-takeover move, the Anheuser-Busch Companies said its board had adopted a plan to distribute preferred share purchase rights to shareholders. The Anheuser-Busch chairman, August A. Busch, said in a statement, ''We have not been, nor do we expect to become involved in any discussions that could affect in any way our independence.''

headline: DAIMLER-BENZ SETS DIVERSIFICATION
abstract: Last week's announcement by Daimler-Benz A.G. that it had bought 24.9 percent of AEG and would seek control of the electronics company is the latest step in a diversification program to reduce its dependence on automotive products.   The AEG takeover is the third major move in recent months to put Daimler-Benz in the field of high technology and to assure future growth despite sluggish sales of its Mercedes cars and trucks.   In March Daimler-Benz announced it was buying a majority stake in Dornier G.m.b.H., an aerospace company, and in May it said that it would acquire control of Motoren und Turbinen Union, a maker of aircraft engines. Similar moves into high technology have been made by American auto companies, with the General Motors Corporation buying Hughes Aircraft and the Chrysler Corporation buying Gulfstream Aerospace.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

headline: Phoenix Offering
abstract: Phoenix is offering $79.3 million of airport revenue bonds, rated A by Moody's, through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company, with yields ranging from 7 1/2 percent for bonds due in 1993 to 7.85 percent in 1995, 8.60 percent in 2000 and 8.80 percent in 2002. In addition, the city is offering $57.5 million of general obligation bonds through the Continental Illinois National Bank, with yields ranging from 5 1/2 percent for bonds due in 1987 to 6 1/2 percent in 1990, 7 1/2 percent in 1995, 8.10 percent in 2000, 8.35 percent in 2005 and 8.40 percent in 2009. The bonds are rated Aa-1 by Moody's and AA+ by S.& P.

headline: Shell-Exxon-China Pact
abstract: Royal Dutch/Shell said it and the Exxon Corporation of the United States signed a contract with the state-owned China National Offshore Oil Corporation to explore for oil in the Pearl River in south China.

headline: Zimbabwe Rejects Charges That Detainees Are Tortured
abstract: Zimbabwe has rejected charges by Amnesty International that it has increased the detention and torture of suspected Government opponents, the country's embassy in Britain said today.   Zimbabwe's Home Affairs Minister, Enos Nkala, met Monday with officials of Amnesty International, the London-based human rights organization, and said its report contained false allegations.

headline: Big Debt Offering By Harte-Hanks
abstract: Harte-Hanks Communications Inc., San Antonio, is offering $400 million of debt securities in a two-part financing, through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.   A $200 million issue of 13 7/8 percent, 10-year senior subordinated notes was offered at 99 5/8 to yield 13.943 percent, while $200 million of 14 3/8 percent, 15-year subordinated notes were offered at 99 3/4 to yield 14.414 percent.   The securities are rated B-1 by Moody's and B- by S.&P. Proceeds from the sale will be used to reduce bank debt incurred in 1984 when a group of Harte-Hank officers bought out previous shareholders.

headline: FARM VOTE IN SENATE
abstract: The Senate today narrowly defeated and Administration-backed effort to add budget restraint to the farm bill.   A 51-48 vote killed an amendment offered by Senator Richard C. Lugar, Republican of Indiana, that would replace the four-year freeze on farm income guarantees now in the bill with a one-year freeze, to be followed by annual cuts of as much as 5 percent.   The Administration has said the bill's cost must be trimmed if President Reagan is to sign it.

headline: Manila to Permit Group To Observe Elections
abstract: The Government elections commission today granted an American-backed civic organization the right to station observers at the country's 90,000 polling stations during the presidential election scheduled for Feb. 7.   Jose Concepcion, the chairman of the civic organization, the National Citizens Movement for Free Elections, said the decision was the ''best Christmas gift'' the commission could give to Filipinos.

headline: HOUSE UNIT REJECTS TAX ON POLICY CASH VALUES
abstract: A working group of House Ways and Means Committee members today rejected President Reagan's proposal to tax life insurance policyholders on the annual increase in the cash value of their policies.   Otherwise the six-member bipartisan group agreed to limit somewhat the favorable tax treatment now enjoyed by the insurance industry.   In the past, the decisions of working groups have been approved without change by the full Ways and Means Committee. The panel will take up the insurance issue Friday.

headline: Colombian Army Chief Wounded in Ambush
abstract: Gunmen suspected of being leftist guerrillas ambushed and wounded the head of Colombia's Army this morning, a Bogota radio station reported.   Gen. Rafael Samudio was hit in the right arm by a bullet and was taken to Bogota's military hospital, the radio station, Todelar, quoted witnesses as having said.

headline: Producer Prices Soar By 0.9%
abstract: Producer prices soared by nine-tenths of 1 percent last month, the biggest increase in four and a half years, as a jump in new-car prices and some food costs disrupted the quiet inflation scene.   Analysts dismissed the increase as a one-month phenomenon that did not change the good prospects for low inflation this year and next.   Even with the big October gain in the Labor Department's Producer Price Index, prices for the first 10 months of 1985 have risen at an annual rate of only nine-tenths of 1 percent, bettering last year's 1.7 percent performance.      Attributed to Auto Factor    The October rise came after a decline of six-tenths of 1 percent in September. The swings in both months were attributed primarily to the same factor, changes in new-car prices. In September, attractive cut-rate financing incentives offered at the end of the model year helped slash car prices 3.8 percent. Most of those incentives were discontinued last month with the introduction of 1986 models, resulting in a sharp 5.1 percent price increase.

headline: William Esty Wins Texaco Competition
abstract: The William Esty Company has won the competition to replace Benton & Bowles on the Texaco account for gasoline, motor oil and antifreeze advertising.

headline: Article 231479 -- No Title
abstract: The stock of the Midcon Corporation rose by $1.625 yesterday after two energy companies announced an offer to buy the company for $62.50 a share, or a total of $2.7 billion. The stock closed at $63.375 on the New York Stock Exchange.   Only last week, Midcon completed a $1.14 billion acquisition of United Energy Resources.   The two bidders are Wagner & Brown of Midland, Tex., and Freeport-McMoran Inc. of New Orleans. Joel L. Reed, chief financial officer of Wagner & Brown, said in an interview: ''We are very much interested in acquiring Midcon. We think it is the premier natural gas pipeline in the United States today.''

headline: PATENTS;  LOW-ENERGY SWITHC FOR OPTICAL COMPUTERS
abstract: An optical device patented this week for AT&T; Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, N.J., has encouraged the company's expectation of the development of optical computers.  David A. B. Miller, a member of the technical staff in the Laser Science Research Department at Holmdel, N.J., was granted patent 4,546,244.  The patented device is a low-energy switch that is being used in further optical computer research.

headline: Hyundai Chips
abstract: The Hyundai Electronics Industries subsidiary of the Hyundai Corporation has closed its semiconductor factory in the United States because of heavy losses, company officials said. They said that Hyundai Electronics America of Santa Clara, Calif., would continue research, development and marketing work, but would cease production of silicon chips. Hyundai Electronics invested $40 million in the subsidiary in October 1984, but industry sources said that it has since lost more than $200 million.

headline: Africa Common Market
abstract: President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia said today that he envisions the birth of a 20-nation African common market in seven years. Mr. Kaunda, who led the British colony of Northern Rhodesia to independence as Zambia in 1964, said the aim of the community - representing 150 million of Africa's 500 million people -would be ''to free ourselves economically'' from former European colonial powers. He spoke at the opening of the fourth summit talks of the Preferential Trade Area for Eastern and Southern African States.

headline: SOUTH AFRICAN POLICE SHOOT AND KILL 3 PROTESTERS
abstract: The police said today that they had shot and killed three black protesters in a segregated township east of here.   Witnesses said a fourth black may have died when a storeowner in the segregated township, Leandra, opened fire on stone-throwing protesters.   The reports came after a weekend of violence elsewhere, and almost four months after the declaration of a state of emergency that was supposed to curb unrest. Leandra township is not one of the 38 districts covered by the emergency.

headline: Warnaco Gets Bid From Its Officers
abstract: Warnaco Inc., the Connecticut-based maker of Hathaway shirts, White Stag skiwear and other apparel, said yesterday that it had received a buyout offer of more than $333 million from an investor group headed by its top executives.   The company said that under the proposal received from a group headed by Warnaco's chairman, Robert J. Matura, shareholders would receive $27 a share in cash and $13 principal amount of junior subordinated discount debentures for each of the 10 million common shares outstanding. At face value, the deal would be worth about $40 a share. But Larry Pflieger, the company president, said the package of cash and debentures is estimated to be worth $33.30 a share.

headline: 'STAR WARS' IN STRATEGY: THE RUSSIAN RESPONSE
abstract: The debate over the ''Star Wars'' missile defense program is increasingly shifting to arguments about its real military value, as opposed to its mere technical feasibility.   Would a space- and land-based shield against missiles offer meaningful protection to the United States? Or, even if it were to become scientifically plausible, would it, instead, weaken America's military power?   Most experts agree that present and prospective Soviet actions will bear heavily on the answers.   But whatever those answers are they will be crucial to what Lieut. Gen. James A. Abrahamson, director of the Strategic Defense Initiative Organization - the official name for the American missile-defense research program - says will ultimately ''be the most complex and complicated decision ever faced by an American government.''   And John E. Pike, a space analyst for the Federation of American Scientists who is generally critical of the program, agrees. He adds, however, ''It is roughly comparable to the Hayes Administration's trying to decide if it wanted to buy an air force.''

headline: U.S. IS PESSIMISTIC OVER EXTRADITING OFFICIAL OF P.L.O.
abstract: The Administration virtually gave up hope today of seizing a Palestinian guerrilla leader who fled to Yugoslavia from Rome as the United States sought to extradite him for planning the hijacking of an Italian cruise ship.   Administration officials said they expected the Yugoslav Government to announce formally Monday that it would neither hold nor extradite the Palestinian, Mohammed Abbas. The United States was given that message informally today in Belgrade, Justice Department officials said.   As officials awaited the formal Yugoslav response, the White House and State Department considered diplomatic moves against the Italian Government for not arresting the Palestinian. The White House called Mr. Abbas, who is known as Abul Abbas, ''one of the most notorious Palestinian terrorists,'' and said he ''has been involved in savage attacks on civilians.''

headline: Frigitronics Offer
abstract: Charles C. Johnston, a Massachusetts investor who holds 9.8 percent of Frigitronics Inc., proposed today to acquire the remaining shares for $24 a share in cash and $10.50 in debt securities.

headline: 11 Are Dead, 4 Hurt In 2 Blasts in Sri Lanka
abstract: Land mines believed planted by Tamil guerrillas killed seven police officers and four soldiers in two explosions today, an army spokesman said.   The police officers were in the front vehicle of a three-jeep convoy when an explosion occurred this morning in Siththaar, near the northeastern port city of Trincomalee.

headline: U.S. BANS ARMS IMPORTS
abstract: The United States today banned imports of firearms, ammunition and technical arms manuals from South Africa.   The ban, imposed by the Treasury Department's Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, stems from a United Nations resolution of December 1984 against arms imports from South Africa and from President Reagan's partial trade embargo ordered against that country on Sept. 9.

headline: WOMAN IN THE NEWS: CORAZONE AQUINO THE TICKET OF 2 THAT SEEKS TO TOPPLE MARCOS
abstract: Corazon C. Aquino, who will face President Ferdinand E. Marcos in elections set for February, says her advisers keep telling her to stop referring to herself as ''just an ordinary housewife.''   ''And anyway,'' she said the other day, ''I am not a housewife any more because I cannot take care of my house anymore, so many things have come up.''   What has now come up, after days of last-ditch negotiation, is her emergence as the leader of the Philippine opposition in its attempt to end the 20-year rule of Mr. Marcos, whom it blames for the country's economic decline and growing instability.   Mrs. Aquino, the 52-year-old widow of Benigno S. Aquino Jr., the most popular opposition figure and a lifelong challenger to Mr. Marcos, has come to symbolize the accumulated grievances within the nation against the President.

headline: READY FOR ANOGHER FLING WITH NO. 2; WARREN E. AVIS
abstract: ''WHAT'S the purpose of getting up in the morning unless there's excitement,'' asks Warren Avis, sipping a soft drink in his luxurious Fifth Avenue apartment overlooking Central Park.   It is mentioned that there are plenty of ways to find excitement. ''I've done them all.''
