Not quite all, which is why the investor and entrepreneur has latched onto an idea that he thinks will furnish him with a new reason to get up in the morning. He is determined to buy back the company that he sold more than 30 years ago, the empire that made his name famous throughout the world: Avis Rent-a-Car.   Late last month, Warren Avis stepped out of the past and declared that he and a group of investors wish to acquire the No. 2 rental car agency from the Beatrice Companies, which has put it up for sale. He may have to battle to get it, though, for last Thursday, the Wesray Capital Corporation, an investment firm headed by William E. Simon, the former Treasury Secretary, said that it was joining with some Avis licensees to consider a bid as well.

headline: Britain's Finance Bill
abstract: The British Government introduced legislation today aimed at reforming business practices in the City of London, the nation's financial center.

headline: U.S. WILL PRESENT NEW ARMS OFFER IN GENEVA TODAY
abstract: President Reagan said today that the United States would offer a new arms proposal to the Soviet Union on Friday calling for ''very significant, balanced reductions'' of nuclear arsenals.   ''I would characterize our arms control position as deep cuts, no first-strike advantage, defensive research and no cheating,'' Mr. Reagan said in the White House press room.   The announcement came less than three weeks before he is scheduled to meet in Geneva with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader. Secretary of State George P. Shultz will travel to Moscow this weekend for a planning conference with Mr. Gorbachev, which some Government officials have said may include discussions of the possibility for future summit meetings.

headline: BURROUGHS'S SURPRISE SETBACK
abstract: Until a few days ago, the Burroughs Corporation looked like one of the few American computer makers that would make it through the industry's worst year in two decades relatively unscathed.   That perception was shattered by a surprise announcement Thursday night that third-quarter earnings would be ''substantially below'' those of a year ago.   The setback has little to do with the slow computer sales that have plagued the industry. Instead, Burroughs acknowledged that it had tripped on a technological problem that has bedeviled I.B.M., driven Control Data to despair and sent Storage Technology into bankruptcy. The problem centers on Burroughs's most sophisticated disk drive, which involves technology that only I.B.M. and the Japanese seem to have mastered.

headline: Sears Seen Promoting Brennan
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Company has scheduled a news conference for Tuesday at which the retailer and financial services company is expected to announce that Edward A. Brennan will be its next chairman.   Mr. Brennan, the 51-year-old president and chief operating officer, would succeed Edward R. Telling, 66, as chairman.   The announcement about Mr. Brennan, who joined Sears 29 years ago as a salesman in Madison, Wis., is expected to be made after the Sears board meets Tuesday morning.

headline: Rome Court Acquits 6 In Anti-American Plot
abstract: An Italian court acquitted six Lebanese on Wednesday of charges of plotting to attack the United States Embassy here, but convicted two of them of a lesser charge of trying to form an armed gang.   One of the two, Kassem Bachrouche, a fugitive who was tried in absentia, was sentenced to four and a half years in prison, and the other, Neemtallah Ali Mohammed Fahs, to two years.

headline: Shamrock-Ghana Deal
abstract: Diamond Shamrock International signed an agreement with the Ghanaian Government today that allows the company to search for oil in the onshore Keta Basin, the Ghana News Agency reported.

headline: U.S. NOT DOUBTING TALKS ON CAPTIVES
abstract: Senior Reagan Administration officials said today that they were confident the United States was now in contact through an intermediary with the captors of at least four Americans in Lebanon. They said the fate of the hostages might be decided in the next few days.   They said that as a result of talks in London on Monday between American officials and Terry Waite, the special envoy of the Archbishop of Cantebury, Washington had no doubt that Mr. Waite had met last week with the kidnappers of four of six Americans who have been abducted in Beirut and not released.   Mr. Waite, who has also had talks with British and French officials, returned to Beirut today.

headline: VEGAS COURTS LOW ROLLERS
abstract: The self-proclaimed ''city that never sleeps'' is awakening again after a few years' doze.   From ''Glitter Gulch'' downtown to the nearby ''Strip,'' most casinos are enjoying double-digit revenue growth for the first time in at least five years. Many, confident that business will remain healthy, are using profits to expand. Some 5,000 hotel rooms are under construction to add to the existing 55,000-room capacity.   Las Vegas has bounced back, thanks, in part, to its aggressive pursuit of a group that many casinos -particularly those on the glamorous Strip - had never actively courted: the middle and working class. These gamblers are what Las Vegas denizens call the ''grinds,'' low rollers for whom a few hundred dollars amounts to real money.

headline: A Firm Faith in Lower Rates
abstract: The Federal Reserve is not expected to change monetary policy at this week's meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, but many credit market participants remained optimistic last week that interest rates may decline in the near future.   The predisposition in favor of lower interest rates was shown on Friday, when traders and investors shrugged off a Commerce Department report of stronger-than-expected gains in employment. Normally, a 414,000 rise in nonfarm payrolls, plus a strong increase in manufacturing employment, would have led to lower bond prices as analysts concluded that a stronger economy would bring stronger credit demands and discourage the Fed from any further easing in monetary policy.   But on Friday the sharp price declines registered after release of the employment statistics were quickly recouped, and bond prices ended the day with modest gains. ''There was heavy, broad-based buying when prices fell in the morning,'' said one Government securities dealer. ''You don't expect the market to trade up in the face of heavy supply and bad economic news,'' he said. ''But I have to believe the evidence, which is that there was good demand last week.''

headline: F.D.I.C. REVISING ITS POLICY
abstract: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation will soon develop a uniform policy to deal with failed banks regardless of their size, L. William Seidman, the new chairman of the F.D.I.C., said today. Such an approach, he explained at a news conference, would be aimed at defusing criticism that the Government provides extra protection to large deposits of major banks even when those deposits do not fall under Federal insurance guidelines.   Separately, Beryl W. Sprinkel, the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, said here at the annual convention of the American Bankers Association that the economy would grow at roughly a 5 percent annual rate in the second half of 1985.   The prediction was consistent with Mr. Sprinkel's most recent forecast, but the fact that he chose to reassert it today suggests that the Administration might be trying to refute some private economists who say it is virtually impossible that the economy will grow at 5 percent in the second half.

headline: Macy's to Sell 12 of Its Stores
abstract: R. H. Macy & Company, the nation's 10th-largest retailer, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell 12 of its stores in Missouri and Kansas to Dillard Department Stores Inc. Terms were not disclosed.   Macy's, whose management has offered to buy the company in a leveraged buyout valued at $3.48 billion, would not comment when asked if the proposed sale was related to the leveraged buyout.

headline: Why Geneva?
abstract: Geneva's role as a gathering point is rooted in the days of John Calvin in the 16th century, when the Reformation attracted Europe's refugees from religious persecution.   Its modern days as a ''city of causes'' began with the establishment of the Red Cross in 1863. Today, Geneva has countless meeting centers and a service industry geared to the business of talk. It is home for the European headquarters of the United Nations, the World Health Organization and the International Labor Organization.

headline: SETBACK SEEN FOR POLICY
abstract: China said this week that the 1985 grain harvest was likely to be about 53 million tons less than the record crop of 407 million tons last year.   It was the largest one-year drop since the Communist takeover in 1949. But there is no food shortage. Granaries across the country have surpluses from last year.

headline: LAW REPEAL URGED FOR SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: A South African Government committee today recommended the abolition of laws that bar blacks from competing on an equal basis in business.   The Economic Committee of the President's Council, an advisory body, condemned the Group Areas Act, which provides for residential segregation, and another law that creates segregated black townships, so-called homelands and business areas.   ''They deny Asian, black and mixed-race businessmen and potential businessmen access to the economically dominant areas of the country,'' the committee said in a report titled ''A Strategy For Small Business Development and For Deregulation.''

headline: Data Bank: December 8, 1985
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: CORPORATE EARNINGS UNEVEN
abstract: Although corporate profits for the third quarter have on the whole been flat to lower, many experts are optimistic about the future outlook.   After falling in each of the four preceding quarters, earnings should begin a period of improving comparisons that could carry through well into next year, several analysts say.   A compilation by The New York Times of 248 companies shows disappointing results are being reported by technology, metals and manufacturing concerns, which are casualties of the strong dollar, low inflation and a soaring trade deficit. By contrast, the beneficiaries of disinflation and falling interest rates, such as banks, insurance companies and utilities, continue to report the favorable results that began three years ago.

headline: PROPERTY MARKET HELPS PACE
abstract: ''MY whole adult life has been in real estate advertising,'' said Milton F. Bagley, the new president of Pace Advertising.   He is 57 years old now, the youngest of the four partners who started the agency. As he sat in his office overlooking the New York Public Library, frequently smiling broadly as he talked about his associates and the people in his business, it was plain he was enjoying his work.   Where once he could go to a party and be pretty much ignored, now his specialty has made him the center of attention. Housing is no longer just for living in. Now, it is for investment, too, and Mr. Bagley said, among the yuppies with their sizable discretionary incomes, it has frequently replaced Wall Street as an investment interest.

headline: SENIOR K.G.B. MAN DEFECTING AGAIN, BACK TO MOSCOW
abstract: Vitaly Yurchenko, a K.G.B. officer described as one of the most senior Russian officials ever to defect to the West, announced today that he was returning to the Soviet Union.   The State Department said Mr. Yurchenko would not be allowed to leave the United States until American authorities had met with him ''in an environment free of Soviet coercion to satisfy ourselves about his real intentions.''   Mr. Yurchenko appeared late this afternoon at a news conference at the Soviet Embassy.   Surrounded by smiling Soviet diplomats, Mr. Yurchenko told reporters he had been kidnapped in Rome last summer by American authorities, drugged and transported to the United States, where he was held prisoner by the Central Intelligence Agency.      Defected in Italy    American officials have said that Mr. Yurchenko defected to the West in Italy three months ago and that he has been giving them information since then at an undisclosed location in the United States.

headline: BRITON TO MEET WITH BEIRUT CAPTORS OF AMERICANS
abstract: Terry Waite, a special representative of the Archbishop of Canterbury, said today that he had made arrangements to talk directly with the captors of four Americans held in Lebanon.   The British mediator said in a statement distributed here to news organizations that he had decided to take the step after he became ''reasonably certain'' that he ''was dealing with the right people.''   Reporters and television crews had gathered in the lobby of the Commodore Hotel in West Beirut expecting Mr. Waite to make an announcement in person. Instead, they were given a brief statement in English that Mr. Waite issued through a Western news agency.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;Tighter Rein Promised For Spendthrift Farm
abstract: The Combs family of Lexington, Ky., knows a bit about bloodstock. And, based  on their recent actions, they are betting that Timothy T. Green does also.         Last Thursday, Leslie Combs 2d and his son Brownell Combs 2d, who together own more than 60 percent of Spendthrift Farm Inc., a publicly held thoroughbred  operation, announced that Mr. Green had been named president and to the newly created position of chief operating officer. A day later they said that negotiations concerning a possible sale of their holdings had been ended.

headline: Dutch Religious Journalist Killed at Dachau Is Beatified
abstract: Pope John Paul II beatified Titus Brandsma, a Dutch religious journalist and priest who died in a Nazi concentration camp, at a ceremony in St. Peter's Basilica today. Beatification is the last step before sainthood in the Roman Catholic Church.

headline: Economic Scene;   The Struggle Over Deficits
abstract: IN the 1985 fiscal year, which ended Sept. 30, the deficits of the Reagan years crossed a bewildering threshold. The four-year, $685 billion accumulation of deficits now exceeds all previous deficits, less periodic surpluses, of the 20th century.   Economists have bewailed such figures since 1981, when Congress and the Reagan Administration ordered income tax cuts without making corresponding cuts in spending. But, for polticians, the budget deficit has been one of those problems, like the condition of the nation's bridges or the proliferation of toxic wastes, that seem too big or too remote to deal with.

headline: YEVTUSHENKO PLAYS REBEL AGAIN, CALLING FOR OPEN SOVIET LITERATURE
abstract: The session was a closed one, but even so the poet's strong words against distortion of history, against censorship, self-flattery, silence and privilege in the world of letters were strikingly bold.   When the poet, Yevgeny Yevtushenko, finished, the congress of Russian writers burst into prolonged applause. Now 52 years old and an honored member of the literary establishment, Mr. Yevtushenko had again taken the mantle of rebel and critic to demand that the candor and openness Mikhail S. Gorbachev has so often discussed be applied to Soviet literature.   ''Today's long-awaited striving for change for the better in our country gives us profound hopes that self-flattery will be forever rejected, and that nonconcealment will become the norm of civic behavior,'' he said. ''We, men of letters, will not be worth a penny if we simply report and laud the social transformations taking place independently of us.''

headline: BUSH CALLS ON SOVIET TO IMITAT CHINA
abstract: Vice President Bush concluded a tour of China today with a call to the Soviet Union to adopt economic changes similar to those that have been proclaimed in China.

headline: Austrian Security Steps
abstract: The Austrian Interior Minister, Karl Blecha, announced new anti-terrorism measures today that are to be introduced at the country's five international airports. Advanced X-ray machines will be installed to screen luggage for weapons or explosives, and plainclothes guards will assist uniformed officers in patrolling airport lounges, a ministry spokesman said.

headline: MALTESE REPORTED TO HAVE BARRED ROLE FOR U.S. OFFICERS IN JET RAID
abstract: The Maltese Government prevented a United States general and two other senior American military officers from playing any role in the Egyptian commando assault on a hijacked Egyptair jet last Sunday, a Maltese source and officials in Washington said today.   The three officers had been flown to Malta with the commandos last Sunday, a day after the airliner on an Athens-to-Cairo flight was hijacked by men who initially identified themselves as members of a group called Egypt's Revolution.   Fifty-seven people aboard the plane died in the Egyptian operation, leading to questions about whether the commandos bungled the job by using too powerful an explosive to blast into the plane.

headline: Deutsche Bank
abstract: Deutsche Bank, West Germany's largest bank, announced yesterday that it was raising almost $400 million from shareholders in the biggest capital-raising operation in the country's history. The bank said it was offering shareholders the opportunity to buy one new share for every 15 already owned, at a price of $170 each, well below the current market price of $258.

headline: INDUSTRIAL COOPERATIVES: THE BENEFITS AND PITFALLS
abstract: While condominiums and co-ops have become the norm in New York's residential market, and office condominiums have started to catch on in recent years, the joint ownership of industrial buildings by small businesses throughout the city is rare.   Even so, the city's Office of Business Development, backed by the recommendations of Interface, a nonprofit, independent research group, believes that industrial cooperatives, condominiums and partnerships can help - on a limited basis - to save some of the city's 430,000 remaining industrial jobs.   ''We're not saying this is any sort of panacea,'' said Barbara Bantivoglio director of management and planning for the Office of Business Development. ''We're looking at this as one possible option to stabilize various groups in the city.''

headline: LONG-TERM BOND PRICES RISE
abstract: Prices in the long-term bond market overcame some carryover selling yesterday, and resumed their advance. Short-term interest rates were basically unchanged.   Corporate bonds posted small gains in light trading, while the tax-exempt market marked time, as it awaited a record volume of offerings next week.   Dealers in government securities attributed early weakness to a negative interpretation of the latest figures on nonfarm employment, a higher-than-expected rise in the weekly M-1 money supply figure and a firm overnight interbank lending rate.

headline: LIST OF PASSENGERS AND CREW MEMBERS ON EGYPTIAN PLANE
abstract: Following is a list of those aboard Egyptair Flight 648 when it was hijacked Saturday in Greek airspace and flown to Malta. The list was released by the Greek authorities today before the plane was stormed by Egyptian commandos. Some names and ages differ from those given by other sources.   American BAKER, Scott Patrick, 28, headed for Cairo NINK, Jackie, 30, headed for Cairo ROGENKAMS, Scarlett, 38, headed for Cairo Australian FISHER, Elizabeth, 22, headed for Cairo LYONS, Albert Roystan Anthony, 46, headed for Cairo Belgian DE LAET, Alfons Philippe, 39, headed for the United Arab Emirates Canadian LEONARD, Jarret Andrew, 1, headed for Saudi Arabia LEONARD, June Yalinda, 27, headed for Saudi Arabia Egyptian ABDEL, Ahmed Yunis Mohammed Hady, 51, headed for Cairo ABDEL KAWY, Salah ABDEL WAHED, Tuni ABDUL RAHMAN, Mohammed AHLAM, Abdel Rahman, 31, headed for Cairo AHMED, Hamdah AHMED, Nabil AHMED, Peim AHMED, Wessam AHMED, Zakya CHODRIAL, Refaat Lovetana, 20, headed for Cairo DIRAZ, Mohammed Elham, 30, headed for Cairo ELSHERKEWI, A. A. FARUK, Nabil FUAD, Mahmud Ahmed, 23, headed for Cairo GHOBRIAL HAMED, Hamed Elpin Facker Mohammed Salah, 45, headed for Cairo HAMES, Miysser HUSSEIN, Abdel Latif Samir el-Abady, 48, headed for Cairo HUSSEIN, Ahmed Mohammed, 43, headed for Cairo HUSSEIN IBRAHIM, Imam Ali, 50, headed for Cairo IBRAHIM, Ashraf Mohammed ISMAIL, Mahmud Maha, 27, headed for Cairo KAMEL, Medhat Mustafa MOSTAFA, Abdel-Ali Foad, 3 months, headed for Cairo MUSAFA, Ahmed SAYED, Ibrahim Ahmed, 34, headed for Cairo EL-SHAMY, Ibrahim Mahmud, 33, headed for Cairo EL-SHESHTAWY, Hassan YUSEF, Faheam Hashem, 51, headed for Cairo Israeli ARTZI, Tamar, 24, headed for Bangkok MENDELSON, Nitzan, 23, headed for Bangkok French BRIARD, Georges Gilbert, 36, headed for Bangkok Ghanaian OCRAN, Peter Djan John, 33, headed for Japan Greek ASLANIDES, Pavlos Michael GEORGIADES, Alexandros Anthimios HALARIS, Ioannis Iakovos HOULIARIS, Ioannis Athanassios KAITSOPOULOUS, Lambros Georgios KALYVAS, Andreas Elias KORTEZIS, Ioannis LIAPIKOS, Georgios Theodoros MEMETOGLOU, Bilal Memet PANERIS, Ioannis Nikolaos PANOS, Christos Constantine ROUSSEAS, Elias Stassinos SVENTERIKOS, Stylianos Dimitrios TSAVDARIS, Nikolaos Athanassios TSOUMAS, Ioannis Dimitrios VENTOURIS, Georgios Stavros VOULGARIS, Dimitrios Anastassios Mexican PALLAS de ORTIZ PINEDO GUADALUPE, Salvador, 59, headed for Cairo PALLAS ORTIZ de PINEDO, Oskar, 26, headed for Cairo Moroccan BOU SAID NOV al-DIN, Muhamt, 23, headed for Cairo CHAKORE, Salem Salah, 25, headed for Cairo Philippine ALONZO, Joselito, 17, headed for Manila BAES, Enrique, 28, headed for Manila BATUIGAS BONIFACIO, Presilias F. CABALAN, Benjael, 36, headed for Manila CARTILA, Noel, 27, headed for Manila CLEMENTE, Cabatic CONALO CORWELIO CRUS, Dela INTING, Ruperto, 24, headed for Manila LIAGAS, Charlie, 25, headed for Manila MARLONI, Cata MOLTES MONTOVA, Pominador, 36, headed for Manila PABAISO PERALTA, Teddoro, 33, headed for Manila SOLANO, Jesusia, 35, headed for Manila SUMIRAN, Pablito, 26, headed for Manila VALTES YANNA Spanish BRUGERA, Marta, 28, headed for Bangkok Tunisian MARZOUKI, Ali Amor, 22, headed for Egypt Crew Members ATIA, Asnean, stewardess BAHY, Fimad, co-pilot CACAMA, Chadia, steward EL-DERBY, Hawaa, hostess GALAL, Hani, captain MABROOK, Hanan, hostess Security Policemen ABDEL RAOUF, Tagreet AHMED, Abdalla AHMED, Aymen AHMED, Iman

headline: BUSINES DIGEST: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 13, 1985
abstract: Companies G.E. said it could take a year to complete its merger with RCA. The comment sent RCA shares skidding by $4.25 a share, to $59.25, well below the $66.50 offering price. Trading was extremely heavy as investors, unwilling to tie up their money that long, sold the stock. G.E. said it would take time to arrange $4 billion or more of financing and to get regulatory approvals for the merger. [Page D10.]  Grant Tinker, the head of NBC, said the resources of the merged company could speed the network's progress, including the possible development of a 24-hour cable news operation. [D10.]  The Big Board is investigating trading in RCA and G.E. stocks before the merger was announced. [D11.]  It took just 36 days h for G.E. and RCA to forge their multibillion-dollar merger, beginning with a meeting of the chairmen of G.E. and RCA at the Upper East Side apartment of Felix Rohatyn. [A1.]  GAF sweetened the terms of its bid for Union Carbide by offering $68 a share in cash for all outstanding shares and by no longer requiring that Carbide's board approve the deal. [D1.]  Oppenheimer & Company officers are discussing buying the investment banking and brokerage house back from Mercantile Holdings of London, according to sources close to both companies. [D1.]  Nippon Oil delayed plans to explore some Texaco oilfields because of Texaco's legal battle with Pennzoil. The action symbolized the concern felt by Texaco's lenders, suppliers and partners.

headline: PROTEST ON ANTI-SAKHAROV LETTER CLOUDS NOBEL CEREMONY IN OSLO
abstract: A dispute swirled today on the eve of the 1985 Nobel Peace Prize ceremony over criticism of the personal physician of Soviet leaders for having signed a joint letter in 1973 denouncing Andrei D. Sakharov.   The Kremlin physician, Dr. Yevgeny I. Chazov, 56 years old, and Dr. Bernard Lown, 64, of the Harvard School of Public Health, have been invited to accept the prize Tuesday on behalf of International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War, a Boston-based group they founded in 1980. The two men are its co-presidents.      Ceremony Boycotted    Because of the information brought to light about Dr. Chazov, the United States and West Germany have instructed their ambassadors to stay away from the ceremony, and Britain is reported to have protested to the Norwegian Nobel Committee.

headline: 2 BUSINESS GROUPS SPLIT OVER HOUSE TAX PLAN
abstract: Two prominent business groups today took opposing sides on the tax revision package produced by the House Ways and Means Committee. Both sides promised a fierce lobbying battle in the next three weeks as the bill moves to a vote on the House floor.   The Chamber of Commerce of the United States, reflecting the view of many capital-intensive businesses that would be hurt by a sharp cutback in investment incentives under the House plan, urged President Reagan and Congress to scrap any further talk of tax revision.   Meanwhile, the Tax Reform Action Coalition, an ad hoc group of corporations and industry groups including the General Motors Corporation and the International Business Machines Corporation, declared its support for the House tax package. This group mainly represents high-tech and service corporations that now can take little advantage of the investment incentives and thus end up paying taxes close to the statutory 46 percent rate.

headline: Advertising;   Loss for D.D.B.
abstract: The Doyle Dane Bernbach Group has released its third-quarter financial statement. And although revenues were up 6.5 percent, to $49.4 million, from $46.4 million in the quarter last year, the agency lost $691,000, compared with a $651,000 loss in the 1984 period.

headline: 2 CANADIAN PLAN UNITS ATTRACT BID
abstract: A European investment group has offered $300 million (Canadian) for two aircraft manufacturers owned by the Canadian Government, it said yesterday. Several other offers are expected in the next few days, the Government added, perhaps including one from the Boeing Company. No date for a decision has been set.

headline: Mexico Shifts On Oil Prices
abstract: Mexico, the biggest single supplier of oil to the United States, announced today that it was raising the price of light crude by an average of 60 cents a barrel. The price of heavy crude will fall an average of 40 cents.

headline: Todd Rival in Aro Bid
abstract: The Todd Shipyards Corporation disclosed Friday, in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, that the Aro Corporation had another corporate suitor when it agreed to be acquired by Todd. The rival, not identified, made a bid on Sept. 10 for less than the $35 a share offered by Todd, according to information Todd said it received from Aro. Todd said Aro considered the offer too low.

headline: ISRAELIS DESCRIBE HEARING MESSAGES OF DIVERTED JET
abstract: Two Israeli airline pilots said today that they picked up radio messages from the pilot of an Egyptian airliner with four Palestinian hijackers aboard as the airliner was being intercepted by American Navy jets.   An El Al Israel Airlines plane flying to Israel from Madrid picked up a radio call from the Egyptair Boeing to the control tower in Athens at 11:45 P.M. Thursday night that said: ''Two military jet fighters are intercepting us and directing us toward Italy.''   The Greeks apparently had trouble comprehending the message. They did not immediately respond and after a brief radio silence called for a repetition, the pilots said.

headline: CHARLES DOUGLAS-HOME, 48, EDITOR OF TIMES OF LONDON
abstract: Charles Douglas-Home, the editor of The Times of London, died yesterday of cancer. He was 48 years old.         Mr. Douglas-Home led his newspaper to large circulation gains, although some  of the tactics he used aroused controversy. He made the once-staid Times a frothier paper, splashing pictures of the Princess of Wales on the front page at regular intervals, introducing gossipy features and running circulation-building giveaway games.

headline: U.S.-E.E.C. STEEL PACT IS CLEARED BY BRITAIN
abstract: The European Economic Community said today that Britain had lifted its objections to a proposed accord limiting the community's steel exports to the United States, clearing the way for the four-year pact to be approved by the Europeans.   Officials of the Common Market said the accord, which limits carbon and certain other steel shipments to six million tons a year, could receive formal ratification when ministers of the trade group meet on Monday. Britain was the last of the 10 Common Market countries to agree to the pact.

headline: Advertising;   TBWA Adds G.Q.
abstract: Conde Nast Publications, which a year ago retained TBWA Advertising to promote its recently acquired Gourmet magazine, must have liked the job it did because it has just moved in a second assignment. It is for both trade and consumer promotion for Gentlemen's Quarterly magazine, which had been assigned to Chalk, Nissan, Hanft.

headline: LAXALT REPORTS PLEDGES BY MARCOS ON POLITICAL AND MILITARY CHANGES
abstract: Senator Paul Laxalt said today that President Ferdinand E. Marcos had agreed to permit American observers at Philippine elections in 1986 and 1987, and to relax his control over the Philippine military.   Mr. Laxalt, who reported to President Reagan today on his informal diplomatic mission last week, said in a statement that the promises were ''positive steps'' toward the political and military initiatives urged by the Administration.   ''We now have a base line from which future reforms can be assessed,'' said Mr. Laxalt, a Nevada Republican.      'No Hostile Messages'    Mr. Laxalt said that contrary to what some Administration officials had earlier told reporters, ''there were no hostile messages delivered on my part, and there was no rejection of our views on President Marcos's part.''

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: AROUND THE WORLD, STOCK EXCHANGES MARK A STRONG YEAR
abstract: Investors will have fond memories of the final quarter of 1985, not only in the United States where Wall Street staged a historic rally, but also in continental Europe and elsewhere where the price of equities was helped by falling interest rates, the weaker dollar and by signs that long-suffering local economies were reviving.   Around the world stock prices rose about 13 percent during the last period of 1985, bringing the full-year gain to about 34 percent, according to the Capital International World Index.   It was a year when it was difficult to find a stock market that performed badly, and of all the major and minor exchanges followed by Capital International only shares on the Singapore/Malaysian exchanges declined. Frankfurt showed the best rise of the major exchanges, and Mexico led the smaller exchanges with a 124 percent gain for the year.      Pockets of Softness    There were pockets of softness in the worldwide equity market, especially where declining oil prices or political and social unrest became a factor.

headline: MARCOS DECLARES HE'LL CALL A VOTE EARLY NEXT YEAR
abstract: President Ferdinand E. Marcos announced today that he intended to call for an early presidential election to settle what he called a ''silly claim'' that his Government is inept.   His announcement in an American television interview followed pressure from Washington for changes in his country's policies, and seemed to reverse earlier assertions that he planned to serve out his six-year term, which ends in 1987, without an election.   After the interview on the ABC program ''This Week,'' he told reporters he would like to begin the campaign in December and hold the vote on Jan. 17.

headline: Patents;  Fingerprint Processor Eliminates Distortion
abstract: Fingermatrix Inc. of North White Plains, N.Y., received a patent this week on a fingerprint-processing apparatus.

headline: THATCHER AFFIRMS ECONOMIC POLICIES
abstract: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, in the face of doubts within her party, today reaffirmed the economic policies that have guided her Government.   Her steadfastness came in the face of a warning from a senior Cabinet member, Energy Secretary Peter Walker, that a failure to deal with unemployment would be ''political suicide'' for the Conservative Party.   Closing the party's annual conference here, the Prime Minister insisted that no problem ''occupies more of my thinking'' than unemployment. Then, in a voice that was pitched to sound patient but sometimes came across as slightly vexed, she catalogued her Government's efforts to speed job creation.

headline: Gen. Heinz Hoffmann, Builder of Berlin Wall
abstract: Gen. Heinz Hoffmann, longtime Defense Minister of East Germany who in the 1960's was in charge of building the Berlin wall, died of heart failure today, the East German press agency reported.

headline: Norelco and Oster Ad Accord Set
abstract: The manufacturers of Norelco and Oster air cleaners have agreed not to misrepresent the ability of their products to eliminate indoor air pollution, the Federal Trade Commission announced. The commission had contended that Norelco Clean Air Machines, made by the North American Philips Corporation, and Oster brand air cleaners, made by the Sunbeam Corporation, do not effectively eliminate significant amounts of air pollution and that advertising for the products was false and misleading.   Without admitting guilt, both companies signed consent orders with the commission promising not to misrepresent their products.

headline: MECHANICAL DEVICE HARVESTS CRAYFISH
abstract: A crayfish harvester, the first mechanical device for this purpose, is the subject of a patent awarded this week to Robert J. Edling and Karl L. Morgan of the agricultural engineering department at Louisiana State University in Baton Rouge.

headline: Burkina Faso Agrees To a Truce With Mali
abstract: Burkina Faso and Mali have agreed to a truce in their five-day-old border conflict, according to official radio reports today from both countries.   The Foreign Ministers of the two countries met in Abidjan with ministers from five other West African nations to try to end the fighting.

headline: Write-Downs By Phillips
abstract: The Phillips Petroleum Company said yesterday that it would incur an after-tax charge of about $350 million against fourth-quarter earnings to provide for write-downs of minerals and chemicals assets.   The write-downs in the minerals businesses, which include uranium, coal and oil shale properties, will total about $188 million.

headline: Tin Halt Is Extended
abstract: The London Metal Exchange on Friday extended its suspension of tin trading until Dec. 16 to give the International Tin Council and its creditors more time to resolve a six-week crisis. Michael Brown, the exchange's chief executive, said the exchange would decide at a meeting on Monday when the tin market should reopen.

headline: FIGHTERS DIVERT IT TO NATO BASE IN ITALY; GUNMEN FACE TRIAL IN SLAYING OF HOSTAGE
abstract: An Egyptian plane carrying the hijackers of an Italian cruise ship was intercepted by American Navy jets as it flew toward Tunisia Thursday night and was forced to land in Italy, the White House announced. A spokesman said the four terrorists had been taken into custody by Italian authorities.   In a late evening news conference, Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, said President Reagan had ordered the dramatic military action after learning that Egypt had turned down repeated American pleas to prosecute the four gunmen and was flying them to freedom. The hijackers are believed to have killed an elderly American tourist aboard the cruise ship.      No Shots Fired    The United States intends to seek ''the prompt extradition'' of the hijackers from Italy, Mr. Speakes said. Later, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said the United States hoped the Italians would waive their right to try the hijackers and would allow them to be prosecuted in the United States.

headline: Martens and His Cabinet Are Installed in Belgium
abstract: Prime Minister Wilfried Martens was sworn in today as head of the country's 33d postwar Government, which closely resembles the previous Government.   The ministers took their oath of office at the royal palace shortly after Mr. Martens, whose four-party coalition has been in power since 1981, reached agreement with his coalition partners on the Government portfolios.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: U.S. Joins Companies In Program
abstract: In a joint approach to providing technical assistance to developing countries, the Government and more than a dozen American corporations have been training hundreds of telecommunications managers and engineers from abroad.   The United States Telecommunications Training Institute, a joint venture of the Federal Government, 17 American telecommunications companies and other private-sector sponsors, was created in 1982 and recently produced its 500th graduate.   The institute has no campus or teachers of its own. Instead, the companies - among them AT&T International, International Business Machines, ITT and Western Union - assign instructors from their own ranks and offer the courses at their corporate training centers around the country. The corporate sponsors thereby bear the burden of about two-thirds of the institute's costs.

headline: 900 G.E. Jobs To Be Ended
abstract: The General Electric Company said today that it would eliminate 900 manufacturing jobs at its Appliance Park complex and buy room air-conditioners from an outside supplier.   The outside sourcing program will begin in late 1986 and expand to include ''all of the Louisville-produced models by the end of 1987,'' G.E. said.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    * British Petroleum Company P.L.C. announced Monday that it was arranging a $1.5 billion, 7-year committed credit facility and an uncommitted 7-year credit facility of approximately $5 billion, through British Petroleum Finance International Ltd., which has approached a number of banks. The financing program will be used to replace existing credit, and for ''backstop or standby purposes,'' a B.P. official said.    * Carter Hawley Hale Stores is offering $150 million of 11 percent notes due 1995 at a price of 98.575 to yield 11.241 percent through Morgan Stanley & Company. The notes are rated Baa-3 by Moody's and BB- by Standard & Poor's.

headline: IN QUOTES
abstract: ''People pay attention to the round numbers. It's just a tradition, like New Year's Eve.''      Robert Colby   Smith Barney, Harris Upham, on the Dow passing 1,400.

headline: Empire Chairman Sees Key Role at Piedmont
abstract: When Paul Quackenbush, the chairman and president of Empire Airlines Inc., was in the Navy as a diver he used the extra hazard pay he received to pay for flying lessons off base. ''I was always interested in flying,'' the 49-year-old founder of Empire said in an interview.   Last week Piedmont Airlines took over his airline, which he had built into one of the largest regional carriers in the Northeast.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: U.N. REFUGEE AGENCY WARNS OF MONEY CRISIS
abstract: The office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, citing a severe financial crisis, will appeal for urgent contributions from donor nations at a pledging conference to be held in New York next Friday.   The 35-year-old agency, which says it has assisted about 25 million people, has said it is in its worst financial crisis ever, with a budget shortfall that by the end of this year will be about $40 million.   ''We are up against the wall,'' said the High Commissioner, Poul Hartling of Denmark, in a recent interview. ''We are not crying wolf; it is a bad situation.''

headline: LIMITED EXPECTED TO ASQUIRE BENDEL
abstract: Henri Bendel, the West 57th Street store revered by many as the epitome of New York chic, is about to be acquired by The Limited Inc., a Columbus, Ohio, retail chain, sources familiar with the negotiations said yesterday.   The sources added that the talks were in their final stages and that an announcement could come as soon as this weekend.   The purchase of Bendel would represent a second major move into the New York market by The Limited this year. The company is about to open a large store on Madison Avenue.

headline: Eli Lilly Posts Gain of 9.3%
abstract: Eli Lilly & Company, a worldwide maker of drugs, reported yesterday that its earnings in the third quarter of 1985 rose 9.3 percent, to $122.1 million, or $1.75 a share, from $111.7 million, or $1.53 a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 10.6 percent, to $787.9 million, from $712.6 million.

headline: DRAFT OF REAGAN BUDGET FOR 1987 SEES END TO I.C.C. AFTER 100 YEARS
abstract: President Reagan's draft budget for the fiscal year 1987 would reduce the staff of the Social Security Administration, abolish the Interstate Commerce Commission and end Federal support for the agricultural Extension Service.   The commerce commission, established in 1887, is the oldest Federal regulatory agency. The Extension Service gives technical and scientific advice to farmers across the country.   Administration officials, giving details of these proposals today in interviews, said they were part of a package of $50 billion in spending cuts and fee increases needed to hold the 1987 deficit to $144 billion, the maximum allowed by a new law. The law is designed to balance the budget by 1991.

headline: Middle South Utilities To Get New Chairman
abstract: Middle South Utilities, the nation's fifth-largest electric utility holding company, announced late yesterday that Floyd W. Lewis, its 60-year-old chairman, chief executive and president, will retire Dec. 1.   Mr. Lewis, who has held his posts since 1970, underwent heart bypass surgery on Sept. 20, and is now underoing cardiac rehabilitation.

headline: REAGAN BACKS EFFORT TO REPEAL U.N. VOTE ATTACKING ZIONISM
abstract: On the tenth anniversary of the passage of a General Assembly resolution equating Zionism with racism, President Reagan sent a message to a conference here today saying he would support any move to repeal it.         ''Few events have so offended the American people as the 'Zionism is racism'  resolution of November 10, 1975,'' the President said in his message to the Conference on Israel, Zionism and the United Nations.

headline: Falkland Islanders Will Vote For a New Legislature Today
abstract: Voters in the Falklands, the islands Britain and Argentina fought over in 1982, will elect a new legislative council Thursday.   A new constitution that explicitly refers to the right of all peoples to self-determination comes into force with the new council. ''We have a safeguard in this stipulation,'' said John Cheek, who is seeking re-election.

headline: Pay TV Job For Cappadona
abstract: Cappadona Mosier & Partners has been named advertising agency for Request Television, a pay-per-view cable service that will begin service on Nov. 28.   It is the creation of Jeffrey C. Reiss, former head of both Showtime and Cable Health Network.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 24, 1985
abstract: The Economy    A rise in September's consumer prices will mean more money for tens of millions of Americans next year because of laws adjusting Social Security and the Federal income tax for inflation. But the 0.2 percent rise means the smallest increase in payments to Social Security, 3.1 percent, since the payments were ''indexed'' in 1972. A median-income family of four will save $81 in taxes. [Page D1.]  Costs in the New York-northeastern New Jersey region rose 0.4 percent. [D6.]  Durable goods orders fell 1.1 percent in September, continuing a seesaw pattern affected by the military category. [D6.]    The Ways and Means Committee voted to limit a tax shelter enjoyed by big banks. The House panel also planned weekend meetings that could make or break the push for tax revision. [D1.]

headline: Supply of Tax-Exempt Issues Soars
abstract: The supply of new tax-exempt bonds is surging, as local governments strive to sell issues that could be banned after the end of the year by changes in the Federal tax law. The result, according to many analysts, is that yields of tax-exempt bond are unusually attractive compared with bonds, whose interest is taxable.   According to Salomon Brothers, more than $4 billion of tax-exempt issues are scheduled for sale this week, with sizable offerings of hospital, electric power and housing revenue bonds. At Goldman, Sachs & Company, officials estimated they would manage the sale of $1.6 billion of new issues - a single-week record for the firm.

headline: Market Place;   Semiconductor Rise Expected
abstract: THE semiconductor industry has suffered heavy losses, intense Japanese competition, severe price cutting and depleted revenues -enough to make any stockholder consider throwing in the towel. But shares of the five biggest chip producers - Advanced Micro Devices, Intel, Motorola, National Semiconductor and Texas Instruments - have outperformed the overall stock market in recent weeks.   Although fears abound when it comes to considering these volatile and admittedly risky stocks, there lurks another anxiety on the part of some money managers and traders, namely, missing any upside explosion.   These professionals remember the run-up in semiconductor stocks from the start of the bull market in August 1982 to January 1984. The group soared 230 percent, while the Standard & Poor's index of 400 industrial stocks rose 67 percent.

headline: BRIDGING THE GAP IN NETWORKS
abstract: THE whole point of personal computing is independence. One person, one machine and the freedom to get the work done -when and in the manner required - are the PC's raison d'etre. There is no scheduling time on a mainframe, no waiting for programmers, no waiting for anyone or anything, in fact.   So, why are more and more personal computers being linked to each other by various networks?

headline: NOW, TEXACO FACES LOSS OF CONFIDENCE
abstract: Texaco's investors grew nervous after the company's president, Alfred C. DeCrane Jr., said it might consider bankruptcy proceedings as an ''extreme step'' because of the costs associated with the $10.53 billion judgment against it in the Pennzoil case. Until all appeals are exhausted, the big oil company could be forced to post a $12 billion bond and set aside interest costs amounting to as much as $3 million a day. Such huge expenses make investors jittery, especially because Texaco has about $8 billion in debt outstanding from its acquisition of Getty Oil - the acquisition that resulted in Pennzoil's suit.   Although Texaco has tried to calm customers and investors, its stock price had continued to fall, and overseas investors as well are starting to have doubts about the safety of Texaco securities. They worry that dealing with the judgment could divert Texaco's management and resources from day-to-day operations, with a resultant weakening of the company.

headline: TAX BILL'S DATES SPUR WARINESS
abstract: With work on tax-overhaul legislation far behind schedule, it appears that businesses and individuals will be forced to manage their financial affairs under a cloud of uncertainty after Jan. 1.         That cloud arises from the Jan. 1 effective dates the House Ways and Means Committee has assigned to most provisions in the comprehensive tax-revision package it is drafting. The House is expected to vote on the bill in December, but Senate consideration is not scheduled to start until next year, with final passage of a House-Senate conference bill predicted in the spring or summer.

headline: BELGIUM IS SHAKEN BY BOMBS AND 'CRAZY KILLERS'
abstract: A spate of banditry and terrorism has shaken this normally tranquil, relatively prosperous country of 10 million to its core.   On Wednesday Prime Minister Wilfried Martens, whose center-right Government was re-elected last month, placed six companies of the Belgian Army - about 1,000 soldiers - at the disposal of the police to help thwart terrorism and other crimes.   The Government also increased security at embassies, public buildings and big businesses for President Reagan's visit to brief Western allies on the Geneva summit meeting. Nonetheless, a terrorist group known as the Fighting Communist Cells exploded a bomb at Motorola's European headquarters in Brussels, causing heavy damage.

headline: Fiat-Ford Talks
abstract: Talks over merging Italy's Fiat and Ford's European subsidiary have run into trouble but are continuing despite the snags, a Fiat spokesman said.

headline: Moroccan King in Paris; Mideast Is Likely Topic
abstract: King Hassan II of Morocco arrived today for a three-day official visit that is expected to focus partly on the King's role in the Middle East peace process.   The King was greeted at Orly Airport by President Francois Mitterrand.   In two meetings with Mr. Mitterrand, King Hassan is also expected to discuss the economic ramifications of the entry Jan. 1 of Spain and Portugal into the European Economic Community, which is likely to hurt Moroccan agricultural exports to Europe.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Iraqis Report Raid on Kharg
abstract: Iraq said today that its planes had raided Iran's Kharg Island oil terminal after a weekend lull. There was no independent confirmation. The air attack was  the 29th reported against Kharg since mid-August.

headline: Punjab Leader Elected President of Sikh Party
abstract: Chief Minister Surjit Singh Barnala of Punjab State, a moderate, was unanimously elected today as president of the Akali Dal, the main Sikh political party.

headline: NET INCOME RISES 23.9% AT G.M.
abstract: The General Motors Corporation today reported a 23.9 percent gain in profits, but a costly sales incentive program and ambitious capital spending left the No. 1 auto maker with an operating loss in the third quarter.   G.M.'s net income was $516.5 million, or $1.46 a share, compared with $416.8 million, or $1.31 a share, during a troubled third quarter last year. However, this year's high costs created an operating loss of $21 million, compared with operating income of $307 million a year ago.   The last time General Motors reported an operating loss was in the third quarter of 1982, when it had net earnings of $129 million.

headline: U.S. TO SEEK UNITARY TAX BAN
abstract: President Reagan announced today that he would ask Congress to prohibit states from taxing multinational corporations on profits earned outside the United States.   The announcement, which represented a reversal of the position Mr. Reagan took when he was Governor of California and during his first term as President, was intended to ease an embarrassing conflict with Britain and other trading partners.   The move was sharply criticized by a dozen senators and organizations representing governors and state legslatures as an intrusion into the states' prerogative to set their own tax policies.

headline: TERRORISTS REPORTEDLY TRAINED IN IRAN
abstract: The head of Italian military intelligence said in a newspaper interview published today that four terrorists who killed 12 people at the Rome Airport on Friday had been trained in Iran and entered Italy by way of Syria.   The intelligence chief, Adm. Fulvio Martini, said the four were followers of Abu Nidal, the renegade Palestinian leader.   The Ministry of Defense, in what was seen by diplomats as an effort to distance itself from the assertion, said later that the remarks ''do not express the thought of the Government.''   But Western diplomats here said the consensus among intelligence officials was that Iran had indeed played a role in training the terrorists.

headline: $618 Million Bond Issue From County in Texas
abstract: Harris County, Tex., and the Port of Houston Authority situated in that county are revamping their finances with a new $618 million bond issue that will be used to refund all their previously issued bonds.   Tentative interest rates on the new bonds were announced yesterday by underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company. For unlimited tax bonds, yields ranged from 5.60 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 7.40 percent in 1990, 8.60 percent in 1995, 9.20 percent in 2000 and 9.50 percent in 2006. Yields were higher by one-tenth of a percentage point for a companion issue of limited tax bonds.

headline: LEADERS OF SIX NATIONS TELL OF THEIR HOPES AND WORRIES
abstract: FINLAND Mauno Koivisto President A Question: Is World A Better Place? The President of Finland, Mauno Koivisto, told the General Assembly of his concerns about global security and nuclear warfare.   ''Many questions haunt us at this anniversary celebration: Do we live today in a better world than we did 40 years ago?'' he said.   ''Is there now less violence and warfare? Is there less human suffering in the world? Do the nations feel more secure and confident in their future?''

headline: Kaiser Aluminum
abstract: The British investor, Alan Clore, has joined a group of investors led by J. A. Frates in seeking control of the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation. According to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Clore has agreed to contribute ''at least $10 million'' to a new partnership with KACC Associates, based in Tulsa, Okla., and controlled by Mr. Frates. The new partnership holds 3.17 percent of Kaiser's shares outstanding.

headline: Capital Plan For Mission
abstract: The Mission Insurance Group Inc. today announced an agreement in principle with the California Insurance Department to allow Carl H. Lindner, Mission's chairman and largest shareholder, to inject an additional $125 million in capital into its Mission American Insurance Company subsidiary.   If approved, the plan would allow Mission American to reinsure the direct liability, property and workers' compensation policies of its insolvent Mission Insurance Company.

headline: SPY SCANDAL LOOSE ENDS
abstract: Israel's explanations thus far of how one of its senior officials became involved with the spy suspect Jonathan Jay Pollard leave many important questions unanswered.   Most of these questions revolve around the degree of ministerial responsibility for Israel's purported espionage operation in Washington.   To put it simply: Was this reported spying affair an act of the Israeli Government, or was it the work of a ''loose cannon'' in Israel's intelligence apparatus?   The answer to this question relates to the even larger issue of American-Israeli relations: Was the Israeli Government, as a Government, involved in a potentially hostile act against the United States, its closest ally?      U.S.-Israeli Relationship    Or, was a senior Israeli official acting on his own initiative running an espionage mission in the United States unbeknownst to the Israeli Cabinet?   In addition, the espionage affair raises the issue of the precise character of the American-Israeli relationship. Is it a relationship purely between two sovereign nations or is it a relationship between members of the same family?

headline: COMMONWEALTH LEADERS AGREE ON SANCTIONS AGAINST SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: Commonwealth leaders agreed tonight to impose limited economic sanctions against South Africa and to set up a group to try to persuade the Pretoria Government to negotiate with black leaders on ending apartheid.   The agreement gave South Africa six months to ''bring about concrete progress'' or face tougher sanctions, including a ban on airline flights.   Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, who initially had opposed economic sanctions, said tonight: ''It was worth paying some price to keep the Commonwealth together. It was hard going.'' Britain is South Africa's main trading partner.

headline: Protesters Battle Police In South Korean Capital
abstract: Hundreds of anti-Government protesters clashed with riot policemen at a university and in the streets of Seoul today, and about 20 people were arrested, witnesses said.   The protesters shouted slogans demanding the resignation of President Chun Doo Hwan and hurled stones at the police, who responded by firing tear gas.   At Hanyang University in Seoul, the police battled students demanding the release of 191 protesters arrested Monday after occupying and damaging a training center operated by the ruling Democratic Justice Party.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Mandela to Undergo Surgery, Family Says
abstract: Nelson Mandela, the jailed black nationalist leader, will undergo surgery within the next two weeks to remove an enlarged prostate gland, his family's lawyer said today.   The lawyer, Ismail M. Ayob, said in a statement that Mr. Mandela, 67 years old, was examined last Sunday at Volks Hospital in Cape Town by a team of three private doctors, including a urologist, chosen by his family. Mr. Mandela's wife, Winnie, and one of his daughters, Zinzi, accompanied the doctors to the hospital.

headline: 3 More Markets For Sears Card
abstract: The credit card subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck & Company announced that it would introduce its Discover credit card in the Denver, Milwaukee and Albany-Schenectady-Troy areas on Dec. 29.

headline: ONTARIO ANNOUNCES PROGRAM TO SHARPLY CURTAIL ACID RAIN
abstract: Ontario Province in Canada, in a step that would significantly reduce acid rain in New York State and New England, announced a program today to curtail sulfur dioxide pollution sharply.   At a news conference in Toronto that was shared with Washington by closed circuit television, Environment Minister Jim Bradley of Ontario, said the province's four biggest industrial sources of sulfur dioxide had been ordered to reduce their emissions to 665,000 metric tons by 1994 from 1.9 million metric tons.   Ontario's action is part of an overall Canadian program to reduce the sources of acid rain. In Canada, the provinces have the major responsibility for environmental protection.

headline: School Bond Issue By Pennsylvania
abstract: The Pennsylvania State Public School Building Authority, the financing arm for 235 school districts throughout the state, is offering $268.4 million of school lease revenue bonds to refund $335 million of similar bonds sold in 1984.   Underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company tentatively priced the new issue to yield from 5 3/4 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 7.20 percent in 1990, 8.20 percent in 1995 and 8.70 percent in 2000.

headline: WHERE IS THE WEALTH? U.S. HOLDINGS ARE CITED
abstract: Soon after the death of Fan Fox Samuels, a New York philanthropist, in 1981, her husband put up for sale her large collection of furnishings and English antiques. The sale was to be handled by an auction house, but before any auction could be held a buyer with wide knowledge of English antiques bought the entire collection for more than $4.5 million.   According to four associates of the Samuels family, the buyer was Imelda Marcos, the First Lady of the Philippines. The collection was bought through an import-export company and transferred to a New York residence, according to one Samuels associate.

headline: ASSAM VOTES QUIETLY 2 YEARS AFTER RIOTS
abstract: As tens of thousands of policemen and paramilitary troopers kept watch, the residents of Assam turned out in large numbers today to vote in a statewide election that is seen as a crucial test for Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's political control over the state.   Election officials said that the balloting was peaceful and that most results would be announced Tuesday.   ''Barring a few, stray, minor incidents, the entire process has been completed peacefully,'' P. C. Misra, the state's chief electoral officer, said.   He added that he was ''astounded'' by the huge numbers of voters who had walked long distances and waited several hours to cast their ballots.

headline: Massey-Ferguson To Close 2 Plants
abstract: Citing a severely constricted market for combine harvesters, Massey-Ferguson Industries Ltd. said that it would suspend combine production at its plants in Toronto and Brantford, Ontario, effective Nov. 15. The closings will idle 1,325 employees.

headline: CAN SEX SELL LIQUOR? SURE SEEMS SO
abstract: IN one magazine ad for Hennessey cognac, a woman in the briefest of bikinis dips her toe into the corner of a swimming pool, almost brushing up against a man, in a similarly scanty costume, who is sitting cross-legged by the pool. Behind them is pitch blackness, the only light coming from the pool. Both are holding brandy snifters of amber liquid. In the lower righthand corner of the ad is a small bottle of Hennessey beside a snifter of cognac on the rocks.

headline: PATENTS;  New Juice Product
abstract: A method of treating juices from citrus fruit peels, invented for I.G.I. Biotechnology Inc. of Columbia, Md., increases the sugar content. Patent 4,547,226 was granted this week to Dr. Robert A. Milch, president of the company, and three co-inventors. The resulting product, a high-fructose syrup, is expected to compete with corn syrup as a sweetener for soft drinks.

headline: ISRAEL SAID TO LINK AMERICAN TO UNIT ON ANTITERRORISM
abstract: An internal Israeli investigation has found that Jonathan Jay Pollard, an employee of the United States Navy, was working as an intelligence operative for a secretive Israeli counterterrorism bureau, a highly placed Israeli source said today.   Israeli television reported tonight that the Cabinet was prepared to return to the United States the hundreds of documents Mr. Pollard is said to have obtained. But the Israeli source said Israel would not accede to an American demand that two Israeli diplomats involved return to the United States for questioning.   In Washington, the State Department had ''no reaction'' to reports of the diplomats' return to Israel, a spokesman, Sondra McCarty, said. In Santa Barbara, Calif., where President Reagan is vacationing, he aides said he would likely ''speak to the nation'' about the recent series of spy arrests. [Page B22.]  Report Is Nearly Complete The Israeli investigation, the source here said, was put together over the last week by Prime Minister Shimon Peres, Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir and Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin, with the help of the chiefs of the branches of Israeli intelligence.

headline: Rumsfeld to Be Blair Adviser
abstract: Donald H. Rumsfeld, who stepped down Sept. 30 after eight years as chairman and chief executive of G. D. Searle & Company, said today that he would serve on a part-time basis as a senior adviser to William Blair & Company, a Chicago investment banking firm.   Mr. Rumsfeld in a phone interview today said, ''I want to take some time to write articles and lecture in addition to investment advising.''

headline: Backer of The Nation Sees Gains by Magazine
abstract: ''The Nation is a 120-year-old treasure that I think should be protected, sustained and expanded,'' said Arthur L. Carter. Mr. Carter is a Connecticut multimillionaire publisher who, with two previous owners, bought The Nation last week for an undisclosed sum.   Mr. Carter, who founded the precursor company of Shearson Lehman Brothers, is the owner and publisher of The Litchfield County Times, a weekly with circulation of about 12,000 serving northwestern Connecticut. He founded the paper, which is in New Milford, in 1980 after a fruitless search to buy a small newspaper in New England.

headline: STOCKING FULL OF FORECASTS
abstract: HERE'S a stocking full of predictions, on Christmas morning, for the reader who has everything else.   The World Future Society, a nonprofit scientific and educational association based in Bethesda, Md., offers these forecasts of consumer goods to come: Custom-made clothes will be made in minutes. A video camera will scan a customer's body and tell a computer the shape, style, color and design of the clothing. The fabric will then be shaped around three-dimensional molds and heated to retain human contours. (But what about the buttons? What about the zippers?) A week's vacation in a space station or a honeymoon on the moon will become commonplace. (Let me slip out of this spacesuit into something more comfortable.) Butlers and other servants will make a comeback - but they will be computers and robots. One computer system already available speaks with a polite British accent, draws water for the bath, mixes cocktails and waters the lawn. (But it won't do windows, balance checkbooks or write columns.) Among other developments predicted by the society are growth hormones for turning children into basketball or football stars, home delivery of groceries with the help of computerized navigation systems and, as the population distribution changes, more elderly criminals.

headline: Pacific Lumber
abstract: A Federal District Court judge in San Francisco today dismissed a suit by three grandchildren of a former chairman of the Pacific Lumber Company who sought to stop the company's takeover by the Maxxam Group, led by Houston investor, Charles E. Hurwitz. The plaintiffs' attorney said the decision will be appealed. In addition, two other shareholders filed similar suits Thursday in San Francisco and Eureka, Calif., in reaction to the Pacific board's decision Oct. 22 to accept a $40-a-share tender offer from Maxxam.

headline: President of Gould Chosen to Be Chief
abstract: James F. McDonald, president and chief operating officer of Gould Inc., has been named to succeed William T. Ylvisaker as chief executive officer of the diversified electronics company.   Mr. McDonald, a 45-year-old native of Louisville, Ky., will move into the job at the end of April next year. Mr. Ylvisaker, who has spearhearded Gould's recent restructuring from a company focusing on batteries to one deeply involved in computers and defense systems, will remain chairman.   Mr. McDonald joined Gould in July 1984 after working at the International Business Machines Corporation for 21 years. Mr. Ylvisaker said Mr. McDonald had come to Gould with the expectation that he would eventually take over as chief executive. At I.B.M. Mr. McDonald was general manager of manufacturing systems products for four years. Before that, he was laboratory director for office products and served on the corporate task force that designed I.B.M.'s general business group.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: Nov. 15, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. General Committee - 9.30 A.M.  Political and Security Committee - 10.30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Special Political Committee - 3 P.M.   Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 10.30 A.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10.30 A.M. Legal Committee - 3 P.M. Conference for Development Activities - 10 A.M.

headline: SOVIET EMBASSY SENDS 60 HOME FROM LEBANON
abstract: The Soviet Union today evacuated nonessential staff members and families of diplomats from its embassy in Moslem West Beirut.   Four embassy men were kidnapped on Monday and one was subsquently murdered, and the professed kidnappers have threatened to destroy the Soviet Embassy if all Russians did not leave the Moslem sector of the city by today.   A Soviet Embassy source said the embassy would not be closed.

headline: HITACHI, SPERRY IN ACCORDS
abstract: The Sperry Corporation said yesterday that it had negotiated several agreements with Hitachi Ltd. to evaluate ''technology exchanges'' between the two companies, leading industry experts to speculate that the Japanese electronics giant will soon be manufacturing key components of Sperry's mainframe computer systems.   The move appears to be another in Sperry's transformation away from manufacturing much of its own hardware, primarily because of heavy price competition from the International Business Machines Corporation and Japanese manufacturers. Already, another Japanese company, Mitsubishi, manufactures Sperry's personal computers.

headline: Advertising;   People
abstract: * Andrew J. Quinn, Stanley Rygor and Raymond E. Zipko have been elected senior vice presidents, financial advertising, at Doremus & Co.

headline: U.S. SAYS MANAGUA HARASSES EMBASSY'S NICARAGUAN STAFF
abstract: The State Department accused the Nicaraguan Government today of harassing Nicaraguan employees of the United States Embassy in Managua by subjecting them to hours of interrogation by state security agents.   Charles E. Redman, a department spokesman, said the United States had protested the questioning to the Nicaraguan Government and demanded that the practice be halted immediately.   Mr. Redman said 14 Nicaraguans who work for the embassy were summoned to the headquarters of the National Directorate of State Security for questioning between Nov. 2 and Nov. 7. He said the sessions had lasted 6 to 13 hours and had been ''intense and abusive.''

headline: LUXURY HOUSING IS BUILT ON RIM OF GARMENT AREA
abstract: A large condominium tower is rising on the easterly blockfront of the Avenue of the Americas between 36th and 37th Streets, just north of Herald Square and Macy's and on the eastern fringe of the garment district. It is a location where no developer has ever tried to sell expensive apartments before, and it is a prime example of a relatively new phenomenon in the New York housing market.   In years past, most large, costly apartment buildings were developed in recognized residential neighborhoods where a market for them was well established. A prime location was the chief consideration for developers and they usually put it before style, architecture, amenities and just about everything else.

headline: AIRPORT TERRORISTS KILL 13 AND WOUND 113 AT ISRAELI COUNTERS IN ROME AND VIENNA
abstract: Terrorists hurled grenades and fired submachine guns at crowds of holiday travelers at airports in Rome and Vienna today in attacks on check-in counters of El Al Israel Airlines.   Authorities quoted by news services said the gunmen had killed at least 13 people, including 4 Americans, and wounded 113 in the two attacks. Four terrorists were killed, and three others were wounded and captured.   While El Al appeared to be a target in both attacks, the authorities said the terrorists in Rome had also thrown grenades and fired indiscriminately with Soviet-made assault rifles into crowds of New York-bound passengers checking in at Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines.      Terrorists Not Identified   The assailants, who were not immediately identified, left the two airline terminals strewn with bloodied and torn bodies, luggage, overturned furniture and broken glass.

headline: PRESIDENT'S FORCES IN CONTROL IN LIBERIA
abstract: President Samuel K. Doe appeared to be back in control of Liberia today, but rebels who tried to stage a coup Tuesday were still putting up a stubborn resistance to loyalist troops.   Sporadic fighting could still be heard on the road from Monrovia to Robertsfield Airport near the city's three main radio stations, which were surrounded by Government troops.   A senior army officer told television viewers that 10 rebel soldiers and 5 government troops died in the fighting after a coup attempt by a former army chief, Brig. Gen. Thomas Quiwonkpa, that was launched at dawn Tuesday.

headline: Agency Search Leaves No Stone Unturned
abstract: If you have always wanted to known what ''left no stone unturned'' meant and were too embarrassed to ask, a recent agency search by the Coleman Company of Wichita, Kan., is a good demonstration.   It was a search that ended up with the selection of Barkley & Evergreen in Shawnee Mission, Kan., but only after every stone was turned.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD;U.S.-SOVIET TALKS HALT ON RESUMING FLIGHTS
abstract: United States-Soviet talks on resuming airline service between the two countries have ended in disagreement and no further meetings have been set, the  State Department said today.         ''There were considerable differences on the economic basis on which service  would be established,'' said the department spokesman, Bernard Kalb.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Beverly Enterprises, Pasadena, Calif., said it had agreed to establish a joint venture in Japan with Shimizu Construction Co. to provide retirement living in Tokyo. Eventually, the companies plan to expand into long-term nursing care and home health services.         * Cessna Aircraft Co., Wichita, Kan., said that no cash dividend would be declared pending completion of its merger with General Dynamics Corp.

headline: Advertising;   Hicks & Greist Loses Heath, but Wins Hood
abstract: Another account departing from a New York agency is L. S. Heath & Sons of Robinson, Ill., which has had its confections served by Hicks & Greist in Gotham.

headline: China Oil Project
abstract: The state-owned China National Offshore Oil Corporation has signed a contract with a consortium of three foreign oil companies for oil exploration in the Pearl River basin, a spokesman for one of the companies said Saturday. Harold R. Allison, a vice president of Texaco Inc., said the consortium consists of AGIP (Overseas) Ltd., Chevron Overseas Petroleum Ltd. and Texaco Petroleum Maatschappij (Nederland) B.V. The consortium would explore an area about 170 miles southeast of Canton, in the Pearl River basin, Mr. Allison said. It is the fourth contract to be signed in a second round of bidding for offshore exploration rights.

headline: Polaroid Profit Up 77%
abstract: The Polaroid Corporation, which cut costs with second-quarter layoffs, has reported a third-quarter profit of $14.8 million, or 48 cents a share, up 77 percent from $1.7 million, or 6 cents a share, a year earlier. Meanwhile, sales fell to $299.9 million from $307.8 million, the company said Monday.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Amca International Corp., Hanover, N.H., said its Menck operating unit, Ellerau, West Germany, had received a contract to provide hydraulic offshore pile-driving hammers and related equipment from Micoperi Offshore S.p.A., Milan, Italy, for about $20 million.    * Amdahl Corp., Sunnyvale, Calif., said it had introduced two new models in its 6000 series of storage products, models 6380 AE4 and BE4.    * American Express Co. said it would move up the expiration date of its outstanding common share purchase warrants to Jan. 23, 1986, from Feb. 28, 1987.

headline: U.N. Appoints Ghanaian
abstract: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar appointed Kenneth K. S. Dadzie today to be Secretary General of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development for a three-year term, beginning Jan. 1. Mr. Dadzie is Ghana's High Commissioner in London. In 1982, he was appointed a personal representative of the Secretary General for Special Missions.

headline: MARCOS FORTUNE: QUESTIONS ARISE ABOUT GRAFT
abstract: As has often happened in the history of the Philippines, official corruption is emerging as a central issue within the nation. Now, according to Congressional sources and Administration officials, it is becoming an increasingly important factor in relations between the United States and the Philippines.   The corruption issue figured in an unsuccessful effort to impeach President Ferdinand E. Marcos last summer. Opposition leaders have said they intend to bring it up in the elections scheduled for early next year and may refile impeachment charges with new documentation.   In the United States, Congressional investigators and a Federal grand jury in the Washington area are looking into corruption in the Philippines.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Some 8.8% Jeep Financing
abstract: The American Motors Corporation said today that it had extended its 8.8 percent financing to some of its 1986 Jeep line of trucks.   The 8.8 percent rate will be available on loans financed for 36 months or less and will include the Jeep Cherokee and Wagoneer sport utility wagons and the new two-wheel- and four-wheel-drive Jeep Comanche pickup trucks.

headline: A Confident South Korea
abstract: DUCK WOO NAM, at the relatively early age of 61, is regarded here as the gray eminence of Korean politics and economics.   As a former Finance Minister, Deputy Prime Minister for Economic Planning and Prime Minister, and now chairman of the Korea Traders Association, a powerful business group that includes virtually every exporter and importer in the country, Mr. Nam has played a key role in the transformation of this once-backward country into one of the world's strongest trading nations.   That performance led South Korea to get the role of host of this year's annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank, which has brought representatives of 149 countries to Seoul. The style and dash with which the Koreans have conducted themselves during this conference have greatly impressed the world's money men.

headline: 2 AT SYNOD DEFEND LIBERATION IDEAS
abstract: Some bishops from Latin America strongly defended the teachings known as liberation theology today.   Their statements came as groups of prelates began offering the special Synod divergent proposals for a final document on the future of Roman Catholicism.   The proposals ranged from political statements on peace and third world debt offered by a group of Canadian bishops to a traditionalist call from a German-speaking study group for support of church authority.   Support for liberation theology came from two leading Brazilian Bishops who appeared to be answering criticisms made not only by their fellow prelates, but also by the Vatican itself.

headline: Market Place;   Interco Lure: Brand Names
abstract: EVERYONE, it seems, likes Interco these days. Consumers each year spend millions of dollars on the company's Florsheim shoes, London Fog overcoats, Schrader Sport dresses, Ethan Allen and Broyhill furniture and its dozens of other famous-name products.   And what the consumers like, Wall Street also tends to like. The big question these days, however, is whether someone likes the company enough to try to take it over, especially at the $1 billion-plus price that would be attached to such a buyout.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 18, 1985
abstract: The Economy    The House of Representatives approved legislation that would make the most extensive changes in the Federal income tax system in more than 40 years. The crucial vote came on a motion to recommit the bill to committee, a parliamentary way of killing the legislation. It lost, 256 to 171, and the bill was then approved by voice vote, The measure now goes to the Senate. [Page A1.]  That body is likely to adopt a tax revision measure of its own next year, but it will probably be more favorable to business than the House bill. [D22.]    Housing construction fell 12.2 percent in November, the sharpest drop in six months. Analysts were divided about the reason for the steep decline, which produced an annual rate of 1.55 million units, the lowest pace since April 1983. [D1.]

headline: Dairy Queen Amendments
abstract: International Dairy Queen Inc. said it had approved proposed amendments to the company's certificate of incorporation that includes a program to convert each existing share of its common stock into three shares of a new class A common stock and two shares of a new class B common stock. It said the amendments would divide its existing common stock into a larger number of shares of two classes, with differing rights and preferences.
