headline: Advertising;   A 2d Playboy Account Won by Smith Burke
abstract: Smith Burke & Azzam of Baltimore, which in October got Playboy's trade advertising account, now has its consumer business as well.

headline: Turner Ends NBC Talks
abstract: Ted Turner, the Atlanta broadcasting entrepreneur, said yesterday that he had decided not to sell a 50 percent stake in his Cable News Network to the National Broadcasting Company because he does not want to give up editorial control.   A Turner spokesman, Arthur Sando, said that Mr. Turner had decided late yesterday not to sell to NBC and that ''negotiations with NBC are ended.''

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    * Beverly Enterprises is offering $500 million of liquid yield option notes due 2003 through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets as sole underwriter.    * Borden Inc.'s $100 million of 10 1/4 percent notes due 1995 were priced at 99.562, to yield 10.322 percent, through Salomon Brothers Inc.    * Elizabethtown Water Co. is offering $25 million of 11 1/8 percent debentures due 2015 at a price of 99.516, to yield 11.18 percent, through E.F. Hutton & Co.    * Farm Credit Corp. of Canada is issuing a $100 million (Canadian) 10 percent Eurobond due 1992 at a price of 99 1/2 through Wood Gundy Ltd.

headline: Careers;   Guidelines On Starting A Business
abstract: SOME 600,000 people a year start businesses in the United States.   Indeed, they provide ''most of the new jobs,'' according to George L. Bernstein, chief executive of Laventhol & Horwath, a large accounting firm that long has serviced hotels, restaurants, clubs and other businesses, both large and small.   Mr. Bernstein adds a warning, not new but one being heard more and more: ''Most new businesses fail, and they generally fail soon after they start up.'' Furthermore, he finds that ''only 30 percent of new businesses last to the second generation and only 15 percent to the third.'' These statistics should have an unnerving impact on entrepreneurs.

headline: European Steel Gets Quotas
abstract: The United States today imposed unilateral quotas on European Economic Community exports of semifinished steel products, and the Common Market immediately vowed retaliation in the latest round of the steel trade war.   Europe's External Trade Commissioner, Willy de Clercq, said that the American decision to limit Common Market exports to 400,000 tons a year until 1989 was unjustified and that it would strike back soon against American exports.

headline: CRAXI GIVEN MANDATE TO FORM NEW ROME CABINET
abstract: Italy's President today asked the caretaker Prime Minister, Bettino Craxi, to form a new government.         Mr. Craxi, a Socialist, was head of the five-party coalition Government that  fell four days ago over its handling of the Achille Lauro hijacking. The request that he form a new Government came amid indications that he had emerged  politically strengthened from the episode.

headline: Talking Business with Schwitter of Swiss Union Bank;   Dollar Plunge Called Possible
abstract: The dollar, after retreating since September, when the five major industrial powers decided to force it lower, has more or less leveled off. The calm is not caused by government policy makers, analysts say, but by a combination of market forces.   The view from Europe is that this apparent calm could well prove fragile, with the dollar falling abruptly, according to Daniel A. Schwitter, senior vice president in charge of worldwide foreign exchange, precious metals and money market operations of the Zurich-based Union Bank of Switzerland. The bank is the largest in Switzerland and an influential force in the currency market.

headline: Amsted Gets Buyout Offer
abstract: Amsted Industries said that a senior management group and a recently formed employee stock ownership plan have made a joint offer to acquire the construction and industrial equipment maker in a leveraged buyout.   For each Amsted share, shareholders would receive $37 in cash and $27 principal amount of subordinated discount debentures, the company said.

headline: DOW TOPS THE 1,400 BARRIER
abstract: With a concerted push from institutional investors in the waning minutes of trading, the Dow Jones industrial average jumped the historic 1,400 hurdle yesterday with relative ease, ending the day at 1,403.44.   Many professional traders believed that the 1,400 plateau would be difficult to surmount without a resting period of at least a few days, and maybe even weeks, after the Dow moved close on Tuesday with a close of 1,396.67. But a surge of enthusiasm for equities carried over from recent sessions as investors were encouraged that interest rates would fall.   At times yesterday, it seemed as if the indicator of 30 blue-chip stocks had given up the quest. While the Dow passed the 1,400 level in both midmorning and midafternoon trading, it was down 1.60 points with only 30 minutes left in the session, putting it 5 points below 1,400.

headline: LIBERIA'S ELECTION TO THE SECURITY COUNCIL IS BLOCKED IN ASSEMBLY
abstract: In an unexpected development, Liberia was blocked today from becoming a nonpermanent member of the Security Council. The General Assembly chose Ghana instead.   The Assembly also elected Bulgaria, Congo, the United Arab Emirates and Venezuela to the two-year Council terms.

headline: Gandhi Asks His Party To Strengthen India
abstract: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi called on Indians today to shun foreign goods and catch up with developed countries in technology.   At the end of centenary celebrations of his Congress Party, held in a Bombay cricket stadium, he called for a return to the simple values of Mohandas K. Gandhi.

headline: GREEK COLLEGE 'IS VERY GOOD' WHEN OPEN
abstract: The office of Prof. Athanasios N. Safacas bustles and hums more like that of a railroad stationmaster than of a university rector.   The slight, bearded 42-year-old electrical engineer oversees Patras University. The school has about 8,000 students, 422 professors and lecturers and 336 administrative employees on a large campus at the edge of Greece's third-largest city.   Delegations of protesting or pleading students file in and out - small groups into the professor's study, larger ones into his conference room. The antechambers are meeting places for delegations or individual students to rehearse their pitch to Professor Safacas while waiting their turn.

headline: JUSTICES HEAR BERKELEY AND TV ANTITRUST CASES
abstract: The Supreme Court heard arguments today on whether a Berkeley, Calif., rent control law violated the antitrust laws and whether Japanese makers of television sets must go to trial on civil charges of antitrust conspiracy and illegal dumping.   The Justices also agreed to decide whether the monetary damages awarded to tax shelter investors who sue promoters successfully for securities fraud should be reduced by the tax savings the investors realized on their lost investments.   In the Berkeley case, Jon Smock, representing landlords who sued to invalidate the law restricting rent increases, said it amounted to ''naked price-fixing'' in violation of the Federal antitrust law policy of ''free competition in the marketplace.''   But Laurence H. Tribe, representing the city, argued that the antitrust laws should not be construed to bar local governments from engaging in reasonable economic regulations. He said the evidence showed the law did not involve the kind of ''combination or conspiracy in restraint of trade'' that the Sherman Antitrust Act of 1890 was designed to forbid and urged the Court to affirm a California Supreme Court decision upholding the law.

headline: Holiday Hotel Sale
abstract: The Holiday Corporation, parent of Holiday Inns Inc., said it has sold 26 hotels to VMS Realty Inc. of Chicago for $390 million. Holiday Inns will have a long-term management contract for all 26 properties, Holiday said in a statement. Holiday will realize after-tax profits of $66 million, the company said. VMS Realty has a real estate portfolio valued at more than $4 billion, with more than $1 billion invested in hotels, Holiday said.

headline: New Job: Software Engineer
abstract: COMPUTER software engineering is not a profession yet, but it will be if John H. Manley has his way. A former Air Force expert, he has just become the director of the Software Engineering Institute, financed by the Government.   The Defense Department has awarded a $103 million, five-year contract to Carnegie-Mellon University to manage the institute, which was established early this year.   What is a software engineer? Dr. Manley defines the job as ''involving the planning, developing and evolution of software systems and products'' for inclusion in the technical and management structure of companies. Such engineers are not to be confused with people whose work involves computer science, such as systems analysts. The software engineer needs a background not only in engineering - specifically in software systems - but also in accounting, economics, cost management and other business-type subjects.

headline: Finding on Dumping
abstract: The Commerce Department has made a preliminary finding that the Japanese have sold one of the highest-volume semiconductors in the American market at deep discounts - as much as 94 percent - below the cost of production.   The department determined that the Japanese were ''dumping'' - that is, selling below fair value - dynamic random access memory chips that can store 64,000 characters.   The department did not make an announcement, but said it notified the complaining company in the so-called 64K RAM case - Micron Technology Inc., of Boise, Idaho - which gave the specifics of the findings to reporters who inquired.

headline: Chevron Net Declines 28.4%
abstract: The Chevron Corporation today reported a 28.4 percent drop in third-quarter earnings to $245 million, or 72 cents a share, from $342 million, or $1 a share, a year ago. Revenues dropped 28 percent, to $10.3 billion, from $14.3 billion a  year ago.         The company attributed the decline in large part to adjustments associated with Chevron's $13.2 billion merger with the Gulf Corporation, although the company said that operating profits before adjustments and special items were stronger than during the first half of the year.

headline: Brennan and Jones In Top Sears Posts
abstract: Edward A. Brennan was elected chairman and chief executive officer of Sears, Roebuck & Company yesterday and Richard M. Jones was elected president.   Effective Jan. 1, Mr. Brennan, Sears's 51-year-old president, will succeed Edward R. Telling, 66, who is retiring. Mr. Jones, 58, the vice chairman and chief financial officer, will succeed Mr. Brennan as president. Mr. Jones will remain chief financial officer.   ''In terms of business philosophy and goals, we think exactly the same way,'' Mr. Brennan said in comparing himself with Mr. Telling. ''In terms of exactly how you get there, we may differ, and that's how it should be.''

headline: STRIKERS ARRESTED IN SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: The police today arrested 718 black student nurses and auxiliary employees who were striking for better wages at South Africa's largest hospital.   The striking employees of Baragwanath Hospital, in the vast black township of Soweto outside Johannesburg, were charged with taking part in an illegal walkout and later released.   The arrests came as President P. W. Botha called on the President's Council, South Africa's highest advisory board, to consider restructuring itself to allow participation by blacks.

headline: Dollar Off, Gold Mixed In Lackluster Trading
abstract: The dollar fell slightly in lackluster Christmas Eve trading. Gold was mixed, ending a half-day of trading at the Republic Bank of New York at $326.25 an ounce, up 75 cents from Monday.   ''It was a non-day,'' said Gordon Beals, an analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities, a New York investment firm. ''It didn't give anybody any insight as to what's going to happen in the future.''

headline: New Polaroid Chief Fits Tough Mold
abstract: For only the third time in 48 years, the Polaroid Corporation has a new boss.   I. M. Booth, president of the photography equipment giant, was named to the additional position of chief executive yesterday, succeeding William J. McCune Jr., who will continue as chairman of the board.   Polaroid has a penchant for picking career employees to lead the company. In 1980, Mr. McCune, who is 70 years old and joined Polaroid in 1939, replaced Dr. Edwin H. Land, the patriarchal inventor who founded the company, which is based in Cambridge, Mass., in 1937.

headline: FRENCH TOP BRITISH ON U.S. CONTRACT
abstract: Despite personal appeals to President Reagan from Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, the Pentagon awarded a $4.3 billion battlefield communications contract today to a consortium led by the Thomson-CSF electronics giant of France, in partnership with the GTE Corporation of Stamford, Conn.   It was one of the largest foreign contracts ever let by the Defense Department and the biggest ever won by France. Mrs. Thatcher had urged that a British bidder be chosen.   Although the new communications system, known as Mobile Subscriber Equipment, was designed by the French company, which has sales of $6 billion a year, the award calls for more than 70 percent of the work to be done in the United States.   This work will be performed by GTE, which said that over the next two years it expects to hire as many as 1,000 workers in the Boston area. Nearby Needham, Mass., is the headquarters of GTE's Communications Systems division.

headline: INDIA REPORTS TRUCE IN SRI LANKA
abstract: India announced tonight that a new cease-fire agreement had been negotiated between the Government of Sri Lanka and leaders of one of the main guerrilla groups on the island.   The officials expressed hope that the new cease-fire could lead to a renewal of discussions to achieve a political settlement ending nearly three years of spreading warfare in Sri Lanka.   The discussions had bogged down in recent months because of violations of the previously agreed upon cease-fire. Sri Lanka accused the guerrillas of killing policemen and army troops, and the guerrillas accused the police of indiscriminate attacks on Tamil civilians.

headline: MRS. MARCOS OFFERS VIEW OF SAD WORLD
abstract: Imelda R. Marcos told the General Assembly today that the problems that confront the world ''have their roots in injustice, intolerance, greed and dominance by the strong.''   ''The solutions to these problems rest not in man's acquisitive nature,'' Mrs. Marcos said, ''but in his sense of justice and sense of community.''   Ordinarily outspoken and outgoing, Mrs. Marcos, wife of President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines, had said little publicly since her arrival in New York on Wednesday, refusing numerous requests for interviews. She made her first public appearance today when she spoke at the United Nations 40th anniversary commemorative session as special envoy and Acting Foreign Minister of the Philippines.

headline: CAPACITY USE DECLINED TO 80.2% IN SEPTEMBER
abstract: Factories, mines and utilities operated at 80.2 percent of capacity in September, compared with 80.5 percent in August and 80.2 percent in July, the Federal Reserve Board said today.   The July number was a downward revision from a previously reported 80.4 percent rate.

headline: COAST THRIFT UNITS PROSPERING
abstract: In perverse moments, Herbert M. Sandler almost wishes interest rates would rise.   That is an extraordinary musing for a thrift unit officer such as Mr. Sandler, chairman of the Golden West Financial Corporation, a $12 billion savings and loan institution based in Oakland, Calif. Higher interest rates would raise the price that thrift units pay for money at a time when hundreds of them around the country are already fighting for survival.   But Mr. Sandler would not mind showing ''how far we've come.'' That is because, while the public perception is that the industry is on the ropes, many thrift units, including Golden West Financial, are earning record sums this year, and are also restructuring their balance sheets to reduce their vulnerability to a new round of higher interest rates.

headline: Economic Scene;   Where China Is Booming
abstract: THIS Special Economic Zone, an area marked out to attract foreign investment through special tax programs and other incentives, is the most spectacular success story of China's open door policy.   While not without its problems, the growth of Shenzhen, which lies just across the water from Hong Kong and is connected to the New Territories of Hong Kong on its southern border, can be seen in a number of ways: Since 1979, its population has mushroomed to 350,000, from 20,000; it has signed more than 2,300 foreign investment agreements valued at more than $1.6 billion; it has attracted more than 30 percent of all foreign investment in China; it has seen the number of businesses grow to 400, and is planning 307 more; its electronics industry has grown from one company employing 300 to 60 companies employing 13,000; its total output has increased 29-fold, and its per-capita output has climbed to almost $2,000 a year in a country where the average has been less than $100 a year.   In addition, Shenzhen is expected to become the principal support base for offshore oil exploration in the South China Sea, and it is likely to become a major exporter of food, textiles and petrochemicals.

headline: Savings
abstract: To the Editor:   I cannot accept that ''incentives only work well when you have more savings to finance additional investment'' (''Modigliani: Talking With a Nobel Economist,'' Forum, Nov. 3).

headline: India Resumes Talks On Sri Lanka Conflict
abstract: India resumed talks with Tamil militants today in an effort to help resolve ethnic conflict in Sri Lanka as Tamil guerrillas were said to have massacred Sinhalese villagers in Sri Lanka in a fresh outbreak of violence.   The United News of India agency, reporting from Colombo, said Tamil guerrillas had stormed the village of Navalwathe in Trincomalee district, killing 32 men, women and children, and setting their homes on fire.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD;Rebels in Colombia May Free 3 Americans
abstract: Left-wing guerrillas have agreed to free three United States missionaries kidnapped 24 days ago in Colombia's eastern jungles and turn them over to a Government peace commission, a commission source said today.         The source said the kidnappers were members of the First Front of the Colombian Revolutionary Armed Forces. A guerrilla representative promised the peace commission Monday night to free the missionaries at a meeting in Bogota, the source said.

headline: BIG BANKS BASKING IN PROFITS
abstract: Many corporate executives who have always considered themselves a breed apart from commercial bankers are probably wishing they were in the bankers' shoes these days. As one big bank after another has reported its earnings for the third quarter, it has become clear that, as a group, they are currently among the most prosperous businesses in the nation.   In contrast to generally lackluster earnings throughout most of corporate America, most of the largest commercial banks managed to sport earnings gains that were well into the double digits. They did so despite the sluggish rate of economic growth that plagued all companies and despite, in their own cases, the continued specter of troubled Latin American debt.

headline: NICARAGUA DENIES CHARGE BY REAGAN
abstract: Interior Minister Tomas Borge has denied an assertion by President Reagan that Nicaragua supplied weapons to leftist guerrillas who staged a takeover of Colombia's Palace of Justice last month.   Mr. Borge, speaking to a group of policemen late Saturday, also accused the military in El Salvador, which receives aid from the United States, of training Nicaraguan rebels in their fight against the Nicaragua Government.   Mr. Reagan, in his weekly radio address Saturday, asserted that Nicaragua aided the rebel April 19 Movement, or M-19, which seized the Palace of Justice in Bogota, Colombia, last month and held it for more than a day before troops recaptured the building in a battle that left about 100 people dead.

headline: Nebraska Agency Offers 'Put' Notes
abstract: The Nebraska Higher Education Loan Program Inc. is offering $145.4 million of ''put'' notes due in 2015 through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers.

headline: LIBERIANS PLANNING TO START TRIALS TODAY FOR COUP PLOT
abstract: Liberia will hold trials starting today for 11 civilians and an undisclosed number of military personnel who were implicated in an unsuccessful coup last week, a spokesman for the Liberian Embassy in Washington said yesterday.   The embassy spokesman, J. Emmanuel Bowier, also said the Liberian head of state, Gen. Samuel K. Doe, had named the Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs, Brig. Gen. Rudolph Kolaco, to be commanding general of the armed forces.   General Kolaco will have responsibility for assuring that anyone detained after the botched coup will not be ''harassed, molested, abused, intimidated or adversely affected in anyway,'' the spokesman said General Doe had announced.

headline: Money Fund Assets Up
abstract: In the largest increase since Aug. 21, assets of the nation's money market mutual funds jumped $2.37 billion, to $209.75 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

headline: Papal Aide to Meet With P.O.W.'s in Iran
abstract: Pope John Paul II, acting on a request from the Government of Iran, sent an envoy to Teheran today with a Christmas ''message of prayer and human solidarity'' for Iraqi prisoners of war.

headline: Progress Is Reported In Uganda Peace Talks
abstract: President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya said today that ''tremendous progress'' had been made in peace talks here between Uganda's military Government and the country's main rebel group.   President Moi, who has been chairing the intermittent negotiations since they started in August, emerged at the end of the day's closed-door session and in a jovial mood told reporters: ''I can say it in two words - tremendous progress.''

headline: SAVINGS RATE
abstract: To the Editor:   In wringing their hands over the decline of Yankee thrift (Americans seem to save less and less) observers are missing the point that Americans have simply changed the way in which they save (''How Economic Policy Has Gone Awry,'' Forum, Nov. 3). The new way does not show up in the Commerce Department's statistics on savings.

headline: Cyprus Write-Off
abstract: Cyprus Minerals Company said it would take an after-tax charge on earnings of $425 million in the fourth quarter in a write-off of its investment in the Thompson Creek molybdenum mine in Challis, Idaho, and some copper and coal assets. The action, taken because of poor business conditions, will reduce its net worth to $805 million, or $30.66 a share, from $1.2 billion, or $46.82 a share.

headline: PENN THAL
abstract: Penn Thal, a former Cambodian diplomat who became a leader of the anti-Vietnamese resistance on the Thai-Cambodian border, died Wednesday in Peking, according to officials of the Khmer People's National Liberation Front. He was 51 years old.   Mr. Penn Thal was the son of Penn Nouth, a former Cambodian Prime Minister.

headline: EVEN WITH A NAME, IT'S HARD TO KNOW WHO THE HIJACKERS ARE
abstract: The hijackers of an Italian cruise ship have said in radio transmissions that they are members of a group called the Palestine Liberation Front, but even if that identification is accurate it may not do much to clear up their motives and allegiances.   The Palestine Liberation Front is thought by some Middle East experts to be one of the eight groups that for many years were united under the umbrella of the Palestine Liberation Organization. Many of the Liberation Front's members broke away from the P.L.O. in disillusionment after the Israeli invasion of Lebanon in 1982.   Some of the Palestine Liberation Front fighters wound up in Damascus, Syria, allying themselves with the National Salvation Front, the group of pro-Syrian Palestinians that ousted Yasir Arafat, head of the P.L.O. and his forces from the northern Lebanese port of Tripoli in 1983. A few remained loyal to Mr. Arafat.

headline: GORBACHEV, IN GENEVA, ASKS FOR END TO THE ARMS RACE
abstract: Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrived here today and said that the ''first and foremost'' issue facing his meetings with President Reagan starting Tuesday was how to halt the arms race ''and its extension to new spheres.''   The allusion was evidently to the United States' space-based misile defense program, which has been a target of Soviet diplomacy.   Swiss sharpshooters scanned surrounding buildings and a Soviet emigre shouted protests as Mr. Gorbachev stepped out of his Aeroflot airliner at Cointrin Airport, holding the arm of his wife, Raisa. A stiff, cold wind blew across the runway and swirled the skirts of Mrs. Gorbachev's ankle-length, fox-trimmed gray coat.   In a statement, Mr. Gorbachev said the Soviet and American people expected ''positive results'' from the summit meeting.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * BankAmerica Corp., San Francisco, said it had closed the previously announced sale of its FinanceAmerica unit to Chrysler Financial Corp. for $405 million.    * Eagle Telephonics Inc., Hauppauge, L.I., said it had signed a purchase agreement with Spurs West, the procurement partnership of U S West operating telephone companies, Mountain Bell and Northwestern Bell.

headline: AIRLINE WAS PENALIZED IN '84 INSPECTION
abstract: Arrow Air, whose plane crashed in Newfoundland yesterday, was one of 16 airlines receiving significant penalties after a Government inspection of 327 American carriers in early 1984.   The Miami-based company was barred by the Federal Aviation Administration from carrying out expansion plans pending the correction of shortcomings found by the inspectors. The problems were cleared up later in the year and the restrictions lifted.   The deficiency found most worrisome by the aviation agency was in procedures that allowed for overly long deferral of maintenance. Other problems included inadequacies of training and operations manuals, and failure to keep proper training records.

headline: U.S. AND ITALY PLANNING EFFORT ON PROBLEMS OF EXTRADTION
abstract: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d and the Italian Interior Minister announced today that the United States and Italy would try to resolve ''extradition problems'' that have strained relations between the two nations.   The announcement appeared to have been prompted in part by last month's furor over Italy's refusal to extradite a Palestinian who the Reagan Administration says ''masterminded'' the hijacking of the cruise ship Achille Lauro. An American passenger on the Italian ship was killed by the hijackers.

headline: THE A.B.A.'S BREAK WITH TRADITION
abstract: WILLARD C. BUTCHER, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, did not show up. And John S. Reed, chairman of Citibank, flew in for the weekend, but left before the sessions.   The annual convention of the American Bankers Association, held in New Orleans last week, is not what it used to be. The snub by the two big New York bankers partly reflected their displeasure over the A.B.A.'s reneging on an agreement to support bills that would have phased in interstate banking. The New York banks are locked out of interstate banking while other banks are merging through regional interstate agreements.

headline: REAGAN SAYS ISRAEL-JORDAN TALKS COULD START BEFORE END OF THE YEAR
abstract: President Reagan met today with King Hussein of Jordan and said afterward that he believed direct negotiations for peace between Israel and Jordan could be started by the end of December.   ''All of us, Jordan, the United States and Israel, share the same realistic objective: direct negotiations, under appropriate auspices, before the end of this year,'' Mr. Reagan told reporters at the White House.   ''There are complex and sensitive issues which must be resolved before actual negotiations can begin,'' Mr. Reagan said. ''But I believe these issues can be resolved.''

headline: 'IT'S WRONG!' SHULTZ SAYS OF TERRORISM
abstract: The news conference here today with Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Raif Dizdarevic was marked by an unusual outburst by Mr. Shultz. Here is some of what the two officials said.   Q. Did you discuss the question of terrorism and hijacking, and specifically Mohammed Abbas, and could you tell us what the positions of the two sides were?

headline: PRICES ON COFFEE SPURT DESPITE RISE IN QUOTAS
abstract: Prices of coffee futures rose sharply today despite a move by an international marketing agency to expand export quotas for the world trade. Coffee prices set life-of-contract highs and were mostly up the limit of 6 cents a pound on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York.   ''Basically, there's continuing buying interest because of the continued drought in Brazil,'' said Pamela Rockley, an analyst in New York with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc.

headline: SPAIN'S POLICE, ONCE DREADED, RALLY TO DEMOCRACY
abstract: The nearly 40 men and women gathered in a meeting hall here were planning a protest campaign against militarism, the keeping of files on citizens and other vestiges of the dictatorship of Francisco Franco.   The beards and jeans might have suggested students or radicals, but the picture on the wall was the giveaway: it was of King Juan Carlos dressed in a police uniform.   Ten years after Franco's death, Spain's police, once his highhanded enforcers, are angrily demanding to be more a part of democratic Spain. Led by their unions, they have staged barracks sit-ins and petition drives. Last week, nearly 30,000 off-duty police officers joined in marches around the country, chanting, ''We want to serve the people.''

headline: A DOCTOR FOR MARCOS IS STABBED TO DEATH
abstract: A kidney specialist who had treated President Ferdinand E. Marcos was found stabbed to death today after armed men kidnapped him.

headline: Basques Protest in Spain
abstract: Thousands of Basque nationalists demonstrated today in this northern Spanish city to protest the death of a Basque who disappeared while in Civil Guard custody and whose body was found in a river. Tens of thousands took part in another protest march Saturday night in San Sebastian.

headline: Chevron Unit
abstract: TheChevron Corporation said today that its Chevron U.S.A. Inc. unit has agreed to sell its holding in the Hill property, a section of the South Belridge oilfield, to the Celeron Oil and Gas Company, a unit of the Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company, for $395 million. The Hill property, located 40 miles west of Bakersfield, Calif., includes 130 producing wells on 502 acres and produces 5,100 barrels of crude oil a day, a Chevron spokesman said.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    * Air Products and Chemicals Inc. is offering $100 million of 11 3/8 percent debentures due 2015 at a price of 99.70, to yield 11.41 percent, through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers.    * Bally Manufacturing Corp. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $240 million of notes and debentures through Drexel Burnham Lambert.    * Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce is issuing 400 million marks, up from 300 million, of 10-year floating rate notes at a price of 100 through Commerzbank A.G. Interest is set at 1/4 of a percentage point over the six-month London interbank offered rate, with a maximum rate of 8 percent.

headline: Several Agencies Offer New Housing Bonds
abstract: Several large new issues of housing revenue bonds were at the forefront of the tax-exempt market yesterday. The ability of state and local governments to finance housing with tax-exempt bonds would be severely restricted under proposed changes in the Federal tax law, so local governments are trying to sell as many bonds this year as the law now allows.   Among this week's largest issues, underwriters at Kidder, Peabody & Company offered $285 million of bonds of the New Jersey Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency and $85 million of bonds of the Washington Housing Finance Commission. Both issues were rated triple-A and are insured by the Municipal Bond Insurance Association.

headline: Insilco-LPL Deal
abstract: The Insilco Corporation has announced that its board has accepted an offer from LPL Investment to acquire Insilco's 66 percent interest in Times Fiber Communications.

headline: Oliver May Head F.T.C.
abstract: President Reagan intends to nominate Daniel Oliver to be a member of the Federal Trade Commission and designate him chairman once he is confirmed by the Senate, the White House announced today. Mr. Oliver, who would succeed James Miller 3d, has been general counsel at the Agriculture Department since 1983. Mr. Miller became President Reagan's budget director earlier this year. From 1981 to 1983, Mr. Oliver was general counsel at the Education Department. From 1973 to 1976, he was executive editor of The National Review magazine. Mr. Oliver practiced law in New York City from 1976 to 1979.

headline: VOLCANO WARNING TERMED DIFFICULT
abstract: Volcano specialists said yesterday that without the aid of extensive monitoring devices, such as those emplaced around Mount St. Helens in Washington, it is difficult to assess the likelihood of further major eruptions from the volcano Nevado del Ruiz. They added, however, that such volcanoes typically produce eruptions of lesser and lesser magnitude at intervals of days, weeks or months over periods that may run to several years.   There have been exceptions. Geological studies of Mount St. Helens have shown that it experienced four large eruptions between 1480 and 1482.

headline: 23 DIE IN WEEK
abstract: The police shot dead at least six people in this black township today, including several elderly women, according to witnesses. The deaths brought the number killed by the authorities so far this week to at least 23.   The police confirmed only two deaths in the township near Pretoria, saying a man and woman were shot dead when groups of blacks attacked police vehicles with gasoline bombs and stones.      Hundreds Injured    The shootings occurred as thousands of residents gathered at a local government office to protest high rents, the presence of police and army squads in the township and the banning of weekend funerals.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Dec. 9, 1985:

headline: VICTIMS OF THE AIRLINE CRASH IN NEWFOUNDLAND
abstract: Following is a list of those aboard the Arrow Air charter jet that crashed Thursday in Gander, Newfoundland. The list of passengers was provided to United Press International by the Defense Department, which was withholding other names pending notification of relatives. The crew list, transmitted by The Associated Press, was provided by the airline, which is based in Miami. The cockpit crew members were from the Miami area; the cabin crew members were from the New York area.

headline: YELENA BONNER OFF DEC. 2, PLEDGED TO AVOID PRESS
abstract: Yelena G. Bonner, the wife of Andrei D. Sakharov, told her children here by telephone today that she had won permission to leave the Soviet Union for medical treatment only after signing a pledge not to talk with reporters abroad.   ''If she breaks the promise, she risks not being allowed to return,'' said Yefrem Yankelevich, a son-in-law.   Miss Bonner said she would fly to Rome on Dec. 2 for an eye examination and to Boston a few days later for a coronary bypass.   The 40-minute call today, placed by Miss Bonner's children to Gorky in the Soviet Union after two days of unsuccessful attempts, was the second time the Sakharovs were able to talk with their relatives in this Boston suburb in the last two weeks.

headline: MARCOS SAYS HE WILL RESIGN BUT STAY ON
abstract: President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that he would submit a letter of resignation Monday to pave the way for elections early next year, but that he would nonetheless remain in office.   ''If we must be technical,'' he said, ''I ask the question: when the constitution says resignation, does it say immediate resignation? It does not.''   His announcement, at the end of a party caucus, was in response to opposition criticism that his plan to call an election without first resigning to create a vacancy would be unconstitutional.   Mr. Marcos said he would send the letter of resignation to the National Assembly on Monday along with his proposal for an election in January. But he said the resignation would take effect only upon the assumption of office of the winner of the election.

headline: Mexico Raises Prices of Oil
abstract: Encouraged by a firmer market and growing winter demand, the state petroleum monopoly Petroleos Mexicanos said today that it was raising the price of its light Isthmus crude oil by an average of 76 cents a barrel in December.   Pemex said the prices of its heavier Maya oil would remain unchanged.

headline: Two Ghanaians Plead Guilty To Passing Secrets to U.S.
abstract: Two former Government security officers pleaded guilty today to charges of passing secrets to the United States Central Intelligence Agency.   At two separate court hearings, the officers, Theodore Attiedu, 37 years old, and Felix Kotoko Peasah, 58, both described as former members of the Ghana Bureau of National Investigations, entered guilty pleas to charges of passing secrets to C.I.A. station chiefs.   The two were to be sentenced Wednesday.

headline: BURKINA FASO SAYS MALI RAIDED BORDER AREAS
abstract: Burkina Faso said today that troops and planes from the neighboring West African country of Mali had attacked a border village and two towns, killing four people, and that its own troops had killed 10 Malians.   In the Malian capital, Bamako, a communique from the ruling party said Malian troops had ''freed'' four border villages occupied by troops from Burkina Faso but denied Burkina Faso's claims that 10 Malians were killed and six tanks destroyed in the fighting.   It said Malian troops had mounted what it called a counterattack on the villages, which it said had been occupied by Burkina Faso forces two weeks ago. It said one Malian was wounded in the attack.

headline: PERES AND HUSSEIN ARE SAID TO REACH ACCORD ON TALKS
abstract: Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel and King Hussein of Jordan have an informal agreement to work toward negotiations in which Israel will agree to attend an international conference in return for Jordan's agreeing to bring to the conference only Palestinians acceptable to Israel, Israeli Government sources said today.         This understanding between King Hussein and Mr. Peres apparently was arranged through American mediation and other contacts over the last month. Israeli politicians have said that Mr. Peres met secretly with Mr. Hussein in Paris last month, but Mr. Peres called the assertion ''nonsense.''

headline: White's Profit Plunges 48.6%
abstract: White Consolidated Industries reported today that its third-quarter earnings plunged 48.6 percent to $7.4 million, or 44 cents a share, from $14.4 million, or 89 cents a share, a year earlier.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: Beverly Enterprises has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $400 million of zero coupon convertible notes, due 2003, through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets as sole underwriter.    * Canada is issuing $500 million (U.S.) of 10 percent, 10-year Eurobonds at 99 3/4, through underwriters led by Deutsche Bank Capital Markets Ltd.    * Chrysler Financial Corp. is issuing $100 million of 10 7/8 percent Eurobonds, due 1991, at 99 7/8, through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

headline: Computerland
abstract: The Computerland Corporation plans to reduce the 8 percent royalty fee charged its franchisees by 1 percent as of Jan. 1, industry sources said.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    * Citicorp is issuing $150 million of 9 3/8 percent Eurobonds due in 1989 at 101 1/4 through Goldman Sachs International.    * CPC International is issuing 200 million marks of 6 3/4 percent, 15-year Eurobonds at a price of 100 through Bank Deutsche Genossenschraftsbank.    * First Jersey National Corp. filed $32.5 million of debt securities.

headline: REPUBLIC BANK CARVES NICHE
abstract: The Republic National Bank of New York is the nation's 30th-largest bank. But one would never know it from its operations.   Under the helm of Edmond J. Safra, its conservative Lebanese founder, Republic neither courts big corporations for loans nor casts a wide net for consumer deposits. Its loans, in fact, represented only $2.71 billion, or 21.6 percent, of its $12.53 billion in assets as of last Sept. 30, probably the lowest percentage for any major banking organization. And it sports only three automatic teller machines.   What Republic does do - quite profitably, analysts say - is earn interest on money it deposits at other banks, deal in gold and deliver foreign currencies to governments and financial institutions.

headline: MANILA COURT SAID TO UPHOLD ELECTION
abstract: The Philippines Supreme Court voted 7 to 5 today to allow early presidential elections to proceed as scheduled on Feb. 7, according to three of the judges.   Their ruling removes an obstacle that had threatened the election since Mr. Marcos announced it early last month. Eleven petitions before the court had claimed that the election, as structured by Mr. Marcos, was unconstitutional because he did not resign to create a vacancy.   ''We'll have an election,'' said Justice Venicio Escolin after 12 of the court's 13 judges met to consider their ruling following two days of hearings.

headline: PUBLIC HAS LOW EXPECTATIONS FOR GENEVA, POLL SHOWS
abstract: Only half the American public expects the summit meeting next week between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev to improve Soviet-American relations, and just a third thinks it will lead to an arms-control agreement, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.   The low expectations appeared to match the cautious prospects that have been outlined by Reagan Administration officials, who have been anxious to avoid raising hopes that might be dashed if the Geneva meeting is unproductive.   The survey showed that Americans were eager for an arms-control treaty with the Soviet Union, even to the point of giving up President Reagan's proposed space-based missile defense system if necessary.      Little Optimism on Compromise    But few said they thought President Reagan and Mr. Gorbachev were ready to make the compromises that might be required to get such an accord. Those surveyed were also about evenly divided about the wisdom of raising human rights issues at a summit meeting and were overwhelmingly convinced that no progress in that field could be made at the Geneva talks.

headline: RETAILERS AWAIT SHOPPING TREND
abstract: The 1985 Christmas shopping season, now slightly past its mid-point, does not yet show a clear pattern, a survey finds. Retailers in six major cities report results ranging widely from ''sluggish'' to gains of about 10 percent over last year.   With this year's season shortened by six shopping days, and amid a pervasive climate of consumer demand for bargains, few stores so far are reporting the ebullient results that should be expected at this point if the season is to be a strong one. Considerable hope, however, is expressed for the remaining nine shopping days, and it is still possible that a buying surge could make up for the erratic behavior thus far.

headline: Laser Beams Used In Cancer Treatment
abstract: A team of eight Japanese inventors has patented a device that uses laser beam pulses to diagnose and treat cancer.

headline: ARGENTINE PRESIDENT SAYS TERRORIST AIM TO OUST DEMOCRACY
abstract: President Raul Alfonsin said tonight that ''professionals of violence who had been left without a function'' in a democratic Argentina were making an ''absurd'' attempt to destabilize his Government.   ''Even though it is incredible, because it appears absurd, they want to take power,'' he said, referring to those accused of involvement in recent bombings and bomb threats.

headline: 'LA VIOLENCIA' IN COLUMBIA: SEEDS WERE SOWN LONG AGO
abstract: ''La Violencia'' is a phrase well known in the history of Colombia, a name given to a specific decade of civil war in which some 280,000 people were killed.   But in a broader sense ''the violence'' is a scourge that has afflicted the South American country from before the turn of the century, giving it an unwanted reputation beyond its borders.   The seeds for the clash Thursday between the army and M-19 guerrillas, which left about 100 people dead at the modernistic Palace of Justice, have ancient roots. Violence has become commonplace for Colombia's 26 million people, arising from the actions of half a dozen leftist guerrilla groups and heightened by the viciousness of the Colombian narcotics trade.

headline: BONNER ARRIVES IN U.S. FOR MEDICAL TREATMENT
abstract: Yelena G. Bonner, the wife of the dissident Soviet physicist Andrei D. Sakharov, arrived in the United States today to seek medical treatment for a heart ailment.   She flew to Boston late this afternoon from New York, where she stopped briefly after a few days in Italy.   Soviet authorities last month granted Miss Bonner, 62 years old, a three-month visa for medical purposes. She flew to Italy on Monday to consult with an eye specialist.

headline: Lorimar Saves Two Accounts
abstract: BY spinning off a new agency, Lorimar Inc. will be able to save about $30 million in billings from conflicting accounts resulting from its latest agency acquisition.   All set to open its doors on Jan. 1 is USAdvertising whose two accounts, for starters, will be Quaker State Oil and Ponderosa Steakhouse division. The account teams that have been serving them at Kenyon & Eckhardt will be moving in to the new, separate quarters somewhere in midtown.

headline: A NOBEL ECONCOMIST LOOKS BACK
abstract: Franco Modigliani, the M.I.T. professor who was awarded the 1985 Nobel Memorial Prize in Econommic Science, started to become a doctor but couldn't stand the sight of blood. A winnng entry in an Italian essay contest put him on the road to law and economics, and he wound up under the tutelage of Jacob Marschak at the New School for Social Research in New York, where he got his first training in macroeconomics and developed many of his neo-Keynesian views.

headline: NIGERIA REPORTS ARREST OF COUP PLOTTERS
abstract: Nigeria has foiled a plot to depose its four-month-old military Government, and many military officers have been arrested, the Defense Minister said today.   Three army generals and several senior air force officers were among those seized for plotting against the Government of Maj. Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, high-ranking military sources said. The coup attempt was still being plotted when the arrests were made, the sources said.

headline: THE LAWYER WHO BEAT TEXACO
abstract: Kirk Douglas sent a note. Willie Nelson called. So did such high-powered personal injury lawyers as Philip Corboy from Chicago, Bruce Walkup from San Francisco and Richard Haynes, from just down the street.   They were congratulating Joseph D. Jamail Jr. on his stunning courtroom victory here Tuesday, when a jury ordered Texaco Inc. to pay $10.53 billion to his client, the Pennzoil Company.

headline: U.N. SPEAKERS DEAL WITH REGIONAL CONFLICTS
abstract: Many speakers at the General Assembly dealt today with the spread of regional conflicts, with some pointing to the continuing violence in South Africa as an example of these tensions.   ''The latest events in South Africa unequivocally reveal the profound crisis gripping the Pretoria regime,'' said the Foreign Minister of Bulgaria, Peter Mladenov.   Mr. Mladenov urged the United Nations to impose mandatory sanctions against South Africa. The Foreign Minister of Tunisia, Beji Caid Essebsi, also called for mandatory sanctions.

headline: Transway Accepts $331.2 Million Bid
abstract: The Transway International Corporation, a freight forwarder based in White Plains, said its board of directors had entered into a merger agreement with a subsidiary of the International Controls Corporation for a package of $24 a share in cash and subordinated debentures that the company said were worth another $24 a share. The deal was valued at around $331.2 million.

headline: SCM Adds a Wrinkle to Bidding War
abstract: The SCM Corporation, in a move apparently intended to put pressure on a British company trying to take it over against its will, said yesterday that its directors had authorized it to pay $74 a share, or $610 million in cash and securities, for two-thirds of the company's stock.   SCM said the offer was intended to protect shareholders in the event of the failures of two competing offers - a $75-a-share bid by Hanson Trust P.L.C. of London and a $74-a-share management buyout proposed by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.   SCM stressed, however, that if either Hanson or Merrill were successful in buying the company, its own offer would be withdrawn.   Analysts noted that if SCM did buy two-thirds of its stock, Hanson, which owns the rest, would then have a stake in a heavily indebted company.

headline: 11 Killed in Sri Lanka In Explosion and Battle
abstract: A land mine attack by Tamil separatists and a battle with security forces killed 11 people, including 4 policemen, in eastern Sri Lanka today, Government officials said.

headline: HIGH DEBT COULD STRANGLE THE ECONOMY
abstract: BY THE end of 1985, American corporations will achieve the dubious distinction of being in debt $1.56 trillion, the highest level in our entire history. After netting out the impact of inflation, this debt has been growing at a dizzying pace of 8.6 percent a year in 1984 and 1985, compared with 2.7 percent annually from 1975 to 1983. Corporate debt now exceeds the total net worth of corporations by 12 percent.   To many observers, this corporate debt is no cause for concern. It merely reflects the strong investment boom we have experienced in the recent economic recovery. Indeed, some suggest that it is a sign of strength - of an economy responding to President Reagan's economic policies; of corporations borrowing to invest in modern plant and equipment; and of confidence among financial institutions that the debt can easily be paid off.

headline: 258 ON U.S. TROOP FLIGHT DIE AS PLANE CRASHES IN GANDER ON WAY HOME FROM MIDEAST
abstract: A chartered jetliner crashed on takeoff at the international airport here today, killing all 258 people reported aboard, all but eight of them American soldiers headed home for Christmas.   The soldiers were returning to Fort Campbell, Ky., from Cairo by way of Cologne, West Germany, after a six-month tour of duty with the international peacekeeping force in the Sinai Peninsula. The other eight dead were believed to be crew members.   American and Canadian officials said there were no preliminary indications of sabotage.

headline: AN OBSTACLE COURSE FOR INTRUDERS
abstract: ANYONE trying to sneak into the operations facility of Great American Federal Operations Center, a savings bank in National City, Calif., has to contend with an electronic obstacle course. Wired iron gates surround the employee parking and vehicle service areas, while closed-circuit televisions monitor activities. And an intruder trying to get into restricted areas without a current access card will set off an alarm at the guard's monitoring station.

headline: NATIONAL GYPSUM GETS BUYOUT OFFER
abstract: Executives of the National Gypsum Company offered yesterday to buy the big supplier of building products for about $1.1 billion in cash and securities and then make it a private company.   The leveraged buyout proposal, which was submitted to directors, calls for the investor group to pay $40.50 in cash plus $17 in debentures for each of Gypsum's 22.8 million shares.   Traders, pointing out that the debentures paid no interest for the first five years, valued them at only about $9.50, which would make the offer worth about $50 a share. At that price, Gypsum's 22.8 million shares would be worth $1.1 billion.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    * American Can Co. is offering $100 million of 11 1/8 percent notes due 1992 at a price of 99 5/8 to yield 11.203 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The notes are rated Baa-1 by Moody's and BBB by Standard & Poor's.    * American Fletcher Corp. is issuing 110 million Swiss francs of 5 1/2 percent, 10-year bonds at a price of 100 1/2 through underwriters led by Citicorp Bank (Switzerland) A.G.    * Boise-Cascade Corp. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of up to $175 million of debt securities.    * Dayton-Hudson Corp. is issuing $100 million of 10 5/8 percent Eurobonds due 1995 at a price of 99 3/4 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs International Corp.    * Ford Motor Credit Bank A.G. is privately placing 75 million West German marks of 6 1/2 percent, 5-year bonds at 100 through underwriters led by Westdeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale.

headline: Nissan Raising Prices
abstract: The Nissan Motor Corporation said today that it was increasing all of its car and truck prices an average of 4 percent, or about $400 a car, because of the increase in the value of the Japanese currency. Nissan's parent company in Japan has been the most vocal of the auto makers there about the need to adjust prices because of the change in the value of the yen. Recently, it increased the prices of the cars it sells its American subsidiary by 4.5 percent.

headline: C.D.'s Little Changed; Money Funds Higher
abstract: Rates on certificates of deposit and money market accounts remained virtually unchanged for the week ended yesterday, while money market mutual fund yields moved up for the first time in two weeks.   According to The Bank Rate Monitor's national index, the average yield on a bank money market account stands at 6.90 percent, down one basis point, or one one-hundredth of a percentage point, from 6.91 percent last week. The average yield on a six-month C.D. inched up to 7.74 percent, from 7.73 percent. The index's yield figures are based on rates available for the lowest minimum deposits at institutions.

headline: FOREIGN LOAN PLAN MET COOLLY
abstract: Representatives of small and medium-size banks gave a chilly reception today  to a speech by Paul A. Volcker, the Federal Reserve chairman, asking that they provide fresh loans to troubled debtor countries. Even some larger banks expressed reservations.         That unwillingness could make it more difficult for for the Reagan Administration to get Western banks to make $20 billion in new loans to debtor countries in the next three years.

headline: Middle South Rate
abstract: Middle South Utilities said its Louisiana Power and Light Company unit had accepted the Louisiana Public Service Commission's offer of an annual rate inrease totaling about $310 million to cover its first-year share of the costs of two nuclear power plants. The utility had requested annual increases of $444 million for the Waterford Three unit, which began commercial operation in September, and $113.9 million for Grand Gulf One, which went into service in July.

headline: ISRAEL SAYS IT HIT BASES IN LEBANON
abstract: Israeli Air Force jets attacked Palestinian guerrilla bases in the Bekaa region of eastern Lebanon today, the Israeli military reported.   There were no immediate reports on casualties in the raid, the 13th against guerrilla bases in Lebanon this year.   An Israeli military spokesman, in a communique, said the aircraft had made direct hits on their targets and had returned safely to base. The communique, quoted in a report by the Israeli radio that was monitored here, said the jets had attacked two bases belonging to the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command, which is led by Ahmed Jabril.

headline: Genex Sues G. D. Searle
abstract: G. D. Searle & Company was accused today of fraud and securities laws violations by the Genex Corporation, which for two years has supplied Searle with a key ingredient for the production of aspartame, the sugar-substitute Searle markets as Nutrasweet and Equal.   Genex, a biotechnology company based in Rockville, Md., is asking in a Federal court suit filed in Baltimore for $40 million in actual damages as well as additional compensation under antitrust and anti-racketeering statutes. A Searle spokesman said that company officials had not seen the suit and could not comment.

headline: The U.N. Today; Dec. 4, 1985
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Political and Security Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Special Political Committee -10:30 A.M.   Economic and Financial Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 3 P.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 7 P.M.   Legal Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Council for Namibia - 10:30 A.M.

headline: Money Fund Assets Fall
abstract: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds decreased $550.3 million, to $208.7 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, marking the second consecutive week that declines were registered in all categories, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The 73 institutional funds led the decline, falling $254.1 million, to $52.837 billion. Assets of the 192 general purpose funds were down $142.9 million, to $61.774 billion, and the 87 broker-dealer funds fell $153.3 million, to $94.093 billion.

headline: LEBANESE MILITIA CHIEFS SIGN PEACE PACT IN SYRIA
abstract: Leaders of Lebanon's rival militia forces signed a pact today designed to end a decade of sectarian warfare that has left tens of thousands of people dead and devastated a country that was once among the most prosperous in the Middle East.   The signing took place in Damascus, Syria, under the supervision of Syria's First Vice President, Abdel Halim Khaddam, who had been the broker at three months of negotiations among the armed factions that have been fighting one another since 1975.   The agreement was signed by Nabih Berri, the leader of the mainstream Shiite Moslem movement called Amal; his ally, Walid Jumblat, who is head of the mostly Druse Progressive Socialist Party, and Elie Hobeika, the commander of the powerful Christian militia known as the Lebanese Forces.   ''It is all over,'' Mr. Berri told reporters, alluding to the civil war that in effect partitioned the country into fiefdoms controlled by militia heads, who virtually replaced the central Government in power.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 25, 1985
abstract: The Economy    The Senate signaled its approval of a bill to limit imports of textiles and footwear. The test vote was 54 to 42, but a final vote was not taken. Sponsors want to make the bill an amendment to a deficit-reduction bill, believing that would shield it from a veto. But Senator Dole said President Reagan is prepared to veto the entire bill if it contains the import provisions. [Page A1.]    Representative Rostenkowski is willing to retain deductions for state and local tax payments, according to the members of his Ways and Means Committee. In return, they said, Mr. Rostenkowski received their pledges to support overall revision of the tax system. This means a tax bill that gets through the committee would probably keep the state and local deductions. [D1.]

headline: A BANK TELLER'S DIPLOMATIC JOB
abstract: THEY blow cigar smoke in Eleanora Ribaudo's face, and she turns the other cheek. They accuse her of cheating them, and she wishes them a nice day. But it was too much when her own employer, Citibank, threw a party last month for some of its tellers and hired a comedian who joked about tellers being reluctant to tell strangers what they did for a living. ''I was really shocked,'' Miss Ribaudo said. ''I'm not ashamed to be a teller.''   Miss Ribaudo, who is 18 years old, has been a teller for about 5 months at Citibank's headquarters branch at Park Avenue and 53d Street. As such, she is in banking's trenches. One of the favorite complaints of New Yorkers is the incompetence, indifference or downright impertinence of the tellers where they bank. But the tellers have a complaint, too: that banking brings out the worst in many New Yorkers.   ''The first thing you learn in teller training is that there are people who come in here, they're angry, they can't count money, they take it out on you,'' said Miss Ribaudo, who underwent two weeks of classroom instruction in a mock banking setup and two days of on-the-job training. ''There's ways and ways to deal with tellers. Sometimes I think there ought to be training for customers.''

headline: Aramco Will Cut 7,000, Paper Says
abstract: Aramco, Saudi Arabia's giant oil production company, plans to reduce its work force by 7,000, or about 13 percent, by the end of 1986, according to a report that quoted company officials. The officials, whose names were not disclosed in the report by the English-language Saudi Gazette, said the cutbacks were necessary because declining oil production had reduced revenues.

headline: Advertising;   Robins Picks Agency
abstract: Just in time for winter, the folks at Scali, McCabe, Sloves have been named to do the creative work for the A. H. Robins Company's Robitussin cough and cold products and Dimetapp cold and allergy medications.

headline: JUSTICE DEPT. BACKS PEOPLE DEAL
abstract: The Justice Department said today that it has urged the Transportation Department to approve the application of People Express Airlines to acquire Frontier Airlines. In comments filed with the Transportation Department, the Justice Department's antitrust division said the proposed acquisition ''clearly would have no anti-competitive effect and therefore should be exempted'' from further Government review.   Separately, in Denver, members of Frontier's Air Line Pilots Association Local 1635 voted 271 to 92 in support of the proposed sale, clearing away another potential obstacle to the transaction.

headline: NEW-HOME SALES OFF BY 5.6%
abstract: Sales of new homes fell 5.6 percent in August from their July peak, the Government said today, but analysts shrugged off the decline, saying that attractive mortgage rates should keep demand strong.   Sales of new single-family homes were put at an annual rate of 705,000 in August, seasonally adjusted, according to a report from the Departments of Commerce and Housing and Urban Development.   The month's decline followed a 5.5 percent rise in July. That was revised upward from an originally reported 1.4 percent increase.

headline: ARMS ACCORD: ELUSIVE GOAL
abstract: With new proposals advanced on both sides, the United States and the Soviet Union are now in a position for some form of general accord on limiting offensive and defensive nuclear arms.   But the assessment on both sides remains that agreement will not be reached.   Nonetheless, key Administration experts have prepared standby drafts calling for 50 percent cuts in strategic and medium-range forces and restricting defenses to ''research'' consistent with existing treaty obligations.   But it is doubtful whether President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, will use these drafts and agree on general principles or guidelines for arms-control negotiators. It depends on whether they are prepared either to make significant mutual concessions, which officials on both sides say they doubt, or to paper over differences on critical details with rhetorical compromises, the value of which is debated by officials on both sides.

headline: JEWISH GROUP SUPPORTS CLAIMS AGAINST FLICK
abstract: A Jewish organization is supporting a demand that Deutsche Bank A.G., which is in the process of buying the giant Flick concern, be required to indemnify former Jewish wartime slave laborers forced to work in Flick's factories.   The group, the Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany, said Thursday that it had endorsed the position of Robert M. W. Kempner, the former Deputy United States Counsel at the Nuremberg war crimes trials, that the bank should satisfy those claims of surviving former slave laborers negotiated in the 1960's.   Friedrich Flick, the father of the present Flick owner, rejected the settlement, which foresaw payment of between 5 million and 7 million marks, then worth $1.25 million to $1.75 million, to the survivors.

headline: Argentine Officer Defends Anti-Terror Role
abstract: One of the nine Argentine armed forces officers on trial for large-scale human-rights abuses addressed the court today for the first time.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 25, 1985
abstract: The Economy    Machine tool orders rose 33 percent in October from September, but fell 18.4 percent from year-ago levels. Analysts saw the increase as encouraging, but said the industry remains plagued by competition from imports and other problems. [Page D1.]

headline: Credit Aid For Farms
abstract: The Senate tonight approved legislation that would reorganize and assist the financially strained Farm Credit System.   The reform bill, passed by a voice vote, now goes back to the House of Representatives, where it was considered and approved a week ago in a slightly different form. The House is expected to consider the bill on Wednesday, approve it and then send it on to the President. Mr. Reagan has said that he would sign it.

headline: MUBARAK REACTION REFLECTS EGYPT'S POLITICAL CLIMATE
abstract: Diplomats and Egyptian officials said today that President Hosni Mubarak's harsh condemnation of the United States was a response not merely to the American diversion of an Egyptian airliner but also to an American assault on Egyptian pride and dignity.   The humiliation of Egypt, they said, was intensified by America's unconcealed jubilation over the interception of the Egyptair Boeing 737 and lingering Egyptian fury over what was seen here as the Reagan Administration's condoning of Israel's air attack on the Palestine Liberation Organization's headquarters in Tunis two weeks ago.   ''Egypt has lost almost everything since 1967, the year of its war with Israel - its wealth, its military prowess, its traditional leadership of the Arab world,'' said one Arab diplomat here today. ''Almost everything has been taken from Egypt,'' he said, except its dignity and self-esteem.   Western and Arab officials interviewed here in the last few days said that in addition to trying to salvage some of his country's self-esteem, Mr. Mubarak's harsh denunciation of the United States was also aimed at protecting his political flanks from internal criticism stemming from Egypt's ties to the United States and his handling of the hijacking episode.

headline: POLICE DRAW FIRE NEAR CAPE TOWN
abstract: A police patrol came under fire in a squatter camp outside Cape Town today, and in the ensuing battle officers killed one black man and wounded another, the police said.   Such exchanges of fire have been rare in the last 14 months of protest in segregated black townships because blacks rarely have access to arms. The police said a pistol and a semiautomatic rifle were confiscated after the shooting, which occurred in a camp known as Crossroads.

headline: Bonds Are Priced For Health Care
abstract: A $165 million tax-exempt bond issue of the Mercy Health Care System of Providence, R.I., and Cincinnati was tentatively priced yesterday with a maximum yield of 9.83 percent for 9 3/4 percent bonds due in 2013 at a price of 99 1/4, according to underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.   The financing, which will refund bonds previously sold on behalf of three hospitals, also includes serial bonds yielding from 5 3/4 percent in 1986 to 8.80 percent in 1995 and 9.40 percent in 2000. Because the bonds are insured by the Ambac Indemnity Corporation, the issue was rated AAA by S.&P.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Maker of Fake MSG Jailed
abstract: Chinese television said today that a court in Fuzhou sentenced a man to life imprisonment on Tuesday for producing fake monosodium glutamate and selling it as the taste-enhancer commonly used in Chinese cooking. The court found Zheng Qing and two accomplices guilty of producing 28 tons of fake MSG, valued at $6,300. The two others were sentenced to three years and two and a half years in prison.

headline: Washington Watch;   Issues for Trade Official
abstract: A former Senate aide, Paul Freedenberg, is about to become Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Trade Administration, a difficult position that has been unfilled for the last two years.   Mr. Freedenberg, whose nomination is expected to be cleared next week and is already working in his new office as a consultant, says his top priority is to obtain greater cooperation with allies in the delicate, often contentious effort to balance trade and national security considerations.

headline: BAKER SEES SELF-INTEREST OF BANKS AS LOAN SPUR
abstract: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d said today that the Government was not ''arm-twisting'' commercial banks or promising either Federal guarantees or regulatory relief in its campaign to persuade the banks to lend an extra $20 billion to developing countries over three years.   ''If the banks participate in this it will be because they find it is in their self-interest,'' he insisted at a hearing before the House Banking Committee. ''They've got loans in trouble. It's like any other workout situation. It's possible that reflows will make bad loans into good loans.''

headline: IRAN'S FUTURE: DIFFERENT SORT OF AYATOLLAH
abstract: His face is featured on huge posters at airports, shops and offices throughout Iran. The posters are equal in size to those of Iran's leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, who calls him ''the fruit of my life.''   But Ayatollah Hussein Ali Montazeri, 63 years old, the ayatollah who was named last week to succeed Ayatollah Khomeini after his death, hardly resembles his spiritual mentor.

headline: 5 DIE IN LEBANON SUICIDE BOMB ATTACK
abstract: Five Christian political leaders escaped an assassination attempt today when a suicide bomber crashed an explosives-laden truck into a monastery where they were meeting north of here.   The assailant and four other people were reported killed and 23 wounded.   A hitherto unknown Christian faction took responsibility. An anonymous caller telephoned a Western news agency and said ''the Vanguard of Arab Christians'' had carried out the attack against the Lebanese Front.

headline: A Trying Year for Anderson
abstract: In 1985, Warren M. Anderson faced a year of virtually unending turmoil.   As chairman and chief executive of the Union Carbide Corporation, he has had to cope with the aftermath of the chemical leak that killed 2,000 and injured 200,000 late in 1984 at the company's Bhopal, India, plant.

headline: Thai Fugitive Reported In West Germany
abstract: The leader of the unsuccessful coup in Thailand last month, Manoon Rupekarchorn, is in West Germany, the Foreign Ministry said today.

headline: VOLCKER TRIP TO ARGENTINA EXPECTED
abstract: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, will make an unusual trip to Argentina in a week or so, according to senior officials of the Reagan Administration and international banking organizations.   International economists speculated that Mr. Volcker, who has been one of the leading figures in helping developing countries deal with their debts, would begin exploring the possibility of a new, less restrictive loan than Argentina has been able to arrange since the world debt crisis erupted three years ago.   They said Argentina might be the first major debtor to be granted a ''Baker loan'' - a long-term loan of $1 billion or more to help the economy grow, rather than the sort of loans requiring severe austerity measures to subdue inflation and other economic excesses of such countries. Under a plan recently proposed by Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d, such financing might be provided by the world bank and private banks.

headline: Yugoslav Leaders Warn of Social Unrest
abstract: The Yugoslav state leadership has warned Prime Minister Milka Planinc's Government that a worsening economic crisis could start social unrest among the country's 22 million people, the Yugoslav press agency said today.   The eight-member collective presidency delivered its message Monday night at an emergency joint session with the Government, the press agency said.

headline: Navy Finds a Defect In McDonnell Fighters
abstract: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation will be required to repair hundreds of F-18 fighter planes and fix the design of future planes because a critical part of the fuselage cracked in stress tests, a Navy officer said today.   Capt. George Strohsahl, the project officer for the Navy's $20 million fighter, said test results supplied by McDonnell Douglas last week indicated that the plane would not last its intended 6,000 hours of flying time -about 20 years of normal operations.   He said engineers estimated the safe flying life of the planes was reduced by the faulty part to at best 5,000 hours, and possibly as low as 2,000 hours.

headline: PROSTITUTION IS BACK, AND PEKING ISN'T HAPPY
abstract: More than 30 years after the Communist Party claimed to have eradicated prostitution in China, the revival of the practice is causing concern at high levels in Peking.   For more than a year, foreign visitors have been aware of young Chinese women engaging in prostitution in and around the big-city hotels where foreigners stay, particularly in the southern city of Canton. But it is only in the last week that the practice has been publicly condemned by party leaders.   The issue has strong political connotations. The tens of thousands of prostitutes in pre-1949 China were regarded by the Communists as a symptom of the country's degradation, and their elimination was hailed as a symbol of the new, wholesome society ordained by Mao Zedong. Their return has been seized on by some party leaders as a fresh and particularly unpalatable example of the dangers of allowing the ''taint'' of Western ''money grubbing'' influence into the country.

headline: New Executive At McCall
abstract: After a four-month search for a No. 2 man, Raymond Eyes, president and publisher of the McCall Publishing Company, has landed Robert J. Krefting, the 41-year-old former president of CBS Publications.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Japan's Bond Rules Irk U.S.
abstract: The United States criticized Japan for failing to move quickly enough to ease restrictions on its capital markets as financial talks ended today.

headline: YEVTUSHENKO TALK IS HEAVILY EDITED
abstract: The Soviet literary weekly today published a heavily censored version of a recent speech by the poet Yevgeny Yevtushenko that had called for candor and openess in Soviet literature.   The version published by the weekly Literaturnaya Gazeta, a main organ of the Soviet Writers' Union, left out several major sections of Mr. Yevtushenko's remarks, including all references to Stalin's purges, the evils of collectivization, the privileges of the elite and all but one comment appealing for an end to censorship.   Although the published version did not completely obscure the bold tone of Mr. Yevtushenko's speech, it muted and blunted his comments.   Russians who compared the original speech and the printed version said the changes altered the character of the address.

headline: Fairchild Quits Saab Venture
abstract: Fairchild Industries said today that it was pulling out of a joint venture with Saab-Scania A.B. of Sweden for production of 340 turbocraft airplanes for the commuter airline market.   Fairchild said it would become a subcontractor on Nov. 1 and ''ultimately end its participation in the program.''

headline: Pacific Merger Raises Objection
abstract: Three grandchildren of a former chairman of the Pacific Lumber Company, who together own 3 percent of the company's shares, said they are ''adamantly opposed'' to the $869 million merger agreement reached between Pacific's board and the Maxxam Group last Wednesday. ''The long-term value of the company's assets is substantially higher'' than Maxxam's $40-a-share offer, said Stanwood Murphy, a grandson of the former chairman, Albert S. Murphy.

headline: CLAUDE SIMON OF FRANCE WINS THE NOBEL PRIZE IN LITERATURE
abstract: Claude Simon, a leading practitioner of the French nouveau roman, or new novel, today won the Nobel Prize in Literature.   The Swedish Academy, in its announcement, said the 72-year-old writer's novels contained ''the poet's and the painter's creativeness'' and ''a deepened awareness of time in the depiction of the human condition.''   Mr. Simon's work, which is not widely known in the United States, is considered to be in the same school as that of Nathalie Sarraute and Alain Robbe-Grillet, but many critics believe that he transcends them, having a more supple, sinuous style and more of an interest in characters. The term ''new novel,'' introduced by the critic Roland Barthes, applied to a broad range of works by novelists in the postwar period whose stories did not unfold in the conventional manner as continuous and realistic narratives.

headline: STUDY WARNS OF INCREASE IN NUCLEAR ARMS SPREAD
abstract: Despite international efforts to stop the spread of nuclear weapons, the problem is worsening, according to a new report.   The study, made public here Monday by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, described developments in Pakistan and India as of particular concern.   The report also asserts that Western nations have been lax in punishing those who have been caught smuggling technology that can be used for making nuclear arms.   The report on ''The New Nuclear Nations'' is the second in a series of annual reviews written by Leonard S. Spector, a senior associate at Carnegie. Mr. Spector previously served as chief counsel of the Senate Energy and Nuclear Proliferation Subcommittee and helped draft 1978 legislation against the spread of nuclear weapons.

headline: Israelis Kill 4 Gunmen Linked to Five Deaths
abstract: The Israeli Army announced tonight that it had killed four Arabs who it said were responsible for killing two Jewish couples and a shopper in an Arab market.   The army said the four also wounded 18 people in their attacks.

headline: THE TETE-A-TETES AT THE SUMMIT: A DRAWN CURTAIN OF UNCERTAINTY
abstract: Tete-a-tetes have been a feature of all of the United States-Soviet summit conferences since World War II.   American Presidents have talked to Soviet leaders in offices, limousines, dachas, cabanas, studies and ordinary meeting rooms. But at none of the preceding meetings have the private sessions loomed as large as they have in Geneva this week.   As Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, noted today, the nearly five hours that President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev have spent together was a good deal more time than they devoted to full-dress meetings surrounded by aides, which were supposed to have taken up almost the entire schedule here.

headline: JACKSON LEADS BRITONS IN DENOUNCING PRETORIA
abstract: Led by the Rev.
