Jesse Jackson, tens of thousands of demonstrators gathered in London today to denounce apartheid in South Africa and to call for stiff economic sanctions against the Pretoria Government.   Fighting between a group of demonstrators and police officers broke out briefly in front of the South African Embassy in Trafalgar Square. Protesters threw fireworks, cans, eggs and red paint at policemen guarding the embassy.

headline: 6 Firebombs Explode In West German Stores
abstract: Six incendiary bombs exploded in department stores today, the ninth straight day of street battles and violence against the police in West German cities.   Five of the bombs set off small fires early today a few hours after thousands of people took to the streets in three cities to protest the death of a left-wing demonstrator killed by a police water cannon Sept. 28 at a protest in Frankfurt.

headline: LATIN ANTI-TERROR AID RESISTED IN CONGRESS
abstract: The Administration's request for $54 million in supplemental aid to create anti-terrorism programs for police and military forces in Central America ran into strong resistance in Congress today.   Representative Dante B. Fascell, a Florida Democrat and chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said he was inclined to cut the request in half and to exclude funds for Guatemala. But even if those reductions were made, he said, the committee might still reject the request.

headline: Bonner Says Remarks Did Not Break Promise
abstract: Yelena G. Bonner, the Soviet human rights activist, does not believe her remarks at a synagogue here on Saturday violated a pledge not to talk to reporters while she is in the West for medical treatment, her daughter said today.   In brief remarks at the synagogue, Miss Bonner said she hoped the Soviet Union would allow all Jews to join their families abroad.

headline: BERGERAC'S SUDDEN REVERSAL
abstract: What gives with Michel Bergerac?   Just two months ago, the 53-year-old chief executive of Revlon Inc. reacted to a hostile takeover bid for the cosmetics and health care giant by saying that ''We are not going to sit around and let these bust-up artists take away the company at a bargain-basement price.''   Now, he and the rest of the Revlon board are backing a buyout proposal from another bidder at a price $9 a share below the $65 Mr. Bergerac had said Revlon was worth. And what Mr. Bergerac and the board endorsed looks very much like the bust-up of Revlon that he seemed determined to avoid.   Under the breakup plan approved by Revlon on Thursday, the leveraged buyout firm of Forstmann Little & Company and members of Revlon's management, including Mr. Bergerac, will take the company private by paying shareholders $56 a share, or $1.77 billion. Before that happens, Revlon will sell off its cosmetics business - and with it, the Revlon name - for $900 million, to another investment firm.

headline: Pakistani Leader Delays Trip to West Germany
abstract: Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq called off a scheduled visit to West Germany today as opposition mounted to a bill meant to pardon him for the last eight years of martial law rule.   General Zia President of Pakistan, had to postpone the Oct. 16 to 19 visit ''due to his commitments in the country,'' a Foreign Ministry spokesman said.

headline: British Coal Chief Chosen
abstract: Ian MacGregor, the 73-year-old Scottish-born American who led Britain's National Coal Board during the bitter yearlong strike that ended in March, will be succeeded when his appointment ends next September by Sir Robert Haslam, Energy Secretary Peter Walker said today.   Sir Robert, 62, is chairman of the state-owned British Steel Corporation and of Tate & Lyle P.L.C., a sugar company.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

headline: HOME STATE INDICTMENTS
abstract: A state grand jury today indicted Marvin L. Warner, the former owner of the failed Home State Savings Bank of Cincinnati, on charges of financial wrongdoing. He was charged with 45 counts of willful misapplication of funds, 4 counts of securities violations and a count of theft by deception.

headline: DEAL PUZZLES MANY ON WALL STREET
abstract: The United States Steel Corporation's $3.6 billion agreement to buy the Texas Oil and Gas Corporation got mixed reviews on Wall Street yesterday.   Many professional traders said they thought some stockholders -particularly those owning Texas Oil - might be unhappy.   But analysts said they thought the deal would be favorable for U.S. Steel stockholders, over the long run.   Many stock watchers, nevertheless, seemed to be at a loss to explain why Texas Oil was sold for what many felt was far less than expected.

headline: RULING ON PHONE ACCESS AIDS CASE FOR BUSINESS
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission division in charge of telephone services has ruled that it is legal for a local telephone company to provide service to business customers in another local phone company's franchise area whenever the customer requests the service.   The decision sets new precedent in granting business customers flexibility in choosing a local phone company, commission officials said.   The ruling, in a memorandum and order issued late Wednesday by the F.C.C.'s Common Carrier Bureau, overturned a ruling by the Texas utility regulatory authority, which held such service illegal on the ground that it violated state franchise laws.

headline: HOMELESS SIKHS RALLY IN INDIA
abstract: More than 1,000 impoverished victims of an anti-Sikh riot one year ago by Hindus held a rally today, demanding justice and aid from Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi.   ''One year after the rioting, we still are haunted and in pain,'' read a sign carried by the peaceful crowd of men, women and children.

headline: REWRITING TAX CODE: SLOW GOING
abstract: On Sept. 8, after the members of his House Ways and Means Committee returned from a weekend retreat to prepare for drafting tax-revision legislation, Representative Dan Rostenkowski warned that the lawmakers would have to ''live in a foxhole for two or three weeks'' to produce a tax bill.   Five weeks later, it is clear that Mr. Rostenkowski, an Illinois Democrat, underestimated the difficulty of rewriting the Federal tax code.   The committee has been in session now for two weeks - but there have been no night sessions, and, contrary to intitial expectations, the committee did not choose to meet over the long holdiay weekend.   A handful of votes has been taken on relatively minor issues. And a few more controversial matters, such as the size of personal exemptions, deductions for charitable contributions and write-offs for business meals and entertainment expenses, have been discussed at length but not voted on.

headline: Britain Urges Release Of Journalist in Lebanon
abstract: Britain appealed today for kidnappers to release Alec Collett, a British journalist held in Lebanon, but said it would not make a deal for his freedom.   Timothy Renton, a minister of state at the Foreign Office, said the release of Mr. Collett, who has been held since March 25, would do more to advance the Palestinian cause ''than anything else.''

headline: Productivity Up in Quarter
abstract: The productivity of American business increased at an annual rate of 2.1 percent in the third quarter, the Government reported today.   Output rose at an annual 3.9 percent rate while hours worked increased 1.8 percent from the second quarter, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported.

headline: THE BOOM IN STRETCH LIMOUSINES
abstract: Several times a day, Earle Moloney's staff removes all the wiring and plush upholstery from a top-of-the-line Cadillac Fleetwood Brougham or Lincoln Town Car, cuts the steel frame in half with a huge hacksaw and then welds on some longer body parts.   Operating out of a former Bally pinball machine factory here and two other plants, Mr. Moloney is one of the nation's foremost car surgeons. And that makes his 16-year-old Moloney Manufacturing Company a leader in a growing business - the stretching of $25,000 luxury sedans into $60,000 limousines, complete with glass partitions separating passengers and driver and the latest in electronic gadgets and other creature comforts.   With Detroit no longer making its own oversized cars, the limousine market largely belongs to Mr. Moloney and three dozen other customizers around the country - and the market is booming.

headline: Trilogy Merger
abstract: Trilogy Ltd. and Elxsi said they had received final approvals for their previously announced merger.

headline: FLUOR IS TAKING BIG WRITE-OFFS
abstract: The Fluor Corporation, acknowledging continuing troubles in its natural resource operations, said today that it would take write-offs totaling $410 million.   The action was expected to produce an overall loss of approximately $600 million at Fluor for its 1985 fiscal year, which closes at the end of October, according to David S. Tappan Jr., chairman.   Appearing before Wall Street analysts in New York, Mr. Tappan said the company's engineering and construction business was recovering from a low point a year ago, but was not expected to be profitable until sometime in 1986. Fluor is one of the nation's largest engineering and construction companies.

headline: BOND BUYING SPREE CONTINUES
abstract: Bond investors resumed their buying spree late last week on renewed expectations of still lower interest rates. While bond investors rushed to lock in existing yields, Treasury bills came under selling pressure from domestic and foreign holders, causing rates to move up smartly on Thursday and Friday as well.   By late Friday, the longest Treasury maturity, the 9 7/8 percent bonds of 2015, were up 2 1/8 points, to 105 18/32, while the yield fell to 9.32 percent, from 9.53 percent. The yield on the long bond compares with that of 10.5 percent last October and nearly 12 percent last March. In dollar terms, the long bond has risen $21.25 per each $1,000 of face value.

headline: ECONOMY GROWING AT SLUGGISH PACE
abstract: The Government said today that the economy appears to be growing at the tepid pace of 3.2 percent from October through December and 2.4 percent for the whole year, the smallest gain since 1982.   The annual figure, while subject to change, shows that the economy has grown about as much as most private economists have been forecasting and significantly less than the 3.9 percent that the Administration predicted at the start of this year.   The Commerce Department's report also estimated that inflation, based on the gross national product, is increasing at a 3.7 percent rate in the current quarter, well above the 2.7 percent rate of the third quarter.      Consumer Prices Up 0.6 Percent    This was consistent with the sharp rise of six-tenths of 1 percent in the Consumer Price Index in November that was reported today by the Labor Department. [Page 33.]  Economists and Administration officials said the fourth-quarter ''flash'' estimate for the gross national product suggested little change in the course of the economy's growth as it enters 1986.

headline: Wyoming Bonds
abstract: The Wyoming Community Development Authority is offering $75 million of single-family mortgage revenue bonds through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company.

headline: Poland Faces I.M.F. Delays
abstract: Poland's admission into the International Monetary Fund, considered vital by  Warsaw to gain fresh credit, has run into minor delays but is expected to be approved by April, monetary sources said Friday.         American Government sources said that Polish officials had been ''less than forthcoming'' with critical data needed to measure economic conditions. They said the United States, wary that Poland might misrepresent the condition of its ailing economy, wanted to scrutinize the data before approving the move.

headline: Liberian Opposition Threatens Vote Boycott
abstract: Opposition parties are threatening to boycott the first multiparty election in more than 130 years in this West African nation.   Opponents of Gen. Samuel K. Doe's military regime, which took power in a coup in 1980, have placed candidates on the ballot for next Tuesday's voting for a president, 26 Senate seats and 65 House of Representatives seats.

headline: E.D.S.'s Key Executive In Detroit Will Join Ford
abstract: Kenneth G. Riedlinger, the Electronic Data Systems Corporation's top official in Detroit, is leaving the General Motors Corporation subsidiary for the Ford Motor Company. Effective Oct. 7, Mr. Reidlinger will be executive director of special systems projects for Ford.

headline: G.M.A.C. Sale Of $400 Million
abstract: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation yesterday offered $400 million of medium-term notes, equally divided between the domestic market and the Euromarket.      The first financing was in the   Euromarket, where a 9 3/4 percent issue of seven-year notes was offered at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

headline: Advertising;   Iberia Air Lines Gives U.S. Billings to Ayer
abstract: Iberia Air Lines of Spain has selected N. W. Ayer as its United States agency. Ayer, which had served Pan American worldwide, is anxious to get the same arrangement with the Spaniards.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Crystal Oil Co., Shreveport, La., has named Joe N. Averett Jr. president, succeeding Robert F. Roberts, who will continue to serve as chairman.    * General Nutrition Inc., Pittsburgh, has elected its president and chief operating officer, Jerry D. Horn, to the additional post of chairman, which has been vacant since September 1984.

headline: SALE OF R.C.A. TO G.E. WILL REUNITE GIANTS
abstract: The sale of RCA was not entirely a surprise, given the popularity of broadcasting companies and the recurrent rumors of the possible purchase of NBC. But the price - $6.3 billion - and the buyer - G.E. - raised some eyebrows. G.E. had, however, said ite was looking for acquisitions to solidify its position in electronics. The G.E.-RCA deal, the larges non-oil merger in history, was put together quickly and quietly, but enough word leaked out that the stock price jumped more than $10 on the day of the announcement. Despite the overall euphoria and praise for the deal, a class-action suit said the companies should have disclosed the talks earlier, instead of allowing the rumor mill to run up the stock price.

headline: Arafat Meets Mubarak For Two Hours in Cairo
abstract: President Hosni Mubarak met for more than two hours today with Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, in an effort to ease strains in relations in the aftermath of the hijacking of the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro.   President Mubarak has been criticized for Egypt's role in resolving the hijacking, and there have been assertions that the P.L.O. was involved.   The talks today focused on ways to revive the Middle East peace intiative started last year by Mr. Mubarak, Mr. Arafat and King Hussein of Jordan.

headline: FIGURING THE TAXES ON FRINGE BENEFITS
abstract: IF the recent stock market rally has helped you reap handsome capital gains on some well-chosen securities, or if your company has provided you with a Mercedes that you also use for weekend jaunts, or if substantial outside income means that part of your Social Security retirement benefits are now taxable, you may be among the thousands of people who need to review their estimated tax status promptly.   The reason: If you do not pay tax as you receive income - either through salary withholding or quarterly estimated tax payments or a combination of the two - you can face a stiff penalty.   ''This year, figuring out your proper estimated tax and withholding is a whole new ball game,'' said Sidney Kess, director of tax policy for the accounting firm of Main Hurdman. ''The name of the game is to avoid paying a penalty.''

headline: EXCERPTS FROM A DRAFT OF THE BISHOPS' PASTORAL EXHORTATION
abstract: Following are excerpts from a draft text, obtained by The New York Times, of a pastoral exhortation from Roman Catholic bishops to the church. The letter was approved today in a slightly different form, which will be officially made public over the weekend.   We, your bishops, having come together from five continents and assembled in Rome for the Synod with the Pope, have come to live an intense moment of communion in prayer. As you know, the Holy Father has invited us in these days to celebrate with him the Second Vatican Council, to evaluate its implementation, and to promote it in the church so that it may be fully lived .

headline: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: ORTEGA CHIC
abstract: After Daniel Ortega Saavedra jogged through Central Park, his aides joked that the Nicaraguan President needs to stay in shape because, if the Reagan Administration gets its wish, the Sandinistas may have to resume the rough life of guerrillas some day.   If the revolutionary leader does return to the hills, he will do so with a full supply of designer eyewear.   His motorcade of 17 cars pulled up to the Cohen's Fashion Optical store on the Upper East Side the other morning. The store's manager, Noel Cottington, said he helped Mr. Ortega pick out something sophisticated and yet simple, lightweight and yet bulletproof.

headline: Computer Controls Speed of a Motor
abstract: A motor patented this week for Genentech Inc. of South San Francisco, Calif., has its speed controlled by a computer.

headline: Tailoring Of Games Magazine
abstract: FIRST there was segmented marketing. Then came marketing to segmented segments.   Example: If an advertiser wanted to reach about 650,000 people who tended to be youngish (average age, 29.8) and upscale (average household income, $37,000) his ad agency would be right on the money if it selected Games magazine for an ad or campaign.   And if that advertiser was interested in reaching only the segment that is responsive to direct marketing, Gerard Calabrese, the publisher, can be particularly obliging in that area too, thanks to technical advances made by his printer, R. R. Donnelley. The particular process is called Selectronic, which harnesses the devious cleverness of the computer with the printing press to allow Donnelley to tailor-make individual issues of the magazine if such is desired.

headline: JAPAN'S POLIC GUARD AGAINST MORE RAIL SABOTAGE
abstract: Several thousand riot policemen and rail workers guarded train stations and other installations of the Japan National Railways today to prevent a recurrence of the sabotage that shut down 23 commuter lines on Friday.   Stopgap repairs restored communications and signal systems that had been knocked out in well-timed raids, and trains ran on schedule throughout the day in Tokyo and Osaka. Both cities were badly snarled in the Friday morning rush hour as millions of stranded commuters jammed roads and private rail lines in search of alternative ways to get to work.   Meanwhile, Japanese police forces pressed their investigation into the sabotage, focusing on a band of left-wing extremists known as the Chukakuha, or Middle Core Faction. Nearly all of the 48 people arrested thus far in connection with the rail disruptions belong to the group, which has often led violent protests over the last two decades at Tokyo's main international airport in Narita.

headline: PENZOIL MAY SETTLE FOR ASSET DEAL
abstract: Indicating that the Pennzoil Company wants to avoid a prolonged court fight, J. Hugh Liedtke, the company's chairman and chief executive, said today that he would consider a transfer of assets by Texaco Inc. to Pennzoil to settle the $11.1 billion judgment entered against Texaco Tuesday.   ''I'm not saying for sure that we would in fact agree to it, but it certainly is something we would consider,'' Mr. Liedtke said during an interview at Pennzoil's headquarters here.   He said lawyers for Pennzoil and Texaco were ''in contact'' today, but declined to provide details of the discussions. He did say, however, that shortly before the decision on Tuesday Texaco had proposed a settlement involving the sale by Texaco of oil to Pennzoil.

headline: TO RESUME JAN. 16
abstract: The last session of arms talks before the Soviet-American summit meeting Nov. 19 and 20 ended today with an agreement to resume the talks early next year.   After a 100-minute meeting at the American headquarters opposite Geneva's botanical gardens, Max M. Kampelman, the chief United States negotiator, expressed the hope that ''the Soviets will study our proposals with utmost seriousness.''   The American envoy said the Reagan Administration's proposal for deep cuts in both sides' nuclear arsenals that was presented last Friday ''is serious, balanced, comprehensive and important.'' In a statement read to journalists, he described the proposal as taking ''into consideration the security needs of all sides.''

headline: MANUEL JOHNSON JR.
abstract: Jude Wanniski, the supply-side pamphleteer, calls Manuel H. Johnson Jr. a diplomat: ''He's civil. He doesn't attempt to put other people down. He doesn't ridicule their views.''   William A. Niskanen, who until early this year was a member of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, says Mr. Johnson ''is quiet and fairly effective,'' adding, ''He doesn't come to a meeting with fire in his eyes.''

headline: Bonner Unable to Book Phone Calls to Sakharov
abstract: Yelena G. Bonner is growing increasingly concerned about her husband, the Soviet dissident Andrei D. Sakharov, after trying in vain today to book a telephone call to him, her son said.   ''She is very worried about him,'' said the son, Alexei I. Semyonov.

headline: EX-HOSTAGE'S DAUGHTER IS KILLED
abstract: A daughter of the Rev. Benjamin Weir, a former American hostage in Lebanon, was killed Sunday night when the bus she was riding in was hit by a train near Alexandria, the United States Consulate said today.   A spokesman at the consulate said the woman, Ann Weir, and another American woman killed in the crash were aboard a Cairo-to-Alexandria express bus, the Golden Jet, when the accident occurred.

headline: Minstar Will Sell Three AMF Units
abstract: Minstar Inc. of Minneapolis, the holding company controlled by Irwin L. Jacobs, said it had signed letters of intent to sell three units of its AMF Inc. subsidiary.

headline: CARBIDE PLAN SENDS SHARES UP
abstract: The Union Carbide Corporation's plan to defend itself from a takeover through a repurchase of its own shares sent the stock price higher today.   The stock rose 75 cents, to $70.50, after trading as high as $71.75. It was the most heavily traded issue on the New York Stock Exchange.   The rise, analysts said, reflected not only the premium that the company would offer for the shares but also the chance that the GAF Corporation might raise its $68-a-share tender offer.

headline: AFGHAN REBELS REPORT U.S. DEATH
abstract: Afghan rebels said today that an American journalist, Charles Thornton, was killed in Afghanistan when the jeep in which he was riding was destroyed by a land mine on Wednesday.   The rebel sources said three other foreigners were wounded.

headline: Countrywide Sets Home Loan Issue
abstract: Countrywide Mortgage Obligations Inc., a subsidiary of Countrywide Credit Industries, a mortgage banking firm, is offering $126.7 million of collateralized mortgage obligations through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.   Yields range from 9.39 percent for 9 percent obligations that have an estimated average life of 2.3 years and a price of 99 29/32, to 10.15 percent for 10.20 percent obligations with an average life of 5.24 years and a price of 99 7/8.

headline: Rymer Offering 13% Debentures
abstract: The Rymer Company, a food processing company based in Rolling Meadows, Ill., is offering 60,000 units of senior subordinated sinking fund debentures and common stock purchase warrants at a price of 92.839 through underwriters led by Prudential-Bache Securities Inc.   Each unit consists of a 13 percent debenture due 1995 plus 12 seven-year warrants to buy an equal number of common shares.

headline: Texas University Bond Issue Set
abstract: A $344.6 million refunding bond issue for the University of Texas was tentatively priced with a maximum yield of 9.11 percent for bonds due in 2005, according to underwriters led by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York.   Among shorter-term maturities, yields ranged from 5 1/4 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 7.30 percent in 1991, 8.30 percent in 1996 and 9.05 percent in 2002. The bonds are rated AA+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation and are expected to be rated Aa by Moody's.

headline: Nuclear Plants' Operating Cost
abstract: The cost of operating and maintaining a nuclear power plant jumped 22 percent last year, according to a study by a consulting group based here. Over all, it found, running a reactor now costs roughly the same as running a coal plant.

headline: MACY BID CUT $2, TO $68 A SHARE
abstract: The management of R.H. Macy & Company said yesterday that it was lowering its offer to buy the retailer in a leveraged buyout to $68 a share in cash from $70 a share.   The revised bid, coming two months after Edward S. Finkelstein, Macy's chairman, and Mark S. Handler, president, announced the original offer, reflected the problem the group had in getting financing for the higher offer. ''The new price is what the financial markets indicate is the acceptable price,'' a spokesman for the buying group said. ''The $70 offer was too high.''

headline: Penn Central
abstract: The Penn Central Corporation said it had taken actions to recoup about $70 million of surplus assets from a number of its overfunded pension plans. The surplus will revert to the company on receipt of regulatory approvals, expected in the next three to nine months. Penn Central said the effects of this action on its earnings would be determined by new guidelines for pension accounting that are expected to be issued within the next week.

headline: AFTER THE ASHES FELL, WORLD BEGAN TO SCREAM
abstract: Survivors of a volcanic eruption that sent an avalanche of mud crashing through their homes early today said the sky lit up with fireballs spewing from the snowcapped mountain.   Edeliberto Nieto, crying uncontrollably, told a Bogota radio chain that he had lost his wife, mother and young daughter under the wall of mud that wiped out the town of Armero in northern Colombia.   ''I think it was past 11 o'clock last night when we heard a frightening noise, and then a blast of wind hit us and we saw fire falling from the sky,'' Mr. Nieto said. ''It was horrible, so horrible. My wife was killed. My mother was killed. My little girl who would have been 4 years old tomorrow died. One of my sisters was killed and one of my little nephews.''

headline: Mack Layoffs
abstract: Mack Trucks will furlough 200 workers and will temporarily shut down operations at its manufacturing plant here, according to a company spokesman. The layoffs, scheduled for Friday, will be for an indefinite period, Bill McCullough said. The furlough will bring to 700 the number of workers idled at the truck maker's Hagerstown plant since spring.

headline: The U.N. Today; Nov. 4, 1985
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Political and Security Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Special Political Committee -10:30 A.M.   Economic and Financial Committee - 10 A.M.   Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Decolonization Committee - 3 P.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Legal Committee - 3 P.M.

headline: 30 Drown in Indonesia
abstract: Thirty people drowned when a ferry capsized after hitting a tree in a river in central Sumatra, the police said today. About 80 people were rescued after the sinking in the Indragiri River on Tuesday.

headline: Shelling of Afghan Town Is Laid to Pakistan
abstract: The official Kabul radio reported today that Pakistani forces recently shelled the Barikot garrison town in eastern Afghanistan, killing 14 Afghan civilians and wounding 11.   The radio, monitored in Islamabad, said the Afghan Foreign Ministry today lodged a strong protest with the Pakistani charge d'affaires in Kabul about the shelling.

headline: Insurance Pact
abstract: The Alexander Syndicate Mangement Ltd. said that terms had been agreed to for an offer of $:13.4 million, or $19.2 million, by Alexander Howden Underwriting Ltd. and the Alexander Howden Group to settle a claim on behalf of two insurance syndicates. The company said the offer to Alexander Syndicate Management, the independent managing agent of syndicates 126 and 127, was to settle claims following the discovery of wrongdoing by former executives of the Howden Group, acquired by Alexander & Alexander Services Inc. of the United States in 1982.

headline: IRAN MAY ABANDON KHARG OIL BASE
abstract: Iran plans to abandon battered Kharg Island as its main oil terminal because of repeated Iraqi air raids, shipping sources said today.   Iran will instead use two new offshore centers to keep vital oil exports flowing during its Persian Gulf war with Iraq, the sources said.   ''Kharg has been badly mauled,'' one source said. ''This is why Iran wants to abandon it, at least for the war's duration.''

headline: Marshal Pokryshkin; Soviet Air Ace in War
abstract: Marshal Aleksandr I. Pokryshkin, a Soviet flying ace who is credited with having shot down 59 German planes in World War II, has died at the age of 72, it was announced in Moscow.   After the war, he served as the deputy commander of Soviet Air Defense Forces from 1968 to 1971, was made an air marshal in 1972, and then served as chairman of Dosaaf, a civilian defense agency, from 1972 to 1981.

headline: PAYING COMPANIES TO OBEY THE LAW
abstract: THE technical and economic magnitude of the problem of disposal of toxic wastes has not yet been reliably estimated. It may, however, prove more serious than all other environmental problems combined. Yet we have made virtually no progress toward its resolution.  The Superfund, the current Congressional grant of billions of dollars for removal of the many hundreds of dangerous-waste sites in the United States, is of course literally a device to clean up past mistakes. Its slow progress since its establishment in 1980 and its enormous expense show just how costly these mistakes can be. More to the point, the Superfund experience confirms that it is best to adopt measures that provide reasonable assurance that toxic wastes will be disposed of properly in the first place, rather than eliminating the potentially lethal mess after it has been made. The design of such preventive measures is our topic here.

headline: Uniworld Gets Coors Account
abstract: The Uniworld Group, a black-owned agency that specializes in advertising to minority communities, has landed the Adolph Coors Company account just a week after it won the Ford Motor Company's Lincoln-Mercury division.

headline: Wall Street Forecaster Has Winning Formula
abstract: Unlike many of his colleagues, Timothy J. Sullivan is one economist who does not not put much faith in econometric models as the best way of projecting the future course of economic growth.   It is an approach that few could fault, based on Mr. Sullivan's recent track record.   Yesterday Mr. Sullivan was named the winner of the fifth annual Silbert Economic Forecasting Award, for the ''accuracy, timeliness and professionalism'' of his projections about how key measurements of economic growth, the rate of inflation and the unemployment rate would perform in 1984.

headline: Koivisto Visits Mill in Maine Run by Finns and Times Co.
abstract: President Mauno Koivisto of Finland, who is in the United States this week for ceremonies marking the 40th anniversary of the United Nations, traveled here today to inspect a paper mill operated jointly by a Finnish company and The New York Times Company.   The plant, Madison Paper Industries, is North America's largest producer of ''supercalendered'' paper, a magazine-quality stock that reproduces colors with extreme fidelity.

headline: Jane's Reports Gains By Soviet in Aviation
abstract: Jane's, the military publisher, said today that the Soviet Union was narrowing the technology gap in aircraft.   The 1985-86 edition of ''Jane's All the World's Aircraft'' includes the first published photographs of the new Sukhoi Su-27 fighter plane, equipped to shoot down intruding missiles and matching the F-15 of the United States, which has been in service since the mid-1970's.

headline: RECENT SETBACKS ASIDE, C.I.A. STILL WANTS MORE 'HUMAN' SPIES
abstract: The following dispatch is based on reporting by Joel Brinkley and Stephen Engelberg and was written by Mr. Engelberg.   Despite recent problems with defectors and its own employees, the Central Intelligence Agency remains committed to rebuilding this country's network of covert intelligence operatives, reversing a trend of extensive reliance on technological intelligence gathering.   The Reagan Administration, with the support of Congress, has concluded that its predecessors placed too much emphasis on the gathering of intelligence by sophisticated satellites, communications listening posts and high-flying airplanes.   Under William J. Casey, Director of Central Intelligence, the Reagan Administration has embarked on a major effort to expand and re-emphasize traditional espionage, called ''human intelligence'' in the jargon of the intelligence field.

headline: GAF SEEMS READY TO LIFT CARBIDE BID
abstract: The GAF Corporation indicated yesterday that it might be willing to raise its $68-a-share bid for the Union Carbide Corporation.   In a letter to Union Carbide's chairman, Warren M. Anderson, GAF's chairman, Samuel J. Heyman, said: ''GAF is willing to negotiate the terms of its proposal. And so that there will be no misunderstanding on your part, you and your board should know that GAF is willing to discuss any aspect of the proposal.''

headline: 3 Die in Blast in Jamaica
abstract: Three people were killed and 22 injured when a cylinder used for blowing up balloons exploded in a shopping center here Tuesday night, the police said today. The cylinder had apparently been filled by an unauthorized operator, and it was not known what type of gas it contained, they said. The center was crowded with last-minute Christmas shoppers at the time.

headline: HELEN GRAY
abstract: Helen Pogson Ariza Gray, a sociologist who served the Governments of Chile and Venezuela during and after World War II, died of cancer on Sunday in Chevy Chase, Md., where she lived.

headline: A 9.44% Top Yield On Denver Bonds
abstract: A $255 million issue of airport revenue bonds for the city and county of Denver was tentatively offered yesterday with a maximum yield of 9.44 percent for bonds due in 2020, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.   For shorter maturities, yields for serial bonds ranged from 6.20 percent for bonds due in 1988 to 8.50 percent in 1997, while term bonds due in 2011 were offered with a 9.24 percent yield and the 2015 issue was at 9.34 percent.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD;Portuguese Is Asked To Form a Cabinet
abstract: Portugal's Social Democratic leader accepted an invitation today from President Antonio Ramalho Eanes to form the nation's 16th government since its return to democracy after the 1974 revolution.         The Social Democrat, Anibal Cavaco Silva, 46 years old, was named Prime Minister-designate after his party's victory over its former coalition partners, the Socialists of the departing Prime Minister, Mario Soares, on Oct. 6.

headline: 3 Experts Look Ahead On Investing
abstract: Three leading Wall Street professionals discuss their outlook for alternative investment opportunities over the next six months to a year. The professionals are: Robert Farrell, vice president and chief market analyst at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith; Robert Heisterberg, senior vice president and director of research for the Alliance Capital Management Corporation, and Susan Byrne, president of the Westwood Management Corporation. They were questioned by Fred R. Bleakley and Jan M. Rosen, editors in the financial news department of The Times. QUESTION: Stocks have gone up more than 60 percent since August 1982. Has the bull market now run out of steam?   HEISTERBERG: The short answer is no, I don't think it has run out of steam. That's contingent on a lot of things happening. The international agreement to force down the value of the dollar was a tip-off that the major risk as perceived by the central bankers is worldwide recession, not its counterpart, inflation. They were trying to say to the markets, ''Hey, look, there are things in the works that should provide for more growth, a lower dollar and perhaps in some sense, lower interest rates.''   Q. Are you saying that whether there's a continued bull market here depends on the worldwide economic situation?

headline: 5.5% Fall in House Sales Is Sharpest Since April
abstract: Housing sales fell 5.5 percent in October, the third consecutive decline and the sharpest drop since April, the Government reported today.   New single-family homes were sold at an annual rate of 652,000 units in October, down from a rate of 690,000 units in September, according to the joint report by the Commerce and Housing and Urban Development departments.   The decline followed drops of 3 percent in September and 4.9 percent in August and was the sharpest setback since a 7.2 percent April fall.

headline: HANSON TRUST IN CREDIT ACCORD
abstract: Hanson Trust P.L.C. obtained commitments from a group of banks for $775 million in credit, it said today in a filing with the Securites and Exchange Commission.   It said the credit pledges would more than suffice for it to complete its purchases of all the remaining shares of the SCM Corporation that it does not already own at $75 a share in cash, an offer it began this morning.

headline: The U.N. Today; Nov. 26, 1985
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Political and Security Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Special Political Committee -10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Economic and Financial Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 3 P.M. and 6 P.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Legal Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: BUDDING LAXALT FAREWELL, MANILA SEEMS TO BRISTLE
abstract: The office of President Ferdinand E. Marcos showed some irritation today at American criticism of his Government. The irritation became apparent after two meetings with Senator Paul Laxalt, who brought Mr. Marcos a message of concern from President Reagan.   While an American Embassy press release described the meetings Wednesday and today as ''cordial and mutually beneficial,'' a statement from the presidential palace characterized them less warmly as a ''frank exchange of views.''

headline: General Foods Helps Dow Post Gain
abstract: A sharp rise in the price of the General Foods Corporation's stock helped the Dow Jones industrial average record a sizable gain yesterday, but the market over all was little changed on only moderately heavy volume.   The trading activity was less impressive considering that the New York Stock Exchange had an extra half-hour to trade: its 9:30 opening was inaugurated yesterday.   The uninspired session followed the cancellation of exchange trading Friday because of Hurricane Gloria. Certain hot stocks, however, traded off the markets that day. That created an unusual situation yesterday in calculating market indicators such as the Dow, which gained 7.84 points yesterday, to close at 1,328.63.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

headline: TO FIRST LADY OF PHILIPPINES, THE MARCOS ERA IS CAMELOT
abstract: Sometimes, says Imelda Romualdez Marcos, when the accusations of extravagance, corruption and misrule get her down she thinks of her favorite movie.   ''O.K., they don't like my face,'' Mrs. Marcos, 52 years old, the wife of President Ferdinand E. Marcos, said of her American critics. ''But I can be a good friend. I feel like the hunchback of Notre Dame. Here was this man, but such a beautiful spirit, you know? It is my favorite movie.''   ''They call me corrupt, frivolous,'' Mrs. Marcos said in an interview in a dining room of Malacanang Palace. ''I am not at all privileged. Maybe the only privileged thing is my face. And corrupt? God! I would not look like this if I am corrupt. Some ugliness would settle down on my system.''

headline: BLACKS URGE END TO SCHOOL PROTEST IN SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: A national conference of black parents, students and teachers urged radical black high school students of South Africa today to lift a boycott of classes that has crippled the nation's segregated educational system for months.   Bishop Desmond Tutu told the gathering at the University of the Witwatersrand that if the authorities did not heed black educational demands within three months he would call for generalized, black economic action.   ''If the Government after three months refuses these requests, then it must not just be the students who lay down tools,'' he said. ''I suggest that teachers, parents, workers, church leaders, university staff and students must all combine in a concerted effort to say 'stop.' ''

headline: Greek Orthodox to Rebuild
abstract: The spiritual leader of Greek Orthodox Christians in the Americas, Archbishop Iakovos, said yesterday that the central building of the Ecumenical Patriarchate in Istanbul, Turkey, ''will be rebuilt'' under a permit expected to be issued soon. The building was destroyed by fire in 1942. The archdiocese reported that Archbishop Iakovos said at a meeting of the Archdiocesan Council in Manhattan that he received assurances about the reconstruction when he met with Prime Minister Turgut Ozal of Turkey yesterday morning.

headline: PAST SUMMIT MEETINGS, UNLIKE REAGAN'S, WERE FOR SIGNING OF KEY ACCORDS
abstract: By and large, most of the past summit meetings involving the Soviet Union and the United States stand in a different category from the one between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Geneva next week.   Some of the past meetings occurred against the backdrop of long preparations and represented the final high-level push toward arms control understandings or formal agreements.   This time the two sides are far apart on fundamental issues, such as the extent to which the research and development of space-based missile defense systems should be limited.   Participants in past summit meetings offer two possible lessons: First, such meetings can be used to break negotiating deadlocks; second, Soviet officials are sometimes prepared to react quickly to American proposals.   Jan M. Lodal, a National Security Council staff member during the Nixon and Ford Administrations who attended past summit meetings, said: ''If you are prepared to be flexible, you can accomplish things at a summit.''

headline: ALFONSIN PARTY WINS IN ARGENTINA BUT THE EXPECTED SWEEP ELUDES IT
abstract: Nearly complete returns from midterm congressional elections Sunday showed that the Radical Party of President Raul Alfonsin had won 43 percent of the national vote, giving the civilian leader a solid victory but falling far short of the hoped-for sweep.   For the opposition Peronists, who are split into two factions, the results showed a second and possibly decisive defeat for the old-line party bosses, according to political analysts.   With more than 80 percent of the vote counted, election officials said both the Radical Party and the Peronists had polled fewer votes than in 1983. But the Radicals, they said, picked up one seat in the lower house of Congress to maintain their majority. The Peronists lost 7 seats.

headline: 1.9 MILLION TAX RETURNS ARE STILL UNPROCESSED
abstract: More than seven months after the April 15 Federal income tax filing deadline, the Internal Revenue Service said today that 1.9 million tax returns remain unprocessed because of taxpayer or agency error.   The statement came as the General Accounting Office was distributing a report confirming that at some tax-processing centers taxpayer letters were destroyed, refund checks were mutilated and tax forms were left in restrooms and on loading docks.   The G.A.O., the investigative arm of Congress, pointed to inadequate staffing, noting that some people put in 80-hour weeks, and a change-over to a new computer system as the primary reasons for what Senator John Heinz, Republican of Pennsylvania, said today was ''the worst tax-filing season in history.''

headline: State Delays Plant Of Louisville Gas
abstract: The Louisville Gas and Electric Company said that the expected service date for one of its coal-fired units has been delayed until at least 1991, from 1988, by the Public Service Commission of Kentucky.

headline: REAGAN TO SEEK TALKS ON FREER CANADA TRADE
abstract: President Reagan is preparing to notify Congress on Tuesday that he wants to begin negotiating a liberalized trade agreement with Canada in the new year, Administration officials said today.   The action, which is required under United States trade law, formally sets in motion a process that could lead to important reductions in the remaining tariff and nontariff barriers between the two countries. Already nearly 80 percent of Canada's exports to the United States enter duty-free, while 65 percent of American exports pay no tariffs into Canada.

headline: Telephone Rate Changes Set
abstract: Sweeping changes in the rates local telephone companies charge long-distance companies for access to local lines were approved by the Federal Communications Commission today, but the impact on individual telephone users will be small because many increases are offset by decreases in other areas.

headline: Technology Stock Choices
abstract: THE stocks of several high-technology companies, particularly those with specialized products, continue to stir enthusiasm among members of the investment community.   Although the overall performance of high-tech equities has been lackluster over the last few years and some are selling well below their highs, analysts say that many long- and short-term opportunities continue to exist.   John Westergaard, editor of Equity Research Associates and a specialist in emerging growth stocks, said several attractive market plays appeared at the three-day seminar he conducted in New York last week. The seminar brought together the managements of more than 30 emerging-growth, high-tech concerns.

headline: PATENTS;  Artificial Larynx Contained in Mouth
abstract: An artificial larynx patented this week is to be wholly contained within the mouth, and can be mounted on or within a dental appliance.

headline: U.S. INDIANS ENLIST IN THE MISKITO CAUSE
abstract: Three American Indian activists have announced in Costa Rica that they are joining the cause of rebel Miskito Indians in Nicaragua.         Russell Means, 46 years old, a leader of the American Indian Movement, said at a news conference in San Jose last week that he hoped to recruit 90 to 100 ''warriors from North America'' to join Miskito fighters to oppose the Sandinista Government. He said sending American Indian combatants to fight in Nicaragua would ''begin the process of uniting the red people of the Western Hemisphere.''

headline: NBC Delays Cable Decision
abstract: A spokesman for the National Broadcasting Company said the network would not decide until Jan. 31 whether to proceed with a proposed all-news cable television network.   NBC had previously said that it would make a decision by mid-December.

headline: Southland Energy Pact
abstract: The Southland Energy Corporation said today that it has been granted an association contract on about 406 square miles in the Llanos Basin by Colombia's state oil company, Empresa Colombiana de Petroleos, or Ecopetrol. The company said the contract provides it with a 95 percent working interest in the block. Southland said it expected to drill its first well at the field before April 1986.

headline: PENNZOIL, TEXACO IN TALKS
abstract: A Federal court hearing was abruptly adjourned yesterday after lawyers for Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company disclosed that they were holding negotiations to settle their multibillion-dollar legal struggle.   It was the first indication that the oil companies had begun serious negotiations to resolve the dispute, which threatens the future of Texaco, the nation's fifth-largest corporation. Previous talks between them about a settlement had not yielded any substantive progress, officials from both companies have said.   United States District Judge Charles L. Brieant Jr. told a packed courtroom in White Plains that he had been informed by lawyers for both companies ''that their clients are still having discussions with each other looking toward the amicable settlement and disposition of all of the underlying litigation.''

headline: AIRPORT SECURITY TIGHT, GREEKS SAY
abstract: Greek authorities, shocked by the second hijacking of an airliner from Athens in five months despite a security crackdown after the first incident, said yesterday that they did not believe the weapons were smuggled aboard at the Greek airport.   The chief security official at the airport was quoted by United Press International as suggesting that the weapons used in the latest incident, which ended in the storming of the plane in Malta and about 50 deaths, might have been put on board in Cairo. The Egyptair plane had initially flown to Athens from the Egyptian capital.   Security at the Greek airport came in for worldwide criticism after the June 14 hijacking of a Trans World Airlines plane that took off from Athens with 153 people on board and ended up in Beirut. An American Navy diver was killed by the Arab hijackers and 39 American hostages were held for 17 days.

headline: Marine to Buy Finance Unit
abstract: Marine Midland Banks Inc. said today that it had agreed to acquire Commercial Credit Business Loans Inc. The company is a unit of the Commercial Credit Company, which is the financial services subsidiary of the Control Data Corporation.   Terms of the transaction, which is expected to be completed by the end of the year, were not announced.

headline: 6 Killed in Sri Lanka Blast
abstract: Five soldiers and a civilian were killed today in an explosion of a land mine planted by separatist Tamil guerrillas, a Defense Ministry spokesman said. Three soldiers were also wounded when the mine exploded under their vehicle in eastern Trincomalee. The blast was the latest attack on security forces by the guerrillas.

headline: CORPOCRACY
abstract: To the Editor:   As one of Ralph Nader's key raiders, Mark Green has been among the most insistent - and certainly the most publicized - proponents of government intervention. How strange it is to see him pontificating about corpocracies, proliferating paperwork, and the like!

headline: Pension Fund Shift Is Planned by FMC
abstract: The FMC Corporation, in a step that several other companies have taken recently, said today that it plans to restructure its retirement plans for salaried and nonunion workers to recover pension fund assets totaling $250 million to $400 million in pretax proceeds. FMC said that it had not decided on a specific use for the surplus funds, only that they would be used ''for general corporate purposes.''   ''They might be hungry for another acquisition,'' said Sean St. Clair, an analyst with Duff & Phelps Inc. in Chicago. In July, the Chicago-based manufacturer of chemicals and machinery bought the Lithium Corporation of America and an engineering company from the Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation for $150 million. He said that proceeds might also be used by the company to buy back more of its own shares. Last year, FMC spent about $500 million in repurchases of its stock.

headline: TEXT OF STATEMENT FROM BISHOPS AT SYNOD: 'MESSAGE TO THE PEOPLE OF GOD'
abstract: Following is the text, issued today by the Vatican, of the ''Message to the People of God'' from the Synod of Bishops:   We bishops, having come together from five continents and assembled in Rome for the Synod with the Pope, have lived with intensity a privileged moment of communion in prayer, dialogue and study. You know, dear brothers and sisters, that the Holy Father invited us during these days to recall with him the Second Vatican Council, to evaluate its implementation, to promote it in the church in such a way that it might be fully lived.   All of us, bishops of the Oriental rites and the Latin rite, have shared unanimously in a spirit of thanksgiving the conviction that the Second Vatican Council is a gift of God to the church and to the world. In full adherence to the Council, we see in it a wellspring offered by the Holy Spirit to the church, for the present and for the future. We do not fix upon the errors, confusions and defects which, because of sin and human weakness, have been the occasion of suffering in the midst of the people of God. We firmly believe and we see that the church finds today in the Council the light and strength that Christ has promised to give to his followers in each period of history.

headline: Lotus Buys Isys
abstract: The Lotus Development Corporation, in its fourth acquisition this year, said it would buy the Isys Corporation, a small software house, in a merger that would give Lotus rights to a series of financial data bases and programs that Isys sells to large companies.

headline: Money Fund Assets Off
abstract: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds fell moderately for the week ended Wednesday, dropping $379.6 million, to $208.41 billion, the Investment Company Institiute said yesterday. Leading the decline, assets of the 87 broker-dealer funds dropped $472.7 million, to $94.02 billion. Assets of the 192 general purpose funds fell $152.2 million, to $60.34 billion, while assets of the 73 institutional funds rose $245.3 million, to $54.05 billion.

headline: RIVAL CYPRIOT CHIEFS VOICE PESSIMISM ON PACT
abstract: President Spyros Kyprianou and Rauf Denktash, the leaders of the Greek and Turkish parts of Cyprus, expressed deep pessimism this week about the chances of reaching an agreement to reunite this divided island.   They spoke in the face of an optimistic declaration Tuesday by Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations, who is seeking to bring them to the negotiating table. Their last meeting under his auspices collapsed in January.

headline: REAGAN TRIES TO MEND FENCES WITH TUNISIA AFTER THE ISRAEL RAID
abstract: President Reagan expressed regret today that Tunisia had been ''swept up'' in Middle East violence, and he praised that country's efforts to encourage a peaceful settlement of the Arab-Israeli conflict.   In his weekly radio address, Mr. Reagan appeared to try to mend relations with Tunisia in the wake of the Administration's mixed reaction to an Israeli air strike last Tuesday at the headquarters of the Palestine Liberation Organization near Tunis.   The White House initially called the air strike, which Israel said was in retaliation for the killing of three Israeli civilians in Cyprus six days earlier, a ''legitimate response'' to ''terrorist attacks.''

headline: ARAFAT SAYS U.S. WAS PARTNER IN ISRAELI RAID
abstract: Yasir Arafat, the head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, accused President Reagan today of complicity in what he said was a plot to assassinate him, and he warned that United States policy in the Middle East, with ''its arrogance of power,'' would lead not to peace but to ''more oppression, more terrorism and more assassinations.''   At the same time, he said that the ''peace process would go on.''   Mr. Arafat said the United States, because of what he called its involvement in the attack - an air strike that virtually destroyed the P.L.O. offices here last Tuesday - had lost whatever credibility it had had in the region and bore part of the responsibility for the deaths of ''innocent Palestinians and Tunisians.''   The latest reports said 50 Palestinians and 22 Tunisians were killed in the attack, which was carried out by Israeli F-15's carrying bombs and air-to-ground missiles.

headline: Late Rally Eases Sharp Drop in Oil
abstract: The inconclusive end of the two-day OPEC meeting sparked a broad slide in prices of crude oil and petroleum products in Europe and the United States in morning trading yesterday.   But prices rallied somewhat during the afternoon and finished only slightly below Thursday's levels.      Several Factors Cited    Analysts said that several factors, including the conclusion of the meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and a desire for profit taking after a week of rising prices, contributed to the downward movement. Most said that the activity did not presage any significant upward or downward price shift.

headline: Marcos and Opposition Agree to Delay Election
abstract: Members of President Ferdinand E. Marcos's governing party and opposition groups said today that they had agreed to delay a special presidential election that Mr. Marcos had proposed for Jan. 17.   Political Affairs Minister Leonardo Perez said that representatives of Mr. Marcos's New Society Movement and opposition assemblymen agreed on a postponement, but had not agreed on a date in an eight-hour bargaining session. Mr. Perez said leaders had agreed that the election ''should not be later than the first week of February.''

headline: Control Data Unit Sells 2 Companies
abstract: The Commercial Credit Company, a subsidiary of the Control Data Corporation, said that it had sold two units as part of a restructuring. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: XEROX AND MANVILLE REPORT LOSSES
abstract: The Xerox Corporation reported yesterday a loss of $15 million in the third quarter after the inclusion of two charges taken in connection with its insurance operations.         As previously announced, Xerox took a $67 million charge for the strengthening of reserves in the L. W. Biegler unit of its Crum & Forster property and casualty insurance subsidiary and a $97 million charge for the phasing out of the operations of Crum & Forster's Industrial Indemnity Financial Corporation unit.

headline: Prudential Names Ball as Chairman
abstract: Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. said yesterday that James T. Barton would become its president on Jan. 1. George L. Ball, presently the securities firm's president, will become chairman. Mr. Ball will remain chief executive.   Prudential-Bache, a subsidiary of the Prudential Insurance Company, said the changes were spurred by the planned retirements of Harry A. Jacobs Jr., 64 years old, its current chairman, and H. Virgil Sherrill, its 65-year-old vice chairman, at the end of this year.

headline: Electric Revenue Bonds Offered
abstract: The Metropolitan Government of Nashville and Davidson County, Tenn., is offering $125.5 million of electric revenue bonds through Goldman, Sachs & Company.

headline: House Panel Tax Review
abstract: A House Ways and Means subcommittee is looking into the use of an investment tax deferral technique that permits delayed payment of taxes on capital gains by several years.   At the request of Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat from Michigan and chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee, the Ways and Means Oversight Subcommittee is examining the use of installment sales of securities, in which an investor sells a large block of stock over a period of years in a series of transactions to delay payment of tax.   The technique was used by John S.R. Shad, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, before he joined the commission in 1981. Mr. Shad delayed payment of some $2.5 million in capital gains taxes for three years, according to a letter from Mr. Dingell to Ways and Means chairman, Dan Rostenkowski, which constituted an interest-free loan. Mr. Dingell called the use of the installment sales technique a ''tax loophole that permits wealthy investors to evade substantial tax liabilities.''

headline: Wolseley-Hughes
abstract: Wolseley-Hughes P.L.C. said it had agreed to acquire the Carolina Builders Corporation of Raleigh, N.C., for $77 million, excluding related expenses. The purchase of the closely held company will be financed largely through the issue of new equity and will be conducted through Wolseley's United States unit, Wolseley-Hughes Management Inc.

headline: 14.79 RISE PUTS DOW AT 1,354.73
abstract: Stock prices rose sharply on Wall Street for the second consecutive session yesterday, lifting the Dow Jones industrial average to within 5 points of its record.   The Dow finished at 1,354.73, up 14.79 points. It was the best gain for the 30-stock blue-chip average since it rose 18 points on Sept. 23.   Traders said the market seemed to be responding again to Friday's encouraging retail sales and producer price reports, which pushed the average up 11.87 points that day.

headline: Plea for EPIC Names Denied
abstract: A Federal bankruptcy court judge in Alexandria, Va., rejected a motion yesterday that he make public the names of about 100 savings and loans and other investors in Equity Programs Investment Corporation real estate partnerships, which filed for bankruptcy several weeks ago.         After a three-hour hearing and testimony from three witnesses, Judge Martin V. B. Bostetter ruled that it was not necessary to release the names of the investors, which he had earlier sealed at the investors' request. They had argued that release of their names at a time of crisis in the thrift industry might cause a panic by depositors in the institutions.

headline: American Express
abstract: The American Express Company said it plans to increase the capital of two units, American Express Bank Ltd. and IDS/American Express Inc. The bank would get $175 million to develop business opportunities and IDS would get $65 million to expand its financial planning business.

headline: U.S. WINS TRADE TALK GO-AHEAD
abstract: The Reagan Administration won unanimous agreement tonight from 90 countries to open a new round of formal negotiations to liberalize world trade.   The decision came at the meeting here of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the group that oversees trade, after more than two years of wrangling over the proposal.   ''Of course there are bloody battles ahead, but the debate is no longer over procedure - it is over the substance of the negotiation,'' GATT's Director General, Arthur Dunkell, said tonight.   Washington, in seeking support from its trading partners for the new round, argued that a pledge to negotiate fairer trade arrangements is the best means of combating growing protectionist pressure, which it warned is threatening to push the world into a new recession.

headline: A CRUCIAL TIME FOR THE COMEX
abstract: New York's Commodity Exchange Inc. has had its share of troubles in the last year, with some of the worst coming from an unexpected quarter.   The 1984 annual report of the Comex, as it is known, showed the smiling visage of Owen J. Morrissey among a group of the exchange's leading members. In addition to being one of the Comex's largest individual gold traders, Mr. Morrissey was co-owner of Volume Investors, a clearing firm whose other owner was Charles E. Federbush, a member of Comex's governing board.   Then - only days after the annual report appeared - Volume Investors collapsed and was charged by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission with a number of rule violations, including fraud. The Comex and its clearing association soon faced charges that they had mishandled Volume's failure.

headline: Japan Penalizes Ciba Geigy Unit
abstract: The Ministry of Health and Welfare ordered Ciba Geigy Japan Ltd. to close two factories and suspend sales operations for 20 days from Jan. 6 because it falsified drug data, a ministry official said. The subsidiary of the Swiss-based pharmaceutical company has been submitting false data on stability testing of 46 new products since 1980, the official said.

headline: IMPACT OF MEXICAN CURBS ON FOREIGN BANKS CALLED UNCLEAR
abstract: It is still too early to measure the actual impact of new curbs on foreign banks in Mexico, according to experts here.         Concerned by the peso's dramatic fall in recent weeks in the free market, Mexico's central bank announced restrictions Tuesday night on foreign banks operating here. The measures are meant to stop speculation in the peso and restrict transactions in the currency outside of Mexico.

headline: INDEX OPTIONS TRADE WIDENS
abstract: Competition intensified yesterday in the crowded fields of stock index and foreign currency options as several exchanges either began trading new products or announced plans to do so within a few weeks.   The National Association of Securities Dealers introduced its Nasdaq 100 over-the-counter stock index options yesterday. Its initial attempt to do so last Friday was canceled by Hurricane Gloria.   In addition, the Chicago Board Options Exchange completed its first full day of trading in its options on six foreign currencies - Japanese yen, West German marks, British pounds, Swiss francs, French francs and Canadian dollars. The C.B.O.E. had traded its new options for about two hours last Friday before the market closed, along with most foreign-exchange activity in New York.

headline: The U.N. Today; Dec. 13, 1985
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Economic and Social Committee -7 P.M.

headline: FED WEIGHS A PENALTY
abstract: The Federal Reserve Board chairman, Paul A. Volcker, said today that the central bank was considering the imposition of a new, heavier penalty against financial institutions whose computer failures force them to seek exceptionally large short-term loans from the Fed.   Mr. Volcker appeared before a House subcommittee inquiring into the Nov. 21-22 episode in which the Fed had to supply $22.6 billion to the Bank of New York to prevent a possible shutdown in the huge market for United States Government securities.   The Bank of New York is the biggest clearing agent for these securities in a market that trades some $200 billion of them each day. Clearers are those who process the transfer of the securities from buyers to sellers and arrange for the related payment and collection of funds.

headline: Bar on Document Upheld
abstract: The Administration won an unheralded but significant victory last week when Federal District Court Judge Thomas F. Flannery ruled that the Environmental Defense Fund was not entitled to certain documents it sought in a suit involving standards for underground waste storage tanks.   Much of the information sought ''does reach into the area of the executive branch and the privilege associated with the deliberative process,'' Judge Flannery held.   Robert P. Bedell of the Office of Management and Budget said he was ''delighted'' by the decision and predicted it would discourage others from seeking such ''non-germane'' material.

headline: PERSONALITIES KEY TO PORTUGUESE VOTING
abstract: Portuguese will vote Sunday in parliamentary elections that will turn more on personalities than policies.   Three weeks of campaigning ended Friday night for the 11 parties battling for 250 parliamentary seats and a chance to replace Prime Minister Mario Soares, a Socialist.   The publication of opinion polls during the campaign is banned, but private polls and political analysts indicate that no one party or likely coalition will win a parliamentary majority.

headline: DAUGHTER OF DUARTE IS RELEASED BY REBELS IN COMPLEX EXCHANGE
abstract: The kidnapped daughter of President Jose Napoleon Duarte was freed unharmed by leftist rebels today in a complex exchange. She had been held hostage for 44 days.   The woman, Ines Guadalupe Duarte, was handed over just before midday in the small town of Tenancingo, 25 miles northeast of the capital, to a delegation of diplomats from France, Mexico and West Germany and the Salvadoran Archbishop.   The Government said it released 22 political prisoners and provided safe passage for 96 guerrillas disabled in the war. The rebels released Miss Duarte and a companion, Ana Cecilia Villeda, who were abducted on Sept. 10.

headline: Officials Eager to Sell Airport Finance Issues
abstract: Although airport financings are not subject to restrictions so severe as those proposed for other kinds of tax-exempt bonds, officials around the country are nevertheless attempting to sell their securities before 1986, when the new restrictions could take place.   The House of Representatives has not passed the tax bill proposed by the Ways and Means Committee, but Wall Street analysts are still recommending that local authorities arrange their financings before the end of the year. ''Many airport issues do not seem to be subject to the volume caps that apply to other issues,'' said one investment banker, who asked not to be identified, ''but there are proposed restrictions on things like cargo facilities, and nobody knows what kind of legislation will emerge.''

headline: DIRECTOR OF 'STAR WARS' PREDICTING A SPEED-UP WHEN MEETING ENDS
abstract: The director of the Strategic Defense Initiative program said today that he expected to receive instructions after the Geneva summit to move ahead ''much more quickly and effectively'' with the design of a space-based defense against nuclear missiles.   The director, Lieut. Gen. James A. Abrahamson, apparently seeking to counter speculation that the Reagan Administration would agree to limits on the research program, popularly called ''Star Wars,'' told military officials and defense industry executives at a space technology conference here that ''when the team comes back from Geneva, it will not be to say what we must give up, but rather that we must go ahead even faster.''   General Abrahamson also disclosed for the first time that the Pentagon had recentlly destroyed a mock-up of a Soviet SS-18 missile booster with a hardened plastic pellet fired at tremendous velocity.   Showing a photograph of the splintered booster, he said that the test demonstrated the potential of electromagnetic rail guns, a highly experimental kinetic-energy weapon that could be based in space to cripple incoming nuclear missiles. In the experiment, the pellet was fired from a special air gun.

headline: NICARAGUA SAYS IT MAY SEEK JETS TO OFFSET A U.S.-HINDURAN PACT
abstract: Nicaragua's Defense Minister suggested today that Nicaragua might soon acquire new military aircraft to counter what he said was a United States decision to send F-5 jet fighter planes to neighboring Honduras.   The Defense Minister, Humberto Ortega Saavedra, also predicted that Government forces would make decisive blows against rebels in the coming months and assure the insurgents' ''total defeat'' by early 1987. [In Washington, a State Department official said the United States would eventually replace Honduras's Super Mystere fighters, possibly with F-5's, but said he knew of no plans to do so in the near future.]  The F-5's are more sophisticated than any aircraft in the arsenal of any Central American country.

headline: ANGOLA REPORTS SOUTH AFRICAN AIR ATTACK
abstract: Angola said South African airplanes attacked its forces in a southeastern province early today, killing more than 50 soldiers in an operation aimed at supporting South African ground troops helping Angolan rebels.   The Angolan Defense Ministry, quoted by the official Angolan press agency in a dispatch received in Lisbon, said six helicopters were shot down by more than eight South African planes in the attack on Angolan forces near Mavinga, in Cuando Cubango province.

headline: RAIDS AND TERROR: VIOLENT PAST OF THE PALESTINIAN FACTIONS
abstract: The Palestine Liberation Front, the organization to which the hijackers of the Italian cruise ship claim they belong, conducted several novel, stunt-like terrorist raids into Israel in 1981, some using hang gliders and hot-air balloons.   That group split up in 1983 into two factions, one loyal to and one against Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization umbrella group. Experts say that makes it hard to identify who is really behind the hijacking of the Italian ship.   The faction that remained loyal to Mr. Arafat is headed by Mohammed Abbas, also known as Abul Abbas. Now a member of the P.L.O.'s executive committee, he is famous among Palestinians for his creativity in devising raids against Israel, including at least two spectacular, but unsuccessful, air attacks in 1981.

headline: IN SOVIET, MAN ON THE STREET IS HOPEFUL ON SUMMIT RESULTS
abstract: Soviet television took to the streets today to ask people who were described as average men and women what they expect from the Geneva summit meeting and what they think about human rights in their country.   People from all walks of life were surprisingly hopeful that the Nov. 19-20 meeting between Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Reagan would produce some kind of an arms accord.   They were outraged when asked about Western allegations that human rights are not observed in the Soviet Union.

headline: WORKING FOR THAT SECOND TEDDY BEAR
abstract: EACH December, John and Karin Pieper take their two sons to the kitchen gadgets section of Fortunoff's on Long Island to buy Christmas gifts. One year, the couple recalls, the boys bought their father a set of reindeer-tipped swizzle sticks; their mother got two cookie cutters, one shaped like a ship, the other a whale.   The Pieper children pay for their gifts with money they earn during the year by cutting grass, taking out the garbage and babysitting for their younger sister. This is one popular approach to allowances: linking the weekly stipend to the performance of household chores. The other main school of thought holds that all generations of a family share household chores, or ought to, and allowances should not be linked to this family function. According to this viewpoint, children have a right to pocket money, but they are too young to be required to earn it as wages.

headline: SANCTIONS ON SOUTH AFRICA ARE CALLED 'BETTER OF 2 EVILS'
abstract: African leaders told the General Assembly today that the world faced a choice between imposing economic sanctions on South Africa or watching a destructive explosion by the black majority there.   ''A catastrophic explosion which will engulf all of us in the region is imminent,'' said President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia.   Sanctions are ''a better of two evils,'' he said later at a news conference.   ''If you don't apply sanctions,'' he said, ''hundreds of thousands of people will die and the investments will go up in flames. With sanctions, there is a possibility of recovery.''

headline: FEDERAL RESERVE
abstract: All data in millions of dollars LatestPreviousYear WeekWeekAgo Monetary Aggregates M-1*as of Nov. 18 $616,600 R $613,800 #552,000 Adj. Mon.Base (St.Louis Fed) *(11/27)#233,400 R 230,400 #216,200 Reserve Position, Eight New York BanksDaily averages for two weeks ended Nov. 20 Excess (Deficit) Reserves (Incl. carryover)R 79 #39 (36) Borrowings at Federal Reserve#197 #98 #187 Net Federal Funds PurchasesR 8,649 #8,141 #8,157 Basic Reserve Surplus (Deficit)R (8,767)(8,200)(8,380) Federal Reserve CreditDaily averages, week ended Nov. 27 Gov'ts. and Agencies Held Outright#179,611 #178,449 #164,130 Gov'ts. and Agencies Under Repurchase#0 R 1,349 #83 Float#1,258 R 1,494 #1,156 Other Assets#13,696 R 13,610 #11,225 Other Factors Affecting ReservesDaily averages, week ended Nov. 27 Gold Stock#11,090 #11,090 #11,096 Special Drawing Rights#4,718 #4,718 #4,618 Currency in Circulation#191,750 R 191,558 #179,847 Treasury Deposits#2,587 #3,008 #2,978 Other Items Gov't.

headline: Productivity Shows Gain
abstract: The productivity of American businesses rose at a 1.2 percent annual rate during the summer, the Labor Department said today. The increase matched the advance recorded from April through June.

headline: ETHIOPIAN, IN U.S., DENIES ASKING FOR ASYLUM
abstract: The head of the Ethiopian Government's famine relief program, Dawit Wolde Georgis, yesterday denied reports that he was seeking asylum in the United States.   In a telephone interview, Mr. Dawit said he was ''on vacation'' in the United States, but declined to say whether he planned to return to Ethiopia.   On Thursday, the State Department denied that Mr. Dawit had asked for refuge, but a highly placed source in Washington said the Ethiopian official had made it known that he intended to stay in the United States.

headline: REAGAN RULES OUT ANY RUSSIAN VETO OF MISSILE SHIELD
abstract: President Reagan sought today to describe in greater detail his position on deployment of a missile defense system.   In an interview with news agency reporters, Mr. Reagan said he preferred to negotiate an arrangement by which both the United States and the Soviet Union would replace offensive nuclear weapons with defensive systems in a coordinated, phased process.   If the Russians refused to take part in such a shift, he added, the United States should reserve the right to deploy its missile defense alone.      Wouldn't Allow Soviet Veto    Earlier in the day, in remarks to reporters, Mr. Reagan said he would never allow Moscow to exercise a veto over American deployment of a shield against incoming enemy missiles.

headline: A FRESH THRUST BY SHISEIDO
abstract: Every so often, Victor Harris, the president of Max Factor's Japanese subsidiary, is pressed by his American supervisors to attack the weaknesses of the Japanese cosmetics giant, Shiseido. But he says: ''I've spent a career examining their weaknesses, and you're not going to find any major ones.''   Mr. Harris, whose company is a leading foreign cosmetics concern in Japan, gives Shiseido top grades in marketing, production, quality and management, all of which have helped to push the company to the top here. Last year, Shiseido had sales of $1.5 billion.

headline: United-Pan Am
abstract: President Reagan will not oppose United's acquisition of Pan Am's Pacific air routes, clearing the way for the $750 million deal to be completed. A United statement said that the only remaining obstacle was the transfer of landing rights by Japan, South Korea, China, Taiwan, Hong Kong, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, Australia and New Zealand. The Transportation Department gave its approval on Oct. 31, despite objections from Northwest Airlines, which said the sale could force it out of the Pacific market and endanger its financial viability.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: CORRECTION
abstract: An article on Washington policymakers in this section on Nov. 17 incorrectly stated Douglas McMinn's former rank in the National Security Council. He was director for international affairs. The senior director for international economic affairs was Roger W. Robinson.

headline: APPLE WILL INTEGRATE PRODUCTS
abstract: Apple Computer Inc., saying that it had regained its footing after the most tumultuous year in its history, outlined a plan yesterday to integrate its products in an ''I.B.M.-defined world'' of computer systems.   The company said the move marked a broad refocusing that some Apple officials conceded would concentrate less on flashy new technologies and more on making machines attractive to businesses.
