In a presentation to Wall Street analysts late yesterday, Apple also predicted that its restructuring earlier this year would allow the company to post ''significantly stronger'' earnings in the fiscal year 1986 than in 1985.   ''I think that the big news is that Apple is doing far better today than many people, even people inside Apple, thought possible five months ago,'' John Sculley, Apple's chief executive, said in an interview yesterday. ''We're a lot more pragmatic today.''

headline: MEASURING FINGERS AND EYES
abstract: MARGARET SCHNEIDER, general manager of La Reserve, a plush Westchester hotel, used to worry about the vulnerability of the wine room. The room housed rare bottles and the hotel's electrical heart, yet security was no more elaborate than a key on a hook in the maitre d'hotel's office. No one had ever broken in, but it seemed too easy to do so.

headline: Advertising;   Global Marketing Debated
abstract: When the topic of global marketing comes up, many people immediately begin to talk about global advertising and its multitude of communications problems. This, said Allen G. Rosenshine, president of BBDO International, is a ''red herring.''   ''Why do we all seem to spend so much time discussing the theories of global advertising instead of the realities of global marketing?'' he asked his audience today in a session at the annual meeting of the Association of National Advertisers.   And one of those realities is that, before any global advertising program can become a reality, international subsidiary companies must become responsive to corporate headquarters, a condition that is not now widely the case.

headline: Nashville Water Bonds Given Yields Up to 9 3/8%
abstract: A $257 million issue of water and sewer revenue bonds of the Metropolitan Government of Nashville and Davidson County was tentatively offered yesterday with a maximum yield of 9 3/8 percent for bonds due in 2015 through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company.   The bonds from Tennessee, rated A+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, will be used to refund outstanding debt.

headline: Freddie Mac Gives Certificate Results
abstract: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, yesterday announced results of a $250 million sale of 15-year mortgage participation certificates, and said it plans to begin offering the certificates daily rather than every two weeks.   For $250 million of 10 1/2 percent certificates, the corporation said the average price submitted by securities dealers was 98 13/32, resulting in a yield of 10.57 percent.

headline: P.& G. Forecasts Better Earnings
abstract: The Procter & Gamble Company's earnings should improve throughout this year compared with last year, P.&G.'s president, John G. Smale, told company shareholders today at their annual meeting.   Mr. Smale said P.& G.'s recent $1.2 billion tender offer to acquire Richardson-Vicks Inc., a drug company based in Wilton, Conn., complements two broad areas of interest for P.& G.: personal care and health care products. The company's stock closed today at $56.625, up 12.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Colt Signs Pact To Buy Walbar
abstract: Colt Industries, a diversified manufacturer of industrial products based in New York, said it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire Walbar Inc., a maker of aircraft jet engine blades and related components, for $37 a share, or $192 million.

headline: ZIA HOPES TO EASE FRICTION WITH INDIA
abstract: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan said today that he hoped his meeting with Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India on Wednesday would ''pave the way for a better, friction-free relationship'' between the two countries.   ''We thought we could meet here to explore the possibilities of how to get over the snail's pace of normalization of relations,'' he said in an interview.   The two leaders, who are attending the 40th anniversary commemoration of the United Nations, have met twice before, at the funerals of Indira Gandhi, the slain Prime Minister of India, and of Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader.   On a separate matter, General Zia reiterated his pledge to sign the treaty banning the spread of nuclear weapons and to open his country's nuclear plants to international safeguards and inspection if India agreed to do the same. He said a regional policy was necessary to deal with the nuclear abilities of the two countries.

headline: Tin Talks to Continue
abstract: The International Tin Council met today and agreed to meet in December in a marathon session to work out a plan for reopening tin trading. The council said in a statement that it would reconvene Dec. 2 and would ''remain in session until it reaches a definitive decision'' to resolve the crisis.

headline: Kuwait Plans To Import Gas
abstract: Kuwait, sitting on enough crude oil reserves to last for 200 years, is running short of gas.   The emirate plans to sign a deal soon with neighboring Iraq to import up to 400 million cubic feet of gas daily via a 60-mile pipeline from its southern oilfields.

headline: TREASURY YIELDS FALL SOME MORE
abstract: Interest rates on Treasury securities continued their descent yesterday, with long-term bond yields moving close to 10 percent, a level not seen since mid-1980.   A lack of supply in the Treasury market, hopes that the Federal Reserve will soon ease its monetary policy and the prospects for Congressional action to reduce Federal budget deficits were all cited by analysts as reasons for the decline in note and bond yields.   Although many market participants doubt that those three reasons justify continued declines in interest rates, their skepticism did not discourage investors or prevent the price of the bellwether 10 5/8 percent Treasury bond due in 2015 from gaining more than 7/8 point on the day, to an offered price of 105 18/32, to yield 10.03 percent. The closely watched 30-year issue traded as high as about 105 25/32 to yield 10.01 percent - a far cry from the Oct. 28 close of 101 to yield 10.51 percent.

headline: NEWS REPORTS BRING SOUTH AFRICA'S TURMOIL INTO AMERICA'S LIVING ROOMS
abstract: In the last nine months South Africa has penetrated the American consciousness with a breadth that it rarely has during a quarter-century of racial strife in that troubled country. Significantly, this turnabout has coincided with sustained and vivid coverage of South Africa by American television.   Funerals and riots, overturned cars aflame and armored vehicles rolling through black townships have all become familiar images. The names of Bishop Desmond M. Tutu, the Anglican leader who opposes apartheid, and P. W. Botha, the South African President, have practically become household names. Calls for disinvestment and sanctions have sounded with wider and more foreful emphasis in recent months from campuses to Congress. In both the power it exerts and the controversy it excites, the television coverage of South Africa bears comparison to the reporting by broadcast journalism on the civil rights movement and the Vietnam War.

headline: British Steel-Slater
abstract: The Slater Steel Corporation said the British Steel Corporation had entered into negotiations to sell its 50.1 percent interest in Slater to a joint venture formed by a New York investment firm, Peterson, Jacobs & Harding, and the Toronto investors Paul and Deavid Fingold. It said if the transaction proceeded, the investors would offer $11.50 in cash and debentures worth $3 for each Slater share.

headline: Article 163284 -- No Title
abstract: Stephen A. Wynn, chairman and president of Golden Nugget Inc., said he had offered to buy the Dunes Hotel and Country Club in Las Vegas, Nev., for $115 million. The Dunes resort, whose managing company filed for protection under Chapter 11 of Federal bankruptcy laws last week, covers 116 acres on the so-called Strip in Las Vegas and includes a 1,200-room hotel, a casino, golf course, tennis courts and recreation facilities.

headline: STANDOFF REPORTED BETWEEN ITALY AND EGYPT ON P.L.O. ESCORTS
abstract: Reagan Administration officials said today that an angry standoff had taken place at the Sicily air base between Italian and Egyptian officials over the fate of two senior Palestinian representatives who had accompanied the four hijackers out of Egypt.   This new complication developed after United States officials reluctantly agreed that the four hijackers would probably be tried in Italy for their act of piracy and the killing of an American tourist. Justice Department officials here were examining methods of seeking the extradition of the two Palestinians being held with the Egyptian plane.   According to the officials, one of the two is Mohammed Abbas, also known as Abul Abbas, the head of the Palestine Liberation Front faction that carried out the hijacking on Monday of the Italian cruise ship, the Achille Lauro. The other is an unidentified Palestine Liberation Organization official.

headline: Continental Illinois Declares Preferred Dividends
abstract: In a move that investment analysts said was encouraging, the directors of the Continental Illinois Corporation today declared current quarterly dividends on two classes of preferred stock, and voted to pay full arrearages on them. The arrearages total $45.8 million and the fourth-quarter dividends total about $9.8 million.   Analysts said today's move showed that things were slowly returning to normal at Continental Illinois, which is the holding company for the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, the bank that was saved last year by a $4.5 billion Federal rescue plan.

headline: Explaining Revamped Newsweek
abstract: NEWSWEEK magazine, totally overhauled from back to front in a $1 million reformatting, will be introduced to its reading public today in a nationwide mass newsstand and home-delivered effort. At the same time, the new look will be explained to agency executives in nine important advertising cities by the magazine's top editorial and business executives.   In a special preview Friday, Gerard Smith, Newsweek's publisher and former agency man, said that the changes had been made in response to reader needs, because of the changing competitive environment and to take advantage of new production technology.   Coincidentally, the cover design is being changed, at a time when Newsweek is running about 3 percent behind last year's levels on newsstand sales. And the entire inside of the magazine has been redesigned in a way that should increase readers per copy, a month and a half after Newsweek became the first major publication to base its advertising rates on total audience, rather than on circulation. While the circulation is about 3,050,000, the audience is 20 million -or 16.8 million - depending on which syndicated research you subscribe to.

headline: 40 Years Since Patton Died
abstract: Belgian veterans who fought under Gen. George S. Patton commemorated over the weekend the 40th anniversary of the death of the World War II commander. The American general died Dec. 21, 1945, in a highway accident in West Germany. A memorial service Saturday at General Patton's tomb at the Hamm military cemetery was attended by Defense Minister Marc Fischbach of Luxembourg and Jean Gerard, the United States Ambassador.

headline: TREASURY ISSUES RISE STRONGLY
abstract: Prices of Treasury debt issues advanced strongly yesterday in heavy daylong buying that carried across all maturity sectors of the market.   Demand was particularly strong for 20-to-30-year Treasury bonds, a sign that many investors think long-term yields may decline further.   Dealers also noted substantial covering by many traders who had made short sales of Treasury debt in the belief, now deemed remote, that the Federal Reserve planned to tighten credit in the near future.   Adding to the bullish mood was the heightened expectation that the Fed would cut its discount rate to help stimulate the economy. The rate, on Fed lending to financial institutions, is currently at 7.5 percent. The last cut, a half point, occurred May 17.

headline: Merrill Lynch
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Company is offering $250 million of 9 3/4 percent, five-year notes at a price of par, to yield 9.75 percent, or 59-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury notes of similar maturity. The notes, which are offered through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, are non-callable for three years, and are rated Aa-3 by Moody's and AA- by Standard & Poor's.

headline: Technology;   The High-Tech Blackboards
abstract: FOR those who have discovered with dismay that the vital information they wrote on the blackboard was erased overnight by the janitor, the answer is at hand. New high-technology blackboards can make paper copies of what is written on them.   The so-called electronic boards are just one example of how technology is transforming even the simple blackboard. Indeed, blackboards, which might more properly be called chalkboards, are usually not even black anymore, but green or another color. And chalkboards themselves are being replaced by the ''whiteboard,'' on which people write with colored markers.

headline: JAPAN PLAN IS CRITICIZED ON HOUSING AND CREDIT
abstract: Japan's steps to spur economic growth, announced with some fanfare early last week, are unlikely to produce as much growth as the Government hopes for, according to economists and industry specialists here.   The incentives were Japan's latest response to increasing world pressure to reduce its large trade and capital surpluses. Since September, Japan and the other leading industrial nations, the United States, Britain, France and West Germany, known as the Group of Five, have been intervening in world currency markets to bring down the strength of the dollar, considered one of the causes of Japan's surplus.   But many economists believe that intervention is only a short-term solution, and so Japan also agreed to spur economic growth. In this way, Japanese consumers would have more to spend on imports, businesses would invest more at home and Japan could derive more growth from its domestic market rather than exports. $19 Billion in Growth Japan's package offered incentives to build more houses, expand consumer credit, increase local government spending on public works and improve electricity and gas services. The Government estimated that the measures would generate about $19 billion in economic growth over the next year, expanding the gross national product by 1.27 percent.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Consolidated Natural Gas Company, Pittsburgh, has elected L. J. Timms Jr. president of the Consolidated Gas Transmission Corp., a pipeline subsidiary based in Clarksburg, W.Va., effective Jan. 1. He succeeds George A. Davidson Jr., who has been elected a vice chairman of the parent company.

headline: Consumer Debt Rises By Record $10.6 Billion
abstract: Americans took on a record $10.6 billion more in consumer debt than they paid off in September, as borrowing for auto purchases hit a record high, the Federal Reserve reported today.   The debt growth in September compared with a $6.3 billion increase in August, and surpassed the old record of $9.09 billion in May 1984.   The bulk of the increase came from a $7.4 billion jump in auto loans, as consumers took advantage of attractive cut-rate financing offers. The previous record monthly increase in the auto category was $3.8 billion, in May of this year.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 11, 1985
abstract: Companies    A judge upheld the full award that Texaco is to pay Pennzoil for having used unethical tactics to break up a merger between Pennzoil and Getty Oil. The Texas judge said that interest so far has brought the $10.53 billion award to $11.1 billion. He also said that Pennzoil would not be allowed to file any liens against Texaco property during an appeal or make any attempt to collect the award without the court's permission and that Texaco would not be able to file a bankruptcy petition. [Page A1.]  Texaco approved a plan to make it prohibitively expensive for an unwanted bidder to take over the company. Analysts said the company acted in the expectation that the judge's ruling could depress Texaco's stock and attract a company hoping to buy Texaco at a bargain price. [D4.]  The decision shocked many analysts, who said the ruling would have a dramatic impact on the nation's third-largest oil company. [D4.]    GAF said it would sell close to half of Union Carbide if it gets control. The sale would include Eveready batteries, Prestone antifreeze, Glad Bags and Simoniz car wax. [D1.]

headline: Advertising;   Leber Katz Attracts New Clients, Quietly
abstract: Leber Katz Partners rarely sends out news releases and never sends out business solicitation letters, but it manages to get accounts nonetheless.

headline: Advertising;   People
abstract: * Nancy Kestenbaum has been promoted to vice president/advertising director for Penthouse and Newlook magazines.

headline: Grace Shares
abstract: W. R. Grace & Company said its planned repurchase of 26 percent of its shares held by the Flick Group of West Germany might ''impair the company's ability to pay dividends in the future.'' W. R. Grace disclosed the imformation in an amended registration statement for 2.5 million common shares with the Securities and Exchange Commission. W. R. Grace is offering the shares to raise part of the $597.8 million needed to purchase the shares from the Flick Group. The company's net income was down to $102.2 million for the first nine months of 1985, compared with $141.6 million for the first nine months of 1984.

headline: TREASURY AWAITS DEBT CEILING ACTION
abstract: Today's regular auction of new Treasury bills due in three and six months was postponed late Friday, because Congress had not yet passed legislation to increase the Federal debt ceiling.   The Treasury has enough cash on hand to keep the Government operating until Thursday, and market participants expect the debt ceiling to be raised by mid-week. The debt ceiling legislation has been delayed because it was tied to proposals to reduce Federal budget deficits. However, Congressional leaders said late Friday they had agreed on a plan to balance the Federal budget by 1991 and impose automatic spending cuts if the deficit does not decline according to schedule.

headline: A Soviet Vessel Fires Warning at Japanese
abstract: A Soviet minelayer ship fired three warning shots Thursday night across the bow of a small Japanese fishing boat that accidentally brushed against it in international waters, a Maritime Safety Agency spokesman said today.

headline: CUTTING CORNERS ON NUCLEAR SAFETY
abstract: WHEN a nuclear plant costs 10 times more than it was supposed to, or when a reactor is broken down more than it runs, fairness - and several public utility commissions - dictate that the utility's stockholders, not ratepayers, should absorb the extra costs. In fact, 15 states have ''incentive'' rate programs covering about 35 reactors that let the utilities earn more if their nuclear plants operate reliably, and less if they are shut down for refueling and repairs for long periods.   But the Nuclear Regulatory Commission is growing increasingly nervous that the incentives for reliability may stop utilities from shutting reactors for necessary maintenance. ''This so-called incentive plan,'' wrote John T. Collins, an N.R.C. regional administrator, in an internal memorandum, ''may actually be a disincentive plan insofar as public health and safety is concerned.''   Such concern prompted the N.R.C. to study the relationship between utility finances and reactor performance last summer. ''Economic regulation can influence the spirit with which a licensee approaches reactor safety issues,'' that study concluded. ''Short-term economic interest may cause utilities to hurry work, take short cuts, or delay action in order to meet a deadline, a cost limitation, or other factors.''

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Japan Air Ruling
abstract: The Japanese Cabinet abolished the rulings that originally divided Japan's international and domestic airline routes, the Transport Ministry said. This effectively ends the Japan Air Line Company's monopoly on international service, it said, noting that there are now seven Japanese airlines, and all want part of that market. All Nippon Airways has already applied for a Tokyo-Guam route, to start on March 3, and is expected to seek a Tokyo-Los Angeles route.

headline: GAF PLANS BIG SELLOFF AT CARBIDE
abstract: The GAF Corporation told its stockholders yesterday that if it succeeded in taking over the Union Carbide Corporation, it would sell off close to half the company.   The chemicals and building materials producer, which is based in Wayne, N.J., said it intended to sell Union Carbide's consumer products division, its metals and carbon products companies and a substantial number of its technology, services and specialty products operations.   These operations accounted for nearly half of Union Carbide's $9.5 billion in sales last year. By contrast, GAF's total sales last year amounted to $731 million.

headline: Market Place;Macy's Buyout Still Up in Air
abstract: THE stock of R. H. Macy & Company is remaining at a high level, despite continuing skepticism that the company's management can carry out its proposed $3.6 billion leveraged buyout.         Some analysts, investment bankers and retailers believe that the Macy's executives and their adviser, Goldman, Sachs & Company, are having a hard time obtaining financing for the cash deal, which was announced three weeks ago. One  possible financing package would consist of some $500 million in equity from a major investor and the remaining $3.1 billion furnished by lenders. Despite Macy's long-term growth potential, this group argues, lenders are put off by retailing's uncertain prospects next year and the deal may have to be reshaped,  postponed or dropped.

headline: EVEN BEFORE A DELUGE, SANG-FROID IN GENEVA
abstract: When the Swiss Army announced that anyone trying to breach security at the summit conference next week would be shot, it raised few eyebrows.   The art of official security is second nature to the Swiss. No one has been shot and killed by the Swiss Army in 40 years.   With less than a week to go before the meeting here of President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Swiss authorities are bracing for what people in the city and state administration say will be the biggest event in Geneva's modern history.

headline: GAF'S BID FOR CARBIDE SWEETENED
abstract: The GAF Corporation yesterday raised its bid to buy the Union Carbide Corporation to $74 a share in cash from $68.   The sweetened offer, unexpectedly made on Christmas Day when Carbide executives were off celebrating the holiday, will make an already complex takeover drama even more confusing. According to Wall Street analysts interviewed last night, the new GAF offer roughly matches an offer by Carbide to buy back part of its stock for a package of cash and securities.   Carbide valued that package at $85 a share, but investment professionals say the offer is worth only around $75. Carbide shareholders thus must now decide which offer they like better: Carbide's cash and securities valued by Wall Street at $75 a share, or GAF's $74 a share in cash.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    * Banque Francaise du Commerce Exterieur is issuing 150 million European Currency Units of 8 5/8 percent, eight-year Eurobonds at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Banque Nationale de Paris.    * Emhart Corp. is issuing 175 million marks of 6 3/4 percent, 10-year Eurobonds at 100 through Berliner Handels-Und Frankfurter Bank.    * Firstcorp Inc. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $14 million of convertible subordinated debentures due 2005.

headline: BEDS THAT BEND, FOLD OR INFLATE
abstract: WATER beds are enjoying the limelight, but other non-traditional beds are inching their way into stores these days, too.   For example, sales of adjustable beds - motor-controlled beds, such as those in hospitals, which can be adjusted to a variety of positions - have more than doubled since 1981, according to Ivan Schatz, founder and president of the Virginia Adjustable Beds Manufacturing Corporation, known as Vamco, in Alexandria.   Adjustable beds are among the most expensive in bedding, and thus among the most profitable items for manufacturers. ''The number of units sold may not be large, but the dollars are impressive,'' said Mr. Schatz.

headline: Catholic College Backs Polish Vote Boycott
abstract: Students at a Roman Catholic university in Lublin, the only Catholic university in Eastern Europe, announced today that they would support a boycott of parliamentary elections on Sunday.

headline: WEINBERGER NOTE SEEN AS OPPOSING SOFTNESS AT TALKS
abstract: Senior Administration officials said today that Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger did not disagree with White House positions on arms control but was concerned that those positions might not be maintained with sufficient firmness at the summit conference here.   They said Mr. Weinberger, who wrote a letter to President Reagan urging that no accords be reached on two key issues, was apparently worried that officials less hawkish than he might be able to sway the President's thinking in a way he would strongly oppose.      Strong Reaction by Officials   The disclosure that Mr. Weinberger had written the letter touched off a strong reaction among Administration officials here, with one official saying that the the disclosure of the letter to the press had been an attempt to sabotage the summit meeting. The letter was not issued officially, but The New York Times and The Washington Post obtained copies of it and published reports on its contents.

headline: LOCAL MONOPOLIES SERVE THE PUBLIC BEST
abstract: WHEN a once-flourishing manufacturing company in Ellenville, N.Y., closed its doors last fall because of dwindling sales, the event was not considered particularly noteworthy. The concern was the Channel Master Company; its product was the rooftop television antenna. Today, with more than 40 percent of American families receiving television signals by cable, we are well into the era of ''single-wire dependence.''   In coming years, that single wire will be virtually a family's sole contact with the outside universe of video news, entertainment and information. This simple fact presents some profound policy questions. Should the content of that vital flow of information be totally controlled by cable companies?

headline: 'STAR WARS' DISPUTE
abstract: For more than a week, Reagan Administration officials have been at odds over the extent to which a 13-year-old arms treaty with the Soviet Union limits President Reagan's plan to develop a space-based missile defense. But beyond the dispute are more fundamental questions about whether a path to missile defense could bring about grave counteractions by the Soviet Union, ranging from repudiation of the treaty obligation to an accelerated military buildup.   The debate within the Administration has centered on the 1972 treaty limiting the development of antiballistic missile defense systems. The dispute has arisen over a new contention by some officials that the United States should interpret the pact as permitting virtually any level of field testing and even ''development'' of advanced antimissile devices.   Other officials think it is enough to rest on the already prevailing argument that the ''Star Wars'' program is designed to defer development and testing of a kind that might violate the treaty.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Belden & Blake Energy Co., North Canton, Ohio, said it had completed the purchase of some oil and gas interests of Willard A. Ryan and others, including seven Mississippi oil wells. Terms were not disclosed.    * Colt Industries said it had extended its $37-a-share tender offer for all shares of Walbar Inc. Colt said it had bought 4,746,000 of Walbar's approximately 5,200,000 outstanding shares.

headline: HOLIDAY SALES RISE EXPECTED
abstract: Despite six fewer shopping days this Christmas season than last, retailers and economists expect the holiday period to produce sales gains of 6 to 10 percent over 1984. They said that pent-up demand for merchandise of many sorts,  improved regional economies and better-planned inventories would help to overcome the shortened season.         Nonetheless, the merchants are girding for what they say will be a difficult, hectic period following Thanksgiving Day, when the season formally starts. With  Thanksgiving falling on Nov. 28, six days later than last year, many retailers are planning even longer store hours than usual for the holiday season to make up for the loss of nearly a week's time in the year's most important shopping period. They are also planning to hold more sales in the first few days of the season.

headline: BRITAIN BRACES FOR A FINANCIAL FREE-FOR-ALL
abstract: IN his oak-paneled office adorned with Victorian prints of English gentlemen hunting and fishing, Somerset Gibbs was complaining good-naturedly about the boom times in his trade - headhunting for clients in the City of London, Britain's Wall Street.   ''The problem for headhunters now,'' he said, grinning, ''is that there's too much business.''   Not just the volume, but the manner, too, of body-snatching has changed markedly, noted the 59-year-old Mr. Gibbs, a former senior partner in a London brokerage house. For years, job-hopping in the square-mile City was conducted by unwritten rules of civility, and the person wanting to leave almost had to ask his boss for permission to leave. ''But now it's all rough and tough and there are lawyers lurking in the background,'' Mr. Gibbs said. ''The old boy's club is disappearing very rapidly.''

headline: RETAILER AT HOUSEHOLD GETS HIS OWN BUSINESS
abstract: Shortly after graduating from the University of Illinois in the early 1950's, Roger E. Stangeland borrowed some money and started a sporting goods business. He sold it four years later and has been working as a retailer for somebody else ever since.   Mr. Stangeland, now 56, is on the verge of going back into business for himself again.

headline: New Thinking On Poor Lands
abstract: IN the flush of confidence that swept the economics profession after World War II, there was widespread belief that the greatest mission that lay ahead was the economic development of the poor countries of Africa, Asia and Latin America, and that this could be accomplished through the knowledge and skills of economists.   This last weekend, the Center for Economic Development of Williams College marked its 25th anniversary by bringing together 80 economists and public officials from developed and developing countries, many of them trained at Williams, to appraise the successes and failures of development economics - and to think about where the field should go from here, if it is to help cure the poverty of nations.   The easy optimism of the early postwar period is gone. That optimism was based on the belief that the difference between rich and poor countries was simply that the rich had enormously greater amounts of capital per unit of labor than the poor, and that the key to development was to speed up the rate of capital formation.

headline: Office Building Backs Eurobonds
abstract: The Equitable-Lord Realty Corporation, a subsidiary of Lord Securities, is offering about $205.8 million of Eurobonds backed by a midtown Manhattan office building.   Underwriters led by Goldman Sachs International offered about $105.8 million of 10 3/8 percent bonds due in 1995 and $100 million of 10 1/2 percent bonds due in 1997, both at a price of 99 3/4. The bonds are secured by lease payments on 1285 Avenue of the Americas, which until recently was the headquarters for the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States and is now the headquarters for Paine Webber Inc.

headline: Oil Shake-Up In Nigeria
abstract: Festus Marinho, a two-term managing director of the National Petroleum Corporation of Nigeria, has been retired in a shake-up of the Government organization.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;Shift Seen as Signal At Philipp Brothers
abstract: By naming Martin N. Kaufman and Henry S. Schachar as chairman and president,  respectively, of Philipp Brothers, its commodity trading subsidiary, Phibro-Salomon Inc. sent a signal to the financial world.         The old way of trading commodities is dead, the message said. These men, both 32 years old and steeped in the technology of computers and telecommunications, are what the future is all about.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Roger Miles Blough, who died at the age of 81, was chewed out by President Kennedy in 1962 for raising steel prices.

headline: FRENCH APPEALS COURT RULING DELAYS BARBIE TRIAL
abstract: France's highest appeals court today overturned a lower-court ruling that prevented Klaus Barbie from being charged with some crimes committed during the Nazi occupation of France. The decision in effect postponed the trial of Mr. Barbie, a former Nazi SS captain, until after the French parliamentary elections in March.   In its decision, the Court of Cassation reversed lower-court rulings that had prevented Mr. Barbie from being prosecuted for crimes against French Resistance fighters, which the lower courts asserted did not constitute ''crimes against humanity.''   The prosecutors had limited the charges under this category to the deportation of 86 people arrested at the office of the Jews of France Committee in Lyons and the deportation to Auschwitz of 44 children and 7 adults from the village of Izieu.

headline: LIMA, UNDER SIEGE, SETS ITS SIGHTS ON KIDNAPPERS
abstract: With a .357 Magnum revolver in his shoulder-holster and a shotgun on his desk, Edgard Rivera sat in front of two television monitors watching clients enter his weapons store.   ''The security situation has got out of hand,'' he said. ''Our sales are three times higher than last year. People are having to arm themselves because the police can't protect them.''

headline: U.S. AIDES SAY SOVIET MAY BE VERGE OF PLAN FOR AFGHAN PULLOUT
abstract: Reagan Administration officials said today that they believed the Soviet Union might be on the verge of offering a timetable for a phased withdrawal of its 100,000 troops as part of a political solution in Afghanistan.   The officials said that of all the issues discussed at the Geneva summit meeting, they came away most intrigued by comments by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, suggesting that he was growing impatient with the drawn-out conflict with Afghan guerrillas.   Today, appearing on the NBC News program ''Meet the Press,'' Secretary of State George P. Shultz was asked if Mr. Gorbachev had indicated any willingness to provide for the first time a schedule for a Soviet troop withdrawal.

headline: MONEY DATA CITED
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities fell modestly yesterday as traders were made uneasy by rapid growth in the nation's basic money supply and an intense debate among economists about the direction of interest rates.   Although prices were little changed after the Federal Reserve's late afternoon announcement of a $4.4 billion rise in the M-1 money supply measure for the week of Nov. 25, the money supply data are attracting more attention than earlier in the year. The latest week's increase was widely anticipated and was attributed in part to a computer failure at the Bank of New York on Nov. 22, which caused that bank to borrow more than $20 billion from the Federal Reserve.   But some economists said there are signs, beyond technical factors, indicating that rapid money supply growth has resumed, after a lull in October. Donald Fine, a vice president at Chase Manhattan Bank who manages a widely followed survey of bank deposits used to predict money supply changes, said preliminary data suggest that the money supply figures next week could show a rise of about $3.5 billion. Some, but not all, of next week's increase could be attributed to unusual deposit flows brought on by Thanksgiving falling late in the month, immediately followed by a Friday that was the last business day of the month.

headline: South Korean Students Seize Ruling Party Office
abstract: Students protesting against the South Korean and United States Governments seized offices of the ruling party for six hours today, setting the building on fire before they were expelled by the police.

headline: Study of Phone Costs
abstract: The Gallup Organization said today that 65 percent of Americans in a survey agreed that ''the cost of my local telephone service is reasonable.'' Fifty-two percent said they paid $15 a month or less for local service, not including buying or renting a phone.

headline: Advertising;   Henderson Friedlich Given Name Change
abstract: Last week's Henderson Friedlich Graf & Doyle is this week's Doyle Graf Mabley, reflecting the arrival last August of Thomas Mabley, 52, to be executive vice president and domestic creative director.

headline: New, Bigger Edition Of 'Patent It Yourself'
abstract: David Pressman, a San Francisco patent attorney, has revised his book, ''Patent It Yourself,'' and it is being published by Nolo Press of Berkeley, Calif.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Technology;   A Future Role For Scramjets
abstract: TREMENDOUS progress in the design of a new class of jet engines - known as scramjets - is propelling the fantasy of a hypersonic plane out of the Twilight Zone toward reality.   For years research on these jets, also known as supersonic-combustion ramjets, has bubbled along in Federal research laboratories on a shoestring budget. Then three weeks ago the President's science adviser and the chief of research and development for the Air Force disclosed that they were ready to commit a half-billion dollars over the next three years to refinement of the engine technology, in hopes of developing a plane that could cross the country in 12 minutes and circle the globe in 90.   If the effort works, it could mark the most significant change in airplane design since the invention of the jet. Air Force officials say scramjets may make it possible for a plane to take off from an ordinary runway and quickly accelerate to Mach 12 or even Mach 25. With the aid of an on-board rocket booster, the plane could even propel itself into orbit, paving the way for a new, less expensive way of launching and retrieving satellites.

headline: CAIRO'S ARMY HAS NEW JOB: MILK THE COW
abstract: Each day Mohammed rises at 5 A.M. to milk his cows. In a long, narrow barn, he attaches metal suction pumps to the udders of a succession of none-too-contented cows and flips a switch. He repeats this exercise twice a day, as do farmers at modern dairy farms throughout Egypt.   Yet Mohammed is no ordinary farmer. He is a soldier. Nor is the farm where he works his family's. It is Modern Dairy Unit 1, a military installation.   This is one of 24 agricultural and industrial plants run by the military to provide Egypt's 450,000-member armed forces with food, clothing, and other requirements.

headline: U.S. PROTESTS TO PRETORIA OVER ARREST OF MANDELA
abstract: The State Department said today that the United States had protested to the South African Government over the arrest of Winnie Mandela on Sunday.   A department spokesman, Charles E. Redman, said, ''We are concerned that Mrs. Mandela's arrest could led to further escalation of violence in South Africa.''   There was a bombing in a white shopping mall south of Durban today, and Mr. Redman said that ''in that connection, we can only condemn another bombing aimed at civilians, this time in Durban.''   ''We call on all parties in South Africa to move toward negotiations and not confrontation,'' he said.

headline: Entertainment Agency Of Della Femina Grows
abstract: Della Femina, Travisano, Sherman & Olken, the Della Femina agency's entertainment and communications advertising subsidiary, is reporting on two pieces of new business, each of which bills about $1 million.

headline: Travelers Reports Gain
abstract: The Travelers Corporation reported today that its net income rose 2.9 percent to $81.7 million in the third quarter of 1985, compared with $79.4 million in the same quarter of 1984. Revenue of $3.9 billion increased 8 percent from $3.6  billion in the same period a year ago. With more common shares outstanding this  year, per-share earnings dropped to 89 cents, from 94 cents a year ago. Operating earnings rose 7 percent, to $86.1 million in the 1985 quarter, compared with $80.4 million in the third quarter of 1984. ''Catastrophe losses,  due largely to hurricanes Elena and Gloria, had a major effect on the third quarter,'' Edward H. Budd, chairman of the insurance company, said.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * American Express Bank Ltd., the international banking arm of the American Express Co., has elected its vice chairman and treasurer, Robert A. Savage, to the additional post of chief operating officer.    * Cellular Telephone Co., Rochelle Park, N.J., a joint venture of Metromedia Inc. and LIN Broadcasting Corp., has named Jerrold D. Addams Corp., has named Jerrold D. Addams president.

headline: TEXACO'S RATINGS CUT
abstract: The Standard & Poor's Corporation said yesterday that it had downgraded its ratings on Texaco Inc.'s bonds and commercial paper in light of the uncertainty over the outcome of Texaco's legal battle with the Pennzoil Company. The action by S.&P. follows the decision on Wednesday by Moody's Investors Service to lower Texaco's credit ratings and means that Texaco's debt is now rated as below investment grade by both major ratings services.

headline: FALLOUT FROM OIL'S DECLINE
abstract: If there was a cloud in the silver lining of last week's lower oil prices, one had to look no further than the precious metals markets to find it. ''These markets have been poor performers all year,'' said Walter L. Emery, director of research at the Commodity Research Bureau, ''but what really put the whammy on them was the OPEC meeting.''

headline: Playboy Posts a Loss
abstract: Playboy Enterprises Inc. said today that it recorded a net loss of $1.95 million, on revenues of $48 million for its first quarter. That compares with a net income of $3.59 million, or 37 cents a share, on revenues of $46.4 million, in the similar period last year.

headline: REPORT FOR U.N. ASSAILS AFGHAN REGIME
abstract: Violations of human rights have become widespread in Afghanistan since Soviet forces joined the fighting there nearly six years ago, according to a report presented today to the United Nations.   The report, prepared for the United Nations Commission on Human Rights, says that violations include indiscriminate mass bombings and killings of civilians; mutilations and routine torture; the forced evacuation of rural areas; the imprisonment without trial of tens of thousands of political prisoners, and religious intolerance.   The report says the actions appear intended not only to destroy opposition to the Afghan Government, but to break the spirit of an independent people and destroy the traditional family and tribal structures.

headline: Financial Corp. Reserves
abstract: The Financial Corporation of America, which is expected to report its earnings for the third quarter on Wednesday, will take major additions to its loan loss reserves that will reduce earnings by two-thirds, the company said today. It will take the additional reserves because of foreclosures in its single-family mortgage portfolio.

headline: 2 Officials in Pope Plot Trial In Turkey to See 2 Witnesses
abstract: The judge and a prosecutor of the trial in the papal shooting plot arrived in Turkey today to question two key witnesses.   The judge, Severino Santiapichi and the public prosecutor, Antonio Marini, want to see whether a Turkish underworld figure, Abuzer Ugurlu, and a convicted killer, Omer Ay, can shed light on the case.   Both men have been named by the convicted Turkish gunman Mehmet Ali Agca as his co-conspirators.

headline: Unilever to Pursue A U.S. Acquisition
abstract: Unilever, thwarted in its effort to buy Richardson-Vicks Inc., still hopes to make a major acquisition in the United States, a spokesman said.

headline: U.S. SENATORS IN LETTER, URGE MARCOS TO HOLD FREE ELECTION
abstract: Senator Richard G. Lugar, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, and three other members of the committee have sent a letter to President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines saying it is ''essential'' that the coming elections there ''be conducted in a free and fair manner.''   The letter, dated last Friday, was made public today by Mr. Lugar, Republican of Indiana. It was also signed by Senators Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island, the ranking Democrat on the committee; Frank H. Murkowski, Republican of Alaska, chairman of the subcommittee on East Asian and Pacific affairs; and Alan Cranston of California, the ranking Democrat on the subcommittee.

headline: GENERAL DYNAMICS SUSPENDED BY U.S. ON NEW CONTRACTS
abstract: The Navy suspended the General Dynamics Corporation today from obtaining any new Government contracts, one day after the giant military contractor and four former or current executives were indicted on fraud charges.   The announcement came as Government officials disclosed that James M. Beggs, the Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and one of those indicted, would take an indefinite leave of absence from his post. Mr. Beggs is a former General Dynamics official.   Under the suspension, General Dynamics cannot receive contracts for new work from any branch of the Government. In the last fiscal year, General Dynamics had about $8 billion in sales, all but $1 billion of it from Government contracts.

headline: REAGAN FAVORING U.S.-SOVIET FLOW OF YOUNG PEOPLE
abstract: President Reagan today proposed ''the broadest people-to-people exchanges in the history of American-Soviet relations.''   Mr. Reagan, set to embark Saturday for Geneva, said his meetings there Tuesday and Wednesday with Mikhail S. Gorbachev ''can be a historic opportunity to set a steady, more constructive course in the 21st century.''   ''My mission, stated simply, is a mission for peace,'' the President said in a televised address. ''It is to engage the new Soviet leader in what I hope will be a dialogue for peace that endures beyond my Presidency. It is to sit down across from Mr. Gorbachev and try to map out, together, a basis for peaceful discourse even though our disagreements on fundamentals will not change.''

headline: Talks Sought on Midcon Bid
abstract: The partnership formed by Wagner & Brown and Freeport-McMoran Inc. to acquire the Midcon Corporation offered yesterday to discuss raising its bid of $62.50 a share for Midcon's 41.5 million shares.   In a letter to Midcon's directors, WB Partners, the vehicle that the two energy concerns created for the takeover of the natural gas pipeline company, said it ''remained prepared to enter into a negotiated transaction which would provide a meaningful increase'' in the bid, now valued at $2.71 billion.

headline: Czechs Hold Hostage-Taker
abstract: The Czechoslovak press agency said today that the police in Brno had overpowered a gunman who took children and nurses hostage in a nursery and demanded to be allowed to emigrate to the West. No one was injured.

headline: U.S. VIEWS SOVIET ARMS PLAN AS REPACKAGING OF OLD IDEAS
abstract: Reagan Administration officials expressed disappointment today about the Soviet Union's new arms proposals in Geneva as the chief United States negotiator prepared to return to Washington for consultations on the American response.   Officials said that the negotiator, Max M. Kampelman, was returning to the United States ''for personal reasons,'' but that it was likely he would meet ranking Administration aides to discuss the Soviet proposals and consider a possible counterproposal.   Although President Reagan and White House spokesmen declined to discuss the details of the Soviet arms proposals, outlined Monday and today in Geneva, United States officials said privately that there was considerable disappointment over the measures.

headline: Grenade Said to Kill 10 At Philippine Cockfight
abstract: A hand grenade exploded in a crowded cockfighting arena in the southern Philippines today, killing at least 10 people and wounding 39, a church-run radio station said.

headline: SOUTH AFRICA'S GOLD COLOSSUS
abstract: Shortly before he assumed the chairmanship of the Anglo American Corporation of South Africa, this country's biggest mining and industrial conglomerate, Gavin Relly was asked about his relationship with his predecessor, Harry Oppenheimer.   As chairman, a reporter inquired, would he feel obliged to emulate the kind of public position established by Mr. Oppenheimer? Mr. Oppenheimer's father, Sir Ernest Oppenheimer, founded South Africa's greatest corporate dynasty almost 70 years ago, and the son's style fused the politics of opposition with the business of creating fortunes in gold and diamonds.   ''One shouldn't make the mistake,'' Mr. Relly replied, ''of thinking it's my job now to fill Harry's boots in an image sense. I don't intend to have to fill his boots. I intend to fill my own.''

headline: Aid for Targets Of Takeover
abstract: The Senate passed a bill today that would make it easier for companies that are targets of hostile takeover bids or proxy fights to communicate with their shareholders.      The bill, which President   Reagan is expected to sign, would require commercial banks that hold stock for customers to disclose the customers' names and addresses to corporations that request a list of their own shareholders, provided the banks had received prior approval from the shareholders.

headline: WHOEVER DREAMED THAT UP?
abstract: His genius he was quite content In one brief sentence to define: Of inspiration one percent, Of perspiration, ninety-nine.   Thomas Alva Edison THEY packaged hamburgers and automobile loans. They created intelligent cameras and nostalgic record albums. In the process, they learned that Thomas Edison was right: Ideas come often; hard work makes a few successful.   This year, various innovators made a success of concepts that others had tried and found wanting. For example, Steven Gottlieb's ''inspiration'' was that the public would pay a high price for recordings of old television tunes if the sound quality was high. His ''perspiration'' went into compiling theme songs from television shows of a previous generation and re-recording those for which the original soundtrack had deteriorated. Mr. Gottlieb's two-record album, although at $17.95 the most expensive television-nostalgia album to hit the market, was the first to be a runaway success.

headline: AMERICAN JOINS THE LOW-COST RANKS
abstract: DALLAS    AMERICAN AIRLINES has for years talked about establishing a hub in Denver, a market dominated by its arch rival, United. The city, located at the edge of the central plains, is a natural gateway for routing business travelers to Los Angeles, San Francisco, and beyond, to Asia.   Yet Robert L. Crandall, the shrewd and cocky chairman of American's parent, the AMR Corporation, balked recently at the prospect of buying a ready-made base in Denver. Despite a war chest of $1.3 billion in cash, he sat by as People Express bought Frontier Airlines, the largest Denver-based carrier, for nearly $300 million.   Mr. Crandall has by no means lost interest in Denver. But, with American's two-tier wage contracts in place, with its cost per seat mile of capacity among the lowest of the major carriers, and with its cash flow high, the airline is increasingly finding it cheaper to move into new markets with its own planes and crews. American has already earmarked $6 billion over the next five years to add 160 planes to its current fleet of 290 - an expenditure that Mr. Crandall expects will turn out to be a prime cost-cutting move. ''It is that principle of low costs that drives us toward internal growth,'' he said.

headline: DOCTOR IS SHIFTED BY SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: Dr. Wendy Orr, a district surgeon who revealed widespread police brutality against political detainees, has been given ''other duties'' so that she may no longer enter prisons to see people held under South Africa's state of emergency, according to her father.   Dr. Orr's father, the Rev. Robert Orr, said she had been assigned to new duties in the Port Elizabeth district surgeon's office and no longer saw detainees.   A spokesman for the National Health Service denied that Dr. Orr had been formally banned from entering prisons, but her father said, ''She has been removed from her normal duties - attending to detainees and prisoners - although she has not officially been told that she has been banned from entering prisons.''

headline: Coleco's Net In Sharp Rise
abstract: Coleco Industries said profits increased sevenfold, to $26.8 million, in the third quarter, a record-breaking performance tied to the sales of Cabbage Patch Kids dolls.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * American District Telegraph Co., which supplies electronic security systems, has elected Edward M. Liddy executive vice president and chief financial officer.    * Canadian Pacific Ltd., Montreal, has named Robert Campbell vice chairman.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD;Somalia Said to Repel 2 Ethiopian Attacks
abstract: Somalia says it has repulsed two attacks by Ethiopian troops, killing 64 soldiers and capturing tanks and weapons.         Somalia and Ethiopia are longstanding antagonists and territorial rivals. Their accounts of sporadic clashes along the border are generally different, with the statements of one side denied by the other.

headline: ZIMBABWE SAYS IT CAN BEAR JOLT OF PRETORIA CURBS
abstract: The Foreign Minister of Zimbabwe told the General Assembly today that his country was prepared to accept the consequences that economic sanctions against South Africa would have on Zimbabwe.   Zimbabwe relies heavily on South Africa's roads and railways to transport its exports. But the Foreign Minister, Dr. Witness Mangwende, said his country does not ''want the international community to shirk its responsibility to the people of South Africa by hiding behind our vulnerability to South Africa's reprisals if mandatory sanctions are imposed against it.''

headline: CORRECTION
abstract: A front-page caption in the Business section on Sept. 22 incorrectly dated a photograph of John Sculley, chief executive of Apple Computer, and Steven P. Jobs. The photo was taken last January.

headline: A TAX BILL BY NOV. 28 IS PLEDGED
abstract: Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, pledged today that his panel would finish work on tax-revision legislation ''by Thanksgiving,'' but he said the bill ''may not sit well with the purists.''   In a speech prepared for delivery in Chicago tonight and again in Washington Friday, Mr. Rostenkowski said the bill would be ''a series of compromises.'' He vowed, however, to come in with a bill that is ''a lot better than present law, in both principle and practice.''

headline: Guerrillas State Conditions For Peace in Western Sahara
abstract: Polisario guerrillas fighting Morocco for control of Western Sahara have set new conditions for peace in the desert territory, the official Algerian press agency reported today.   In a communique issued by its executive committee and carried by the press agency, the Polisario demanded total evacuation of the Moroccan army and administration and withdrawal of ''100,000 Moroccan settlers'' from towns and costal areas.   The communique also called for direct talks ''between the Saharan and Moroccan Governments'' to arrange an interim administration and a joint United Nations and African security force to run affairs of the former-Spanish territory in a transitional period.

headline: Sanko Steamship Loans
abstract: The Daiwa Bank and the Tokai Bank said Friday that they had written off most of their outstanding loans to the Sanko Steamship Company, which is seeking court protection from its creditors. Daiwa, estimated to have the largest exposure to Sanko - about 100 billion yen, or $481.5 million - said it wrote off 62.4 billion yen, or $311.9 million, in the fiscal first half, ended Sept. 30.

headline: AMERICAN AWAITS A SOVIET GIFT: HER HUSBAND
abstract: Gregory, 2 1/2 years old, listens carefully when his mother says that the father he has never met will be coming home from Leningrad in a few months. Sometimes, he runs to the front door expectantly.   His mother, Edith Luthi, is full of expectation, too, about a new life with the Soviet citizen she married five years ago but has lived with for only three months. They have not seen each other for three years.

headline: Haitian Opposition Chief Is Reported Assaulted
abstract: Family members said Tuesday that 10 men, some in uniform, entered the home of the opposition leader Sylvio Claude and beat him with ''clubs, gun butts and fists'' and that he had gone into hiding.

headline: Cuomo Signs Takeover Bill
abstract: Governor Cuomo signed yesterday what he called a unique law to curb hostile takeovers of New York corporations and said he believed it was ''invulnerable'' to legal challenge.   ''I would expect a challenge,'' he said in a signing ceremony in his office in the World Trade Center.

headline: Cox Family Member Leads Bid for Swift
abstract: His family has amassed a vast fortune in the oil and gas business, but Edwin L. Cox Jr., 38, has always been interested in animals.   Mr. Cox, whose agribusiness interests range from beef processing and distribution to cattle feedlots, appears on the verge of increasing those holdings considerably.   On Monday the Swift Independent Corporation, the meat and poultry company, said it had received a leveraged buyout offer totaling about $135 million in cash and preferred stock from a partnership led by Mr. Cox.

headline: General Public
abstract: The General Public Utilities Corporation said that rate changes expected to go into effect around Nov. 8 because of the return of Three Mile Island Unit One to operation would reduce electric rates to customers by about $78.9 million a year. It said that Three Mile Island One has met operating criteria by operating at 35 percent capacity for 100 consecutive hours, and its subsidiaries have given 10 days' notice of rate changes. General Public said that the changes are expected to increase base rates about $99.2 million a year but cut energy charges $178.1 million.

headline: FIDELITY SWITCHES MANAGERS, QUIETLY
abstract: The Fidelity Freedom Fund has been one of the most visible stock funds offered by Boston's Fidelity Investments. Heavily promoted as a fund for the huge market for Individual Retirement Accounts and Keogh plans, the $500 million growth stock fund is managed without regard for tax consequences.

headline: Bruce-Marcade
abstract: Robert Bruce Industries said it had signed a letter of intent to buy a 51 percent stake in Marcade Group Inc., a financially troubled maker of women's apparel.

headline: 20 ARE HURT IN CLASHES IN NEW CALEDONIA
abstract: Twenty people were hurt overnight in clashes between loyalists and separatists in Noumea, capital of this French territory in the Pacific, the police said today.   They said the unrest began late Friday night when about 200 white settlers opposed to an end to French rule on the island attacked local Melanesians, or Kanaks, as they were leaving two Noumea nightclubs.

headline: AFGHAN TROOPS RING U.S. EMBASSY IN STANDOFF OVER A SOVIET SOLDIER
abstract: Afghan troops have ringed the United States Embassy in Kabul, cut off the electricity and doused it with powerful searchlights in an effort to force American diplomats to turn over a Soviet soldier who has been there since Thursday, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today.   Expressing high-level concern for the first time about a potentially touchy situation with the Soviet Union as he goes to Moscow for talks with Soviet leaders, Mr. Shultz said the United States had protested about the harassment at the embassy.   In a news conference held as he flew here from Washington on his way to Helsinki, the first leg of his Moscow mission, Mr. Shultz and other officials provided many more details about the incident than the State Department made known on Friday.   An aide to Mr. Shultz said the secretary had personally protested to Anatoly F. Dobrynin, the Soviet Ambassador, about the threatening moves around the embassy in Afghanistan on Thursday. The United States regards the Afghan troops as taking orders from the Soviet military command, which has more than 100,000 soldiers in Afghanistan.

headline: Police in Peru Seize 1,000 After Rebel Deeds
abstract: The Peruvian police arrested 1,000 people today in a sweep through Lima suburbs after Maoist guerrillas blacked out an Andean city, blew up seven vehicles and dynamited a statue, the police said.   Many of the suspects were detained because they lacked identification papers.

headline: SMALL BUSINESS FINDS A FRIEND ON TAX PANEL
abstract: Time and again over the last month, members of the House Ways and Means Committee have demonstrated a soft spot for small business.   While chopping away at special tax benefits for larger companies, they preserved special tax treatment for smaller timber producers and financial institutions. They exempted small contractors from more onerous accounting methods. And they provided small corporations with a more generous tax rate schedule than President Reagan had proposed and endorsed the idea of a new tax credit for small manufacturers.

headline: Sri Lanka Land Mine Kills 6
abstract: A land mine killed six soldiers and wounded seven in Sri Lanka's Northern Province today. Security officials said the wounded were taken to hospital after the attack at Mullaitivu.

headline: Advertising;   Bozell & Jacobs Office Gets Commercial Trust
abstract: The Commercial Trust Company of New Jersey in Jersey City, which is the flagship bank of Commercial Bancshares of New Jersey, has decided to cast its lot with the Bozell & Jacobs Union, N.J., office.   The search, which started with a field of 16 agencies on both sides of the river, ended up with the House Group and Homer & Durham in New York and Harcom of Boston, and of course, the winner.   The bank, which had a budget of some $900,000 last year, should have one of $2.2 million next year.

headline: PATENTS;  ENGINE COOLING SYSTEM
abstract: A cooling system for internal combustion engines that was patented this week is being promoted by National Technologies Inc. of Sharon, Conn., as offering fuel economy and other benefits. Patent 4,550,694 was granted to John W. Evans, also of Sharon.  To get a copy of a patent, send the number and $1.50 to the Patent and Trademark Office, Washington, D.C. 20231.

headline: OFFICIALS ARE WARY ON THE CAUSE OF THE CRASH
abstract: Officials declined tonight to say whether the DC-8 jetliner that crashed here with 250 American soldiers and 8 crew members this morning had undergone de-icing before taking off in a freezing drizzle.   The officials appeared at a late-evening briefing at Gander International Airport, where the chartered plane had stopped to refuel on its flight from Egypt via West Germany to Fort Campbell, Ky., where the servicemen were returning home.   John Pitman, the airport manager, provided a detailed timetable of the flight's stopover for one hour and seven minutes at Gander. But when he was asked whether the DC-8 had been de-iced, Mr. Pitman said, ''I will leave that for someone else to answer.''

headline: NEW EFFORT ON ARMS PLANNED; PRESIDENT SEES A FRESH START
abstract: President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, ended their summit conference here today without achieving breakthroughs on key issues. But they expressed hope that they had opened a new, more promising chapter in United States-Soviet relations.   After two days of intensive conversations, the two men approved a joint statement agreeing to step up arms negotiations and to meet more regularly.   They chatted jovially before speaking to about 300 journalists at a brief closing ceremony. But they conceded that ''serious differences remain on a number of crucial issues.''

headline: UNITED NATIONS CALENDAR
abstract: LUNCHEON POLITICS - The concept of the ''power meal'' will take on new dimensions today as the world leaders visiting New York for the 40th anniversary of the United Nations mix international affairs and fine dining. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar will sponsor a luncheon in the Delegates' Dining Room of the United Nations. A more private affair, meanwhile, will take place at Lutece, where Prime Minister Lho Shin Yong of South Korea is scheduled to have lunch with former President Richard M. Nixon.

headline: Snag in Buyout Plan for Amsted
abstract: Amsted Industries, a Chicago-based maker of products for the construction market, said that a management group does not expect to pursue the leveraged buyout proposal it made Nov. 4 but is working on an alternative offer.   The original proposal, made in conjunction with an employee stock ownership plan, offered $37 in cash and $27 principal amount of debentures for each Amsted share.

headline: SALVADOR REBELS TRYING TO UNIFY IN MARXIST PARTY
abstract: The top military leaders of the Salvadoran guerrilla movement say that they are trying to unite in a single Marxist-Leninist political party.   The decision to try to form a Marxist-Leninist party represents the first time the rebel military Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front has publicly defined itself as a Marxist movement.   The shift appears to reflect an ideological hardening among the rebels, as well as a narrowing of their public appeal and of the political forces that they once hoped would support them.   The decision is one of the strongest indications yet of the growing distance between the five factions that make up the rebel military front and the handful of small social democratic parties that have been allied to them for five years under the banner of the Democratic Revolutionary Front.   The social democratic parties have had an increasingly troubled relationship with the armed guerrilla groups. The Democratic Revolutionary Front has consistently defined itself as a supporter of political pluralism, and its senior officials say they will not join the Marxist-Leninist party the rebels hope to form.

headline: TUNISIANS REPORTED AT ODDS ON LETTING THE P.L.O. STAY
abstract: President Habib Bourguiba was reported today be at odds with most of his key advisers over whether to allow the Palestine Liberation Organization to keep its political headquarters here.   According to diplomats and Tunisian and Palestinian officials, Mr. Bourguiba has argued that the P.L.O. presence is a source of trouble for the country. The sources said he cited the hijacking of the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro last week and the Israeli bombing of the P.L.O. headquarters here Oct. 1 in which about 70 Palestinians and Tunisians were killed.   But almost his entire Cabinet - angered at the United States for its endorsement, later qualified, of the bombing and for its interception of an Egyptian plane carrying the hijackers of the ship - is arguing instead for cooler relations with Washington and closing ranks with the Arab world, the sources said.

headline: ISRAEL CALLS BOMBING A WARNING TO TERRORISTS
abstract: Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin said today that the bombing of Palestine Liberation Organization headquarters in Tunisia was a warning to terrorists that they were not safe anywhere from Israeli punishment.   The raid, the first Israeli attack on foreign soil outside of Lebanon since 1981, was in retaliation for the killing last Wednesday of three Israelis aboard a yacht in Larnaca, Cyprus, Mr. Rabin said at a news conference.   Israel knew that Yasir Arafat, head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, was in Tunisia, said Lieut. Gen. Moshe Levy, the Israeli chief of staff, at the same news conference. But he would not say if Israel had specifically tried to kill Mr. Arafat. P.L.O. spokesmen said Mr. Arafat was not hurt in the raid.

headline: FEDERAL RESERVE'S CURB ON BONDS IS ASSAILED BY THE ADMINISTRATION
abstract: The Reagan Administration today severely criticized the Federal Reserve Board's proposal to limit the use of low-grade bonds in corporate takeovers.   The Departments of Justice, Treasury, Labor and Commerce - along with the Office of Management and Budget and the Council of Economic Advisers - questioned the Federal Reserve's legal authority to apply margin requirement rules to takeovers financed with the bonds.   The Administration was apparently angered by the proposal, taking the view that the Federal Reserve was trying to slow the rash of corporate takeovers. Today's action represents their strongest disagreement over the working of a free marketplace. It also represented an unusually broad attack marshaled by the Administration.

headline: EMIGRATION WORRIES ISRAEL AS ECONOMY SAGS
abstract: With the Israeli economy heading into a recession, and with unemployment rising, Government officials say they are concerned that they may be faced with a new wave of emigration, particularly of young people.   Although the number of those who have recently emigrated cannot be precisely established, Israeli officials say they believe that more and more young Israelis have been leaving the country to look for work abroad, and that many will not come back even if Israel's economy recovers.   Up-to-date figures are unavailable, the officials involved in emigration matters said, because an emigrant is defined by the Central Bureau of Statistics as an Israeli who has lived abroad for at least four years.   ''There is an atmosphere of an economic catastrophe and this atmosphere has pushed people to emigrate,'' said Dov Shilansky, a Likud Member of Parliament who is involved with emigration issues. The rate of unemployment in Israel is etsimated to be at least 6 percent of the work force, and it is expected to rise in the coming months as a result of planned large-scale layoffs.

headline: PARIS AND BONN SET ACCORD ON PROJECTS
abstract: France and West Germany, at the close of two days of talks here, announced agreement today on a range of joint military, space and transportation undertakings.   But officials who took part in the talks between President Francois Mitterrand and Chancellor Helmut Kohl said they did not discuss ways to finance the projects.   In a significant gesture, Mr. Mitterrand said France would reverse a recent decision and take part in the development of a joint European fighter plane to be developed and built by West Germany, Italy, Britain and Spain. What is important, he added, ''is the symbolic value'' of France's participation. Discussing the French role in the plane's development, the French President told a news conference that ''I have thought of 10 percent; if not 10 percent, it could be as little as 5 percent.''

headline: M.A.C. in Bond Offering
abstract: The Municipal Assistance Corporation of the City of New York is offering $125 million of bonds through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.   The financing consists of insured and uninsured bonds, all of which are backed by a pledge of revenues from taxes on sales and stock transfers and from New York State's per capita aid payments to the city.

headline: MARKET STEADIES, WITH DOW UP 1.15
abstract: The stock market broke its two-day skid, but just barely yesterday, as prices rose slightly on improved volume.   Traders said the market was recovering from a bout of profit taking and was helped by the bond market's ability to stabilize after a steep slide on Monday.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which fell 14 points on Monday, moved in a narrow range yesterday, closing ahead 1.15 points, at 1,459.06. Trading volume picked up slightly, to 109.7 million shares, from 103.5 million on Monday.

headline: PRETORIA UNIONS BACK DIVESTMENT
abstract: The newly formed Congress of South African Trade Unions, the biggest labor federation in the country's history, said in its first policy statement today that it supported divestment by American and British companies of their South African holdings.   In its statement the Congress also called for the resignation of President P. W. Botha, the nationalization of the country's mines, the withdrawal of troops from segregated black townships and the abolition of the so-called pass laws that limit blacks' access to white areas.      Radical Political Agenda    If those laws are not repealed within six months, the Congress's newly elected president, Elijah Barayi, told 10,000 supporters in a rugby stadium here, ''We are going to burn all the passes of the black man.'' The Congress says it has a following of 500,000 workers, predominantly black, from 36 labor unions.
