headline: SHULTZ, IN SOVIET, STARTS TO DRAFT SUMMIT PACTS
abstract: Senior United States and Soviet officials conferred here today to see what agreements could be reached for the meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Geneva this month, American diplomats said.   Secretary of State George P. Shultz, carrying a letter from President Reagan, is to see the Soviet leader on Tuesday to discuss an ''agenda for the future,'' the Americans said.   As today's talks stretched into the evening, Izvestia, the Government newspaper, published virtually the entire text of an often contentious interview given by Mr. Reagan to Soviet journalists. The granting of the interview and its publication in the Soviet Union are regarded by the two sides as something of a milestone in relations.

headline: WINNIE MANDELA HELD FOR SECOND TIME
abstract: Winnie Mandela was arrested for the second time in eight days today for breaking government restrictions on her movements.   White plainclothesmen in unmarked cars detained her after forcing her car to pull over on a freeway leading to Soweto from Jan Smuts Airport outside Johannesburg.   ''Don't touch me with those hands,'' Mrs. Mandela shouted at one white policeman. ''I do not know if you have AIDS.''

headline: U.N. STALWART FOR 40 YEARS PLANS TO RETIRE
abstract: The books and United Nations memorabilia are being packed, and Under Secretary General Brian E. Urquhart is preparing to retire after 40 years with the world body.   But he will not be going far - across First Avenue to take up another career as scholar-in-residence at the Ford Foundation at 320 East 43d Street. He says that he plans to leave early next year and that he intends to go quietly.   ''I hope nobody will take any notice of me,'' Mr. Urquhart, 66 years old, said said the other day. ''As for what I plan to do next, let's see what the results are first. Why not wait until I accomplish something?''

headline: RENOVATION TAX AID FACES CUT
abstract: The House Ways and Means Committee voted today to limit the tax credits that can be claimed by investors in projects to rehabilitate old buildings, but the panel rejected President Reagan's proposal to disallow the credits altogether.   On the eve of a weekend of work that the chairman, Dan Rostenkowski, hopes will lead to final committee approval of tax revision legislation by the end of next week, the panel also approved changes in the tax treatment of insurance companies and of homeowners who install energy-saving devices.   The rehabilitation credits, first enacted in 1978 and expanded in 1981, have been especially important to older cities in the Northeast and Middle West, and mayors and legislators from those areas worked against the President's proposal.

headline: WAR TURNS ANGOLAN BREADBASKET INTO LAND OF HUNGER
abstract: In what may be Africa's most expensive but least known emergency food program, airplanes of the International Committee of the Red Cross are flying about 400 tons of food weekly into Angola's fertile central highlands.   The airlift is helping to feed 200,000 people who are suffering from malnutrition in an area that was once the breadbasket of Angola.   It is not drought that has caused fields to lie fallow. Insterad, guerrillas of the Union for the Total Independence of Angola, led by Jonas Savimbi, have made it unsafe to cultivate the land or to transport crops to market.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM REAGAN'S NEWS CONFERENCE
abstract: Following are excerpts from President Reagan's news session in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:   OPENING STATEMENT I have instructed our negotiators in Geneva at the nuclear and space talks to present a new United States proposal designed to advance the prospects for achieving real reductions in nuclear arms, enhancing stability and addressing the legitimate concerns of the United States and our allies as well as of the Soviet Union.   I have also asked our negotiators to seek Soviet agreement to extend this round of the negotiations into next week so that our negotiating team can make a full presentation of our proposal and have a real give-and-take with the Soviets on its details.   Finally, I have written to the leaders of allied nations and have transmitted a personal letter to General Secretary Gorbachev on this subject. History has shown that progress is more surely made through confidential negotiations. Therefore, I'm not going into any details about our proposal. Suffice to say that our proposal is serious, it is detailed and it addresses all three areas of the negotiations. It builds upon the very concrete reductions proposals which our negotiators had tabled earlier as well as the Soviet counterproposal.

headline: Market Place;   Speculators And Bankrupts
abstract: THE trouble with speculating in bankrupt companies, an investment adviser once observed, is that most people buy the stocks before the companies enter bankruptcy proceedings. The trick is to ferret out potential winners after a company files for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.   The aim of Chapter 11 is to protect a company from lawsuits while it works out a plan to repay its debt. Under the wing of the bankruptcy court, a company can continue operating while attempts are made to resolve its problems.

headline: Channel Will Buy Charter Oil Unit
abstract: Channel Refinery Inc., a company affiliated with Marc Rich, the commodities trader who is in Switzerland to avoid prosecution on tax evasion charges, has agreed to purchase the Charter Oil International Corporation.

headline: Ad Pages Increase 0.6%
abstract: The total advertising pages carried by member magazines in the Publishers Information Bureau inched up six-tenths of 1 percent in September from the same month last year, to about 14,517. Revenues, thanks to advertising rate increases, were up 11.4 percent, to $456.6 million.

headline: Baldrige Asks Soviet Trade
abstract: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said here today that the United States would intensify its promotion of American goods in the Soviet Union to foster increased trade.   Addressing one of the largest gatherings of American business executives ever to visit the Soviet Union, Mr. Baldrige said that Washington would sponsor company exhibits in Moscow, assist sales missions, participate in Russian trade fairs and increase the size of the commercial section of the United States Embassy.

headline: REAGAN CURBS ENTRY OF CUBAN OFFICALS
abstract: President Reagan today imposed restrictions on the entry into the United States of Cuban officials.   The action, effective immediately, was seen as retaliation against Cuba's suspension of an immigration agreement with the United States. Fidel Castro, the Cuban leader, took that step in May in response to the Reagan Administration's decision to begin operation of Radio Marti, an anti-Castro radio station.   A proclamation signed by Mr. Reagan bars the entry of Cuban Government and Communist Party officials unless they are coming exclusively to conduct business at the Cuban Interests Section in Washington, the Cuban Mission to the United Nations in New York or the United Nations itself.

headline: Two West Bank Arabs Found Slain in Israel
abstract: The bodies of two Arabs who had been slain were found by Israeli police today in an orchard 15 miles west of here.   The two men, whose names were not made public, were 29 and 31 years old and were from the West Bank, the police said.

headline: GULF RULERS IN WARNING ON IRAN-IRAQ FIGHTING
abstract: The conservative rulers of the Persian Gulf wound up their annual summit meeting here today with a warning that the ''recent escalation'' of the Iran-Iraq war threatened the stability of the region and freedom of navigation in its waters.   The war and the fears of spreading terrorism in the Middle East were the major topics at the sixth meeting of the Gulf Cooperation Council, officials and diplomats said.   But the communique issued at the end of the four-day session today disclosed little specific accomplishment and repeated the studiously vague phrases that have been used in communiques over the last several years.   The council officials also repeated their offer to mediate in the gulf war.

headline: CHALLENGES TO QADDAFI DISCOUNTED
abstract: The relative weakness of Libyan opposition groups and the rising anti-Americanism among several of Libya's neighbors are likely to complicate any effort to undermine the Government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, according to Western and Middle Eastern diplomats and specialists here.   Administration officials and Congressional sources said recently that President Reagan had approved a covert plan aimed at weakening the Libyan Government.   But the diplomats and experts said they questioned whether such a plan could succeed, despite their view that the Libyan leader appeared to be at one of his most vulnerable points in his 16-year rule.   ''The fact that this plan has been made public automatically decreases the chances of success,'' said Pierre Lellouche, deputy director of the Paris-based French Institute of International Relations.

headline: A GORBACHEV TRADE WARNING
abstract: Mikhail S. Gorbachev told 400 American business executives today that while the Geneva summit meeting had opened the way to better Soviet-American relations, trade would remain limited until Washington lifted ''political obstacles.''   ''I will be absolutely frank with you,'' the Soviet leader told the representatives of about 150 American companies, who are in Moscow with Secretary of Commerce Malcolm Baldrige to test the economic waters in the wake of the summit meeting last month.   ''So long as those obstacles exist,'' Mr. Gorbachev said, ''there will be no normal development of Soviet-U.S. trade and other economic ties on a large scale. This is regrettable but we are not going to beg the United States for anything.''

headline: MANY ASK CURBS ON PRETORIA AS THE COMMONWEALTH MEETS
abstract: The heads of government of the Commonwealth nations opened a weeklong meeting here today with an apparent majority seeking to increase pressure on South Africa to end apartheid.   But Britain, which once dictated policy to the Commonwealth members when they were colonies or dominions of the British Empire, has indicated that it is opposed to taking further measures against South Afica.   Thus, in the meetings over the next few days, which are to take place behind closed doors, as is customary at these conferences, many of the heads of government will try to persuade Britain to shift its position.      Terrorism and Drugs    In initial remarks, Lynden O. Pindling, the Prime Minister of the Bahamas, said the heads of government would also take up the issues of terrorism, drug trafficking and economic problems.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: PRIME RATE   9.50   9.50   12.75

headline: BUSINESS SOURING ON TAX PLAN
abstract: Support for President Reagan's proposed overhaul of the tax system is fast eroding among many of the nation's leading business executives.   ''My own guess is you've got three-four-five to one of businessmen who are saying 'just forget the whole thing,' '' said Edmund T. Pratt Jr., chairman of Pfizer Inc., after a meeting here with other corporate chairmen.   The executives, about 100 current and former chairmen of the biggest banks, industrial companies and retailing chains, are members of a group known as the Business Council. They have gathered at the Homestead resort here for the council's semiannual, three-day private meeting with senior Government officials.

headline: PACIFIC TELESIS NET UP
abstract: The GTE Corporation, plagued by heavy losses in its Sprint long-distance telephone unit, yesterday reported a 1 percent increase in third-quarter net income, to $290 million, from $287 million in the period a year earlier. Earnings per share, however, fell to $1.33, from $1.40, because of an increase in the number of shares outstanding.   GTE said the slight increase in net income resulted from improved earnings in local telephone operations and communications products, which offset the $96 million operating loss from the division that includes Sprint. Excluding Sprint, operating income would have risen 22 percent, the company said.

headline: Restructuring At RCA Units
abstract: The RCA Corporation said it would restructure some of its electronics and communications businesses and take a charge of $140 million before taxes, or $81 million after taxes, against its third-quarter earnings. The company said that, including an after-tax gain of $92.6 million from the sale of the Hertz Corporation, net income for the period was expected to be higher than in the same quarter last year, when it reported earnings of $78 million, or 74 cents a share.

headline: Johnson Net Up by 14.7%
abstract: Johnson & Johnson, the medical and institutional supplies company based in New Brunswick, N.J., said yesterday that third-quarter earnings rose 14.7 percent, to $158 million, or 87 cents a share, from $137.7 million, or 75 cents a share, a year ago.   The company said that sales rose to $1.6 billion, a 6.7 percent increase from the $1.5 billion in the 1984 quarter.

headline: Merrill Ad Review
abstract: Merrill Lynch confirmed Friday that it planned to review its advertising situation in keeping with a year-old corporate policy of periodic review of all vendors. Young & Rubicam has been the agency since 1979. The current budget is $40 million. According to the brokerage, the country's largest, it has not yet contacted any other agencies and is getting complete cooperation from Y.&R. What's its alternative?

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Americus Shareowner Service Corp. said the Americus Trust for Exxon shares has met requirements for its establishment and will begin trading on the American Stock Exchange today.    * Bell Group Ltd., Perth, Australia, said its holding in Broken Hill Proprietary Co., Australia's largest company, had been purchased as a long-term investment, not a bid for control of the company.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: RESPONDING TO A FALSE ALARM ON DEBT
abstract: IN adopting the Williams bill, the 1968 law that established the basic Federal regulations for tender offers, Congress made clear that it was Federal policy to proceed without ''tipping the balance of regulation, either in favor of management or the person making the bid.'' Now, however, the Federal Reserve Board has proposed a change in its ''margin requirements'' that would provide for extensive new Fed intrusion in the tender-offer process, with significant adverse consequences to bidders.   The doctrine of Federal neutrality has been frequently reaffirmed by Congress and various Government agencies. The 1985 Economic Report of the President to Congress concluded that ''further Federal regulation of the market for corporate control would be premature, unnecessary and unwise.''

headline: Construction Spending Surges 1.9%
abstract: Spending on new construction rose a sharp 1.9 percent in September, the biggest gain in six months, the Government reported today.   The September gain left construction spending at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $350.4 billion, 9 percent higher than a year ago.   The increase followed a three-tenths of 1 percent drop in August and was the biggest advance since a 2.5 percent rise in April.

headline: AUTO RISE IS CHIEF SPUR
abstract: Retail sales rose at the strongest clip in five months in September as heavy demand for new cars overshadowed disappointing department store sales, the Commerce Department reported today.   Sales jumped 2.7 percent, to a record $120.2 billion. Without the big increase in auto demand in September, total retail sales would have risen only six-tenths of 1 percent.

headline: Top 8.88% Yield For School Bonds
abstract: The Chicago School Finance Authority is selling $194.2 million of general obligation school assistance refunding bonds, through underwriters led by First National Bank of Chicago.   The tax-exempt bonds were offered yesterday with yields ranging from 5 1/2 percent for bonds due in 1987 to 6 1/2 percent in 1990, 7.70 percent in 1995, 8.30 percent in 2000 and 8 3/4 percent in 2005.

headline: COMPLEX CARBIDE CHESS GAME
abstract: A $5 billion battle of wits to take over the Union Carbide Corporation that began in early December continued over the weekend, with Carbide and its unfriendly suitor, the GAF Corporation, fighting to determine the future of the giant chemical company.   As the situation currently stands, stockholders of Carbide have two offers:    * They can accept a revised bid from GAF for $74 a share, or $5.1 billion, that GAF made last Thursday. GAF's first bid of $68 a share, made on Dec. 9, was rejected by Carbide.    * They can sell to Carbide for an $85-a-share package of cash and securities that Carbide made on Dec. 15. Carbide's offer is for at least 23.55 million shares, 35 percent of its stock outstanding, although it reserved the right to buy more.

headline: SEOUL IS PESSIMISTIC ABOUT BETTER TIES WITH NORTH
abstract: After more than a year of unusually steady and even amicable negotiations, South Korean officials say no substantive progress has been made with North Korea on possible two-way trade and large-scale exchanges of war-separated families.   Despite the pessimistic assessment, however, officials say that they are not disappointed and that they will pursue talks with the North into 1986.   ''We did not anticipate that any rapid progress would be made,'' said South Korea's Foreign Minister, Lee Won-kyung, in an interview this week.   ''It will take a very, very long time,'' he said. ''But this is the best way to keep North Korea under control and to ease tensions of the Korean peninsula.''

headline: TO CLOSE SOME PLANTS
abstract: The Reynolds Metals Company, hurt by low aluminum prices and import competition, said yesterday that it would close some of its plants and take a $313.5 million charge against its third-quarter earnings.   As a result, the Richmond company said, it lost $303.8 million in the third quarter on sales of $875.8 million, in contrast to a gain of $39.3 million, or $1.82 a share, on sales of $940.7 million last year.   Analysts said the move stemmed largely from market factors beyond the company's control. They agreed with yesterday's statements by Reynolds's chairman, David P. Reynolds, that the concern would have higher earnings in future quarters as a result of writing down its unprofitable operations.

headline: UNION IN FRANCE CONFIRMS IT GETS U.S. FUNDS
abstract: A French labor union said today that it had received American Government funds to support foreign trade union activists who had come to France to escape persecution in such countries as Poland and Afghanistan. The union said there was ''nothing scandalous'' in its activities.   The labor union, the Force Ouvriere, was responding to a report published today in the newspaper Liberation. The paper said that a public American foundation had used ''secret funds'' provided by Congress to support several politically conservative French organizations. The Force Ouvriere is widely regarded as center-right in its political orientation.

headline: HUNDREDS FEARED KILLED BY PUERTO RICO MUD SLIDE
abstract: Hundreds of people apparently died in a mud slide that buried a hillside shantytown north of this city Monday after a three-day rainstorm, the authorities said today.   Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon called it the ''worst tragedy to ever strike the island.'' He proclaimed a state of emergency.   By evening, rescue workers had uncovered 29 bodies from the claylike muddy earth that sealed the crumpled community of Mameyes.

headline: TREASURY BOND PRICES DROP A BIT
abstract: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds fell slightly yesterday after having risen sharply during the previous six trading sessions.   Securities dealers said there were no new economic or financial data to prompt the change in direction, but many noted that some retrenching could be expected after a strong rally. The bellwether 10 5/8 percent Treasury issue due in 2015 was offered late in the day at 104 1/8, down 6/32, to yield 10.18 percent. Early in the day this closely watched 30-year issue rose to about 104 5/8, and it remains well above the Oct. 28 closing price of about 101, to yield 10.51 percent.

headline: Rumors Spur Teledyne Shares
abstract: Shares of Teledyne Inc. soared yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, amid rumors that the conglomerate is planning another stock buyback. Teledyne closed at $336, up $17 a share from Thursday.

headline: Investor Raises Sea-Land Stake
abstract: Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas investor who has offered to acquire the Sea-Land Corporation for $25 a share, said yesterday that he had increased his stake in the shipping company to 22.1 percent. He had owned about 10 percent on Tuesday and had increased his holdings to 18 percent by Wednesday, according to filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Bank Board Names Enforcement Chief
abstract: Rosemary Stewart, an attorney at the Federal Home Loan Bank Board since 1974, has learned how to live with red tape. But from now on, Mrs. Stewart intends to be dealing with less of it.   On Tuesday the bank board said that it had created an Office of Enforcement to deal with the growing problem of unsound lending practices and insider abuses at savings and loan associations. Mrs. Stewart, who is 36 years old, was named to head up the department.

headline: GORBACHEV'S GLOOMY AMERICA
abstract: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's America is a land controlled by wealthy capitalists and conservative business interests.   Right-wing forces dictate Government policy and would never permit a lasting improvement in relations with the Soviet Union.   A profit-hungry military-industrial complex is the real force behind the development of space-based weapons.   These are among the impressions of the United States that Mr. Gorbachev has presented in conversations with American officials and politicians since becoming Soviet leader in March, according to Western diplomats who have been briefed in detail about the meetings.

headline: U.S. and Britain Assailed Over Curbs on Press
abstract: The International Press Institute accused United States and British leaders today of ''double standards'' in calling for curbs on press coverage, particularly of terrorist attacks.   ''It has been a year of strange double standards,'' the institute said in an annual review.

headline: U.S. POLICY ON ANGOLA MOVES CLOSER TO REBEL AID
abstract: The Reagan Administration said today, in a policy statement of support for rebels fighting the Soviet-backed Government in Angola, that the United States ''should sympathize with and support such resistence.''   It said it intended to work with Congress in coming weeks on how best to do this.   The statement came after several weeks of discussion in the Administration over how to respond to growing demands in Congress for open financing of aid to the rebels, as well as a parallel move by Administration officials to put together a covert military aid program for the insurgents.   No decisions have been made on how to proceed, a senior Administration official said, and the statement clearly left open the possibility of further efforts for a negotiated settlement in southern Africa that might remove the need for American aid to the rebels.

headline: O.E.C.D. TAX CUT BID
abstract: Warning that the world could return to economic ''stagnation'' next year, senior Western economic policy officials appealed today to a number of major countries to reduce taxes in an effort to strengthen investment and increase growth.   The appeal for what were called ''supply-oriented tax cuts'' was aimed mainly at Britain, West Germany and Japan, officials said, although no countries were named in the statement issued today by the Economic Policy Committee of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. The committee, which concluded a two-day meeting here, is currently under the chairmanship of Beryl W. Sprinkel, the chairman of President Reagan's Council of Economic Advisers, Several officials at the meetingsaw the public call as another sign that Britain, West Germany and Japan were moving slowly toward a more expansionary fiscal policy, which would offset the depressive effect on the world economy of a slowdown widely expected in the United States economy. Mr. Sprinkel, however, made a surprise prediction here of a robust 4 percent growth rate in the United States economy next year.

headline: ITALIANS REPORT A BROADER PLOT IN THE HIJACKING
abstract: Italian magistrates said today that their investigation of four Arab militants charged with hijacking the cruise ship Achille Lauro had disclosed the possible involvement of accomplices and possible links to other recent terrorism in Italy.   Dolcino Favi, the magistrate investigating the hijacking, said at a news conference in Syracuse, the Sicilian city where the four hijackers are being detained, ''We assume others were involved, accomplices in Italy.''   He said investigators had not been able to identify the accomplices. But magistrates in Genoa, where the Achille Lauro is scheduled to arrive late Wednesday after having been released by Egyptian officials, said that a formal arrest order had been issued for a fifth man, now in custody for suspected passport violations.

headline: Air Jamaica Change
abstract: Altschiller Reitzfeld Advertising quietly split about a month ago with Air Jamaica, for which it was promoting both passenger and cargo. According to David Altschiller, the agency's chairman, the budget (which had been about $1 million at its high point) had dwindled to next to nothing. Now the word is that the carrier is talking to other agencies.

headline: GAF LOSES A ROUND IN COURT
abstract: A Federal judge in Manhattan refused yesterday to grant the GAF Corporation a preliminary injunction that would have prevented the Union Carbide Corporation from defending itself against an unwanted takeover by GAF.   One leading Wall Street trader, who asked not to be identified, called the decision ''a real negative'' for GAF, a chemicals and building materials producer waging a $5 billion battle to take over Carbide against its will.   GAF now has much less of a chance of taking over Carbide, the trader said. But when asked whether he thought the battle was over, he replied, ''It's too early to say, although this is a real hindrance.''

headline: SINGAPORE ACTION TROUBLING PRESS
abstract: A recent apology to a Singapore court by the editor of The Asian Wall Street Journal for an editorial has raised some troubling journalistic questions, according to journalism and human rights organizations.   In particular, the apology has touched off discussion on the appropriate response when a foreign court challenges the editorial freedom of a United States news organization publishing abroad. It has also focused scrutiny on the degree of press freedom in Singapore.   On Nov. 19, Fred Zimmerman, editor and publisher of The Asian Wall Street Journal, apologized to the High Court in Singapore for any contempt of court caused by an editorial that appeared Oct. 17. The apology came at a hearing on contempt charges, prompted by the editorial, against The Asian Wall Street Journal and several other parties. The case is still pending.

headline: YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC JEALOUSLY GUARDS ITS GAINS
abstract: This country, a leader in the group of 77 nations that demands a ''new international economic order'' on behalf of the developing countries, has a north-south problem of its own. The republics of Slovenia and Croatia are the developed north, and people there say they feel that their less developed brothers are milking them.   The feeling is most outspoken in this capital of Slovenia, the republic with the highest living levels.   Because jealousies among the Yugoslav republics make standard-of-living comparisons political dynamite, only estimates are given. Stanislav Valant, executive vice president of Ljubljanska Banka, said Slovenia was 50 percent or more above the national average, and Croatia 10 to 15 percent. Slovenia's per capita gross product is six times greater than that of Kosovo, the Albanian-minority region in the south.

headline: Soviet Fills Vacancy In Its Finance Ministry
abstract: Boris I. Gostev, a former aide to Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, has been appointed Finance Minister, the official press agency Tass said today.   He replaces Vasily F. Garbuzov, who died last month after 25 years in the post.   Mr. Gostev, 58 years old, worked for more than two and a half years as deputy to Mr. Ryzhkov in the economic department of the ruling Communist Party Central Committee, before Mr. Ryzhkov was named Prime Minister in September.

headline: CHIP SETTLEMENT WITH JAPAN SOUGHT
abstract: Negotiations are under way to settle a trade complaint against the Japanese semiconductor industry, but Clayton K. Yeutter, the United States trade representative, said yesterday that he would resist pressure from some American chip makers to reach a quick settlement with ''a Band-Aid solution.''   Mr. Yeutter's comments, in response to a question during testimony before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, marked the first time the Reagan Administration has indicated it is trying to settle one of the bitterest trade disputes between the two countries. The case centers on a complaint filed in June by the Semiconductor Industry Association, which represents American manufacturers. It says they have been systematically excluded from Japanese markets.

headline: SHULTZ LEAVES U.S. FOR SOVIET TALKS
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz left Washington today on the first leg of a mission to Moscow to try to prepare understandings and agreements for announcement when President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev meet this month in Geneva.   Before landing here for a refueling stop en route to Helsinki, Finland, he told reporters that his talks with Soviet leaders on Monday and Tuesday would be intended to work out the basis for an ''agenda for the future'' in Soviet-American relations, including regular summit meetings.   He said the two sides would also explore an agreement in principle to give ''a political impulse'' to the Geneva arms talks. And he revealed that the United States had proposed an increase in ''people-to-people exchanges,'' perhaps in the thousands.

headline: ADVANCE TO GO -- OR TO THE BRONX
abstract: PLAYERS of the new ''Beverly Hills: The Golden Triangle'' board game can pretend-shop to their hearts' content. And players of the new ''Vegas: The Game'' can be pseudo-high rollers as long as their luck holds out. But players of ''NYC: The Big Apple'' get to make real changes in their city - S. Alden Inc., in Kansas City, Kan., which owns the game, donates $2 of the $35 purchase price to the Ellis Island Foundation.

headline: $201.9 Million Sale For Texas Roads
abstract: The Texas Turnpike Authority is offering $201.9 million of refunding revenue bonds tentatively priced yesterday to yield a maxiumum of 9.30 percent for bonds due in 2013, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.   For bonds with shorter maturities, yields ranged from 7 percent in 1990 to 8.10 percent in 1995, 9 percent in 2000 and 9.22 percent in 2005. Underwriters expect an A rating from Moody's Investors Service.

headline: REAGAN TO PRESS AHEAD WITH PLAN TO PROVIDE AID TO ANGOLA REBELS
abstract: The Reagan Administration intends to tell the Congressional intelligence committees next month that it plans to provide $15 million in covert aid for rebels fighting the Marxist Government of Angola, Administration and Congressional sources said today.   Administration officials said Secretary of State George P. Shultz had approved the aid proposal before he left on Monday for a 10-day trip to Europe. But it was uncertain when the assistance would actually start flowing to the rebels, known as the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola and led by Jonas Savimbi.

headline: Philippine Fire Destroys Hotel for U.S. Personnel
abstract: A six-hour fire destroyed a hotel that housed United States Air Force personnel and their families today, but Filipino and American officials said there were no casualties.   Fire officials in Angeles, 45 miles northwest of Manila, said no signs emerged that the fire at the Maharajah Hotel, just outside the gates of Clark Air Base, was part of a series of hotel fires that the Government said were set by Communist guerrillas.

headline: BANKERS 'TO ASSESS' BAKER PLAN
abstract: The Reagan Administration is hoping that a consensus in favor of its recent initiative to ease the global debt crisis will emerge here Monday at a closed-door meeting of commercial banks holding 85 percent of the third world's debt.   But opposition to the plan, which calls on the banks to lend an additional $20 billion over three years to debtors that streamline their economies, could delay, or even prevent, a public endorsement, which the United States seeks.   Some European bankers say they doubt the wisdom of calling on banks to increase their holdings of shaky loans. They say that the governments of industrialized countries should be playing a larger role by giving more credits, and by guaranteeing more of any new commercial bank loans.

headline: AIRLINES DOUBTFUL ON GUARDS
abstract: The weekend hijacking of an Egyptian airliner has underscored international airline officials' concerns that posting armed guards aboard airliners may be counterproductive.   According an account by one of the surviving passengers, a midair shootout began shortly after the plane was hijacked when one of the assailants approached a passenger who turned out to be an Egyptian security guard. The guard drew a pistol as the hijacker approached, and there was an exchange of fire. There were contradictory reports on whether anyone was killed.

headline: Subsidy Deal for Union Oil
abstract: The embattled Synthetic Fuels Corporation approved up to $500 million in new price-support and loan-guarantee subsidies today for the Union Oil Company's thus-far unsuccessful Colorado shale oil plant.   But the agency, targeted for abolition by critics in Congress and the Reagan Administration, structured the deal so that the new aid cannot begin flowing until 1987.

headline: Thailand Accuses 40 In Failed Coup Attempt
abstract: A former Prime Minister and 39 others accused of roles in a failed coup were charged in criminal court today with inciting rebellion against the Thai Government.   The charge carries maximum penalties of life imprisonment or death.   The suspects, including former Prime Minister Kriangsak Chomanan, were named as co-conspirators in an attempt on Sept. 9 to topple Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda.

headline: A RISING TIDE OF FORECLOSURES
abstract: LIKE tens of thousands of others in the late 1970's and early 80's, James and Linda Low left Illinois and came to Houston in search of a bigger piece of the American dream.   And like many others, they quickly found it, he, first as a teacher, then as a grocery manager earning more money, and she as a bank supervisor. In 1983, with two salaries and their skills much in demand, they bought a $64,000 home in a new subdivision in West Houston, carrying an initial 11.5 percent interest rate and affordable monthly payments of $720. The dream seemed secure.   Now, the Lows have joined countless others who have been rudely awakened by the downward spiral of Texas's once-booming economy. Mr. Low lost his job and his wife's salary could not meet the bills. And as their monthly payments rose to $850, the value of their investment plunged: A house across the street, identical to the Low's, sold for a low $47,500 and several other homes on their street stand vacant.

headline: OPEC PLANS TO END OIL-PRICE DEFENSE TO CAPTURE SALES
abstract: OPEC oil ministers agreed today on a change in market strategy that could lead to a new oil-price war and bring lower world prices next year.   The 13-nation producer organization decided in principle to abandon its official policy of trying to defend a $28-a-barrel oil price through cuts in output, which all its members are now flouting.   Instead, the members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will seek to protect a fixed share of the world oil market by cutting the prices they charge, as needed, to secure sales, OPEC delegates said.   In practical terms, the ministers are bringing the official strategy into line with present practice. For most of this year, all members have been either producing above their official quotas or selling below the official price - and usually doing both.

headline: EG & G Contract
abstract: EG & G Inc. said its Florida subsidiary had been awarded a three-year, $360 million extension to its existing prime contract for base operations management and services for NASA's John F. Kennedy Space Center.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: American Express Bank Ltd., the international banking arm of the American Express Co., has elected Francois Giscard d'Estaing chairman of the Trade Development Bank (France) S.A., a Paris-based subsidiary.

headline: Pet Unit Bought By Challer Foods
abstract: Pet Inc. said it had sold its dairy division to Challer Foods Inc., a subsidiary of Finevest Dairy Holdings Inc. While terms were not disclosed, industry sources estimated the deal, which includes all of Pet's refrigerated and fresh dairy products, to be worth about $55 million. Pet, a St. Louis-based subsidiary of IC Industries, said its evaporated milk business was not included in the sale.

headline: POWER PACT GALLING TO NEWFOUNDLAND
abstract: The adage ''Marry in haste, repent at leisure'' can apply not just to couples but sometimes to provinces in Canada too.   In 1969, Newfoundland and Quebec negotiated a 65-year contract, beginning in September 1976, under which Quebec could buy nearly all of the hydroelectric power generated by a major dam that Newfoundland was building at Churchill Falls in Labrador on Canada' mainland.   Quebec agreed to pay 0.3 Canadian cents (currently about .22 United States cents) per kilowatt hour for the power. Neither province, however, foresaw that the Arab oil embargo in 1973 would send energy prices spiraling upward.

headline: Military Contracts
abstract: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation was awarded a $73 million Air Force contract for work on the F-16 aircraft's fire control radar, the Defense Department said.

headline: DECADE'S TOP JOBS
abstract: NEED A JOB? Or a new one that might last a few years? Planning your business and wondering what occupations you can count on hiring in the future? Economists at the Bureau of Labor Statistics in the United States Department of Labor have prepared a list of 20 occupations expected to grow the fastest in the next 10 years. These range from technical positions such as computer analysts and injection-mold-machine operators to legal assistants and mechanical engineers.  Dozens of professional organizations and associations will send free or inexpensive materials that describe what these positions entail, what they pay and what training is needed. Below is a list of the names and addresses of some of the organizations that have information on the 20 projected fastest-growing occupations.  Computer-service technicians, computer operators and operators of peripheral electronic data-processor equipment. It's expected there will be 10 times more computers in use during the next decade than exist today. As a result there will be a drastic need for people to run and repair them. By 1995 computer-service technicians alone will experience a whopping 97 percent growth in employment. And by the early 1990's, the introduction of fifth-generation machines will mean a need for the number of computer- and peripheral-equipment operators.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    * Aluminum Co. of America has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of up to $300 million of debt securities and warrants.    * Citicorp sold $50 million of 91-day commercial paper at an average rate of 7.899 percent, up from 7.833 percent last week, and $50 million of 182-day paper at an average rate of 7.90 percent, up from 7.85 percent.

headline: PRESIDENT'S PARTY MAKES A STRONG SHOWING IN GREEK CYPRIOT VOTE
abstract: President Spyros Kyprianou's party appeared this morning to be winning enough votes in Parliamentary elections to defeat an opposition effort to force his resignation over his handling of negotiations to reunite the island.   Incomplete results in the voting by Greek Cypriots for a new Parliament, which had been sought by the Communist and conservative parties, indicated that the legislative strength of Mr. Kyprianou's Democratic Party would increase.   At 7 A.M., with 425 of 662 electoral districts counted, the Democrats had 31.51 percent of the vote for seats in the House of Representatives, whose membership has been expanded from 35 to 56 seats. In the outgoing one-chamber legislature the Democrats held nine seats, based on winning 19.5 percent of the popular vote of 1981.

headline: CABINET IN ISRAEL AVERTS COLLAPSE
abstract: The collapse of Israel's national unity Cabinet was averted late tonight when Prime Minister Shimon Peres and Ariel Sharon, the Minister of Industry and Commerce, hammered out a compromise settlement in their private war.   After about 12 hours of negotiations today, Mr. Peres withdrew his threat to dismiss Mr. Sharon from the Cabinet. The move came after Mr. Sharon added ''clarifications'' to an apology Wednesday for accusations he had made against the Prime Minister.   Political commentators here seemed to agree that what began Wednesday as a battle of high principle about the proper behavior of a Cabinet minister degenerated by late tonight into a messy, personal political quarrel. They said all of the principals - Mr. Peres, Mr. Sharon and Yitzhak Shamir, head of the Likud bloc - appeared to have scored political gains and losses. #6 Verbal Attacks on Peres The day opened with Mr. Peres again threatening to dismiss Mr. Sharon by noon if he did not come forward with a public apology for six specific verbal attacks on the Prime Minister. Mr. Peres said the apology offered by Mr. Sharon on Wednesday for the style of his remarks, but not the substance, was totally inadequate.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, OCTOBER 28, 1985
abstract: The Economy    The stalemate has been broken on a new tax bill, according to members of the House Ways and Means Committee. Dan Rostenkowski, its chairman, kept the committee in session all weekend and declared that he felt confident a House bill would be produced this year. The Illinois Democrat was joined in that assessment by the panel's ranking Republican, John J. Duncan of Tennessee. But Senate action is still not expected before next year. [Page A1.]

headline: The New Ideas At Seoul Talks
abstract: THE key idea coming out of the International Monetary Fund/World Bank meeting here is that nations should free up their economies for more efficient use of resources and that austerity alone, important as it may be for nations with budgetary and debt problems, cannot solve the world's overall debt problem. What is needed is an environment of overall growth, especially in the industrial countries.   This implies that there must be some accommodation by the I.M.F. to stress long-term growth policies in countries in addition to the more short-term austerity measures that it is accustomed to imposing as conditions for its loans.   Virtually everyone here acknowledges - and welcomes - the greater willingness by the United States to recognize that the problems of the poor countries are connected to its own. Further, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d drove home the point that the United States means to play a more active role in solving the debt problem within the context of world economic growth.

headline: The U.N. Today; Dec. 17, 1985
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Mission Will Miss Interest Payment
abstract: Mission Insurance Group Inc., the financially troubled insurance company said that it would not pay its semiannual interest payment of $950,000 due Dec. 1 on its 9 percent debentures of 2003, of which about $50 million worth are outstanding.

headline: PEOPLE EXPRESS ACQUIRING FRONTIER
abstract: People Express agreed yesterday to buy Frontier Holdings, the owner of Frontier Airlines, in a deal the companies described as binding. The merger would catapult People from its position as the nation's 12th-largest airline, in terms of passengers carried, to No. 5.   The directors of Frontier yesterday approved the offer of $24 a share, totaling about $300 million, according to Sandy Allen, the company's director of corporate communications.   If the takeover is approved by Frontier's shareholders, it will be a coup for Donald C. Burr, chairman of People Express, and the second major defeat for Frank Lorenzo, president of the Texas Air Corporation, which also bid for the airline. Frontier, with its hub at Denver, would give People a base from which to feed flights to the West Coast and to expand into new markets in the Southeast and Northwest.

headline: Business and the Law;   Tobacco Ads: Curbs Legal?
abstract: WOULD it be unconstitutional to bar the Marlboro man from billboards and newspaper advertisements?   Many lawyers have heatedly debated that question since the American Medical Association earlier this month called on Congress to ban tobacco advertising altogether. Such a ban is needed to reduce smoking, it said, especially among the young.   The tobacco industry - along with the publishing industry, much of the advertising industry and the American Civil Liberties Union - vigorously argues that such a ban would violate the First Amendment's guarantees of freedom of speech and freedom of the press.

headline: Officer to Quit At Allegheny
abstract: Clayton A. Sweeney, widely regarded as the successor to Robert J. Buckley as chairman and chief executive of Allegheny International Inc., intends to resign as vice chairman and chief administrative officer, the consumer products company said yesterday.

headline: 12.50 RISE PUTS DOW AT 1,511.70
abstract: Helped by a string of developments that could aid businesses for years to come, the Dow Jones industrial average demolished the stubborn 1,500 barrier yesterday in the fifth-busiest session in Wall Street history.   More than 178 million shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange, just a day after House and Senate conferees approved a bill intended to shrink the Federal deficit until the Government's budget is balanced by 1991. When the Government spends less, it needs to borrow less, and according to Wall Street analysts and economists, this would lead to lower interest rates in the future and better corporate profits.   With that in mind, investors yesterday stampeded into the equities market, sending the Dow up 12.50 points, to a record close of 1,511.70. The blue-chip average of the stocks of 30 of the biggest United States companies had briefly exceeded the 1,500 level on several occasions in the last few weeks but never finished above it.

headline: HOUSING PRESSES ON A COMMERCIAL ZONE
abstract: Just north of the Queensboro Bridge in Manhattan there is a neighborhood that is not a neighborhood. It consists of some eight square blocks, from 59th Street to the south side of 62d Street, and from York Avenue almost to Second Avenue. And although it contains dozens of residential buildings - mostly five-story brick walk-ups - it is considered by the city to be a commercial rather than residential district.   That means that all the residential buildings in the bridge zone are at least 25 years old, and most are far older - they were in place when the city adopted its current zoning in 1961. Because of the zoning, no new residential buildings can be constructed.

headline: Tax Plan Divides Executives
abstract: As they have throughout the yearlong process of developing a tax-revision package, business executives reached yesterday had varying reactions to the proposals that emerged this weekend from the House Ways and Means Committee.   The array of opinions turned up by a spot check of corporate officials and their representatives in Washington depended largely on how the tax plan affected the self-interest of their companies and their views on how it would change the business environment.   ''Those organizations that represent the capital-intensive sector of the economy will be pretty opposed to it, and those that are inventory-intensive, labor-intensive and thought-intensive will be for it,'' said John M. Albertine, president of the American Business Conference, a lobbying group that represents about 100 mid-sized companies. Heavy industry generally makes up the capital-intensive sector.

headline: U.N. Assembly Assails Israel On Occupation of Arab Lands
abstract: The General Assembly adopted three resolutions today condemning Israel's occupation of Arab territories as the core of the conflict in the Middle East.   One resolution, demanding Israel's immediate withdrawal from occupied lands and calling on countries to sever diplomatic, economic and cultural relations with Israel, was passed by a vote of 86 to 23, with 37 abstentions.

headline: Ford Credit Notes
abstract: The Ford Motor Credit Corporation is offering $200 million of floating-rate notes due in 1992 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. Interest on the notes, rated A-1 by Moody's and A+ by S.&P., will be adjusted and paid semiannually at 1/8 percentage point above the offered rate for interbank deposits in London.

headline: 4 Managers In the Thick Of Things
abstract: ''I'm a Cubs fan,'' said Ralph Wanger, ''and therefore I've learned to have patience and root for losers.'' But the manager of the Acorn Fund, a no-load growth fund that specializes in emerging companies, is not sentimental when it comes to investing. He shuns the stocks of the American automobile companies, for instance, and has invested in Fuji Heavy Industries, which makes Subaru cars and trucks.   More often than not, Mr. Wanger, 51 years old and the manager of the Acorn Fund for 15 years, likes to hunt obscure, smaller-than-average companies because they tend to outperform the market. ''The theory is,'' he said, ''that although these stocks tend to grow faster, they have a lot of volatility. Someone buying stock in just one or two of these small companies could very easily come up with a bad experience. By owning stock in many companies, we hope the disasters will average out.''   In fact, Mr. Wanger has done better than ''average out.'' The $269 million Acorn Fund in the past 10 years has returned 22.4 percent on a compound annual basis, good enough to rank among the top 25 funds in the industry.

headline: U.S., Turkey Sign Pact
abstract: Turkey and the United States signed an economic aid agreement today totaling $100 million, the semiofficial Anatolia press agency reported.

headline: Hospital Corp. Divestment Order
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission ordered the nation's largest for-profit hospital chain to dispose of two hospitals and a hospital management contract in the Chattanooga, Tenn., area.

headline: HOUSEHOLD TO SELL BIG SUBSIDIARY
abstract: Household International Inc. said today that it had reached an agreement in principle with a group of investors, including the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation and the Foxmeyer Corporation, to sell Household's merchandising unit in a leveraged buyout valued at about $690 million in cash and securities. Household will retain a 10 percent equity interest in the new company if the deal is completed.   Household Merchandising includes supermarkets and general merchandise stores as well as franchised hardware and variety stores. For the first six months of this year, it reported net income of $20.4 million on sales of $2.47 billion. While it contributes about 65 percent of Household International's sales, it accounts for only 20 percent of the parent's total net earnings.

headline: Advertising;   H.H.C.C. Joins Polaroid Team
abstract: Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos of Boston has joined the agency roster of the Polaroid Corporation in nearby Cambridge. The assignment is for the industrial, technical and professional products resigned in September by Doyle Dane Bernbach, which bade farewell to the client that grew to world fame with its help.

headline: TRADE TRIP TO SOVIET PLANNED
abstract: More than 300 American executives, hoping the Geneva summit talks will expand trade opportunities, plan to visit Moscow next month.   The occasion is a three-day meeting of the U.S.-U.S.S.R. Trade and Economic Council, William D. Forrester, a spokesman for the organization, said today. The council is a non-government group set up 12 years ago to promote commerce between the United States and the Soviet Union.   The Moscow meeting was scheduled for Dec. 9-11 independently of this week's Geneva event, but the meeting of President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, has seemed to swell the list of Americans registering for the Moscow trip, Mr. Forrester said. The group will include about 20 heads of companies.

headline: 25,000 ON STRIKE IN EL SALVADOR
abstract: About 15,000 workers went on strike today, joining 10,000 other workers who previously walked off their jobs to demand higher wages and to protest arrests of union leaders on subversion charges.   Workers of the Ministry of Public Works and the Ministry of Agriculture joined postal and waterworks employees belonging to the National Association of Telecommunications to protest Government policies.

headline: BRITAIN FAILS TO WIN SPACE-ARMS PLEDGE
abstract: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger and his British counterpart, Michael Heseltine, failed today to reach agreement on terms that would commit Britain to participation in the Reagan Administration's research program for a space-based missile defense.         At a one-hour meeting here during a gathering of North Atlantic Treaty Organization defense ministers, the two did agree to assign aides to address the issue of technology sharing, according to officials in both delegations. Mr. Weinberger and Mr. Heseltine are to hold a news conference on Wednesday.

headline: VOLCANOES: THE 10 WORST
abstract: Krakatoa, Indonesia. Aug. 26-27, 1883.   A total of 36,000 people died when the volcano on the island of Krakatoa erupted Aug. 26 and then, at 10:02 A.M. Aug. 27, exploded with a sound heard 3,000 miles away. Scores of villages at the base disappeared. Waves of 60 to 130 feet waves swept over western Java, southeastern Sumatra, and hundreds of smaller islands. Mont Pelee, Martinique. May 8, 1902. More than 30,000 people were killed as a liquid-like superheated mass of dust, steam, and gas engulfed the seaport of Saint-Pierre, wiped out smaller villages and plantations, and destroyed 16 of 18 ships in the harbor. Mount Vesuvius, Italy. Aug. 24, A.D. 79. Twenty thousand died when violent eruptions followed a series of sharp earthquakes. Ash and cinders buried the city of Pompeii, and mud buried the city of Herculaneum. Mount Etna, Sicily. March 25, 1669.  Earth tremors preceded an eruption that sent lava flowing over 14 cities and towns, killing 20,000 people. Tambora, Java. April 5, 1815.  Some 10,000 to 12,000 people died when 36 cubic miles of volcanic matter erupted, removing 4,000 feet from the mountain's height. Laki, Iceland. June-Aug. 1783. Lava wiped out 20 villages in southern Iceland. Dust, ash and gases destroyed crops and livestock, and an estimated 10,000 people died of starvation. Mount Kelut, Indonesia.

headline: Advertising;   Gerrity Joins Subsidiary Of Needham Harper
abstract: Edward J. Gerrity, who has been one of the better known corporate communications directors, is joining Needham Porter Novelli/New York, the public relations subsidiary of Needham Harper Worldwide, as a senior counselor.

headline: FINANCIAL PLANNERS FACE OUTCRY FOR SUPERVISION
abstract: An Arizona financial planner wasted $1.1 million of his customers' money in a tax shelter for financing development of a genetically superior rabbit. Another planner in Georgia took $100,000 from the savings and investments of his clients and put it into worthless certificates of deposit. And two financial planners in Maryland promised investors returns of 30 percent in 90 days, but squandered the funds instead.   These and other documented horror stories about a small group in the fast-expanding field of financial planning are behind the increased outcry for supervision of the field. Both the Securities and Exchange Commission and the North American Securities Administrators Association are considering the possibility of tough standards for this business.

headline: Ex-officer at G.E. Joining Bank Group
abstract: The American Express Bank Ltd., the international banking arm of the American Express Company, announced that George J. Stathakis, formerly president and chief executive of the giant General Electric Trading Company, will become associated with the bank in its merchant banking group.   Mr. Stathakis, who is 55 years old , has spent his entire business career with General Electric, a company he joined in 1953. But in a telephone interview he said he had been contemplating this move, which is effective Sunday, for some time.

headline: Toyota in Canada
abstract: The Toyota Motor Corporation said it would build a $400 million (Canadian) plant in Cambridge, Ontario, to make a 1.6-liter-engine type of passenger car by 1988. The plant will be the company's first car manufacturing facility in Canada and will employ about 1,000 workers when peak production of 50,000 units is achieved, Toyota said. On Wednesday, the company announced plans to invest $800 million in a car plant in Kentucky.

headline: More Bank Disclosure Urged
abstract: The Comptroller of the Currency proposed a regulation today that would require national banks to make increased disclosures about their operations, including enforcement actions against them.   The proposal is similar to one adopted by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation covering state-chartered banks that are not members of the Federal Reserve System.

headline: PREMIER OF ITALY, SCORNING U.S. ACTS, QUITS OVER FUROR
abstract: The Prime Minister of Italy resigned today after a speech to Parliament in which he spoke of his ''bitterness'' over actions by the United States in the aftermath of the hijacking of the liner Achille Lauro.   The collapse of the 26-month-old coalition Cabinet led by Prime Minister Bettino Craxi produced one of the most dramatic days in Italian politics in several years.   The Prime Minister was forced to resign after Giovanni Spadolini, the Defense Minister, pulled his Republican Party out of the Government on Wednesday to protest its handling of the hijacking and its decision to free Mohammed Abbas, a Palestinian guerrilla sought by the United States.   The United States also condemned Mr. Craxi's decision to release Mr. Abbas.      Final Cabinet Meeting    After a final Cabinet meeting today, which the Republicans did not attend, Mr. Craxi made his address and then drove to the Presidential Palace to hand his resignation to President Francesco Cossiga.

headline: ETHIOPIAN JEWS REACH ACCORD WITH ISRAELI RABBIS ON STATUS
abstract: A monthlong strike and sit-in by hundreds of Ethiopian Jews against Israel's Chief Rabbinate ended today with an agreement between the protesters and the rabbis over how to determine whether individual Ethiopian immigrants are Jewish.   Under the agreement, special religious courts are to be formed by the Ethiopians' religious leaders, who are called kessim.

headline: Chase in Maryland
abstract: The Chase Manhattan Corporation opened 13 branches in Maryland today, freeing $500 million in deposits that have been frozen since state-insured thrift institutions collapsed in May. Operating as Chase Bank of Maryland, the New York banking giant acquired three major thrift units - Merritt Commercial of Baltimore, Friendship of Bethesda and Chesapeake of Annapolis - and converted them to commercial banks. The acquisition adds assets of $817 million to Chase Manhattan's $87 billion in assets.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: 30 SAID TO DIE IN PERU PRISON RIOT
abstract: Thirty inmates died tonight in a riot at Lurigancho Prison on the outskirts of Lima, an official reported.   Most of the prison's 500 inmates are accused of belonging to the Shining Path movement, a guerrilla organization that has been waging a terrorist campaign for the last five years.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: Oct. 28, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 3 P.M.   Political and Security Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Special Political Committee - 12 noon.   Economic and Financial Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10:30 A.M. Legal Committee - 3 P.M. Council for Namibia - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: DOUBTS ON GASOLINE PRICE CUTS
abstract: When OPEC announced its oil embargo in 1973, the price at the gasoline pumps here quickly followed the steep rise in the cost of crude oil.   But analysts were divided yesterday over whether falling prices for crude, touched off by OPEC's announcement this week that it might engage in a price war, would soon translate into a savings at the pump and for home heating oil.   Some cautioned that dealers and refiners would cling tenaciously to any price break on the spot petroleum and commodities markets before passing it through. Indeed, oil prices recovered somewhat yesterday, creating uncertainty about their ultimate direction. [Page D6.]  No Effect Daniel Lundberg, president of the Lundberg Survey Inc. of North Hollywood, Calif., thinks that changes in the price of crude often have no effect on the price of gasoline at the pump. He plays down the value of formulas showing that a drop of so many dollars in the price of crude automatically results in a decline of so many cents at the pump.

headline: Advertising;   Avenue Magazine Has New Product for 1986
abstract: Judy Price, creator of the highly successful 10-year-old Avenue magazine, which is delivered to the Gotham homes of the elite by Rolls-Royce, is coming up with a new product for the new year that she describes colorfully as the ''yellow pages for blue bloods.''   Actually it is the Avenue 1986 Diary and Directory, whose features include a calendar of New York's very social events, a daily diary with space only for notations during the evening hours, and a directory of important hotels and spas worldwide, each of which includes the name of the general manager.

headline: ALEXANDER'S WILL CLOSE 58TH ST. FLAGSHIP STORE
abstract: Alexander's Inc. said yesterday that it planned to close its flagship store at 58th Street and Lexington Avenue as part of a redevelopment of the blocklong site into what is expected to be an office and condominium complex.   In the past, Alexander's has indicated that it planned to redevelop the site but would keep a smaller store there. Yesterday's announcement did not say when the company would close the store, which, when it was built in 1965, was Manhattan's most expensive in 40 years.   Alexander's said it expected the owners of real estate on the rest of the block to contribute their property to a partnership to redevelop the site. That agreement, expected yesterday, would be submitted to Alexander's board for approval today, the company said.

headline: F.C.C. Approves A.T.&T. Services
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission authorized the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to offer two new long-distance service packages that could reduce costs to big business customers but force local phone service rates higher. Local telephone companies had fought the proposals.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD;Immune System Flaws Are Found at Bhopal
abstract: Many survivors of the Union Carbide pesticide gas leak in Bhopal suffered chromosomal changes and damage to their immune systems, the head of a Government study into the tragedy said today.         S. Ray, director of the Industrial Toxicology Research Center, told the Press Trust of India in Lucknow that his team of 25 scientists heard complaints from the survivors of impotency, menstrual disorders and sleeplessness.

headline: Confusion in West Africa Over Cease-Fire Plans
abstract: Mali and Burkina Faso, which fought a five-day border war, have agreed to cease-fires worked out by two separate parties, and the result today was confusion over which was the operative pact.   The first cease-fire was promoted by Libya and Nigeria and included both these countries in a military observer force.

headline: English Archbishop Defends Report on Cities
abstract: The Archbishop of Canterbury hit back today at critics of a church report on urban problems that questioned Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's economic policies.   The 400-page report, ''Faith in the City,'' was a ''rigorous, informed and objective'' analysis of inner-city troubles, the Archbishop, the Most Rev. Robert Runcie, said at a news conference.

headline: ICAHN SAID TO WEIGH SHIFT IN BID
abstract: Carl C. Icahn and his financial advisers made an intense effort over the weekend to put together from $800 million to $1 billion in financing to enable the New York-based investor to buy out the remaining shareholders of Trans World Airlines, according to sources involved in the effort.   A key part of the effort, the sources said yesterday, was a proposal by Mr. Icahn to restructure the $24-a-share offer he made to stockholders last Aug. 6. The proposal would lower the cash portion of the offer to about $15 a share, from $19.50, while increasing the amount the shareholders would get in preferred stock.   The carrier's board was expected to meet late last night to consider the proposal. It was not known how potential participants in the financing were being approached.

headline: Ad Director Resigns Post at New Yorker
abstract: Robert F. Young, with 25 years -or half of his lifetime - at The New Yorker has resigned from the position of vice president and advertising director. Steven T. Florio, the new publisher, said that negotiations with a potential replacement from the outsidewere nearing completion.   Mr. Young, 50 years old, was ad manager in 1980 when he was promoted to replace William P. Buxton.

headline: IN FRANCE, STORM OVER POLE'S VISIT GOES ON
abstract: An unusual public disagreement between President Francois Mitterrand and his Prime Minister, Laurent Fabius, has created a political storm in France, with many commentators and officials asserting that the Socialist Government is deeply divided.   The disagreement emerged when Mr. Fabius, in what many here characterized as an astonishing gesture for a French Prime Minister, said in the National Assembly that he was ''personally troubled'' that Mr. Mitterrand met here Wednesday with the Polish leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski.   Mr. Fabius's critical remarks on Wednesday seemed highly unusual in a country where the Prime Minister presumably serves at the pleasure of the President. They also added to an impression widely held in this country that the Socialists, facing likely defeat in parliamentary elections in March, have been floundering as they have tried to reverse a decline in popularity.

headline: ARABS PRESS ARAFAT ON U.N. MEASURE
abstract: Yasir Arafat is coming under increasing pressure from politically moderate Arabs to accept a United Nations resolution that calls for recognition of Israel's right to exist. The alternative, he is being told, is to be dropped from the Middle East peace initiative being pressed by King Hussein of Jordan.   For more than a week now, Mr. Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, has been expected in Amman at the invitation of King Hussein, who wants to try again to obtain Mr. Arafat's commitment to the crucial United Nations Resolution 242. The United States has said Mr. Arafat's endorsement of the measure is a step vital to the success of peace negotiations.

headline: First Chicago's Stake in Brazil
abstract: The First Chicago Corporation said today that the Federal Reserve Board had approved the request of the First Chicago International Finance Corporation to make a capital investment in Banco Denasa de Investimento S.A., a Brazilian bank in which First Chicago has held a minority interest.   The infusion of capital will raise First Chicago's stake in Banco Denasa from 44.5 percent to about 98 percent. Last July, First Chicago announced that it had established a special pretax reserve of $115 million to cover the impact of Banco Denasa's troubled loan portfolio on the Chicago company's earnings.

headline: Farm Credit Bill Discussed
abstract: The Reagan Administration renewed its opposition today to an immediate Federal bailout of the Farm Credit System, but welcomed parts of a House bill to reorganize the nation's largest farm lender.   Officials of the Treasury and Agriculture Departments reaffirmed the Administration's position that changes in the system must be carried out before any Federal rescue money can be considered.

headline: S.E.C. CITES KIDDER, PEABODY
abstract: Kidder, Peabody & Company mishandled ''at least $145 million of its customers' fully paid-for securities,'' according to an administrative complaint issued yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission.   The regulatory agency said the 120-year-old firm used $90 million of the securities to make repurchase agreements and $55 million as collateral for bank loans between late 1983 and late 1984. In effect, repurchase agreements are the pawning of securities for brief periods as a means of raising cash. Rules prohibit a brokerage firm from using paid-for securities for its own use unless the customers agree.

headline: 7.9% G.M. LOAN RATE EXPECTED
abstract: The General Motors Corporation will offer a 7.9 percent interest rate later this week as an incentive to increase flagging car sales, auto industry sources reported today.   Several G.M. dealers said the incentives, to be announced Thursday, would be offered on about half the automobile giant's product line, including the Chevrolet Nova, the product of G.M.'s venture with the Toyota Motor Corporation. The program is expected to extend through February.   If there was any surprise in the G.M. plan, it was the attention the incentive campaign will draw to the slow-selling Nova, a key part of G.M.'s effort to hold on to part of the small-car market through various alliances with Japanese car makers.

headline: Dallas Offering School Bonds
abstract: The Dallas Independent School District is offering $153.8 million of unlimited tax bonds to refund outstanding debt. Underwriters are led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.      The bonds, rated Aaa by   Moody's and AA+ by Standard & Poor's, were offered with yields from 6.75 percent for bonds due in 1990 to 7.75 percent in 1995 and 8 percent in 1998.

headline: LTV Agrees To Sell Mill
abstract: The LTV Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell a steel mill in Alabama formerly owned by the Republic Steel Corporation to the mill's employees.   Terms of the sale, which will take the form of an employee stock ownership plan, were not disclosed.

headline: RAGEN AND 'THE OTHER GUY'
abstract: The phone rang and rang yesterday in Room 928 of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.   First a woman called offering gifts from the Government of Sri Lanka. She was politely turned down. Then a group of French business officials called to arrange a meeting. They were told that would be impossible. Several other callers, with incomprehensible accents and unfamiliar nationalities, were also turned away.

headline: BANK MONEY ACCOUNTS AND C.D.'S GAIN A BIT
abstract: Rates on certificates of deposit and money market accounts made minor advances for the week ended yesterday, while money market mutual funds moved slightly lower for the second week.   According to The Bank Rate Monitor's national index, the average yield on a bank money market account stands at 6.91 percent, up one one-hundredths of a percentage point from 6.90 percent last week. The average yield on a six-month C.D. climbed four one-hundredths of a percentage point, to 7.73 percent, the highest since June 12, when it was 7.72 percent. Yield figures in the index are based on rates available for the lowest minimum deposits at institutions.

headline: A Spinoff Challenge At Allied-Signal
abstract: To some analysts, it looked as if Michael D. Dingman, the 54-year-old president of Allied-Signal Inc., was taking a fall when Edward L. Hennessy Jr., Allied's chairman and chief executive, announced on Wednesday that the company was spinning off 30 subsidiary operations into a separate company that Mr. Dingman would run.   Mr. Dingman, the former president of the Signal Companies, was promised by the board when Signal merged with Allied earlier this year that he would inherit Mr. Hennessy's job in 1991, when Mr. Hennessy is scheduled to retire.   But in a telephone interview yesterday from San Diego, Mr. Dingman was not talking like a man who had been slapped in the face.

headline: Sudan Says Rebels Kill 14 Despite a Cease-Fire
abstract: Southern Sudanese rebels attacked a Nile steamer despite a cease-fire, killing 14 soldiers, Defense Minister Osman Abdallah Mohammed said today.   One civilian was wounded in the attack on Saturday and five people were missing, the official Sudanese press agency quoted the minister as saying.

headline: SEA-LAND REJECTS SIMMONS OFFER OF $25 A SHARE
abstract: The Sea-Land Corporation said yesterday that it had rejected as ''inadequate'' an unsolicited $25-a-share takeover bid by Harold C. Simmons, a Dallas investor.   But Sea-Land's chairman and chief executive officer, Joseph F. Abely Jr., agreed to meet with Mr. Simmons next Tuesday to discuss the offer and Sea-Land's response, according to J. Landis Martin, a lawyer for Mr. Simmons.   The shipping concern's board also said that it had authorized its management and its financial adviser, Dillon, Read & Company, ''to explore all available alternatives to maximize value to the company's shareholders.''

headline: Daily for Sale In Los Angeles
abstract: The owners of The San Francisco Chronicle are among those trying to buy The Daily News of Los Angeles, the newspaper reported today.      Other contenders, it said, are   Jack Kent Cooke, who owns the Washington Redskins football team; the A. H. Belo Corporation, which publishes The Dallas Morning News and owns television stations, and the Ingersoll Publications Company, a Connecticut-based publisher of daily and weekly papers.

headline: SCM AND MERRIL WIN ROUND
abstract: A Federal judge in Manhattan yesterday refused to prevent Merrill Lynch Capital Markets from exercising an option to buy two key businesses from the SCM Corporation as part of a larger plan to buy the entire company.   Under an agreement reached late yesterday between Merrill Lynch and Hanson Trust P.L.C., which is also attempting to buy SCM, however, the status quo will be maintained until the big British conglomerate's appeal has been heard. The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in New York set a hearing in the case before a three-judge panel for Dec. 16.   The long-awaited ruling is expected to give considerable comfort to corporate directors attempting to fight off unwanted takeovers. Directors had been concerned after a Delaware Chancery Court judge ruled that Revlon directors breached their fiduciary duty by giving a friendly suitor the right to buy two key operations.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    * Banque Francaise du Commerce Exterieur is issuing $270 million of floating-rate notes, through underwriters led by Societe Generale. Interest is set at four-hundredths of a percentage point over the three-month London interbank offered rate.    * Gulf States Utilities Co. has filed for up to $100 million of first mortgage bonds.

headline: Dunes Hotels Unit In Chapter 11
abstract: The major subsidiary of Dunes Hotels and Casinos of Las Vegas, Nev., filed under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws after a bank sought to have a receiver appointed for the resort over its default on a loan.

headline: ECONOMY GIVES ALTERNATING SIGNALS
abstract: The economy rebounded smartly during the third quarter, and there are no signs that the nearly four-year-old expansion is about to expire, statistics to be published this week are expected to show.   Based on early reports - particularly of lower-than-expected imports the past few months and a burst of activity in automobile showrooms brought on by special, low-interest-rate financing - analysts expect that figures to be released Thursday will show that the gross national product expanded at an annualized rate of about 3 1/2 percent in the three months ended with September, after excluding inflation.   But alternating signals in the past few months of strength and weakness in the economy have helped to cause more than the usual amount of debate about the future.   Many analysts doubt that the third-quarter growth will be sustained unless interest rates come down, and they see an economy that is not much stronger than the first half of this year, when G.N.P. grew at a meager 1 percent rate.

headline: TRAFALGAR BID FOR MINEBEA
abstract: Trafalgar Holdings Ltd. and the Glen International Financial Service Company, a London-based securities and investment company, formally announced a bid today to acquire the Minebea Company, a Japanese manufacturer of miniature ball bearings and electronic parts.   If successful, it would become the first unfriendly takeover of a Japanese company by an American one.

headline: Turner Outlines MGM/UA Plans
abstract: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. says a joint film-distribution venture between Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and United Artists studios is planned, even after the companies are split.   Turner Broadcasting, headed by Ted Turner, is offering about $1.46 billion in cash and stock for the MGM/ UA Entertainment Company but would immediately sell the company's United Artists subsidiary back to the financier Kirk Kerkorian for $470 million cash. In a Securities and Exchange Commission registration of debt securities to finance the deal, Turner Broadcasting said MGM and UA would continue to work closely together on feature-film distribution even after the split.

headline: THE QUESTION IS 'HOW?'
abstract: Hondurans are preparing to choose a new President, but with elections only two weeks away a debate over exactly what voting method to use has thrown the process in doubt.   In light of a long record of brokered political deals and military coups, the infighting is beginning to lead Honduran and foreign political analysts to consider the interesting possibility that Honduras may hold presidential elections, but may not wind up with a President, at least not immediately.   The period leading up to the election has been marked by unusual intrigue and slander, according to several Honduran and foreign political experts.
