The chicanery has been such that the Archbishop of Honduras, Hector Enrique Santos, gave a sermon last week in which he denounced the country's politicians en masse.

headline: GORBACHEV, BACK HOME, IS GREETED BY OPTIMISM
abstract: As Mikhail S. Gorbachev returned to Moscow today, there was a palpable sense of optimism among many Russians over his meetings with President Reagan.   Many Muscovites said they had a more favorable impression of President Reagan after seeing him on television this week and hearing the remarks he made Thursday at a joint appearance with Mr. Gorbachev.   Whether Soviet authorities intended it or not, Western diplomats here said, the extensive television coverage seemed to have produced at least a momentary change in public opinion about Mr. Reagan.   Western news organizations that took informal samplings of public opinion today found similar responses among dozens of Muscovites questioned. Typical was the response of a metalworker who said, ''Now that I have seen Reagan, I think he is a man who wants peace.''

headline: Treasury Sales Reduced by Holiday
abstract: The Treasury will auction $15.2 billion of three- and six-month bills today. Aside from the Treasury's regular weekly bill sales, the list of new fixed-income securities offerings will be shortened by the Christmas holiday on Wednesday.   Topping the list of taxable offerings scheduled for sale one day this week is $200 million of money market notes in two series that will be offered for the National Rural Utilities Cooperative Finance Corporation through an underwriting group headed by Shearson Lehman Brothers. Another major issue due one day this week is $150 million of Bally Manufacturing Corporation's 25-year subordinated debentures that will be brought to market by a group led by Drexel Burnham Lambert.

headline: HEAVY PRESSURE PULLED MALTA BOTH WAYS
abstract: Malta's decision to allow Egyptian troops to storm a hijacked airliner was made under heavy diplomatic and political pressure, some of which militated against the operation, according to Maltese officials, diplomats and others familiar with the episode.   The decision to allow the assault, in which 57 lives were lost, was described as especially difficult for Malta because of its financial and political ties to its close neighbor, Libya.   To the country's dismay, Malta found itself caught in the sharp, longstanding dispute between Egypt and Libya. At the same time, Maltese officials appeared concerned with establishing a clear record of toughness against terrorism, partly to offset a belief among some Western nations that it had been lax in the past.   The full details of the reasoning behind Malta's decision and the pressures it came under are still not known. But statements by Maltese officials and interviews with the diplomats and others familiar with the decisions made during the ordeal demonstrate the difficulties that were faced by this tiny archipelago in the Mediterranean.

headline: REVLON INC. AGREES TO PAY FORSTMANN
abstract: Forstmann Little & Company, the New York investment firm, said yesterday that Revlon Inc. would pay it $20 million in cash to settle a dispute arising from Forstmann's losing battle with Pantry Pride Inc. to take over the cosmetics and health care company.   Forstmann Little said that in return for the payment it would drop its claim to an option to purchase two Revlon divisions as part of a deal it had struck to buy the entire company.

headline: Stone Plans to Buy Parts of Champion
abstract: The Stone Container Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy most of the Champion International Corporation's packaging business for about $457 million.   Stone, based in Chicago, will acquire 3 container board mills, 39 corrugated container plants, 9 multiwall shipping sack plants and 4 specialty bag and packaging plants.

headline: Big Chance For Media Promoters
abstract: What would heaven on earth be for a peddler from the media?   How about getting the chance to pitch to a group representing advertisers whose total annual media spending is well over $10 billion? Do you hear those angels singing?   Just such an opportunity fell into the laps of some top people from the advertising promotion associations of magazines, radio, newspapers and television today, as the the Association of National Advertisers ended its three-day annual meeting at the Boca Raton Hotel and Club.   The theme for the session was ''Creativity: How It Looks and Sounds,'' which meant that none of the participants slipped in any competitive needles, nor did they get bogged down in the statistics that sometimes fill such presentations.

headline: Patents;  Furnace Tests Metal In Space
abstract: A FURNACE to be used in space shuttles to conduct metallurgical experiments that are only possible in zero gravity was patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.  The special information gained may be useful not only to NASA but to private industry.

headline: EAST-WEST TIES 'ENCOURAGING,' NATO SAYS
abstract: The NATO allies, in a communique at the end of their two-day winter meeting here, said today that they were encouraged by recent East-West developments.   The allies said they hoped the recent American-Soviet summit meeting and those planned for the future ''will lead to improved relations'' and to ''broad cooperation on the full range of East-West questions.''   In one of the most conciliatory final communiques issued by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in years, criticism of the Russians was muted, amid expectations expressed by several allies of possible progress on arms control issues in coming months.   Secretary of State George P. Shultz cautioned, however, that these expectations should not push the United States into questionable accords.

headline: THE SELLING OF CARS TO WOMEN
abstract: Ford has tried wine and cheese parties. Chevrolet established a special marketing committee and advertising strategy. A Toyota dealer in California set up a special office to handle inquiries and complaints. All to draw women into their showrooms to buy their cars.   While cars have long been one of the rites of passage for the American male, they are now playing a larger role in women's lives, too. As auto companies - both domestic and imported - have increasingly recognized in the last few years, the economic power of working women and their influence on the majority of car-buying decisions has surged.

headline: Bethlehem Steel Pricing Decision
abstract: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation has revised prices on its steel plate, following the lead of the United States Steel Corporation.

headline: Thousands Attend Funeral Of West German Anti-Fascist
abstract: Thousands of people, some raising clenched fists in salute, attended the funeral today of an anti-fascist protester whose death touched off violence, arson and bombings in 16 cities.   ''Gunther Sare was a man who could love and who could hate,'' Lothar Helm, a clergyman, told mourners who crowded into the chapel at Hochst cemetery here.

headline: PANEL VOTES A STIFFER MINIMUM TAX
abstract: The House Ways and Means Committee tonight approved a stiff minimum tax on wealthy people and profitable corporations.   The measure would prevent many individuals and companies from taking advantage of tax breaks to trim their tax liability to little or nothing. It would also raise billions of dollars more than President Reagan's minimum tax plan.   The committee then began debating limits on deductions for business meals and entertainment, one of the few thorny issues remaining.

headline: Peru's Main Prison Rocked By a Second Day of Violence
abstract: About 6,000 inmates rioted at Peru's biggest prison today, one day after 30 people died and at least 69 were wounded in a mutiny by jailed guerrillas, the police said.

headline: SLIM CHANCE SEEN FOR ARMS AGENDA AT SUMMIT TALKS
abstract: Reagan Administration officials said today that there was an outside possibility that the meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev might produce an agreement on guidelines to provide impetus to the arms control  negotiations. But they stressed there was only a slim chance of this.         With Mr. Reagan scheduled to leave on Saturday for the meetings in Geneva on  Nov. 19 and 20, the officials, in separate discussions, said that because of the wide gap between the United States and the Soviet Union, it was unrealistic in the week remaining to expect major agreements to emerge.

headline: IN QUOTES
abstract: ''For Texaco it's like sleeping with the sword of Damocles over you.'' Rosario Ilacqua, L. F. Rothschild analyst, on uncertainty at Texaco.

headline: Emilio Medici, a Brazil Leader
abstract: Gen. Emilio Garrastazu Medici, President of Brazil from 1969 to 1974, died today in a hospital after being ill for months, doctors said. He was 79 years old.

headline: Rise Forecast In Air Fares
abstract: World airlines, which posted their first collective profit in six years in 1984, still face a financial struggle and fares will probably go up, the International Air Transport Association said today.   The annual report for I.A.T.A., which has 140 members and dominates commercial air traffic, said: ''There is a long way to go before the industry collectively reaches levels of return adequate to finance future development.''

headline: Cuban Sugar-Cane Fields Hurt by Hurricane
abstract: Nearly 2.5 million acres of sugar cane were damaged by Hurricane Kate, which whipped across Cuba on Tuesday and Wednesday with winds of more than 100 miles per hour, the official Communist Party newspaper Granma reported today.   The damaged areas, in 7 of Cuba's 14 provinces, amount to about a quarter of Cuba's cultivated land.

headline: Money Fund Assets Up
abstract: Reversing a three-week decline, assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose $888.3 million, to $209.59 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Leading the upward turn, assets of the 73 institutional funds rose $1.47 billion, to $54.30 billion. But assets of the 192 general purpose funds fell $140.2 million, to $61.63 billion, and the 87 broker-dealer funds dropped $443.2 million, to $93.65 billion.

headline: Advertising;   CBS Magazines Restructures at Top
abstract: CBS Magazines yesterday announced a restructuring that follows the early retirement of three top executives and results in the mutually agreed upon resignation of a fourth.   Thomas M. Kenney, 38 years old, an executive vice president, is leaving the company.

headline: 17 Reported Killed In Sri Lanka Violence
abstract: At least 17 people, including 11 Tamil separatist guerrillas, were killed in ethnic violence in Sri Lanka's Northern and Eastern provinces over the weekend, security sources said today.   Seven guerrillas were killed and 32 were captured Friday when troops raided a rebel hideout at Amparai in the east, they said.

headline: Iraq Says Iran Plans 'Human Wave' Offensive
abstract: Iraq's Defense Minister said today that Iran was preparing a ''human wave'' offensive in an attempt to gain ground in the Persian Gulf war.

headline: Advertising;   Traveler Cuts Base
abstract: National Geographic Traveler, a quarterly introduced in March 1984, will cut its circulation rate base next year to 850,000 from 1 million, which it went to from 600,000 in September 1984. Although the publiction is cutting its base 15 percent, it will cut its rates only 8.6 percent.

headline: Advertising;   Air Canada Picks Young & Rubicam
abstract: Young & Rubicam has been appointed the international agency for Air Canada in Britain, Europe, India, the Far East and Australia.

headline: A Busy Initiation For Itel President
abstract: Rod Dammeyer joined the Itel Corporation as president and chief operating officer only two weeks ago, but he has already negotiated a deal the company had been mulling for months: the acquisition of Great Lakes International Inc., the nation's largest dredging and harbor improvement concern.   Itel, which leases transportation containers, had acquired 27.2 percent of Great Lakes' shares over the last six months, but Great Lakes, which is based in the Chicago suburb of Oak Brook, Ill., resisted its advances and adopted a ''poison pill'' anti-takeover plan.   Early last week, Great Lakes refused to join merger discussions, and last Friday it termed Itel's first formal offer of $60 a share ''unsolicited,'' saying only that it would review it. But, after a weekend of negotiations in which Itel raised its bid to $62.50, or about $129.7 million, Great Lakes gave in.

headline: DAPPER TEXAS JUDGE FOR A HISTORIC CASE
abstract: Until Tuesday, when he affirmed the largest civil damages award in American history, Solomon J. Casseb Jr. was not known in Texas legal circles for any particular ruling from the bench.   Instead, Judge Casseb (pronounced KAH-seb) was considered a workaday jurist who, during his eight years sitting full time in State District Court here in the 1960's, improved court decorum and changed the docket system to speed cases to trial. He was also known as a flashy dresser.   ''He was just a well-grounded, well-educated trial judge with a flamboyant appearance, who believed in working hard and taking on his share of heavy-duty cases,'' said State District Judge James E. Barlow, who sat in the same courthouse with Judge Casseb for five years.

headline: U.S. CANDY MAKERS STRUGGLING
abstract: Americans ate more sweets last year than they had in any year of the past decade, but domestic candy makers still have a slightly sour taste in their mouths these days.   From West German lollipops and Dutch candy canes to Brazilian mints and Canadian chocolate chips, cheaper, imported candies and baking confections have carved out a small but rapidly growing market in America.   The imports, which have nearly tripled in volume in the last five years, have yet to dent the growing sales of industry giants such as the Hershey Chocolate Company and M&M/ Mars, which sell brand-name candy bars and confections.   But smaller manufacturers in the $10 billion industry who sell bulk candy that competes directly with cheaper imports say they have already been hurt. Some have laid off workers, moved operations overseas and abandoned unprofitable products. Others may soon join them.

headline: TREASURY BOND YIELDS DOWN
abstract: Treasury bond yields fell to the lowest level of the year yesterday, causing credit market participants to take more seriously the possibility that bellwether 30-year Treasury bond yields might soon fall to 10 percent for the first time since mid-1980.   ''It's not just fluff,'' said a Treasury bond trader at one of the largest securities firms in New York. ''Over the past five or six days we have had the heaviest flow of business ever,'' he said, adding that the strong investor demand at last week's Treasury note and bond auctions has not disappeared.   By late in the day the 10 5/8 percent Treasury bonds, due in 2015, a bellwether issue for the long-term bond market, were offered at 104 10/32, up 3/8 point, to yield 10.16 percent. As recently as Oct. 28, the closely followed 30-year issue was offered at about 101, to yield 10.51 percent.

headline: KOREAN DISSIDENT GOES HOME TO UNSEEN SHACKLES
abstract: Nearly eight months after returning from exile in the United States, Kim Dae Jung has yet to make it all the way back home.   Mr. Kim, probably South Korea's best-known dissident, has regained an unofficial leadership role in the political opposition, as he had expected. However, restraints imposed by the Government and his own sense of caution have kept him from fully finding his niche.   He is, above all, a politician, but he is forbidden to join an organized political party. He is a gifted stump speaker, but he avoids delivering public speeches out of fear of annoying the Government. He is, technically, a free man, but that does not keep him from being placed under occasional house arrest.

headline: Suzuki to Ship Vehicle to U.S.
abstract: The four-wheel-drive Samurai, a jeep-like utility vehicle developed 17 years ago for the third world, will be introduced in the United States by the Suzuki Motor Car Company of Japan.

headline: OPEC Official Says Pricing to End
abstract: The oil minister of the United Arab Emirates, Mani Said al-Otaiba, said yesterday that each member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is free to sell its oil at any price it chooses, according to a Reuters report from Abu Dhabi.   But an OPEC spokesman in Vienna, Gonzalo Plaza, said that ''as far as I know'' there has been no agreement to allow OPEC members to set their own prices.   John H. Lichtblau, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, said that oil prices had essentially been set by market forces for some time. He said that the only real control OPEC has been exercising recently has been on production, and he pointed out that Sheik Otaiba apparently had made no reference to OPEC's production quotas.

headline: Shad Dubious Of Fed Plan
abstract: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission said today that the restrictions proposed by the Federal Reserve Board on using so-called junk bonds for financing hostile takeover would have little impact.   Speaking to the National Press Club, John S. R. Shad said, ''We've been told that the market would find a number of ways to get around the Fed's proposal.''

headline: Illinois Bonds Yield Up to 8 7/8%
abstract: A $90 million issue of Cook County, Ill., general obligation bonds was offered yesterday with yields ranging from 5.40 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 7.10 percent in 1990, 8.30 percent in 1995 and 8 7/8 percent in 1999 through underwriters led by the First National Bank of Chicago.   The high-grade bonds, rated Aa by Moody's, are offered only in book-entry form, with no printed certificates available to investors.

headline: DAIMLER RACES INTO HIGH TECH
abstract: TWO years ago, when Werner Breitschwerdt took over the chairmanship at Daimler-Benz, he had each of the company's management board members write a strategy paper for Daimler's growth into the next century. Then, in a closed session, the papers were distilled into a master blueprint.   The contents of the document have never been disclosed publicly, but these days the company's strategy is anything but a secret.   As it approaches its 100th year, Daimler-Benz, flush with cash from the success of its Mercedes-Benz line, has been racing into high technology with three major acquisitions.   Daimler is counting on its new affliates to give its famous Mercedes-Benz car a sharper edge in state-of-the-art equipment. And it hopes to offset the expected slow growth in luxury cars and its troubles in truck sales with profits from two new areas - the electronics and aerospace industries.

headline: Trade Surplus Gains in Japan
abstract: Japan's trade surplus has jumped more than 25 percent, to nearly $30 billion in the first half of this financial year, as the yen continues to strengthen, according to official figures released today.   The country's trade surplus was $29.26 billion for the six months up to Sept. 30.

headline: MCI-I.B.M. Pact
abstract: The MCI Communications Corporation said it had signed a definitive agreement with the International Business Machines Corporation for the previously announced purchase of I.B.M.'s Satellite Business Systems unit. Under the agreement, I.B.M. will sell the unit and make $400 million in investments in MCI between Sept. 1, 1986, and Dec. 31, 1988, in return for 46.7 million MCI shares, or 16.6 percent of the company's outstanding stock.

headline: REGULATOR CONTINUING EXTRA FEE
abstract: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board will continue an extra $1 billion-a-year assessment on the thrift industry for the next three to five years, a senior bank board official said today.   The assessment will be used to bolster the bank board's deposit insurance fund, the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, which insures thrift institution deposits for up to $100,000.   At the annual gathering of the United States League of Savings Institutions, Donald I. Hovde, one official of the three-member bank board, said in a news conference that the agency would continue to require the payments from the 3,500 federally insured thrift institutions ''at least for three years, and maybe for five.''

headline: SINAI FORCE HALTS USE OF AIRLINE
abstract: The international peacekeeping force that is deployed in Sinai will not use Arrow Air for a coming scheduled flight of American troops, a State Department official said today.   The decision was made by the force, which is formerly known as the Multinational Force and Observers, after the crash of an Arrow Air plane in Canada that killed 248 American troops on their way home from their peacekeeping mission in Sinai.

headline: Iraq Says Its Warplanes Had Busy Day Over Iran
abstract: Iraq said its planes flew 120 sorties against Iranian positions on the south-central war front today amid reports from both sides that Iran was preparing to mount a new ground offensive.

headline: 4 KILLED IN BLAST AT AN ITALIAN OIL DEPOT
abstract: An explosion ripped through a petroleum storage depot in this port city early today, killing at least 4 people, injuring more than 160, forcing the evacuation of as many as 2,000 residents and touching off an oil-fed fire that raged into the night.   About 700 to 800 firefighters were called in from throughout south-central Italy to fight the blaze, and air tanker planes dumped fire-retardant foam on the fire, according to Renato Profili, a spokesman for the Naples city government.   The Italian Minister of Civil Protection, Giuseppe Zamberletti, declared a state of emergency in the area, where the fire kept blazing in two dozen storage tanks more than 12 hours after the predawn explosion at an oil installation of the state-owned company AGIP.   Thick columns of choking black smoke darkened the sky for 20 square miles over the Bay of Naples.

headline: Wertheim Hires RCA Executive
abstract: Herbert S. Schlosser, an executive vice president at the RCA Corporation and a former president and chief executive of the National Broadcasting Company, will become a senior adviser at Wertheim & Company, the Wall Street investment banking firm, at the start of next year, according to an announcement by James A. Harmon, vice chairman of Wertheim.   Mr. Schlosser, who is 59, intends to retire from RCA at the end of the year, ending an association with the company that spans nearly 30 years.   ''I have been planning to do this for some time,'' Mr. Schlosser said in an interview. ''I guess I don't have to retire right now, but I figure that if I am going to have an active business life after I leave here, then I had better do it now.''

headline: Data Bank; December 29, 1985
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: REAGAN NOMINATES 2 FOR FED
abstract: The White House tonight announced the nomination of two new members of the Federal Reserve Board: Wayne D. Angell, a Kansas professor, banker and farmer, and Manuel H. Johnson Jr. of the Treasury Department.   In making the appointments, which are subject to Senate confirmation, President Reagan has filled a majority of the seats on the seven-member panel and thus will probably leave an imprint on monetary policy that will endure long after he leaves office. A full term on the board is 14 years.   Mr. Johnson, now Assistant Secretary of Treasury for Economic Policy, is a supply-sider known to favor expanding the monetary supply to stimulate economic growth. Mr. Johnson, 36 years old, was previously an associate professor of economics at George Mason University in Fairfax, Va.

headline: TWISTS AT THE SUMMIT: INSIDE THE GENEVA TALKS
abstract: In the predawn hours before President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev left Geneva on Thursday, American officials grew concerned about the outcome of the summit meeting and devised a ''blow-up scenario'' to limit political damage in case the meeting collapsed at the final ceremony.   ''We had a nightmare vision with world headlines saying, 'Summit Breaks Up Over 'Star Wars,' '' an American official said.   The specter of a collapse - and the resolution of this last-minute hitch with the agreement on a joint statement -were among accounts of the summit meeting pieced together from descriptions provided by officials of the White House, the State Department and the Pentagon who had been close to the negotiating sessions and the leaders' private talks.   The President described the private talks to Secretary of State George P. Shultz, Robert C. McFarlane, his national security adviser, and Donald T. Regan, his chief of staff. Details were provided to other officials, and their descriptions were used to reconstruct these episodes.

headline: Prices in Sweden Rise
abstract: Swedish producer prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent in September from August and were up 4.2 percent from a year earlier, the Government said today. Statistics Sweden said producer prices for engineering products, nonferrous metals and food products rose sharply in September, while prices for commercial steel and petroleum and coal products dropped.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Last weekend, when the Toronto Blue Jays beat the Yankees to clinch the Eastern Division of the American League, it was as if Canada's biggest city had come of age. For Torontoans, the baseball team's successes in two of the first three playoff games against the Kansas City Royals has only heightened the sensation.   ''It wasn't just that the Blue Jays had achieved the improbable,'' said Trent Frayne, who writes a sports column for The Globe and Mail. ''It was also that they'd beat the Yankees to do it, the damn Yankees, a team that has become a legend in America's game, a game that each year becomes a little more Canadian too.''

headline: T.W.A. Studies New Icahn Bid
abstract: The board of Trans World Airlines will consider a revised acquisition offer from Carl C. Icahn, the New York investor, in the next few days, sources involved in the offer said yesterday. The bid provides less cash per share and more preferred stock, but will still be valued at $24 a share.

headline: Inflation Rises in Chile
abstract: Chile's cost of living rose 1.2 percent in September, putting prices up 21 percent since Jan. 1, the Government said today. It said that in 1984, the cost of living held steady in September and that prices for the year at that point were up 11.5 percent.

headline: VOODOO POLITICS TAKES CENTER STAGE
abstract: AS a Representative in 1981, Phil Gramm played a major role in developing the economic program of tax cuts and enhanced military spending that President Reagan promised would automatically produce higher revenues and a balanced budget. We would ''grow our way'' out of the deficit, they said.   As a Republican Senator from Texas in 1985, and with a projected Federal deficit of over $200 billion, Mr. Gramm has conceived a new quick fix: A plan of automatic spending cuts to balance the budget by 1991. President Reagan, his Laffer Curve gone flat, has given this latest nonsense nostrum - Gramm-Rudman-Hollings - the White House seal of approval.

headline: HOW THE BIG SIX STEER THE ECONOMY
abstract: AROUND 10 A.M. on Tuesday, Sept. 24, the currency markets were acting up, and Richard G. Darman, Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, was shown a snippet from the Treasury's news ticker. The item quoted the Secretary of Commerce, Malcolm Baldrige, doubting that the United States and other countries would intervene strongly in the currency markets to reduce the exchange rate of the dollar.   Mr. Darman got his boss, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d, out of a meeting, and Mr. Baker telephoned Mr. Baldrige. According to people familiar with the incident, Mr. Baker told Mr. Baldrige that he had stepped out of bounds. Just two days before, at the Plaza Hotel in New York, Mr. Baker had announced an American-led five-nation agreement to knock down the dollar. But Mr. Baldrige, in theory one of the Administration's top economic policy makers, had not been included in the planning and misread the announcement. ''He didn't know,'' said a senior Administration official.

headline: HARLEY-DAVIDSON ROARS BACK
abstract: The Hell's Angels motorcycle club and the California Highway Patrol seldom have much in common, but they could chat about their mutual admiration for recent models of Harley-Davidson motorcycles.   ''It's amazing, the difference,'' Michael (Irish) O'Farrell, president of the Hell's Angels chapter in Oakland, Calif., said of the latest models. ''They don't beat you to death any more, and your kidneys are still intact.''   Mr. O'Farrell is delighted with his 1985 Harley, and expects the Hell's Angels will continue to require all members to have Harleys rather than Japanese-made bikes. For one thing, he said, the club prefers to buy American. Likewise, the California Highway Patrol is buying Harleys again, after a 10-year period in which it purchased Kawasakis and Suzukis.

headline: IN THE WESTERN PACIFIC, AN EVER-WARY WATCH
abstract: As they maneuver their navies in a widening competition for dominance in the Pacific, the Russians and Americans keep a constant wary eye on each other's movements.   Here aboard the flagship of the Seventh Fleet, an amphibious command ship crowned by a flamboyant tiara of antennae, satellite receiving dishes and radar, an intelligence officer pointed on a map to the precise locations this morning of elements of the Soviet Pacific Fleet.   For example, in Cam Ranh Bay, the former American base in Vietnam that has become the hub of Soviet operations in Southeast Asia, 24 vessels are docked today, including two submarines, a guided-missile cruiser and four light frigates.   On the base's runways, from which American planes once took off for bombing runs over North Vietnam, satellites today detected what the intelligence officer said were ''more than a half dozen'' long-range Bear surveillance and antisubmarine aircraft, a dozen Badger bombers and several swing-wing MIG-23 supersonic interceptors.

headline: COMPUTERS RESHAPE MARKETS
abstract: A Wall Street lunch, five years from now, may consist of soup, steak, a 5,000-share trade and dessert, in that order.   ''If the name of a security comes up, it'll be commonplace for someone to reach into his pocket and pull out a device that gives the security's current price and relates it to other data,'' said Gordon S. Macklin, the president of the National Association of Securities Dealers. ''And then you'll be able to use the device to put in an order.''   That is but one vision of the future of financial information where electronic communication of data will increasingly call the shots. What is dawning, say experts, is a new generation of financial interchange stemming not just from the instant awareness of information but from the ability to act upon data by trading through a computer.

headline: U.S. Says Two Ships Joined Moscow's Fleet in the Pacific
abstract: A 28,000-ton Soviet cruiser and a 7,900-ton destroyer are heading into the South China Sea from the Indian Ocean, apparently the first ships of their class to join the Soviet Pacific Fleet, a United States Navy spokesman said today.

headline: 2D-HOME DEDUCTION IS BACKED
abstract: A working group of members of the House Ways and Means Committee, rejecting President Reagan's proposal, voted today to permit taxpayers to deduct all their interest payments on mortgages on second homes.   The six-member bipartisan group also rejected another proposal by the President that would limit deductions by real estate investors to the amount of money they actually invest and the amount of mortgages they are personally required to repay.   The group's recommendations are likely to be adopted by the full Ways and Means Committee Tuesday and incorporated in the tax legislation it hopes to send to the floor of the House of Representatives for a vote next month. So far the committee has accepted the recommendations of its working groups without change.

headline: TEXACO BATTLE: A CRITICAL JUNCTURE
abstract: Having signaled in a Federal District Court on Friday that they are negotiating a settlement of their high-stakes legal and financial battle, Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company find themselves at a critical juncture of the nearly two-year-old case.   After months of wrangling in the courts over Texaco's disputed $10.1 billion purchase of the Getty Oil Company in 1984 and weeks of exchanging emotional charges and countercharges in the news media, the two companies agreed on Friday to a limited legal truce and a news blackout intended to aid them in pursuing settlement talks.   The recent public posturing and legal maneuvering that often seemed more like a somewhat implausible episode of ''Dallas'' than real life now appear to be giving way to a quieter, if no less important, phase of the tangled case.   The talks are expected to be complex and arduous. While the form of any settlement being discussed now is not known, it is widely believed that Texaco will offer Pennzoil certain oil properties. Pennzoil has also indicated that it would like to avoid paying taxes on the transaction.

headline: COMPLEX PROJECT ENDING AT BANK'S FIFTH AVE. SITE
abstract: The anticipated completion next month of the Fifth Avenue headquarters of the Republic National Bank of New York will bring to a close one of midtown Manhattan's most complex building projects.   Under construction for nearly five years, the project at 452 Fifth Avenue, between 39th and 40th Streets, includes the largest building to rise on Fifth Avenue south of 42d Street since the Empire State Building went up more than 50 years ago. The Republic National project has involved construction of the new glass tower, the retrofitting of other structures and a delicate restoration and reconstuction of a landmark building.   ''It has been a struggle for all involved but well worth the effort,'' said Walter H. Weiner, president of the Republic National Bank, speaking from his office on the ninth floor of the new tower. ''We are more than pleased with the results.''

headline: CHINA FREES AMERICAN IN HOTEL FIRE CASE
abstract: An American businessman was freed today after serving five months of an 18-month prison term for purportedly causing a hotel fire that killed 10 people in Harbin last April.   The American, Richard S. Ondrik, 34 years old, said in a telephone interview after his release in the Manchurian city that he was told this morning he would be released.   He said he had been told that he was being freed because he had ''gone through re-education, followed prison discipline and been a good boy.''

headline: STOCK AVERAGE SOARS BY 27.52 TO RECORD CLOSE
abstract: The stock market yesterday recorded its best one-day gain in 10 months as investors bought up shares, drawing confidence from lower interest rates. Most major indicators advanced sharply into record territory.   Detractors of Wall Street's recent rally apparently conceded defeat, and the result was the best advance in blue-chip issues since Jan. 21 and a startling jump by broader market indexes.   The Dow Jones industrial average soared 27.52 points, to a record 1,431.88, despite the absence of many large investors because of the Veterans Day holiday. The average, which crossed the 1,400 mark for the first time last Wednesday, has set a record in six of the last nine sessions. More than half of its gain yesterday came in the final hour as investors engaged in what traders described as frenzied activity.

headline: SOVIET AIRLINER REPORTEDLY HIJACKED TO CHINA
abstract: Chinese officials said today that a Soviet jetliner with about 50 people aboard was hijacked to China over the weekend. There was no word on whether the plane was still in the country or on the fate of the passengers.   The aircraft was reported to have landed at Hailar, a city of about 100,000 people in Inner Mongolia about 70 miles from the Soviet border.

headline: 101 VIEWS OF THIS 'FAR FORM PERFECT' WAR
abstract: Ten days of general debate have brought 101 kings, presidents, prime ministers, foreign ministers and other officials to the podium of the General Assembly to offer their views of the world. About half a million words have been uttered, exclaimed and shouted.   Although each nation has had its particular causes to promote and issues to discuss - Morocco its conflict in the Western Sahara; Malaysia its interest in Antarctica - there are some issues that have attracted almost universal comment.

headline: Rights Group's Accusations Called 'Groundless' by China
abstract: China dismissed as ''groundless'' today a report by the human rights group Amnesty International that criticized what it said were widespread executions and human rights violations in China.   ''It is groundless for Amnesty International to accuse China of violating human rights,'' said a Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman, Ma Yuzhen.   Mr. Ma said the London-based human rights group, which called on Peking to abolish the death penalty, was wrongly applying Western legal norms to China.

headline: A SECRET EFFORT IS REPORTED FOR A PACT ON AIRLINE FLIGHTS
abstract: In a last-minute effort to provide more agreements to announce at the Geneva summit meeting, American negotiators flew secretly to Moscow on Sunday to reopen talks on restoring direct air service between the United States and the Soviet Union, Reagan Administration officials said today.   The negotiators, working without publicity at the Soviet Ministry of Aviation since Monday, have been trying to reach enough agreement so that something positive could be announced when the summit meeting ends, the officials said.   Accord on a new civil aviation agreement would open the way to a companion agreement, on exchanging new consulates in Kiev and New York, to add to the list of concrete achievements that could be made public in Geneva. The Soviet side has maintained that the consulate accord, first agreed to in principle in 1979, could not go ahead until there was a civil aviation agreement.

headline: FOR ZIA, MUCH OF THE POWER REMAINS
abstract: By lifting martial law in Pakistan, President Mohammed Zia ul-Haq has enhanced the power of the new civilian Government while retaining his and the Army's ability to curb dissent and jail political opponents.   In addition, even some of General Zia's allies say that in a nominally civilian Government, army officers are likely to retain much of their accustomed behind-the-scenes role in running the administrative bureacracy.   Few people in Pakistan doubt that General Zia will also continue to stop his foes from mounting an effective opposition. Under civilian rule he will have, for example, ample police powers to ban demonstrations and strikes and to outlaw certain political parties.

headline: New Acquisition Target For Houston Investor
abstract: Charles E. Hurwitz, the Houston investor who has built an empire with interests in everything from oil and gas to real estate and savings and loans, is on the acquisition path again.   This time Mr. Hurwitz's target is the Pacific Lumber Company, a timber and welding products concern based in San Francisco. The Maxxam Group, a New York real estate company controlled by Mr. Hurwitz, formally began a tender offer for Pacific yesterday at $38.50 a share, or about $798 million.

headline: U.S. SAYS SOVIET OFFER COULD BE A BEGINNING
abstract: The Reagan Administration, in its first full response to the recent Soviet arms proposals, said today that the measures could be the start of a ''successful process'' in the effort to reduce the nuclear weaponry of the two sides.   It was the first time the Administration has made it plain that the Soviet proposal, and the negotiations over it, could lead to a positive outcome at the Geneva arms talks.   But a ranking Administration official made it plain that President Reagan and his aides have serious reservations about the proposal, saying it was ''highly unequal'' and would insure that the Soviet Union retained ''major advantages in the numbers of nuclear weapons, nuclear delivery vehicles and ballistic missile throw weight.''   The official, who briefed reporters at the White House, said that the Soviet proposal was ''a place to start.'' He added, ''The President finds that the very fact that the Soviet Union has made a counterproposal is a promising development.''

headline: KEEPING TABS ON COMPETITORS
abstract: After more than 20 years of analyzing weapons-related technological developments for the Central Intelligence Agency, Jan Herring is now working for Motorola Inc., helping the big electronics company analyze the technological advances of its competitors.   Stuart A. Feldstein has spent most of his career as a business journalist, and his partner, Mark S. Kamm, worked as a private investigator. Now they hire themselves out to major corporations willing to pay generously for information on a competitor's costs, its plans to introduce a new product or the type of research it is conducting.   Whether they are doing it themselves or hiring the likes of Mr. Feldstein and Mr. Kamm, a rapidly growing number of American companies are stepping up their efforts to keep tabs on each other as well as foreign competitors - especially the Japanese.      Overseeing Intelligence Efforts    Several companies, including Motorola, Eastman Kodak, General Motors and Cross & Trecker, the big machine tool maker, have either established formal intelligence units or designated specialists to oversee their intelligence efforts within the last two or three years.

headline: FORD MATCHES 7.9% G.M. RATE
abstract: The General Motors Corporation opened a new round of automobile pricing competition today by announcing 7.9 percent financing on some of its cars and trucks, and the Ford Motor Company quickly followed suit with the same incentives.   G.M., the nation's No. 1 auto maker, announced it would offer the lower rates to consumers on about 40 percent of its vehicles. Ford announced a few hours later that it, too, would offer 7.9 percent financing on about 40 percent of its cars.   ''Essentially, it is a competitive response to help us maintain our sales momentum,'' said John Seig, a spokesman for Ford, the second-largest domestic auto maker.

headline: New Deputy Governor At Bank of England
abstract: The announcement last week by the British Government naming George Blunden as future deputy governor of the Bank of England came as a surprise to many in the City. In an unusual move, Mr. Blunden, who is 62, has been brought back from semiretirement to fill the vacancy created when Christopher McMahon decided to become Midland Bank P.L.C.'s chief executive last month.   Mr. Blunden had been one of the bank's top executives from 1976 to 1984 and had remained on its board of directors when he retired.

headline: THE BID FOR MIDCON INTENSIFIES
abstract: The struggle between the Midcon Corporation and the partnership of Wagner & Brown and Freeport-McMoran Inc., which wants to acquire it, intensified yesterday, as Midcon sought to derail the takeover attempt in court.   Separately, rumors on Wall Street pointed to several companies as possible friendly bidders for the natural gas pipeline company. That pushed Midcon's stock to $64.50, up $1.625, on the New York Stock Exchange and made it the exchange's third-most-active stock. The day's rise pushed Midcon further above the $62.50 price offered by the partnership.

headline: MARCOS PREDICTS HAVOC IF HELOSES VOTE
abstract: President Ferdinand E. Marcos today accused his election opponent, Corazon Aquino, of being influenced by both Communist ''reds'' and American ''whites,'' and he warned that 10 years of bloodshed would follow an Aquino victory.   At a speech and a news conference that opened his campaign for re-election, Mr. Marcos accused his opponent of weakness and ignorance of affairs of state. ''You cannot discharge the presidency with smiles or tears,'' he said.   At the same time, he publicly acknowledged for the first time that the elections, which are scheduled for Feb. 7, might not be held because of a constitutional flaw in the way he has structured them. Next Tuesday, the Supreme Court is scheduled to hear 11 challenges to the constitutionality of the elections because the President has not stepped down to create a vacancy.

headline: EX-PRIME MINISTER OF JORDAN
abstract: Abdel Monem Rifai, a former Prime Minister of Jordan and special adviser to King Hussein, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Amman, the Jordanian capital, the state radio announced. He was 68 years old and an uncle of Jordan's present Prime Minister, Zaid al-Rifai.   Abdel Monem Rifai, a soft-spoken man, spent many years as a diplomat and also wrote Arabic poetry in a traditional vein. He was Prime Minister and concurrently Minister of Culture and Information from March 1969 to August 1969 and Prime Minister again from June 1970 to September 1970. In 1973 and 1974 he served as special adviser on international affairs to the King, who wields supreme power in Jordan.

headline: Advertising;   Edwin Bird Wilson Inc. Gets a Ricoh Account
abstract: Edwin Bird Wilson Inc., an agency big in financial and corporate advertising, has won the Ricoh Corporation Consumer Products Group, which offers 35-millimeter cameras and other photo equipment.

headline: A FIGHT OVER UNEQUAL STOCK
abstract: In the 1960's a highly successful New York Stock Exchange advertising campaign convinced millions of investors to own shares of American business. These days, the Big Board is still promoting share ownership, but, to its chagrin, is having to acknowledge that not all shareholders of some corporations get the same rights for their money.         The discrepancy between two different classes of stock within the same company, in fact, is the subject of a heated debate between Congress and Wall Street that now appears headed for a showdown - and will shape the future control and ownership of many of the nation's largest corporations. It stems from the moves in recent years by prominent companies, such as the Coastal Corporation, Hershey Foods and General Cinema, that have issued a second class of stock with superior voting rights.

headline: EGYPT SAYS IT GAVE GUNMEN TO P.L.O.
abstract: The departure of the four Palestinian hijackers from Egypt came after a day of confusion over their whereabouts and denials by Egypt that they were still in the country.   Early Thursday, President Hosni Mubarak insisted that the four gunmen who hijacked the Italian cruise liner Achille Lauro and killed one elderly American had left Egypt. In impromptu remarks to newsmen, he said he thought they were under the custody of the P.L.O.   Throughout the day, Egyptian officials clung to this position despite skepticism among diplomats in Egypt and statements from Washington that it was believed that the four were still being held at an airport near Cairo.      Motives Are Unclear    As late as 6:30 P.M. Thursday, Cairo time, Egypt's Foreign Minister, Esmat Abdel Meguid, was insisting at a news conference that the four had left Egypt and would ''soon'' be the sole responsibility of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

headline: MAKING THAT DREAM HOUSE AFFORDABLE
abstract: KENNETH N. RASHBAUM and his wife, Vicki H. Kaplan, recently bought the dream house they thought they could never afford. After a lengthy search, the couple found a 102-year-old Federal townhouse in Brooklyn's Park Slope with marble mantels, a large backyard - and a ready-made rental apartment that helps pay the mortgage. The carrying costs for the three-story house are less than the payments on the small co-op apartment they just sold.   Confronted with the skyscraper prices of choice real estate in New York and elsewhere, people are devising creative solutions to trade up to homes they might be unable to afford otherwise. Two of the most common strategies: Turning the new house into a tax shelter by renting out some portion of it, and borrowing some of the purchase money from the former owner as an alternative to conventional bank financing.

headline: THREE GROUPS ARE SAID TO BID FOR GROUP W CABLE
abstract: At least three groups, including ones headed by Time Inc. and Viacom International Inc., have made preliminary bids for the Westinghouse Electric Corporation's Group W cable unit, sources close to the bidders said yesterday.   In a statement yesterday, Westinghouse said that a number of potential purchasers had submitted first round bids for Group W, the nation's third-largest cable system operator, with more than two million subscribers.   Westinghouse declined to state the number or identify the bidders. The company said that after evaluating the bids with its investment bankers, it would hold additional discussions with ''selected bidders.''

headline: Agreement Reported On Duarte's Daughter
abstract: A high official of the Salvadoran Government confirmed today that Government representatives and the leftist guerrilla front had met for three days in Panama and had worked out out a series of ''public'' and ''private'' agreements.   Adolfo Rey Prendes, the Minister of Information, said the ''public'' agreement involved the release of the daughter of President Jose Napoleon Duarte, Ines Guadalupe Duarte, who was kidnapped on Sept. 10.

headline: 25.34 JUMP PUTS DOW AT 1,484.40
abstract: Stock prices exploded yesterday, under the pressure of demand that had been building for the last week.   ''This was one of the best days of the rally,'' said Laszlo Birinyi, manager of equity market analysis at Salomon Brothers Inc. ''It's really giving people a lot of confidence in the market's ability to go higher.''   The Dow Jones industrial average gained 25.34 points, pushing it to a record close of 1,484.40.   Traders and market analysts said that no single event was responsible for the buying binge. They speculated that investors who had been waiting for the market to retreat finally gave in and decided to join the equity-buying throng.

headline: Citicorp, Morgan Backed on Underwriting
abstract: The Justice Department has asked the Federal Reserve Board to permit Citicorp and J.P. Morgan & Company to underwrite and sell certain securities, such as commercial paper, industrial revenue bonds and mortgage-backed securities.   Bank regulators have heretofore considered such underwriting activities off limits for banks and their holding companies under the provisions of the Glass-Steagall Act.

headline: Bear, Stearns Stock Offering
abstract: Bear, Stearns & Company, one of the largest private partnerships on Wall Street, today begins a previously announced public offering of its own shares at $21.50 a share.   The offering of 10 million shares will raise $215 million of new capital, and increase the 62-year-old firm's equity capital to $565 million.

headline: Combustion Engineering
abstract: Combustion Engineering Inc. has combined two of its business groups into one division that will sell products and services to cities, towns and governmental agencies, the company announced.

headline: FOOD INDUSTRY'S BIG MERGERS
abstract: Mary L. Balestra, a 33-year-old working mother of three who lives in Pelham, N.Y., is aware of Philip Morris Inc.'s recent agreement to buy the General Foods Corporation. She also knows that the nearly $5.8 billion deal is only the latest of many takeovers that have occurred in the food industry in recent years.   Is she concerned that this acquisition binge may affect her choices at the supermarket and the prices she has to pay for food?   ''Nope,'' said Mrs. Balestra. ''As a consumer, it's not going to affect me. If Philip Morris takes over General Foods and Jell-O goes up a nickel, I'll just buy Royal Pudding or a store brand. I don't care about the takeovers.

headline: U.S. AND SOVIET AGREE TO RESUME AIRLINE SERVICE
abstract: The United States and the Soviet Union agreed today to resume direct commercial airline service between the two countries, the Department of Transportation announced.   Under the agreement, airlines of both countries would be allowed up to four round-trip flights a week between the two countries. Service will probably be resumed in late April, department officials said.

headline: BRITAIN AND IRELAND SIGN ACCORD THAT GIVES DUBLIN ROLE IN ULSTER
abstract: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher signed a treaty here today giving the Irish Republic a formal consultative role and official presence in this province, long a sectarian battleground. It was the first such arrangement since Ireland's partition 65 years ago.   Under the potentially far-reaching accord, the Dublin Government is given a mechanism for pressing its views on virtually all matters touching the Roman Catholicminority here, including the security policies of the army and the police, the administration of justice and prisons.   This is to be done through a joint secretariat of Irish and British officials to be set up here, officials said, within a matter of weeks to serve a ''conference'' of Cabinet ministers from the two countries that will be more or less permanently in session to discuss sensitive issues and matters of policy.

headline: TOYS THE BIG KIDS ARE BUYING
abstract: ''IT used to be so simple,'' the man was saying. ''You'd get the wife a blouse. Maybe a necklace. I'd get my 15th pair of bedroom slippers. Now look at me.''   The man, a lawyer, was in the electronics department at Bloomingdale's the other day, getting an early jump on his Christmas list. (He didn't want to say who he was, because he didn't want the recipients to know about his selections.) ''I'm considering getting my wife a compact disk player,'' he said. ''You see, her sister and brother-in-law got one last Christmas. If we don't get one, we're out of it. They're cheaper, but they're not cheap. I'll tell you this: If I splurge for a CD, I damn well better get the stereo TV from her.''   For many shoppers on this year's gift trail, shirts or slippers just will not do; instead, they must give hard thought to video cameras (which are in drastically short supply) and compact disk players, not to mention radios that will float serenely next to you while you soak in the bathtub. Some feel they must even contemplate whether it is time, at last, to buy their wives or husbands a robot.

headline: Transamerica Doubles Net
abstract: The Transamerica Corporation today reported third-quarter earnings of $16.3 million, or 22 cents a share, more than double the $5.9 million, or 9 cents a share, earned in the comparable quarter a year ago.   The San Francisco-based insurance, finance and travel company had total revenues for the quarter of $1.7 billion, up 21.4 percent from $1.4 billion in the 1984 period.

headline: QUESTIONS WITHOUT ANSWERS
abstract: Often an event captures headlines, then fades from view with important questions unanswered - questions that defy news reporting, at least for a while. This column periodically offers a selection of such questions, with today's group concentrating on people - and things - that are missing.   SOVIET MARSHAL. What has become of Marshal Nikolai A. Ogarkov, the ousted Chief of Staff of the Soviet armed forces?

headline: A MYSTERY SOLVED: TALE OF THE MISSING PHOTO
abstract: It is a cover-up of Himalayan proportions. An American mountain-climbing team wanted to do something monumental to honor the General Assembly's 40th session. So last May the team, sponsored by the United Nations, braved glacial cold and howling winds to put the blue and white United Nations flag at the summit of Mount Everest.

headline: FOR SOVIET ROLE IN LEBANON, KIDNAPPINGS ARE A HEAVY BLOW
abstract: Lebanese officials and commmentators say the kidnapping of four Russians connected with the Soviet Embassy in Moslem West Beirut has dealt a heavy blow to Soviet diplomacy at a time when Lebanon was moving closer to Moscow and away from Washington.   The abduction, and the subsequent murder of one of the hostages, came only a few days after a senior adviser to President Amin Gemayel said that Lebanon's relations with the United States were declining and its relations with the Soviet Union were improving.   ''For the first time, the Soviet Ambassador is being treated by us on an equal footing with the American Ambassador,'' Dr. George Deeb, the Government's counselor on foreign policy, said in a television interview to mark the third anniversary of the election of Mr. Gemayel as President.      Embassy Remained Large   The Soviet Embassy, which had retained a large contingent of diplomats that contrasted with the depleted missions of other foreign powers in West Beirut, appears now to be primarily concerned with assuring the safety of its diplomats and eventually evacuating them.

headline: Plessey Faults Rockwell on Bid
abstract: The Plessey Company P.L.C. said that the Rockwell International Corporation was at fault for Plessey's loss of a multibillion-dollar contract to supply the United States Army with a battlefield communication system.

headline: COMPANIES FIND TWIST IN HOLIDAYS
abstract: Christmas and New Year's are approaching and with them the sweet season of office parties and family feasts. But this year the calendar will be unkind to millions of workers who have come to count on celebrating each holiday with three or four consecutive days off.   For the first time since 1974-75, both holidays will fall on Wednesday, and at many companies around the country that means just two paid days off - one on Dec. 25, and the other on Jan. 1, 1986. Only leap year's caprice has caused an 11-year stretch of Christmas holidays near weekends, and the holidays will next fall on Wednesday in the 1991-92 season, and then again in 1996-97.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

headline: REAGAN WILL GET PENTAGON REPORT ON ARMS NEEDS
abstract: The Pentagon said today that before President Reagan goes to the summit meeting next week, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger plans to submit a report on purported Soviet violations of arms accords and on proposed American responses.   A senior Pentagon official said that ''the President does need to know what some of the options are'' and that the report was necessary to insure that future military options are not foreclosed by ''the activity in Geneva.''   The report, which may be presented in person by Mr. Weinberger, may not include a list of specific responses, in part because the issue has not been fully considered by the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the official added.   The type of responses recommended could involve expanding strategic arms programs or adopting new interpretations of the antiballistic missile treaty of 1972, the official said.

headline: Case Against Turkey Is Dropped in Accord
abstract: Five West European countries that accused Turkey in the European Court of Human Rights of torturing political prisoners and other abuses have agreed to drop the case after Turkey promised to speed up its return to democracy, it was announced today.   The agreement, announced by the European Commission of Human Rights, ends more than three years of litigation on charges against Turkey of violating the European Convention of Human Rights.

headline: ANTARCTICA TREATY NATIONS THREATEN TO BOYCOTT U.N. DEBATES
abstract: Delegates from countries that administer Antarctica said today that they would boycott future debates on the future of the continent unless a group of developing countries abandons what the delegates described as a confrontational approach.   The decision was linked to the adoption Monday of three resolutions in the General Assembly that seek to undermine the authority of the Antarctica Treaty, an accord that gives 18 ''consultative parties,'' including the United States and the Soviet Union, the right to determine how the continent is run.   The parties work together to ban military use of the continent, carry out scientific studies, control mineral exploration and prevent further territorial claims.

headline: BEATRICE TO OPEN TALKS ON BUYOUT BY KOHLBERG
abstract: The Beatrice Companies, producer of some of the nation's best-known consumer products, agreed yesterday to open negotiations with Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company about a management buyout - a deal that could involve close to $6 billion.   If successful, it could become the biggest takeover in history outside the oil business, a distinction now held by Philip Morris Inc. with its deal to buy the General Foods Corporation for some $5.8 billion.   Beatrice cautioned, however, that there was no assurance that mutually acceptable terms could be reached with the New York investment house or with any other bidders.   It agreed, nevertheless, to ''explore all alternatives'' so that it could ''maximize values'' for stockholders.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: HIGH-TECH FILING, AND A TOUCH OF CLASS
abstract: ORGANIZATIONAL mania has hit the nation's automotive junkyards. Owners are filling weed- and rust-infested yards with gravel and asphalt, stacking auto frames neatly on huge metal shelves, and cataloguing their inventories on computer. Some even display their wares in carpeted showrooms.

headline: Gunmen Kill 11 in Pakistan
abstract: At least 11 people were killed and 10 wounded when gunmen in the Baluchistan region of western Pakistan opened fire on a bus that had ignored their order to stop. The police said today that six people were arrested after the shooting Friday at Dera Murad Jamali, about 250 miles north of Karachi. Bandits in Baluchistan and Sind Provinces frequently attack buses, trucks, cars and trains, but the raids have decreased since the authorities increased security.

headline: P.& G. GETS KEY LINES OF SEARLE
abstract: The Procter & Gamble Company agreed today to acquire two of the nation's leading over-the-counter drug products from G.D. Searle & Company. They are the nation's top-selling laxative, Metamucil, and the nation's leading motion sickness medicine, Dramamine.   Procter is also buying an analgesic rub, Icy Hot. It is getting the products by agreeing to buy Searle's consumer product group except for the tabletop sweetener, Equal, which is made from Searle's Nutrasweet.

headline: Wilson Picks President
abstract: James N. Harvey, 58, has become an ad agency president for the fourth time. The agency is the 69-year-old Edwin Bird Wilson, where the title has been unused since Richard G. Farrell left for Muir Cornelius Moore a couple of years ago. Delano W. Ladd Jr. is chairman and chief executive. Mr. Harvey, who first worked on the creative side for Young & Rubicam and then McCann-Erickson, was president of Richard K. Manoff, Harvey & Carlson and of his own place, James Neal Harvey Inc., which he sold to Creamer Inc.

headline: AFRIKANER ASKS U.S. BANKS TO RESTRICT LOANS
abstract: The Rev. Beyers Naude, general secretary of the South African Council of Churches, has called on American banks to make future loans to South Africa conditional on a lessening by the Pretoria Government of its crackdown against opponents.   On a visit to the United States, Dr. Naude, who is a leading Afrikaner opponent of the South African system of racial compartmentalizaion, said sanctions announced by the United States Government to date had been inadequate.   More meaningful pressure, he said, would be produced if banks used their ''economic leverage to demand concrete political steps, such as the cessation of the general state of emergency, the release of Nelson Mandela from prison, the withdrawal of the security forces from the townships, and the return of exiles.''   Mr. Mandela is the imprisoned leader of the African National Congress, an outlawed organization that commands the support of large numbers of the country's blacks.

headline: 10 1/4% Redeemable Swedish Bonds
abstract: The Kingdom of Sweden is offering $300 million of 10 1/4 percent bonds due in 2015 with an unusual feature allowing investors to redeem the bonds at a price of 100 after 10 years.   Underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company increased the size of the issue from $250 million, and offered the bonds at a price of 99 3/8, to yield 10.351 percent to the ''put'' date, or 10.317 percent if the bonds are held to maturity.

headline: U.S.-SOVIET CULTURAL ACCORD IS READY FOR SIGNING
abstract: The United States and the Soviet Union have completed drafting a cultural exchange agreement that the Reagan Administration hopes will open the way to a major exchange of young people, Government officials said today.   The officials said that President Reagan was expected to discuss the accord in a speech on Soviet-American relations on Thursday. It is to be signed during the summit meeting next week.   Mr. Reagan has become interested in increasing the exchange of young people, particularly young Soviet citizens coming to the United States, in the belief that such visits may help reduce misunderstandings, officials said.

headline: COMPANIES HAVE GIFT LISTS, TOO
abstract: TWENTY-TWO sets of hurricane lamps have been ordered, and the shopper has moved on to the next item on her Christmas list: gifts with $150 price tags.   ''I take it these are people who pretty much have everything?'' the salesman inquires. The shopper nods.  ''That's difficult,'' he says sympathetically. ''We can do a dozen wines or a dozen champagnes. Or perhaps a superb-looking decanter.''

headline: The Summit Record
abstract: July 1955.President Eisenhower meets in Geneva with Nikolai A. Bulganin, British and French leaders. Results: The ''Spirit of Geneva'' began to thaw the cold war. General discussion; no agreements. September 1959. Mr. Eisenhower and Nikita S. Khrushchev meet at Camp David, Md. Results: ''The Spirit of Camp David'' - a general feeling that scientific and cultural exchanges would be good, and that disarmament is the world's main problem - but no concrete results. May 1960. Mr. Eisenhower and Mr. Khrushchev go to Paris, but the Russian uses the shooting down of the American U-2 spy plane over the Soviet Union to torpedo the meeting. Results: Increased tensions. June 1961. Mr. Khrushchev and President Kennedy, in Vienna, have heated exchanges. Results: No formal agreements. A year later, the Soviet Union tries to put missiles in Cuba; U.S. forces their removal. June 1967.President Johnson meets in Glassboro, N.J., with Aleksei N. Kosygin to discuss Middle East, the Vietnam War and nuclear arms. Results: No results on Vietnam; seeds sown for later arms talks. May 1972. President Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev, in Moscow, sign first treaties setting ceilings on strategic nuclear arms and limiting antiballistic missile systems. Results: They agree to keep negotiating on arms; regional issues still divide them. June 1973. Mr. Nixon and Mr. Brezhnev meet in Washington. Results: Agreement to try to complete a new arms treaty by 1974; agreements on practical issues. June-July 1974. Mr. Nixon and Mr. Brezhnev meet in Moscow and Yalta.

headline: ADVERTISING;New Yorker Magazine Appoints Ad Director
abstract: Wasting no time, The New Yorker magazine has replaced its departing 50-year-old advertising director with 34-year-old Michael Trainor, who since last year has been vice president and advertising director of Esquire magazine.          Unlike his predecessor, Robert F. Young, Mr. Trainor will have the title associate publisher responsible for advertising sales.

headline: CREDIT CARD RATES DEFENDED
abstract: Martha R. Seger, a governor of the Federal Reserve Board, told Congress today that the credit card business was ''reasonably competitive'' and there was no need for a Federal ceiling on credit card interest rates.         Miss Seger, one of President Reagan's appointees to the board, gave that appraisal to a House Banking subcommittee that heard two New York Democrats outline their bills to impose ceilings.

headline: CHRYSLER BUYING BANK AMERICA UNIT
abstract: The BankAmerica Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell FinanceAmerica, its consumer finance subsidiary, to the Chrysler Corporation for $405 million.   The transaction is expected to add more than $100 million in net income for BankAmerica in the fourth quarter, virtually assuring that the bank will report a profit for that period despite large loan losses, analysts said.   For Chrysler, the move is a further step for its Chrysler Financial Corporation subsidiary in its efforts to expand beyond financing automobile purchases. ''It puts Chrysler Corporation in the heart of the consumer finance business,'' Lee A. Iacocca, Chrysler's chairman, said in a statement. Earlier this year, Chrysler Finance formed a leasing joint venture with the General Electric Credit Corporation and acquired E. F. Hutton Credit.

headline: NEW ZEALAND SUBMITS BILL TO BAN NUCLEAR-ARMED SHIPS AND PLANES
abstract: The Government, in a measure that could further strain relations with the United States, introduced legislation today to ban nuclear-armed ships and aircraft from New Zealand.   When New Zealand refused to allow the destroyer Buchanan to make a port visit in February, the United States retaliated by halting intelligence sharing with Wellington. Relations between the two allies remain near an all-time low.

headline: Midmonth Auto Sales Off 27.2%
abstract: Sales of new American-made automobiles continued to slide in the mid-November period, falling 27.2 percent from the comparable period last year on a daily selling rate basis, the manufacturers reported today.   ''There's no question that sales are on the anemic side,'' said Scott Merlis, an auto analyst for Morgan Stanley & Company. ''With more imports coming in and consumers heavy with debt, I think there will continue to be downward pressure on auto sales into next year,'' he said.

headline: A SET BACK TO TERRORISM AND MORE: REAGAN'S PROGRAMS STAND TO BENEFIT
abstract: In a single stroke, President Reagan has altered the impression held by many, including some within the White House, that the American Government is virtually helpless in the face of terrorism, aides and political analysts asserted today.   Of almost equal importance was the lift that Mr. Reagan's advisers expect to gain for the Administration's agenda in domestic and foreign affairs.   The White House is counting on a ripple effect from Mr. Reagan's decision to do more than lift his already high personal popularity and provide a shot of pride for the American public.   Key Reagan aides say the President has stengthened the perception of his leadership just as he enters one of the most critical periods of his Presidency.

headline: American Standard To Sell Some Divisions
abstract: American Standard Inc. said yesterday that it planned to sell several divisions, restructure several others and repurchase an undetermined amount of its stock with ''a major portion'' of the proceeds from the sales.   Lois Stewart, a company spokesman, said American Standard had no definite buyers for the businesses designated for sale, which have revenues of approximately $500 million and account for about one-sixth of the company's sales. But in a statement, American Standard said it expected to realize a ''substantial after-tax gain'' from the sales.

headline: THE SUDDEN DECLINE AT APOLLO
abstract: For much of its five-year history, Apollo Computer Inc. had been one of the computer industry's great success stories. When its stock went public, it sold for a dizzying 50 times earnings. And sales of the company's powerful desktop computers, known as engineering work stations and used by engineers and other product designers, doubled and doubled again in 1983 and 1984, to reach $215.9 million.   These days, however, sales are flat and the stock has tumbled. On Wednesday, Apollo reported an $18.5 million loss in the third quarter, its first deficit since going public in March 1983. Apollo executives say they expect a turnaround soon, but Wall Street analysts are skeptical.   ''I don't think you will see much good news out of this company in the next six months,'' said David Wu, an analyst at Montgomery Securities Inc., a San Francisco-based securities firm. ''To recommend a stock like this, you'd have to look way out in the future.''

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 7, 1985
abstract: Markets    The Dow Jones industrial average closed above 1,400 for the first time, helped by a late surge in trading by institutional investors. The average finished the day at 1,403.44, for a gain of 6.77 points, after being down 1.60 points a half-hour before the close. The Dow has been generally climbing since crossing 1,300 in May, and most traders took the latest gain in stride. There were only feeble gains in the broader indicators, with most of them still several points below their records. Volume widened to 129.5 million shares, from 119.2 million. [Page D1.]    Prices of Treasury issues fell modestly, in what dealers said was a normal retrenchment after the six-day rally in the credit markets. [D21.]  The largest tax-exempt bond issue ever was announced by the New Jersey Turnpike Authority. The $2 billion sale, more than double the previous largest issue, will be used to widen the turnpike. [D21.]  Yields on money market mutual funds inched higher in the latest week. [D24.]

headline: ISRAEL SAYS SYRIA PUT NEW MISSILES CLOSE TO LEBANON
abstract: Israel announced today that, in the last three weeks, Syria had stationed a variety of surface-to-air missiles along its border with Lebanon. Israel said the deployment seriously threatened regular Israeli reconnaissance missions over Lebanon.   Israeli military sources said the Syrian move - which Israel said began soon after Israeli jets shot down two Syrian MIG-23's in Syrian airspace on Nov. 19 - constituted a ''dangerous change in the status quo.''   Any Israeli plane flying over Lebanon will now be exposed to Soviet-made SAM-2, SAM-6 and SAM-8 surface-to-air missiles, the military sources said. Before three weeks ago, the Syrians had no SAM-2 batteries near the Lebanese border and far fewer SAM-6's and SAM-8's in that area, the sources said.

headline: NATIONAL STEEL'S JAPANESE ALLY
abstract: A dozen or so Japanese steel executives here are taking an intense interest in the workings of the National Steel Corporation, America's sixth-largest steel producer.   But unlike the chilly reception that most domestic steelmakers might give their arch-competitors, National Steel is eager to make its visitors feel at home. That is because the Japanese own 50 percent of the company, and they are here to help turn it around.   National Steel faces the same problems as its domestic competitors -imports, poor steel prices, lower demand - and each American steel company has sought its own solutions in a steel world turned upside down, National's solution has been to embrace its foreign competitors and try to learn from them.      Nippon Kokan Paid $300 Million    National Intergroup Inc., National Steel's parent, sold a half-interest in National Steel a year ago August for some $300 million to Nippon Kokan, Japan's No. 2 steelmaker after the Nippon Steel Corporation.

headline: SOVIET PRESSES U.S. TO JOIN MORATORIUM ON A-TESTS
abstract: The Soviet Union pressed the United States today to join a moratorium on all nuclear testing, contending that its offer to permit on-site inspection of test ranges satisfied Reagan Administration concerns about monitoring a ban.   A series of press commentaries today criticized the Administration's refusal to join the moratorium. The press agency Tass accused Washington of seeking ''one-sided disarmament by the Soviet Union.''   The sudden flare-up on the issue was the first heated exchange between Washington and Moscow since the meeting last month between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.

headline: DOW RISES 6.99, TO A RECORD 1,396.67
abstract: Fueled by strength in blue-chip stocks, the Dow Jones industrial average rose to record levels yesterday as it drew a closer bead on the 1,400 mark.   After being slightly lower in early trading and then trading briefly above 1,400, the Dow ended the day 6.99 points higher at 1,396.67. The previous record close was 1,390.25 last Friday. Advances on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered declines by 986 to 548.

headline: Fed Warns Banks on Payouts
abstract: The Federal Reserve Board issued a policy statement today warning banks and bank holding companies that are experiencing financial trouble that they should reduce their dividends or not pay them at all.   Concerned about the strength of capital in the banking industry and the pressure from Wall Street on banks to keep dividends at ever-growing levels, the Federal Reserve suggested that prudent banking practices include withholding dividends to protect the financial soundness of banks and their holding companies.   The central bank's action came one week after the Comptroller of the Currency issued a similar directive to the 4,900 national banks it supervises. The Fed's policy statement was directed to the state-chartered banks belonging to the Federal Reserve System and bank holding companies.

headline: WHY JUSTICE DEPARTMENT OPPOSES RAILROAD MERGER IN WEST
abstract: Since 1970, rail merger after rail merger has passed the Justice Department's antitrust scrutiny. But a proposal to unite two parallel railroad systems in the West has stirred the department to protest, illustrating the competitive overlap necessary to arouse antitrust opposition.         In a move that surprised the railroad industry, the department's antitrust division filed a strongly worded brief last month with the Interstate Commerce Commission opposing the creation of a huge system through a merger of the Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe Railway Company and the Southern Pacific Transportation Company.

headline: PROBLEMS INCREASING AT SEAWAY
abstract: The rumble of the heavy machinery goes on 24 hours a day here as engineers and construction workers try to repair a 150-foot concrete chunk of Lock No. 7 in the Welland Canal that slammed into the side of a ship on Oct. 14.   By the time the lock is reopened -perhaps by Nov. 6 - the owners of more than 70 ships stranded by the accident will have lost about $350,000 in revenues for each ship.   The accident here is the second to rock the St. Lawrence Seaway in less than a year. Last year, a lift-bridge jammed at Valleyfield, Quebec, causing an 18-day shutdown and costing shippers a total of more than $40 million in lost business.

headline: Nikko Acquisition
abstract: The Nikko International Capital Management Company, an investment unit of Japan's Nikko Securities Company, has acquired 51 percent of Fraser Green Ltd., a British investment advisory firm, a Nikko official said. The acquisition, valued at $579,360, is significant because it gives a Japanese company access to new areas of investment advice, industry sources said. Nikko wants to strengthen its ability to advise clients in Europe, the United States and Japan on investment in worldwide markets.

headline: INVENTORIES ROSE 0.5% IN OCTOBER
abstract: Business inventories rose five-tenths of 1 percent in October, the biggest increase in a year, while sales were falling sharply, the Government reported today.
