Analysts said the combination of sharply rising inventories and falling sales could act to restrain future economic growth unless retailers were successful in working down a giant buildup in inventories during the current Christmas season. The push to get rid of the large inventories will be a boon to consumers, however, who should benefit from deep price-cutting before Christmas, the analysts added.

headline: INTERPOL REPORTED WARNED OF RAIDS ON AIRPORTS
abstract: A warning of possible terrorist attacks on airports and airlines was issued two weeks ago by Interpol, the international police agency, a Dutch police spokesman said in Amsterdam today.   The spokesman, Rik Hirs, said the alert had been very general, raising the possibility of an attack ''somewhere in the world'' by terrorists ''of probably Arab origin,'' possibly carrying false Moroccan or Egyptian passports.   The Interpol office in Washington said it had no information that such a warning had been given. A spokesman at Interpol's headquarters in Paris gave an entirely different time for the alert, saying it had been issued in November.

headline: Paper Insert Plugged on TV
abstract: The big three in newspaper free-standing inserts are the George Valassis Company, Product Movers - until recently Marketing Showcase -and Blair Marketing.   There is little to set their products apart.

headline: TREASURY BONDS GET LATE LIFT
abstract: Although dealers and investors in fixed-income securities were mostly on the sidelines after lunch yesterday, there was sufficient pre-weekend short-covering throughout the day to keep prices firm. And when leaders of the Senate and House approved the main points in the Gramm-Rudman budget-balancing bill late in the day, a flurry of buying converted losses of about 5/32d's on longer maturities into gains of about that size, but the bills market continued to show losses.   Dealers noted that the afternoon market was thin as word was awaited on the fate of the Gramm-Rudman bill. The near standstill in trading also reflected Congressional inaction on the national debt ceiling, which was due to fall back to $1.8 trillion at midnight from the temporary level of $2 trillion.

headline: FOREIGN ENVOYS EXPECTED TO GET U.S. BODYGUARDS
abstract: The Reagan Administration will seek funds next month to provide full-time bodyguards for certain foreign ambassadors stationed in Washington, a senior State Department official said today.   The official said the move grew out of the Administration's concern over what it regards as threats to the safety of some foreign ambassadors here.   Robert E. Lamb, the director of the department's newly formed Bureau of Diplomatic Security, said in an interview that he expected about 10 envoys to be eligible for bodyguards at any one time, but that the number would fluctuate depending on the actual threats.      Some Envoys Threatened    Mr. Lamb said threats had been made against certain ambassadors, but he declined to be specific.

headline: REAGAN TEMPERS HIS VIEW ON SOVIET
abstract: President Reagan said today that Soviet-American relations would continue to feel the impact of human rights issues. But in his annual speech marking International Human Rights Day, he abandoned the harsh tone with which he has previously denounced rights violations by the Soviet Union.   ''Make no mistake about it,'' he said. ''Human rights will continue to have a profound effect on the United States-Soviet relationship as a whole because they are fundamental to our vision of an enduring peace.''

headline: New Zealand Says U.S. Spurns Meeting
abstract: Prime Minister David Lange said today that United States officials had refused to meet with an official delegation that was planning to travel to Washington early next month to explain New Zealand's proposed legislative ban on nuclear warships.   ''I think the spirit of Geneva lasted less than 24 hours when it comes to an ally such as ourselves,'' Mr. Lange said, alluding to last week's meeting between President Reagan and the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

headline: NEW INQUIRY ON ATHENS AIRPORT IS SET
abstract: The Athens airport, the security of which was strongly criticized by Washington after hijackers boarded a T.W.A. airliner there earlier this year, is to come under renewed investigation as the starting point of another hijacking.   An airport spokesman said the Government planned to find out how hijackers of an Egyptian airliner on a flight from Athens to Cairo Saturday night might have smuggled weapons aboard the plane.   Tight security had been in force at the airport since a Trans World Airlines jetliner, carrying mainly American passengers, was commandeered to Beirut in June by Lebanese Shiite Moslems. One American seaman was killed in the incident.

headline: 2 Journalists Cited for Works On 'Subversion of the Media'
abstract: Paul Anastasiades, a Cypriot journalist, and John Barron, senior editor of The Reader's Digest in Washington, have been given a joint award of $70,000 for ''the best investigative journalism into subversion of the media.''   The award was made by Sir James Goldsmith, a British financier and publisher who has an international food manufacturing and retailing group.

headline: 100 Lost in Bangladesh As Two Ships Collide
abstract: A ferry carrying 200 passengers broke in half and sank after hitting a fishing trawler, and as many as 100 people were missing and feared drowned, a newspaper reported today.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Allied-Signal Inc., Morristown, N.J., said it would include some chemical operations in the Henley Group, a new company it plans to form by spinning off about 30 operations.    * American Information Technologies Inc. (Ameritech), Chicago, said it had bought nearly 4.4 million shares, or 59 percent, of Applied Data Research Inc. at $32 a share, in its bid to acquire the company for $215 million.

headline: I.B.M. to Make Announcement
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation notified industry analysts yesterday to expect a ''significant'' announcement this morning, fueling speculation that the company was preparing to enter the supercomputer market.   Analysts guessed that the company's first product in the area could be an array processor that attaches to one of the company's new Sierra mainframe computers.

headline: CP Air, Nordair Planning to Merge
abstract: CP Air, which is wholly owned by Canadian Pacific Ltd., and Nordair Ltd. said that they had agreed in principle to merge for a $43 million exchange of stock. Under the proposal, Nordair's outstanding common shares would be exchanged for CP Air preferred shares valued at $43 million, or $17.57 a share, the companies said.

headline: Europe Security Talks Yield Some Optimism
abstract: The eighth session of the 35-nation European Security Conference ended today with both the Soviet and United States representatives saying they were optimistic about reaching an agreement.

headline: McGraw Deal On Ziff Unit
abstract: McGraw-Hill Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired some of the assets of the Ziff-Davis Publishing Company's Data Decisions unit, which publishes reports and newsletters on computers and communications systems. Terms were not disclosed, but a source close to Ziff-Davis said the price was probably less than $25 million.

headline: Deneuve's New Role: Symbol of All France
abstract: Parisians began voting today on which statuette of the film star Catherine Deneuve - traditional or modern, clothed or naked - they want as the new symbol of the French Republic.   The most popular statuette will replace a representation of Brigitte Bardot as Marianne, a traditional symbol of the republic that adorns town halls across France.

headline: American Medical Stake for Basses
abstract: Members of the Bass family of Fort Worth said that they had purchased more than 7.4 million shares of American Medical International Inc., or 8.7 percent of the shares outstanding.

headline: U.S. Envoy Arrives in Greece
abstract: A United States envoy arrived in Athens today for three days of talks with senior officials that are expected to concentrate on the future of American military bases in Greece. The official, Michael Armacost, arrived just hours after two cars belonging to United States military personnel were set on fire. No one asserted responsibility for the attacks but left-wing groups have made similar attacks and demanded that the American military bases be dismantled.

headline: FRANCE WANTS 2 AGENTS BACK
abstract: Defense Minister Paul Quiles said today that he hoped to arrange the quick return to France of two covert agents who were sentenced to 10-year prison sentences for their role in the sinking of the flagship of the antinuclear, environmentalist organization Greenpeace.   The agents, Maj. Alain Mafart and Capt. Dominique Prieur, officers in the French intelligence agency, pleaded guilty to manslaughter in the planting of mines on the vessel, the Rainbow Warrior, in the harbor of Auckland, New Zealand, last July. They were sentenced by a judge there earlier today, New Zealand time.

headline: Thousands in Colombia Panic in Volcano Drill
abstract: Thousands of people living near the Nevado del Ruiz volcano northwest of here, which erupted eight days ago, panicked late Wednesday night when the Government, for the second time in five days, ordered a sudden evacuation of the area.   As people rushed through the streets on foot and in cars, a close aide to President Belisario Betancur went on Bogota radio stations to explain that the evacuation was not in response to a new eruption but was merely a drill.

headline: A BATTLE FOR BREVITY IS WON, BUT THE BIG GUNS LIE AHEAD
abstract: Time is on everyone's mind as the United Nations heads into its final week of 40th anniversary celebration. And no one is more concerned about time than Jaime de Pinies, the President of the General Assembly.   As the man charged with persuading the legions of presidents and prime ministers who will address the General Assembly this week to keep to the 15-minute limit in their remarks, Mr. de Pinies has a delicate diplomatic task.

headline: PRETORIA EXPANDS EMERGENCY ORDER
abstract: President P. W. Botha declared a state of emergency today in and around this city, South Africa's second largest, and seven other areas.   In the last two months, more than 65 people have died in the Western Cape area in violent protests against apartheid. In Cape Town and its environs, at least 30 people have been killed in the last 12 days.   The declaration extends to this area an emergency rule imposed on July 21 in 36 of the nation's 265 magisterial districts. The extension was announced a day after Mr. Botha said that the emergency regulations would be lifted in 6 of the original 36 areas because they had effectively insured a ''return to stability.''

headline: Intel Manager Becomes President of Valid Logic
abstract: Valid Logic Systems Inc., a fast-growing manufacturer of computer-aided engineering work stations, said yesterday that Kenneth B. Fine, an executive at the Intel Corporation, had been named president.   Mr. Fine, who has been general manager of Intel's highly profitable microprocessor division, succeeds C. Richard Moore, who resigned.   Mr. Moore, who is 51, had held the post at Valid Logic for the last 13 months. The company, which is based in San Jose, Calif., said he had resigned to pursue ''personal interests.'' Securities analysts said the company has been stumbling lately in spite of an impressive track record.

headline: REAGAN AIDES CALL BILL VEHICLE
abstract: Key White House advisers are close to recommending that President Reagan support the House Democrats' tax bill so that the measure can serve as a vehicle for introducing the issue of tax revision in the Senate.   Administration officials said today that the emerging White House strategy would require Mr. Reagan to endorse the Democratic bill over the objections of House Republicans.   They also noted that the bill, which the Democratic-controlled House Ways and Means Committee finished drafting over the weekend, contains many provisions distasteful to the President. But by siding with House Democrats to secure passage of the current measure, Mr. Reagan can help get it into the Republican-controlled Senate.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Coast Thrift Unit Plans $500 Million Financing
abstract: The California Federal Savings and Loan Association announced plans yesterday to sell up to $500 million of fixed-rate medium-term notes backed by fixed-rate home mortgages.   According to officials at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, which will offer the notes as agent, the financing is the first of its kind by a thrift institution.

headline: REAGAN'S LETTER TO CRAXI
abstract: Following is the letter sent today by President Reagan to Bettino Craxi, the caretaker Prime Minister, as made public by the Prime Minister's office: Dear Bettino:   I'm anxious to see you next week in New York for the session of consultations which we will have with our major allies. I deeply value the suggestions you gave me in the past and appreciate your willingness to share your thoughts and your impressions while we approach my important meeting in Geneva with General Secretary Gorbachev.

headline: CHRYSLER RESUMES LOWER CAR RATES
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation said today that it was offering buyers 8.6 percent financing or direct rebates of up to $1,000 on many of its 1985 and 1986 model automobiles. The program begins today and runs until further notice.   Chrysler is the first domestic auto maker to reactivate the incentives device. A Ford Motor Company official said today that the company was studying Chrysler's offer and some form of response is likely next week. The General Motors Corporation declined to comment, but industry souces said today that G.M. is expected to announce a similar program by Monday.

headline: FOR 56 AMERICANS WAITING IN ITALY, SOBERING NEWS
abstract: They hung around Leonardo da Vinci Airport early today, gleaning snatches of news from reporters and trying to decide what to do.   About 56 Americans, passengers who had disembarked from the cruise liner Achille Lauro before it was seized Monday by hijackers, had been pulled out of bed at 5 A.M. and carried by bus to the airport, where two chartered jets waited to whisk them to Tel Aviv to rejoin the Achille Lauro.   They had left the vessel in Alexandria, Egypt, on Monday for a sightseeing tour of the Pyramids. Shortly thereafter it put back out to sea and was seized by four heavily armed Palestinians. The 56 were then flown to Rome by the cruise operators for the duration of the hijacking drama.

headline: THE LURE (AND THE LORE) OF ARGENTINA'S SUMMER
abstract: As the weather turns warm in South America, whatever the economic climate, one idea takes hold of most Argentines -it's time for the annual vacation.   This nation's summer season, and how it is spent, says much about the country's union rights, class system and convivial spirit.   In Argentina it is not only the rich who travel. The powerful unions made the summer vacation an egalitarian frolic in the 1940's by building huge seaside hotels for their members. Since then the Argentine summer season has become sacrosanct.

headline: Deal Is Seen On Tri-Star
abstract: Home Box Office, the largest pay-television service, is expected to sell a significant portion of its interest in Tri-Star Pictures to Columbia Pictures Industries, sources familiar with the transaction said yesterday.   Tri-Star's major owners are Home Box Office, Columbia Pictures and CBS Inc. Each company has roughly a 28 percent stake, with the balance held by the public.

headline: President Is Appointed By Encore Computer
abstract: The Encore Computer Corporation, a start-up company that has faced difficulties in bringing its new superminicomputer to market, yesterday named James R. Pompa, a former executive at Honeywell Inc., to be president and chief operating officer.   As president, Mr. Pompa, 47, succeeds Kenneth G. Fisher, Encore's 54-year-old co-founder, who remains chairman and chief executive. The chief operating officer's post is new.

headline: Police in Soweto Say Blacks Shot at Them
abstract: The police reported a rare gunfight with armed blacks in Soweto today, the huge black township near Johannesburg.   The police said in a statement that a riot patrol returned fire with shotguns after a police vehicle was shot at, and that three shots were fired from a crowd at troops, who were called in a year ago to help the police control unrest.

headline: COMMENTS BY 2 LEADERS: 'COOPERATION' FOR 'HARD WORK AHEAD'
abstract: Following are transcripts of remarks today by Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Reagan at a ceremony marking the end of the summit conference here, as recorded by the White House, which also translated Mr. Gorbachev's remarks:   Gorbachev's Remarks You've already been handed the joint statement. The President and I have done a huge amount of work. We've gone into great detail; we've really done it in depth. And we've done it totally openly and frankly.   We've discussed several most important issues. The relations between our two countries and the situations in the world in general today - these are issues and problems the solving of which in the most concrete way is of concern both to our countries and to the peoples of other countries in the world.

headline: U.S. Panel Drops Limits On China Nuclear Pact
abstract: Congressional negotiators, acting under strong pressure from the White House, today dropped a proposal that would have placed restrictions on the sale of American nuclear technology to China.

headline: D'Arcy Masius Benton Gets Managing Director
abstract: Thomas H. Carey, 41 years old, and a former executive of Benton & Bowles, has been named managing director of the New York office of the merged D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, at 909 Third Avenue, the D'Arcy crowd having bid a sad farewell to 360 Madison Avenue, the refurbished headquarters of Abercrombie & Fitch of sainted memory.   Additionally, the new international company has created an eight-man management committee made up of John S. Bowen, chairman and chief executive; Hal Bay, president and chief operating officer; Roy Bostock, Peter Redsell, George Simko, Craig Brown, Robert Lyman and Bernard Kanner.   A board of directors with 10 members from each company has been created and awaits stockholder approval.

headline: Green Party to Join Hesse State Government
abstract: The Green Party is entering government for the first time in a coalition that will govern the West German state of Hesse.

headline: Harassment Missile
abstract: The Boeing Company of Seattle received a patent this week for a naval harassment missile to be launched by a ship. The missile searches for a target such as a warship and then guides other missiles to the target. The inventor named in patent 4,553,718 is George T. Pinson, manager of the Boeing research center in Huntsville, Ala.

headline: SCHOOL BOYCOTT IS ERASING DREAMS IN SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: Each morning, the father said, he washes and dresses and heads off to work, leaving behind a teen-age daughter whose fate for the day he will not know until evening.   In normal times, the man said, his 16-year-old daughter would be at school, and he would not be so worried about her future. But schools and year-end examinations are being boycotted by many high school students in this great sprawl of segregated, black housing outside Johannesburg, so the concerns are different.   ''The doctors are saying the rate of teen-age pregnancy has risen tremendously because of the boycotts,'' said the man, an insurance clerk who works in Johannesburg. ''And crime will come, teen-age crime.''

headline: LOCAL ROSE 0.2% LAST MONTH
abstract: The Consumer Price Index for the New York-northeastern New Jersey region rose two-tenths of 1 percent last month, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday. The price of liquor, fuel oil, shoes and furniture increased, while food, electricity and gas prices dropped, The bureau's regional commissioner, Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, noted that the index has been relatively steady all year. He said the October rise was equivalent to an annual rate of 3.5 percent, while October 1984's rise was at an annual rate of 4.7 percent. Both were much lower than the 10 percent inflation rates of the early 1980's.

headline: ANGLICAN ENVOY LEAVES U.S.
abstract: Terry Waite, the Church of England envoy, left yesterday for London, stating that his mission to seek the release of four American hostages in Lebanon had moved ''a step forward.''   He said he had received ''personal thanks and support'' from American officials and believed the problem had moved closer to a solution.

headline: Interfirst Plans To Reduce Staff
abstract: The Interfirst Corporation, parent of the second-largest bank holding company in Texas, said that it would trim some of its work force of 10,200 employees in an effort to reduce costs. A bank spokesman declined to say how many jobs would be cut, but one analyst, who asked not to be named, estimated that it would be close to 1,000.

headline: STOCK FALLS ON TEXACO STATEMENT
abstract: The stock of Texaco Inc. fell yesterday in response to published remarks by its president that the company could be forced into bankruptcy proceedings if it were required to post a $12 billion bond to appeal a Texas jury's verdict against it in the Pennzoil case.   The remarks by Alfred C. DeCrane Jr. and a similar statement issued yesterday at the company's headquarters in White Plains sent the stock down $2.125, to $32.125, Texaco was the volume leader on the New York Stock Exchange with 8.6 million shares changing hands.   However, oil industry analysts, while agreeing that Texaco would not be able to meet a $12 billion bond order, viewed the DeCrane statement as part of its overall strategy of overturning the $10.53 billion jury judgment in favor of the Pennzoil Company.   ''I think it was done to make everyone aware that a bond could have an extreme impact on Texaco, and to emphasize that the judge can change the jury's award,'' said John A, Martin of the Provident National Bank in Philadelphia.

headline: AQUINO IN ASSURANCE ON BASES
abstract: The opposition presidential candidate, Corazon Aquino, said today to thousands of cheering people who live near the Subic Bay Naval Base that she would allow the United States to use Philippine military bases at least until 1991.   It was her most pro-American statement yet in the campaign for the Feb. 7 election, which President Ferdinand E. Marcos called more than a year ahead of schedule in an effort to prove he has public support.   President Marcos has accused his opponents of having Communist sympathies and of receiving funding from United States sources. Both contentions have been denied by Mrs. Aquino, wife of the assassinated opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr., and Salvador H. Laurel, her vice presidential running mate.

headline: BRITISH HOSTILE BIDS SETTING OWN STYLE
abstract: In recent weeks British television has been showing a 60-second commercial that tells about Alexander Elder, an Englishman who set sail for Australia in 1839 to seek his fortune. The spot ends with a deep-voiced narrator saying: ''Elders IXL. It's great to be back.''   Not everyone would agree - certainly not the management of Allied-Lyons P.L.C., a leading British beer and food company. Elders IXL Ltd., the far-flung business empire that bears Mr. Elder's name, has come ''back'' to England to make a record $2.6 billion bid for Allied-Lyons. The IXL part of the corporate name represents the Elders slogan: ''I excel.''   The Elders takeover attempt, which Allied-Lyons shareholders are now considering, is the most notable of a growing wave of aggressive bids for British corporations. Six of the ten largest takeover offers announced or completed this year have been hostile bids.

headline: Tin Trading Suspension By Exchange Extended
abstract: The British Government put pressure on the troubled International Tin Council today to end the crisis that has halted trading and threatens to collapse the metal's oversupplied market.   But the London Metal Exchange said trading will remain suspended next week because lack of an agreement to support the artificially high price of $11,900 per metric ton could bankrupt some brokers.   The crisis emerged Oct. 24, when the 22-nation tin council scrapped price-support operations, and the metal exchange halted trading in its tin contract. An emergency meeting of the council last month failed to resolve the problem and adjourned until Nov. 12.

headline: United Westburne
abstract: Westburne International Industries, a retail company that also has oil and gas holdings, said a group including management and employees of its United Westburne Industries subsidiary is offering to repurchase all United Westburne shares for $144.5 million (Canadian currency). The company also said the group includes Westburne International's chairman, John A. Scrymgeour, and president, Sam Abramovitch.

headline: 'TRADITION' IN A TRIVIA GAME
abstract: Question: During what holiday is gelt given to children?   Did you answer Hanukkah? Good, then move one square and roll the die again. Next question: What was Lee J. Cobb's name before he changed it to become successful as a stage and screen actor? Answer: Lee Jacob.   Nearly everybody, it seems, has an idea for a board game. But three Jewish women from Houston have actually marketed one on their own and it is selling like, well, latkes, which is Yiddish for potato pancakes.

headline: Midcon Suing Chemical Bank
abstract: The Midcon Corporation said yesterday that it had obtained a temporary restraining order in a suit against Chemical Bank of New York to prevent the bank from disclosing confidential financial information about Midcon to WB Partners, the partnership that is making a hostile takeover offer for Midcon.   Midcon's stock, meanwhile, moved up sharply in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, closing at $65.625, up $1.125.

headline: Hospital Corporation
abstract: The Hospital Corporation of America, the world's largest operator of for-profit hospitals, said Friday that its board had authorized the repurchase of up to $350 million of its common stock. The company, which has 89.8 million common shares outstanding, said that the purchases would be made from time to time on the open market and in private transactions.

headline: YOUR MONEY
abstract: CONTRARY to what many individuals thought, the Internal Revenue Service still requires extensive record-keeping to support tax deductions for the business use of a car.   When the rules regarding business use of cars were changed under the Tax Reform Act of 1974, a daily diary of business auto use was required. An outcry followed that and Congress repealed this requirement last May. This month, however, the I.R.S. published voluminous regulations requiring that drivers show some kind of corroborating evidence of their business auto use.

headline: UNDER MOSCOW SUN, GIRLS TRY SASHA'S SKATEBOARD
abstract: It was an Indian summer Sunday in Moscow. After weeks of unusually cold, rainy weather, even by Moscow standards, the sun took charge today. The gentle, warm breeze seemed to soften the hard edges of the Soviet capital.   Muscovites responded by heading out to their neighborhood parks for leisurely strolls, pick-up games of soccer or simply a few undisturbed moments sitting on a bench beneath the turning trees to savor the parting touch of summer.

headline: SOUTH AFRICAN RIGHTISTS GAIN IN VOTE
abstract: Right-wing parties opposed to the Government's policies of cautious racial change scored significant successes in five by-elections held on Wednesday, according to reports of voting results early today.   The results were expected to indicate how much white resistance existed to the Government's proposed limited changes in South Africa's policies of apartheid.   In Sasolburg, south of here, President P. W. Botha's National Party suffered a major setback when the far-right Reconstituted National Party, headed by Jaap Marais, ousted a National Party candidate to claim its first-ever seat in Parliament.   The extreme right-wing group, which wants to return to the traditional canons of apartheid, got 6,606 votes to 6,239 for the National Party candidate.

headline: Economic Scene;   Trade Talks: Threats Persist
abstract: THE Reagan Administration has finally got agreement on the new round of trade talks it has been seeking for the last two years. On Thanksgiving Day, the 90 members of the General Agreement on Trade and Tariffs agreed to start formal preparations for opening multilateral trade negotiations next September.   Speaking at an international monetary and trade conference in Philadelphia on Monday, Arthur Dunkel, Director General of GATT, said: ''We can now look to the future with confidence that the tensions which have bedeviled international trade relations in recent years can be resolved through negotiation and not through threats of unilateral restrictions on trade which would endanger the survival of the trading system itself.''   But many threats to the system remain. One is the challenge to the old industrial leaders posed by the emergence of Japan as the world's largest exporter of manufactures, surpassing the United States and West Germany. In total exports, Japan is now tied for second place with West Germany, with each country's exports in 1984 equal to 8.9 percent of world trade.

headline: Italy's Prime Minister Receives Mrs. Bonner
abstract: Yelena G. Bonner, wife of the Soviet dissident Andrei D. Sakharov, met with Prime Minister Bettino Craxi today and called the encounter an expression of respect for her husband.   ''One can only hope that my husband can enjoy in his own country the same respect as in Italy and in many other countries around the world,'' Mrs. Bonner said.

headline: PHILIPPINE AIDE SAYS DEFEAT OF REBELS MAY TAKE A DECADE
abstract: The Philippine Defense Minister said today that it would take at least a decade before the anti-Government insurgency could be contained, an estimate sharply different from one made last week by President Ferdinand E. Marcos.   The official, Juan Ponce Enrile, said he believed that the prediction by Mr. Marcos that the insurgency would be defeated in one year had been made ''to buoy up the confidence of the nation.''   He continued: ''The struggle will go on for a long time. It could be a matter of a few years. It could be decades. It will be at least a decade before the situation is contained.''

headline: EXCERPTS FROM INTERVIEW WITH KING HUSSEIN ON ISRAEL'S PEACE PROPOSALS
abstract: Following are excerpts from an interview with King Hussein today:   QUESTION: What is your reaction to Mr. Peres's speech at the United Nations and his specific proposals?   ANSWER: I feel that the spirit is what I had anticipated it to be, having watched his political actions over a period of time and having listened to his statements.   I believe he is a man of vision and a man who is acting with very strong feelings regarding the rights of future generations in our area and their right to live under conditions different from those we have known.   I realize he has enormous difficulties. One can only see him as a bright light in an area of darkness. This is not true for Israel as a whole, but one can see extremists at home whose views are consistent with those elsewhere who want to destroy the last chance for peace.

headline: U.S. IS REPORTED TO HAVE SENT AID FOR MALTA RESCUE
abstract: American antiterrorism experts were on their way here to help Egypt try to free the hostages aboard a hijacked Egyptian airliner last weekend but did not arrive before Egyptian commandos stormed the plane, Maltese and other sources close to the investigation of the episode said today.   The sources said Egypt had requested American technical assistance and advice at least 15 hours before the attempted rescue operation, during which 57 of the 59 deaths in the hijacking episode occurred, most of them apparently as a result of smoke inhalation from fire aboard the plane.   The United States promptly agreed to provide help, the sources said.      Landing Reportedly Barred   But the sources said the help did not arrive because Malta was unwilling to permit American military aircraft to land here. Protracted negotiations with the Maltese Government over conditions of entry, combined with confusion on the ground and serious gaps in communications among the parties concerned, kept the American technical team from arriving, according to these accounts.

headline: Italian Is in New York, Investigating Papal Plot
abstract: A Italian judge investigating the purported conspiracy to assassinate Pope John Paul II came to New York yesterday to interrogate a former Italian secret service agent who is in Federal custody here.   The judge, Ilario Martella, traveled from Rome to question the former agent, Francesco Pazienza, about assertions that he prompted Mehmet Ali Agca to confess that the shooting of the Pope in 1981 was ordered by Bulgarian officials.

headline: Knight Chain Net Falls 13%
abstract: Citing the adverse effects of the Philadelphia newspaper strike, Knight-Ridder Newspapers today announced a 13 percent drop in net income for the third quarter.   ''The strike at our two newspapers in Philadelphia has been quite costly and resulted in a drop in our net income,'' said Robert Singleton, Knight-Ridder's senior vice president of finance.

headline: Ex-Steel Chief In Pay Accord
abstract: Allen E. Paulson, who assumed control of the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation last month, has disclosed that he agreed to pay Dennis J. Carney, Wheeling's former chairman, nearly $1.4 million in 15 annual payments beginning next year. Mr. Carney would forfeit the amount if he goes back to work for Wheeling or for ''any business in direct competition,'' Mr. Paulson said. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission last week, Mr. Paulson also said that he would make a $73,710 retirement payment to Mr. Carney and buy about $34,000 in Wheeling stock with an option to buy additional shares before year-end. Mr. Paulson will also indemnify Mr. Carney up to $300,000 for any claims resulting from his employment at Wheeling.

headline: Multinational Clients Challenge the Industry
abstract: One of the chores of international agencies these days is to prepare for the expected increase of multinational clients by making sure that the agency's network of offices, which might previously have operated fairly autonomously, can now work together smoothly as a team and that there are enough offices in the right places to serve the multinationals.   Both those topics were on the agenda when Doyle Dane Bernbach International had a three-day meeting recently in Brussels.

headline: Shipyard Protest in Spain
abstract: Hundreds of shipyard workers blocked roads and railways today with blazing barricades during protest marches that marked the first anniversary of violent clashes with the police in this Basque port city over an overhaul program that had cut jobs and was designed to prepare Spain's aging shipyards for entry next year into the European Economic Community. The police said no arrests were made today.

headline: THE DOW PREPARES FOR LIFE AFTER 1,400
abstract: The 1,400 mark on the Dow seemed unattainable just a few years ago, but on Friday the industrial average closed at 1,404.36, 14.11 points higher for the week. Traders and analysts had mixed feelings about passing the milestone: Some said the rise just reflected short-term factors, such as takeover activity. Others said the increase pointed to strong economic growth; still others saw 1929 in every uptick. But the advance is impressive: It took the market more than 10 years to go from 1,000 to 1,100, but it took less than five months for it to leap from 1,300 to 1,400.   Paul A. Volcker helped the rally by repeating, in an unusually open manner, that the Fed was keeping a loose rein on monetary policy, apparently because it wants interest rates to fall even more. In the latest week, the basic money supply fell $2.2 billion. Bond prices rose moderately. Chrysler is regrouping into four divisions in a reorganization that will move the dynamic chairman, Lee A. Iacocca, farther from day-to-day operations. The new groups -Chrysler Motors, Chrysler Financial, Gulfstream Aerospace and Chrysler Technologies - will allow the company to more effectively diversify. Some analysts also said the reorganization may enhance Chrysler's stock by emphasizing that the company's business covers more than cars.

headline: U.N. ADOPTS RESOLUTION ON TERROR
abstract: The General Assembly unanimously adopted a landmark resolution today that condemns all acts of terrorism as ''criminal.''   Never before had the Assembly adopted a comprehensive resolution condeming international terrorism, and the vote taken today was praised as a step toward dealing with one of the most divisive issues before the 159-member United Nations.

headline: A DECK STACKED AGAINST SMALL INVESTORS
abstract: LAST week, the management at R. H. Macy & Company, the New York retailer, proposed to take the company private by purchasing each public share for $70 in cash. Though the deal had been quietly in the works for months, the executives disclosed their bid earlier than planned, after rumors of a buyout had suddenly lifted the stock $4 on heavy volume.   In mid-October, when a New York investment group offered $45 a share for the Beatrice Companies, the stock of the giant consumer products conglomerate had already risen $10 on a month-long spate of rumors.   Similar pre-announcement trading patterns have shown up in takeover or leveraged buyout offers for General Foods, Hoover, Richardson-Vicks, Pacific Lumber and Revlon. And in recent weeks, the stock and/or options of Avon Products, Freeport-McMoran, Gulf and Western and Westinghouse jumped prior to announcements that the companies would buy back some of their own shares.

headline: EUROPEANS SHUNNING SPOTLIGHT
abstract: Once again, Western Europe is being urged to serve as the locomotive of the world's economy, but its governments are balking, seared by the problems that followed the last time Europe accepted the global leadership role.   The Reagan Administration, the International Monetary Fund, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development and many policymakers and academic economists want European nations to step up economic growth by lowering taxes and increasing government spending.   Without greater vigor in Europe, it is feared, the slowdown from 1984's rapid growth rate in the United States will leave the whole Western economy growing dangerously slowly in coming years. That would make it harder for the United States to cut its trade deficit and resist protectionism. It would also hurt third-world exports and increase the risk of a new debt crisis, and it would push Europe's already high unemployment rate even higher.

headline: People
abstract: Kenneth Angel has rejoined BBDO as senior vice president and management supervisor.

headline: BURGER KINGS ON WHEELS
abstract: Beginning next month in Miami, the fast-food chain will roll out the first of 20 mobile restaurants. The daily goal of the gastronomic experiment will be to reach large pockets of take-out customers on college campuses, construction sites, industrial parks and military bases before they decide to eat elsewhere.   ''It's the ultimate evolution of the fast-food industry: bringing the restaurant to the people,'' said Stephen A. Finn, vice president and general manager of Burger King's new mobile restaurant division.   The roving restaurants mark one of the more innovative efforts to build high-volume stores at lower costs, while also meeting a demand for greater convenience, restaurant analysts said. Michael Culp, analyst at Prudential-Bache, said: ''It opens up a market that's not available with standard stores.''

headline: EXCERPTS FROM REAGAN INTERVIEW WITH BRITISH BROADCASTERS
abstract: Following are excerpts from an interview with President Reagan by the British Broadcasting Corporation on Tuesday, as made public by the White House today:   QUESTION. Mr. President, you are meeting with Mr. Gorbachev -it's only three weeks away now. Everyone regards it as crucial. What do you hope personally to get out of the summit with Mr. Gorbachev?   PRESIDENT REAGAN. I think that the most that we could get out is if we could eliminate some of the paranoia, if we could reduce the hostility, the suspicion that keeps our two countries particularly - but basically should we say the Warsaw bloc and the West - at odds with each other. And while I know everyone is looking toward and emphasizing a reduction in arms, this is vital and important, but I see reduction in arms as a result, not a cause.

headline: Standoff Near London Ends
abstract: Police officers threw stun grenades and stormed an apartment house near London tonight to end a 32-hour siege in which a woman was killed and a 4-year-old girl held at knifepoint.

headline: 2 Killers Hanged in Guyana
abstract: Guyana has hanged two murderers in the first executions in the South American country in 15 years, the official Guyana News Agency said.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 19, 1985
abstract: The Economy    The Administration expects the Senate to pass a tax plan next year giving greater incentives for business investment than are contained in the bill approved by the House, White House officials said. But Senator Packwood, the Republican chairman of the Finance Committee, said the Senate bill would not differ much from the House version. [Page A1.]  The House has asked senior House and Senate tax writers to pledge that some provisions will not take effect on Jan. 1, if a tax bill becomes law in 1986. The goal was to keep business activity from being disrupted while the Senate debates the measure. [B23.]      Companies    T.W.A. failed to resolve its takeover stalemate. The airline was unable to persuade its unions to consider an offer from Texas Air or attract other suitors. Unless something happens soon, a union official said, Carl C. Icahn could be left with 52 percent of T.W.A. shares but without full control as the airline's losses mount. [D1.]

headline: BISHOPS AT THE ROME SYNOD CLASH OVER ISSUING ITS PROPOSALS PUBLICLY
abstract: A major clash has broken out among Roman Catholic bishops at the extraordinary Synod here over the form and substance of the assembly's final documents.   The debate has become a test of supremacy between two competing views of the church among the 161 bishops.   Synod sessions are closed, but the shape of the dispute has become known through official news conferences and in interviews with those close to the proceedings.      Matter 'Is Completely Open'   The pivotal question is whether the bishops will issue a statement of specific proposals as well as a pastoral message.

headline: Weinberger Expects the U.S. To Have Laser Arms in 90's
abstract: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that the United States might have the ability to deploy an antimissile shield using ground-based laser weapons as early as the mid-1990's.   Addressing a seminar of West German and United States military officers, he said there had been breakthroughs in research on the Strategic Defense Initiative, or ''Star Wars.''   Experiments in Hawaii have resulted in a method of removing the effects of the atmosphere on lasers and showing that high-quality beams can be projected into space in any weather, he said.

headline: U.S. Insisting On Steel Pact
abstract: The United States is ready to take trade measures against the Common Market if negotiations with the 10-nation European bloc fail to produce a steel import agreement by Thursday's deadline, officials said today.   If a settlement is not reached, the most likely consequence would be a deduction of 100,000 tons of pipe from the Europeans' quota of pipe and tube shipments to the United States next year, said Desiree Tucker, spokesman for the United States trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: American Restaurants Corp., Ventura, Calif., which operates Wendy's and Pizza Time Theater restaurant franchises, said Robert W. Moses had joined the company as chief financial officer.

headline: New Lineup For Coca-Cola
abstract: The Coca-Cola Company has announced a realignment in its North American advertising agencies. Most of the realignment is under the Interpublic umbrella.

headline: Iraq Raids Kharg Island; Pipeline and Tanker Hit
abstract: Iraqi warplanes raided Iran's main oil terminal at Kharg Island on Monday, damaging a pipeline serving a main loading jetty and hitting a tanker, shipping sources said today.

headline: TAKING MEDICINE THROUGH THE SKIN
abstract: An electrically powered applicator that passes medicine through the skin into the bloodstream was patented this week by Dan Sibalis.

headline: Iraq Says Its Jets Attacked Iranian Targets
abstract: Iraq reported a string of attacks on targets in Iran and the Persian Gulf today.

headline: WHITE HOUSE SEEKS TAX DATA ON THOSE RECEIVING U.S. AID
abstract: The Reagan Administration plans to ask Congress for the legal authority to expand greatly the Government's use of confidential tax data and give Federal agencies direct access to information about the private insurance coverage of anyone in the United States.   Under the proposal, the tax information would be used by the Government to determine the eligibility of millions of people applying for such widely used Federal programs as guaranteed student loans and veterans' insurance.   The access to private insurance records would allow Federal agencies to make sure an individual was not eligible for privately financed insurance benefits before it paid a claim under such Government programs as Medicare.      Congress Expected to Get Bill    The Government does not now have the legal authority either to use tax information for such purposes or to gain access to private insurance files.

headline: ISRAELI CABINET DEBATES PERE'S PEACE PROPOSAL
abstract: Israel's fragile national unity Cabinet held a long and often acrimonious debate today on Prime Minister Shimon Peres's peace overture to Jordan, but the Government appeared to be in no immediate danger of falling apart over the issue.   A senior Cabinet official said that only if Jordan was to ''respond positively'' to Mr. Peres's offer would there be a real chance of the year-old coalition collapsing over how to proceed in negotiations.   Cabinet sources said two right-wing Likud ministers, David Levy and Ariel Sharon, led an attack on the Prime Minister's peace initiative, particularly his suggestion that the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council provide some kind of ''international accompaniment'' for the negotiations.   The Israeli radio said the Likud ministers left the six-and-a-half-hour session feeling Mr. Peres was not being frank with the Cabinet about the secret contacts now being conducted.

headline: G.M. Landmark
abstract: The General Motors Corporation's elaborate 15-story world headquarters building here has been dedicated as a national historic landmark by Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel. ''This building is important to the development of Detroit, to the nation and, in fact, because of the company it has housed, to the world,'' Mr. Hodel declared before unveiling a plaque on Tuesday.

headline: SOUTH AFRICA TOLIMIT NEWS COVERAGE
abstract: The Government plans to ban radio, television and photo coverage of unrest in 38 districts under an emergency decree in an attempt to cut down on violence, it was reported today.   The regulations, which are expected to be carried in the Government Gazette on Saturday, would ban television, still photography and coverage with sound equipment of unrest in areas covered by the emergency decree declared 60 days ago by President P. W. Botha. Publication would make the regulations effective immediately.

headline: HOUSE VOTE HOLDS KEY TO CHANGE
abstract: After more than a year of writing and rewriting tax legislation, of speechmaking, lobbying and political horse trading in the Treasury Department, the White House and Congress, the question of tax revision will come down to one 15-minute vote in the House of Representatives this week.   The consensus in the capital is that if that vote is not an affirmative one, the chance of changing the tax law in any comprehensive way will be nil for years to come.   ''If we don't move something out of the House of Representatives,'' Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d said in a television interview today, ''tax reform is dead.''   Before arriving at the conclusive vote on whether to send the bill to the Senate for action next year, the House will be allowed to vote on only one amendment, a Republican alternative tax plan that would be more favorable to business as a whole than either the plan submitted to Congress by President Reagan last May or the bill adopted by the Ways and Means Committee last week. All but a handful of Republicans will vote for the alternative, but, by the end of last week, not a single Democrat had agreed to support it. The Democratic majority in the House is so large, 253 seats to 182, that the alternative will surely be rejected.

headline: Occidental Stock
abstract: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation paid $86.1 million to redeem preferred stock it had issued to the financier, David H. Murdock, as part of Occidental's purchase of Iowa Beef Processors Inc. four years ago.

headline: The U.N. Today: Dec. 6, 1985
abstract: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 11 A.M. on complaint by Angola.      GENERAL ASSEMBLY    Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Political and Security Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Special Political Committee - 3 P.M.   Economic and Financial Committee - 3 P.M.   Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 10:30 A.M., 3 P.M. and 7 P.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Legal Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 7 P.M.

headline: Economic Scene;   China's Fight Over Ideology
abstract: YESTERDAY was National Day, the 36th anniversary of the founding of the People's Republic of China, and the Cantonese were firing off skyrockets and firecrackers, strolling and shopping, and eating up a storm.   The saying here is, ''The Cantonese will eat anything with four legs except the table.'' Or, for that matter, anything without legs. One of the local delicacies is called ''tiger fighting dragon.'' It is actually a combination of cat and snake.

headline: Six Experts on Soviet Give Reagan Briefing
abstract: As part of his preparation for his meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Geneva on Nov. 19 and 20, President Reagan had lunch at the White House today with six prominent specialists on the Soviet Union.   The White House said those at the lunch were William G. Hyland, editor of Foreign Affairs magazine, who served as a top adviser on Soviet affairs to Henry A. Kissinger when he was Secretary of State; James H. Billington, director of the Wilson Center in Washington, a specialist in Russian culture and history; Arnold L. Horelick, director of Soviet studies at the Rand Corporation, formerly national intelligence officer for the Central Intelligence Agency; Nina Tumarkin, professor of history at Wellesley College, an expert on Soviet internal policy; Adam B. Ulam, professor of history and international relations at Harvard University, and Richard Pipes, professor of history at Harvard, and a former Reagan adviser on Soviet affairs.   One of the participants said later that Mr. Reagan was ''very affable'' and listened intently to the presentations but asked no questions.

headline: Blue Bonnet Enlists Talking Cows for TV
abstract: In the wonderful land of margarine and butter, the only category that is showing growth is the one that combines the two. And that category was pioneered by a butter organization, Land O'Lakes.

headline: Careers;Negotiators in Demand
abstract: THE courts are crowded, but alternatives to litigation are emerging. Now arbitration and mediation are being taught in law schools.         Until recent years, law schools did little to teach these peacemaking skills. Arbitration involves the help of one or more third-party experts chosen to listen to both sides of a dispute and hand down a decision usually binding on both parties. A mediator, by contrast, acts to bring the disputants together and tries to help them reach a settlement, which is not binding.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Continental Air
abstract: A Federal bankruptcy judge ruled today that striking Continental Airlines pilots and flight attendants were not wrongfully discharged, and he dismissed $1.4 billion in claims against the carrier. Judge R. Glover Roberts granted the airline's motion for summary judgment on claims by the Air Line Pilots Association and the Union of Flight Attendants. Telephone calls to offices of both unions went unanswered yesterday evening.

headline: Wien Chapter 11 Filing
abstract: New Wien Airlines has filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Fedzation under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy code, seeking protection from its creditors for the second time within a year. The low-cost carrier, which flies between Anchorage, Seattle and Reno, was grounded on Friday after its operating permit was revoked by the Transporation Department. In documents filed Monday in Federal Bankruptcy Court, the carrier listed assets of $3.5 million and debts of about $3 million.

headline: Icahn's T.W.A. Bid Reportedly Revised
abstract: Carl C. Icahn and negotiators for the board of Trans World Airlines have agreed on a restructuring of Mr. Icahn's offer for the airline, sharply reducing the cash portion, a source involved in the negotiations said yesterday.   Under the new terms, shareholders would get $11 in cash and $13 in preferred stock for each share of T.W.A., instead of $19.50 in cash and $4.50 in preferred stock. The bid has been valued at a total of $360 million.

headline: Advertising;   Ally & Gargano Resigns From Polaroid Account
abstract: Ally & Gargano, for 15 months the Polaroid Corporation's domestic film and camera agency, has resigned effective Feb. 28 from the $30 million account rather than engage in a competition for a new product assignment to which all of the business is being tied.   The Ally shop won the Polaroid business from Doyle Dane Bernbach, which had worked on it for 20 years.

headline: FRANCO MATTEI
abstract: Franco Mattei, president of an Italian holding company, died today in Milan, the employers' federation Confindustria said. He was 66 years old.  Mr. Mattei, an economist, headed the Gemina company, which has holdings in Montedison, the chemical concern, and Rizzoli, the publishing empire. He was also vice president of Confindustria, the management association.

headline: HILLENBRAND PACT WITH BED MAKER
abstract: Hillenbrand Industries said it had reached a definitive agreement to purchase all the assets of Support Systems International Inc., a maker of wound-therapy beds, for $100 million in cash, plus contingent payments based on financial performance over a five-year period.   Support Systems, which is based in Charleston, S.C., had revenues of about $98 million for the year ended Sept. 30. The company makes a special bed of silicon-coated microspheres used by patients with burns, skin diseases, bone cancer or orthopedic problems.

headline: Algeria Rules Out Multiparty System
abstract: Algeria's National Liberation Front ruled out a multiparty system for the country and strongly denounced opposition groups in a resolution published here today.

headline: New York State Issue Has Top Yield of 9.10%
abstract: New York State is offering $160 million of general obligation bonds with a maximum yield of 9.10 percent for bonds reaching maturity in 2015, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.   Yields on the bonds, which are rated A by Moody's Investors Service and A+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, range from 5 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 6.85 percent in 1990, 7.85 percent in 1995, 8 1/2 percent in 2000, 8.90 percent in 2005 and 9.05 percent in 2010.   Because the state's credit rating is slightly higher than New York City's rating, and because the state sells far fewer bonds than the city, its new bonds yield about half a percentage point less than city bonds offered two weeks ago. The city's long-term bond rating is Baa by Moody's and BBB+ by S.& P. The state's offering is one of 43 tax-exempt bond sales totaling $3.132 billion that may be offered this quarter by the state, various state authorities and New York City.

headline: Turner Pessimism On MGM
abstract: Turner Broadcasting System has suggested that its heavy borrowing to acquire the MGM/UA Entertainment Company could cripple its ability to run MGM as a major movie studio.   In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington on Friday, Turner Broadcasting said that MGM's cash flow after the acquisition ''would be insufficient to fund new motion picture production by MGM or debt service by Turner Broadcasting.''   The filing also said that MGM suffered ''a substantial loss'' for the quarter ended Nov. 30, 1985.

headline: Potlatch to Reopen Idaho Operations
abstract: The Potlatch Corporation, a major forest products company based here, said it would reopen its Idaho wood products operations because wage and benefit concessions from the International Woodworkers of America union would save the company approximately $11 million annually.

headline: HONEYWELL'S STOCK JUMPS
abstract: Honeywell Inc.'s stock jumped $13.25 a share yesterday morning, reaching $86.50 at one point, on rumors that management was considering a leveraged buyout.

headline: ISRAELIS QUESTIONING ACCOUNT OFFERED BY EGYPT IN KILLINGS
abstract: Israel raised doubts today about Egypt's assertion that a demented policeman was responsible for shooting to death seven Israeli vacationers at a beach on the Sinai coast Saturday. Officials said the gunman may have been an Egyptian soldier, whose presence in the area would violate the 1979 peace treaty.   Egypt said a crazed policeman had fired on a group of tourists and on his own unit at Ras Bourka, a coral-lined beach 27 miles south of the border crossing at Taba. One Egyptian was reportedly killed before the gunman was captured.

headline: Market Place;   Foreign Fund Leads the Pack
abstract: GEORGE L. NOBLE has been buying Spanish utility stocks lately and adding to holdings of railway issues in Japan. But he views the Japanese securities market - whose capitalization accounts for nearly half of all stock markets outside the United States - as less appealing than that of certain other countries.   Describing his $104 million portfolio, the money manager said last week: ''I am overweighted in Hong Kong, the Netherlands, Italy, France and Spain. I am underweighted in Japan - price-earnings ratios appear excessive there - and in the United Kingdom.''

headline: 44% in Survey Want U.S. to Press Pretoria
abstract: Close to half the American people want the Government to take stronger action to press South Africa to abandon apartheid and want major corporations to stop doing business in that country, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.   Forty-four percent of those interviewed by telephone Nov. 6 through 10 said the Government should be doing ''more than it is now,'' while 37 percent said it should not do more.

headline: Buyout Cash Is Borrowed
abstract: Leveraged buyouts are an increasingly popular way for a company's top management to take it private, assure a larger ownership position and remain in  control. The buyout is leveraged because most of the cash that is used to buy out existing public shareholders is borrowed.         Oftentimes, the amount of permanent equity capital that is invested in a leveraged buyout amounts to only about 10 percent or less of the purchase price. The plan is that the loans will be paid back out of future earnings or, in some  cases, parts of the company are sold off after the transaction to repay debt. Once the buyout group purchases the shares, management is free from stockholder  pressures to perform for quarterly results and the company no longer has to pay  out dividends to public shareholders.

headline: Business and the Law;   Pennzoil's Huge Award
abstract: LAWYERS from coast to coast are wondering whether the record award given the Pennzoil Company in its suit against Texaco Inc. will stand up on appeal.   Because the award - $10.53 billion - is so extraordinarily large, the consensus in the legal community is that either the trial judge in Houston, Solomon Casseb, or appellate judges will find some way to overturn or reduce the award. But some lawyers contend that it will not be as easy to overturn the award as people may think.   During the four-month trial, the jury had to decide two questions of fact: Should an informal agreement - in this case between Pennzoil and the Getty Oil Company - be considered a binding contract? Did a third party - in this case Texaco, which ultimately bought Getty for $10.1 billion -improperly interfere with the performance of that agreement? On both issues, the jury said yes.

headline: Baldrige's Antitrust Campaign
abstract: Secretary of Commerce Malcolm Baldrige has stepped out alone on a couple of issues, such as his proposal to merge the Commerce Department and the special trade representative's office, and they have gotten nowhere. But he may be making headway with his campaign to relax the antitrust laws.   Mr. Baldrige argues that the antitrust laws are antiquated in that they were written to protect consumers from price-fixing and other monopolistic abuses in the largely insular American economy of the early 1900's. But American companies now compete in a much bigger world market, he says, and foreign competitors, with easy access to the American market, serve as a check against such practices.

headline: P.L.O. SAYS TUNISIANS REFUSED ENTRY TO EGYPTIAN PLANE BEFORE IT LEFT CAIRO
abstract: Palestine Liberation Organization officials said here early this morning that Tunisia refused entry Thursday night to an Egyptian airplane before the plane left Cairo.   Egyptian officials radioed from Cairo late Thursday night requesting permission for a plane to land without saying who would be on board the special flight, the P.L.O. officials said. Tunisian officials said they assumed the plane would be carrying the four men who hijacked an Italian cruise liner on Monday.   Palestinian officials here were trying to contact Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the P.L.O., who was in Senegal, but said that to their knowledge, the P.L.O. had no role in the effort to bring the hijackers to Tunis.

headline: MICRONESIA RESENTS A FAR LAND CALLED WASHINGTON
abstract: Capitol Hill in the Federated States of Micronesia is a wing of an old one-story hospital that was condemned long ago. The President's office used to be the pediatrics ward.   There are plans to build a new Government center in a more choice location a few miles away in Kolonia, but money is scarce and the necessary water mains and power lines exist only in blueprints.   So President Tosiwo Nakayama and the 14-member Congress make do in aging tin-roofed buildings by the coconut trees, hoping for the situation to improve. But then, they have become good at waiting, they say. When the United States is involved, they are prepared to wait without end.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    * Chrysler Financial Corp. is offering $400 million of 9.80 percent senior notes, due 1988, at 100, or 1.05 percentage points over the three-year Treasury note, through First Boston Corp. The notes are rated Baa-2 by Moody's and BBB by S.&P.. In a separate financing, Chrysler Financial is issuing 160 million Swiss francs of a 5 3/4 percent, 10 1/2-year Eurobond at 100 through Morgan Guaranty (Switzerland) Ltd.

headline: Poet's Mother Is Target
abstract: Soldiers tonight surrounded and tear-gassed the home of the elderly mother of Benjamin Moloise as she held a vigil on the eve of her son's scheduled hanging for the murder of a security policeman in 1982, according to witnesses.   The incident occurred as organizations and governments around the world called on the South African authorities to grant clemency to Mr. Moloise.   The witnesses said that about 300 youths began gathering at about 7 P.M. at the modest home of Mamike Moloise in the black township of Soweto, outside this city. Priscilla Jana, a lawyer for the condemned man, said that she had accompanied Mrs. Moloise to the house, where a message was waiting for Mrs. Moloise and her husband to go to the local police station.

headline: FAMINE RELIEF SHIFTS TO PERMANENT SOLUTIONS
abstract: A year after the start of an international relief effort for drought-stricken African nations, organizers are redirecting their efforts to solve problems that they say are at the root of the recent famine.   Although United Nations, United States and private agency authorities have expressed satisfaction that international aid helped saved millions of lives in Africa, they said they feared that declining public interest and the intractability of Africa's deeper economic problems would make their new task much more difficult.   Maurice Strong, executive director of the United Nations Office of Emergency Operations in Africa, said: ''Thirty-five million people were at imminent risk at the beginning of this year and 33 million of them are still alive. But we can only pause momentarily in our satisfaction. This is just the first battle in what will be a long and painful war.''

headline: A.M. NAMES NEW CHAIRMAN
abstract: The American Motors Corporation announced a series of executive changes yesterday, including the unexpected election of a new chairman, Pierre Semerena, who is a former vice president of Renault, the French auto maker that owns 46 percent of A.M.C.   Mr. Semerena fills a vacancy created when W. Paul Tippett resigned last April to become president of Springs Industries, a textile company. Mr. Tippett remains a director of A.M.C.      The directors, who met in   New York yesterday, also elected Jose J. Dedeurwaerder as chairman of the executive committee, replacing Mr. Tippett. Mr. Dedeurwaerder continues as president and chief executive officer. He was elected president and chief operating officer in January 1982 and has been chief executive since September 1984.      The board also voted to make   Joseph E. Cappy, executive vice president, the chief operating officer.

headline: Loews Adds to Stake in CBS
abstract: The Loews Corporation said yesterday that it had raised its stake in CBS Inc. from 9.9 percent of the stock outstanding, to 11.1 percent. The announcement revived speculation about the acquisition of the broadcasting company and drove its stock price up $6.125, to $116.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: LOWER FARES IN THE AIR
abstract: Hijackings, accidents and even hurricanes have created a downdraft on airline traffic - and, perhaps, on fares, too.   In September, after 12 months of posting double-digit traffic growth, the industry reported only 5.6 percent growth in traffic, says RoseAnn Tortora, an analyst for the First Boston Corporation. Traffic for October - and perhaps the fourth quarter - is not expected to show much more than an 8 percent rise, said Miss Tortora, despite good business travel.   With their flight frequencies already scheduled, carriers now face the prospect of some empty seats. And, says Miss Tortora, ''airlines have to fill seats when they are empty. If they haven't got enough volume, they'll lower the pricing.''

headline: Advertising;   D.D.B. Regains Piece Of Airline's Business
abstract: Jubilation time at 437 Madison Avenue. Doyle Dane Bernbach International, which lost the American Airlines account to Bozell & Jacobs in 1981 after 20 years of service and some brilliant advertising, just got its foot back in the hangar door.

headline: CITIBANK JAPAN BID DISCLOSED
abstract: In a bold bid to expand its presence in Japan, Citibank is seeking to acquire a Japanese bank, according to Citibank officials here. If the bank's bid succeeds, it would be the first foreign financial institution to take over a Japanese bank.

headline: COUNCIL ON FOREIGN RELATIONS: NEW LOOK
abstract: Changes have not always come easily to the Council on Foreign Relations, which after 64 years is probably still the pre-eminent American meeting place on international affairs.   In 1970, the Council opened its membership rolls to women, after difficult deliberations by its board of directors. ''The women won by one single vote,'' George S. Franklin, a former executive director of the Council, recalled the other night. ''Every member under 65 voted for the women. Every member over 65 voted against.''

headline: U.S. Steel Planning More Price Rises
abstract: The United States Steel Corporation today expanded its efforts to raise prices on key products, saying it intends to charge $40 a ton more for hot-rolled bar and semifinished steel.   U.S. Steel also said it was eliminating its formal list prices for the two product lines and would negotiate prices with each customer.

headline: MCFARLANE CONTENDS SOVIET PLAN INCREASES 'FIRST STRIKE' THREAT
abstract: The Soviet Union's proposal for a 50 percent cut in strategic nuclear weapons would increase Moscow's ability to launch a ''first strike'' on American missiles, Robert C. McFarlane, the national security adviser, said today.   Such an ability would permit the Soviet Union to ''coerce or blackmail our behavior during a crisis without firing a shot,'' Mr. McFarlane said on the NBC News program ''Meet the Press.''

headline: SECRECY BACKED IN EPIC CASE
abstract: In a ruling with Constitutional implications, a Federal bankruptcy judge ruled here today that the names of financial institutions that lent money to the troubled Equity Programs Investment Corporation be withheld from the public.   Equity Programs, a real estate company based in Falls Church, Va., disclosed in August that it had missed payments on more than $1 billion of its mortgages and mortgage-backed securities. Equity Programs has since filed for bankruptcy protection, and most of the approximately 100 banks, savings and loan associations and other financial institutions that lent money to the company have been seeking to have their names kept secret.   Today, Judge Martin V. B. Bostetter granted their request. The judge did not issue a formal opinion explaining his order, but he apparently agreed with lawyers representing the financial institutions who argued that release of the names would lead to depositor panic and heavy withdrawals.

headline: PRETORIA LIMITS FREED PRISONERS
abstract: The authorities said today that stringent restrictions had been placed on the activities of five men released from detention under the state of emergency.   They said it represented the first time that such former detainees had their movements curtailed without being criminally charged.   Under the restrictions, the men are barred from such activities as traveling outside of Johannesburg, taking part in various organizations, attending meetings where Government policy is criticized or discussed, assisting in any publications or entering schools.   Critics of the Government immediately denounced the action, charging that it effectively ''banned'' opponents of white minority rule and was further evidence that the authorities were using emergency powers to suppress all opposition.

headline: Burley Tobacco Crop
abstract: The 1985 burley tobacco harvest is estimated at 616 million pounds, down 14 percent from last year, the Agriculture Department said today. Production is down in all burley states this year except Missouri, the department's Crop Reporting Board said.

headline: G.E. Realigns Management
abstract: In a reorganization aimed at reducing its layers of management, the General Electric Company said that it would discontinue its four-sector arrangement as of Jan. 1 and have its 21 businesses report directly to a four-man corporate executive office.   G.E. said Tuesday that Paul W. Van Orden, 58 years old, the executive vice president in charge of the consumer products sector, would retain his title and join the chairman, John F. Welch Jr., and two vice chairmen in the corporate executive office.

headline: Real Estate;   Mixed-Use Growth in Manhattan
abstract: WHEN zoning regulations encouraging offices and apartments in the same buildings were loosened in 1982, the districts where the mixed-use projects could be built were extended from the original areas along 57th Street and down Fifth Avenue to most of midtown Manhattan.   Since then, several new buildings have been designed that incorporate both first-class office space and expensive condominium apartments in the same structure. They share the same foundation and framework but have separate lobbies, service cores and mechanical systems and otherwise operate as two separate buildings.   Developers hope that by melding the different uses they can heighten demand for undersized office buildings and spur sales of apartments in commercial areas.

headline: Deposit Relief In Maryland
abstract: More than 70,000 depositors in two ailing Maryland savings and loan institutions will be able to make withdrawals if they face extreme hardships, or can prove they need the money for ''necessities of life,'' under a plan approved today.   Gov. Harry R. Hughes, who proposed the relief, said applications would be processed swiftly by a team of 60 state employees.

headline: A Warnaco Buyout Backed
abstract: Warnaco Inc., one of the nation's largest apparel companies, said yesterday that its independent directors had approved a merger proposal from RLL Inc., a group of private investors headed by Warnaco's senior management.   The group has offered $27 in cash and $13 in principal amount of debentures for each of Warnaco's 10 million shares outstanding.

headline: A SWEET DEAL FOR NEW HIRES
abstract: ATTRACTING housewives, actors and students to work part-time in stores - not to mention bright, young college graduates willing to make retailing a career - is one of the prime concerns (some say nightmares) that retailers must face during the Christmas season. The merchants need to expand their staffs to handle the shopper bulge. Yet the relatively low pay, long hours and hectic pace are not exactly drawing cards.

headline: 11.26% Stake In Mercury
abstract: Mercury Securities said today that Reliance Group Holding Inc. of the United States, which is controlled by the financier Saul P. Steinberg, had raised its stake in Mercury to 11.26 percent, through the purchase of an additional 250,000 shares.   A Mercury spokesman said the purchase remained within the scope of the limitation agreement between the company and Reliance that was announced late last November.

headline: A 'Fire-Sale Price' Irks The Head of Sea-Land
abstract: In the years he served as vice chairman of R. J. Reynolds Industries and, earlier, when he held the same post at the General Foods Corporation, Joseph F. Abely Jr. was involved in a corporate takeover or two. But what is happening now is outside his experience.   ''We did takeovers at both Reynolds and General Foods,'' said Mr. Abely, who is now chairman and chief executive officer of the Sea-Land Corporation, a world leader in freight services and containerized freight transportation based in Menlo Park, N.J. ''But they were friendly acquisitions, and we did them in a somewhat different way.''

headline: SURGE IN STRIFE FROM LEFT AND RIGHT SLOWS COLOMBIA'S PEACE EFFORTS
abstract: In the last two weeks there has been a surge in fighting and right-wing terrorism in Colombia's long guerrilla war, signaling a further setback to President Belisario Betancur's efforts to bring peace to this country.   Guerrillas of the April 19 Movement, or M-19, have carried out 15 attacks including one in which they took over an entire town of 35,000 people and held it for nearly eight hours.   Paramilitary forces, said to be closely associated with Colombia's armed forces, are believed responsible for bombing the headquarters of the Communist Party and gunning down two prominent leftist leaders, one of them an outspoken advocate of Mr. Betancur's peace initiatives.   In the last few days M-19 has issued a series of threats to take over country clubs and public buildings and to kidnap executives of foreign corporations.

headline: JWT Net Falls 8.3%
abstract: The JWT Group reported third-quarter revenues of $135.5 million, up 9.4 percent from the $123.8 million for the period in 1984. Income, however, was down 8.3 percent, to $4.4 million, from $4.8 million. That comes to $1.21 a share, compared with $1.61.

headline: U.S. SHOULD HEED THIRD WORLD DEMANDS
abstract: THE General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade has provided a mechanism that has facilitatedthe phenomenal postwar growth of world commerce. But it oversees only trade in goods.   Services, now estimated at up to a quarter of world trade, have no corresponding international pact that defines rules and procedures that govern their trade. For half a decade now, the United States has led efforts to fill this vacuum. But, at the November 1982 GATT interministerial meeting and again last month at an ad hoc senior ministers' meeting in Geneva, important developing countries led by Brazil and India adamantly opposed these initiatives.

headline: SICILIANS WON'T PURSUE INQUIRY ON U.S. TROOPS
abstract: A Sicilian prosecutor said today that there were no grounds for a formal investigation of the behavior of United States soldiers after the interception of an Egyptian plane carrying the hijackers of the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro.   Sicilian prosecutors let it be known over the weekend that they were looking into possible crimes committed by United States military forces during a standoff with Italian soldiers at Sigonella Air Base near Catania, Sicily, on the night of Oct. 10.   But Dolcino Favi, the assistant prosecutor in Syracuse, Sicily, said by telephone that a study of an exhaustive police account of the 22 hours the Egyptian plane was on the ground at Sigonella found no cause to continue inquiries. ''Nothing emerged that would mandate a further urgent investigation,'' Mr. Favi said.

headline: WORKER DRUG TESTS RESISTED
abstract: Two court cases here involving an employer's right to test workers for alcohol and drug abuse are being closely watched by labor and management officials from around the country. The cases, along with a San Francisco ordinance that awaits action by the mayor, are at the forefront of a growing legal fight that pits an employer's need to ferret out substance abuse against a worker's right to privacy.   An initial hearing was held today in one of the cases, a suit brought by a computer programmer against her former employer, the Southern Pacific Transportation Company, charging that she was improperly discharged because she refused to submit to a urine test.   In the second suit, a temporary restraining order against a Government program that would test railroad workers was lifted today by a Federal judge.
