The suit is considered a key public-sector case that could affect airlines and other federally regulated transportation companies throughout the nation.

headline: A GIANT STEP FORWARD FOR TECHNOLOGY
abstract: SINCE the dawn of history, the promise of beating swords into plowshares has been an integral part of human culture. Mankind's hunger for weapons can spawn valuable non-military technologies, as our recent experiences show. The Manhattan Project to develop the atom bomb gave birth to nuclear power, and the construction of the American intercontinental ballistic missile force greatly advanced the development of semiconductors, high-speed computers and space exploration.   The Strategic Defense Initiative is the most challenging large-scale technology program ever conceived. Its potential for bringing advanced technologies into the commercial arena is equal to or greater than these past efforts.

headline: Armstrong Tire May Shut a Plant
abstract: The Armstrong Tire Company said that it may close its plant in Hanford, Calif., on April 1.

headline: Novelist Reported Ill
abstract: Francoise Sagan, the French novelist, has suffered a heart attack and is in a coma in a Bogota hospital, official French sources said.

headline: RUSSIANS WITH KIN IN U.S. ARE LEAVING
abstract: The Soviet Union has begun approving exit visas for Russians with links to the United States who were on a list made public by the State Department last month, American diplomats said Thursday.   They said one of the Soviet citizens, Helle Frejus of Tallinn, Estonia, who is married to Kazimierz Frejus of Pomona, Calif., was expected to leave the Soviet Union before the end of the week.   They also reported that a longtime Jewish activist who was not on the list, Aleksandr Rozman, received an exit visa recently and has reportedly already joined his wife, Jan Feldman, in the United States.   Also, Mikhail Iossel, a Leningrad resident who is married to Edith Luthi of Holliston, Mass., said today that he had received his exit visa and planned to leave the Soviet Union in early January after a brief stop in Moscow.

headline: ORDERS FOR DURABLES UP 0.9%
abstract: Orders to factories for durable goods, spurred by a rebound in military hardware, gained nine-tenths of 1 percent in November, their first increase in three months, the Government reported today.   The increase was viewed as good news by many analysts who said it could be signaling better days ahead for manufacturers. But military orders turned around in November, rising 17.2 percent. Without that, total orders would have fallen one-tenth of 1 percent.

headline: PATENTS;  Cancer Cell Antibiotic
abstract: An antibiotic that reduces the growth rate of two varieties of cancer cells was patented this week for the Kitasato Institute, a research center in Tokyo.

headline: Derailment Kills 13 in Sudan
abstract: A train carrying famine relief supplies and troops derailed in the southwest Sudan, killing 13 people and wounding 15 others, a daily newspaper, Al Ayam, reported today. A railway official said the accident in the Bahr al-Ghazal region was caused by faulty maintenance of tracks.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Champion International Corp., Stamford, Conn., a producer of paper and wood building material, said it had sold its distribution yards and industrial supply division to Michael R. Mastro of Seattle. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Mexico and GATT
abstract: Mexico has announced that it will negotiate entry into the General Agreement on Trade and Tariffs. The announcement was contained in a letter from Mexico's President, Miguel de la Madrid, that was published in the Government's official gazette and instructed the nation's Finance Secretary, Hector Hernandez, to begin the negotiating process. The Mexican Government made the decision in light of a weakening of its foreign economic relations and a trade deficit that has contributed to the country's indebtedness, the letter said.

headline: Macy and Woolworth Profits Rise
abstract: Two of the nation's leading retailers yesterday reported sharply higher earnings for their most recent quarters. R.H. Macy & Company showed a 36 percent rise, while F. W. Woolworth & Company gained 46.2 percent.      R.H. Macy    Macy said that net income in the fiscal first quarter, ended Nov. 2, rose to $42.7 million, or 83 cents a share, from $31.4 million, or 61 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year earlier. Sales advanced 8.9 percent, to $1.1 billion, from $1.01 billion.

headline: 4-Day Layoff At Control Data
abstract: The Control Data Corporation, which has been battered by the weak market for computers and peripherals, said that its entire domestic work force would be required to take four days off without pay by Nov. 30 in an effort to reduce expenses. About 40,000 employees will be affected.

headline: Blast Mars Opening Of European Meeting
abstract: The opening of a two-day summit meeting of the European Economic Community was disrupted today when a small bomb exploded less than a hundred yards from the building where the leaders are meeting. No one was hurt.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1985
abstract: The Economy    The President's draft budget proposes selling the F.H.A., which has provided mortgage insurance to more than 51 million American households since it was created a half-century ago. Confidential budget documents state that under the President's proposal, ''F.H.A. will be sold in its entirety as a single package, including all existing assets and liabilities,'' to ''private bidders'' in the ''private sector.'' [Page 1.]  House and Senate negotiators agreed on a 1986 Pentagon budget of $298.7 billion. Agreement was also reached on legislation to subsidize the sale of surplus tobacco to cigarette companies, bailing out the program that aids tobacco producers. [1.]    President Reagan plans to keep working to gain enough Republican votes to win passage of the tax revision bill. House Republican leaders appeared to be demanding concessions that, if given, could disrupt Democratic support for the bill. Mr. Reagan was said to have lined up 35 Republican votes so far. [33.]

headline: Market Place;   Singapore's Chilling Effect
abstract: THE bull market in stocks has assumed global proportions this year, thanks partly to the infusion of cash from pension funds and other investors in the United States. But foreign markets felt a decided chill yesterday with the weekend announcement that the Singapore Stock Exchange -the largest in Asia after Japan and Hong Kong -had closed indefinitely.   This action was taken after Pan-Electric Industries, a conglomerate whose shares trade on the Singapore board, went into receivership Saturday.   ''It was widely known that Pan-Electric was suffering financial problems, but the feeling had been that the central government planners, who tightly control the Singapore economy, would not let the company go under,'' said an executive at one firm that invests in foreign stocks. ''But it appears that the bank creditors pulled the plug, and that came as a surprise to the market.''

headline: MCFARLANE IS DOUBTFUL ON EXTENDING '79 PACT
abstract: The White House national security adviser, Robert C. McFarlane, said today that it was unlikely that President Reagan would agree this week to a joint affirmation with Mikhail S. Gorbachev to extend compliance with the 1979 strategic arms treaty.   A verbal ratification of the 1979 agreement is something that has been eagerly sought by the Western European allies, who hope for gestures from the American and Soviet leaders at the summit meeting to indicate that the arms-control process is being sustained.   But the disclosure of a letter by Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger urging Mr. Reagan to avoid making pledges to the Soviet leader on two key arms issues appears to have forced the Administration to sharpen some of its public positions more than it might have liked before the talks begin.      Reagan Visits Chateau    Mr. Reagan and Mr. Gorbachev are to meet for more than eight hours on Tuesday and Wednesday in the first United States-Soviet summit meeting since 1979.

headline: Advertising;   People
abstract: * Eugene P. Beard has been named executive vice president, finance and operations of the Interpublic Group of Companies.    * Philip M. Asche, Richard Kahn and Mark C. Linder have been promoted to senior vice president at Young & Rubicam USA.

headline: FINANCING U.S. DEFICIT ABROAD
abstract: In helping to finance the largest budget deficits in American history, overseas investors have stepped forward with large appetites for United States Government securities. Without them, interest rates undoubtedly would have been higher, and the economic recovery following the 1981-82 recession may well have been less robust.   Now, however, economists say that the delicate balance these investors provide is threatened by the new American policy that aims to lower the value of the dollar against other currencies. And the concern is focusing a fresh look at where overseas buying is coming from, how important it is and to what extent it might dry up if a lower dollar lessens the attractiveness of Treasury securities.   In the first six months of 1985, net foreign purchases of Treasury securities totaled $14.3 billion, more than 17 percent of all investment in new Treasury issues. As recently as 1980, net purchases for the full year were only $10 billion, accounting for less than 10 percent of the total increase in Treasury debt.

headline: GERMANY'S DIVISION IS 'INHUMAN,' SHULTZ DECLARES ON VISIT TO BERLIN
abstract: On the eve of his first visit to Eastern Europe as Secretary of State, George P. Shultz today attacked the postwar division of Berlin and Germany as ''unnatural and inhuman.''   He said the United States rejected the incorporation of Eastern Europe ''into a Soviet sphere of influence.''   Flying to this divided city, which has often symbolized East-West tensions, Mr. Shultz made a forceful restatement of the American position on an issue that has contributed to those tensions for 40 years - Soviet control over the nations of Eastern Europe that the Red Army marched into toward the end of World War II.      'We Will Not Be Bullied'    In a speech tonight, Mr. Shultz said the determination of the United States, Britain and France to remain as the protecting powers in West Berlin through the 40 postwar years was proof to the Russians ''that the democracies will stand firm against pressures.''

headline: BRAZIL'S BURGEONING ARMS INDUSTRY
abstract: BRAZIL'S new 40-ton battle tank, the Osorio, is being tested in the deserts of Saudi Arabia. Its Tucano trainer aircraft has just been adopted by Britain's Royal Air Force. And the first 10 Brazilian-made Astros II rocket systems are already being used by Iraq in its war against Iran.   That is not all. Last year, foreign defense attaches were surprised to spot Brazilian-made armored vehicles at a military parade in Peking. And last month, as evidence of the importance of the occasion, President Jose Sarney was on hand for the maiden flight of Brazil's new AMX subsonic jet fighter, which is being built in collaboration with Italy.   A decade ago, Brazil barely had an arms industry. Now, analysts generally rank the country as the fifth-biggest arms exporter in the world, after the United States, the Soviet Union, France and Britain. Most of its 40 client nations are in the third world, where it often competes successfully with the big powers, but some of its more imaginative military equipment is also attracting the interest of members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

headline: Philippine Army Kills 14 Communist Guerrillas
abstract: An army anti-insurgency patrol killed at least 14 Communist guerrillas in a gun battle on the southern island of Mindanao, the official Philippine news agency said today.   The agency said the soldiers clashed with a force of guerrillas from the Communist New People's Army on Saturday at Polanco in Zamboanga Province, 450 miles southeast of Manila.   There were no army casualties, the agency said, and the soldiers recovered assorted firearms and ammunition at the scene.

headline: PRETORIA HANGS A BLACK ACTIVIST
abstract: Despite international appeals for clemency, a black supporter of the outlawed African National Congress was hanged today in Pretoria for his role in the 1982 murder of a security policeman.   The execution of the black activist, Benjamin Moloise, 30 years old, set off rioting by hundreds of blacks in downtown Johannesburg. Two white policemen were stabbed, a black man was shot by security forces and at least eight white pedestrians were beaten on the city streets.   President P. W. Botha had received appeals from around the world to commute the execution, including appeals from the United States, the Commonwealth, the European Economic Community and the United Nations. The United Nations Security Council passed a resolution last year calling on the South African authorities not to execute Mr. Moloise. [In Washington, a State Department spokesman said, ''We have made plain our opinion that clemency in this case was justified.'' At the United Nations, Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar deplored the hanging, and the Organization of African Unity denounced what it called the South African Government's ''act of barbarism.'']  Mr. Moloise's lawyers had asked that the case be reopened because of new evidence that they said would have led to commutation of the sentence. Mr. Moloise was sentenced to death in September 1983 for the murder of the security policeman 10 months earlier.

headline: U.S. SEEMS PUZZLED BY SOVIET STANCE ON SPACE WEAPONS
abstract: A high-ranking Reagan Administration official said today that Soviet negotiators continued to insist on barring research into space-based defense systems although Mikhail S. Gorbachev has hinted that such research might be allowed.   In discussing the difficulties of finding common ground only a few days before the Soviet-American summit meeting, the official said ''it boggles the mind'' that the Russians were still ''playing from two sheets of music,'' being conciliatory in public and less so in private.   Mr. Gorbachev, in an interview with Time magazine in September and in a meeting with a group of senators, said the Soviet Union was not trying to ban research, but only the design of weapons in the program popularly known as ''Star Wars.''      No Change in Arms-Talks Stance    But in the Geneva arms talks, the American official said, the Russians continue to call for a ban on ''scientific research, testing and deployment.''

headline: SUDAN TRYING EX-AIDES IN AIRLIFT OF ETHIOPIA JEWS
abstract: Former Vice President Omar el-Tayeb of the Sudan and four officers of the dissolved State Security Service pleaded not guilty today to charges of helping smuggle Ethiopian Jews to Israel in a secret airlift.   A spokesman for the state security tribunal hearing the case said former President Gaafar al-Nimeiry, deposed in an April coup and now believed to be in Egypt, would be tried in absentia on similar charges later.

headline: Reynolds Closes 2 Arkansas Plants
abstract: The Reynolds Metals Company said it had permanently closed two of its primary aluminum plants in Arkansas.

headline: ADRIFT IN POLAND: 2 POLICEMEN, SONS OF SOLIDARITY
abstract: Once a policeman, still a nonbeliever, Zdzislaw Kledzik came by himself to attend a special mass for the police last week. It was held at the Warsaw church where the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko, a Roman Catholic priest killed by Government security police, once preached pro-Solidarity sermons.   Mr. Kledzik, a 49-year-old former riot police captain and Communist Party member, was retired after 15 years on the force. He was later detained for a year after he helped organize an embryonic police labor union during the Solidarity summer of 1981.

headline: BUSINESS WOLVES STALK HIS NOVELS
abstract: AS Louis Auchincloss sees it, things have never been worse. ''We've fabricated a society of wolves and coyotes,'' he said. ''Why does anybody think we're better than we were in the robber baron days?''   It is more than 30 years since Mr. Auchincloss, the 68-year-old writer and lawyer, began worrying about business ethics. Recently, with scandals exploding at military contractors, brokerage firms and banks, the rest of the world seems to be catching up with him. The Harvard Business Review is holding its second annual competition for the best article by a manager or executive on ethical problems in business. It appeals to men and women ''caught in the jaws of expediency and conscience,'' as the Review editor put it.

headline: MOST WOULD PAY 9% LESS TAX UNDER HOUSE PANEL'S PACKAGE
abstract: The vast majority of Americans could expect to pay an average of about 9 percent less in taxes under the tax-revision plan completed by the House Ways and Means Committee over the weekend.   Lower- and middle-income taxpayers would receive the largest benefits, according to Congressional estimates, while upper-income individuals could expect to receive only modest savings.   Largely because the House package retains a number of the most popular tax benefits used by the middle class, individuals with incomes of less than $75,000 could expect to receive an even bigger tax cut than they would have under the tax proposal offered by President Reagan last May. The tax benefits retained include the deduction for state and local taxes and the exclusion for employer-paid health insurance premiums.

headline: Greenpeace Says Ships Will Continue Protest
abstract: Five Greenpeace ships in the South Pacific are prepared to continue their protest against French nuclear testing indefinitely, a Greenpeace official said today.

headline: FOR SOWETO, THE HOLIDAY IS A MEMORY
abstract: At around noon today, on the Emmarentia Dam in Johannesburg's white northern suburbs, the wind stiffened a little and the windsurfers took to the water, to be carried some way by its embrace.   Elsewhere, in the same prosperous sort of area, a passer-by saw people sitting by private pools, caressed by the same breezes, celebrating Christmas. Across town, in this bleak ghetto, the wind seemed to bear different omens.   Christmas in Soweto this year, as in some other segregated black townships across the land, has been declared a ''black Christmas,'' a time when celebration has been deemed inappropriate because the residents feel there is nothing to celebrate, so gifts and greetings are not exchanged.

headline: TUNNEL IS A BAD DREAM TO ENGLAND'S CHANNEL PORTS
abstract: The outlook here under the fabled white cliffs is as gloomy as the English Channel in a lashing rain, for the notion is sinking in that this time the engineers are going to realize a dream they have kept alive since Napoleon's day.   It is the dream of what used to be half-derided as the ''chunnel'' and is now formally described in British and French Government specifications as the ''fixed link'': the channel tunnel or tunnels, or combination of tunnels and viaducts, that will finally join Britain to the Continent, symbolically ending its insular status.   Early in the new year, the two Governments are expected to announce a formal agreement to proceed with one of four privately financed projects for what the rival promoters have been hailing as Europe's greatest civil engineering project. Dover, the largest of the 16 British Channel ports between Plymouth in the southwest and Hull in the northeast, will die a little when that happens.   By the time - maybe five years from now - that the ''fixed link'' becomes a reality, taking most of the traffic that now moves by ferry or Hovercraft or Channel freighter, Dover and the other channel ports in England's southeast will have lost their reason for being. At least that is the despairing forecast of a loose coalition of ferry companies, local merchants, environmentalists and village parish councils throughout Kent's green countryside who consider themselves to be menaced by the project.

headline: Rumor Flood And the S.E.C.
abstract: OCTOBER 1985 will long be remembered on Wall Street as the month when the rumor was king. The stock of dozens of corporations rose and fell in frantic fashion as gossip of supposed merger deals whipped around the trading floors.   Some of the deals came true, like R.H. Macy's proposed management buyout. Most did not, leaving even the most professional of traders with a severe case of whiplash as they watched the rumors whiz by. ''There was a period when you just dove in,'' said one professional trader, who added that it did not matter then whether the rumors came true. Many of the pros, he said, survived by simply going with the trend - buying stock when a rumor started moving it higher and trying to sell the position before the speculation faded. ''The only mistake you could make was selling too soon,'' he added.

headline: INDIA A YEAR LATER: GANDHI LEAVING HIS MARK
abstract: The assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi a year ago Thursday stunned India and raised the question of what life would be like without the woman who dominated national politics for nearly two decades.         The answer, to the surprise of many critics and supporters of the Gandhi family, is that Rajiv Gandhi, her son and successor as Prime Minister, has put such a strong personal stamp on the Government that the memory of Mrs. Gandhi has receded.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    * ALC Communications Corp. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $50 million of senior subordinated debentures and 2.75 million warrants to purchase ALC common stock, through Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp.    * Branch Corp. has filed for $50 million of floating-rate subordinated notes, due 1997, through First Boston Corp.    * California Federal Savings and Loan plans to offer $50 million of floating-rate mortgage-backed notes, due 1988, through Paine Webber Inc.    * CDF Chimie (Paris) is issuing 900 million francs of 10 1/2 percent, 10-year bonds at 95.68, through Banque Paribas. The bonds carry a French Government guarantee.    * The Danish Finance Institute for Industry and Crafts is issuing 100 million marks of a capped five-year floating-rate note through Commerzbank A.G. Interest is set at 1/4 percentage point over the six-month London interbank offered rate for marks, with a maximum coupon set at 7 3/4 percent.

headline: VATICAN TO ALLOW INDULGENCES BY TV
abstract: The Vatican, in an unusual shift in Roman Catholic devotional practice, said today that Catholics who follow the Pope's annual Christmas benediction on television or radio will partake for the first time in the plenary indulgence reserved until now for those who were physically present at the service.   Indulgences are a release by way of devotional practices from certain forms of punishment resulting from sin.   A plenary indulgence, according to Catholic teaching, represents a total release from the temporal punishment still due from sin after the guilt has been forgiven. It is ordinarily conferred on the faithful who are present at devotional practices with the proper intention and attitude.

headline: MARKETING THE PROFESSIONS
abstract: ''WE had perfected one art for the first 65 years of our existence - the art of anonymity.''   Charles Kaiser Jr. was speaking about Pannell Kerr Forster, the Houston-based accounting firm of which he is managing partner. But he could just as easily have been referring to lawyers, doctors or the accounting profession as a whole.

headline: LETTER RULINGS TROUBLE I.R.S.
abstract: THE Internal Revenue Service is concerned these days about the increase in the number of private letter rulings appearing in briefs prepared by lawyers and judges in court cases. If such citations continue, the I.R.S. says, it may lengthen its review of such rulings, thereby reducing their number.   About 7,000 to 8,000 private letter rulings, or special advance rulings, on substantive questions are requested each year from the revenue service. Their purpose is to give assurance that a transaction under consideration can be completed in such a way that it will not be challenged by the Government. In effect, a private letter ruling is an insurance policy that offers protection to the individual or company that makes the request.

headline: SOVIET ACKNOWLEDGES A FEW CASES OF AIDS
abstract: The existence of AIDS in the Soviet Union was officially acknowleged for the first time today, although a Soviet professor said the number of cases was less than ''the fingers on one's hand.''   The professor, V.M. Zhdanov, wrote in an official daily publication, Sovietskaya Kultura, or Soviet Culture, that he had received letters from readers worried that AIDS -- acquired immuned deficiency syndrome -- had struck in the Soviet Union.

headline: U.S., Japan In Chip Talks
abstract: Japan and the United States agreed today to seek a ''realistic'' solution to trade friction over computer chips but did not discuss specific measures, a Japanese Government official said.   After meetings Tuesday and today, the two countries agreed that issues of market access, pricing of semiconductors and cooperation between Japanese and United States semiconductor manufacturers ''require a realistic solution,'' an official of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said.

headline: Protest in West Germany
abstract: West German anti-nuclear activists today slashed the tires of a truck carrying nuclear waste, the police said. The protesters blocked the road to a waste dump at Gorleben, 80 miles northeast of here, for about an hour before the truck proceeded under escort, a police spokesman said.

headline: REAGAN NOW OPEN TO FINAL CEREMONY
abstract: President Reagan is prepared to make a joint appearance with Mikhail S. Gorbachev and issue a separate statement at the conclusion of the Geneva summit conference next week if the two-day meeting yields positive results, a White House official said today.   On the eve of Mr. Reagan's departure for Geneva, officials said the President was now convinced that although the summit meeting would probably produce no substantive breakthrough, it could set the tone for American-Soviet relations and open the way for further meetings between the leaders of the two superpowers.   Within recent days, officials said, Mr. Reagan has expressed a willingness to appear with the Soviet leader and to issue separate statements with him in a ceremony at the end of the conference on Wednesday. Mr. Reagan is scheduled to leave Geneva on Thursday, stop off in Brussels to discuss the conference with European leaders and return to Washington that night in time to deliver an address before a joint meeting of Congress.      Communique Virtually Ruled Out   Although Mr. Reagan and ranking Administration officials have virtually rejected the possibility of a joint communique at the end of the conference, an official made it clear today that Mr. Reagan was hoping to appear with Mr. Gorbachev, so long as their talks proved amicable and paved the way for possible future summit meetings.

headline: Special Session Set By Evening News
abstract: The president and directors of the Evening News Association have recommended that shareholders approve the proposed takeover by the Gannett Company at a special meeting Dec. 20. The special meeting was included in a proxy statement mailed to shareholders by Peter B. Clark, Evening News Association president and publisher of The Detroit News.

headline: BUSINESSES PLAN LESS SPENDING IN '86
abstract: In what may be an ominous sign for the economy, a Government survey predicted today that American businesses will cut back on investment spending by 1 percent in 1986.   The Reagan Administration called the survey's findings too pessimistic and some private economists agreed. However, others said business investment is likely to be sluggish at least through the first half of next year as industry continues to suffer from intense foreign competition.

headline: MIDEAST ATTACK AND REPLY
abstract: A note carried by one of the gunmen in the airport attack in Rome indicated that the assault and the one at the Vienna airport were part of a cycle of attack and reprisal in the Middle East in recent months. Here are the key events in this string of attacks: Sept. 25 - A Briton and two Palestinians commandeer a yacht moored in the harbor of Larnaca, Cyprus, and kill the three Israelis aboard.

headline: Pillsbury German Snag
abstract: The Pillsbury Company's proposed acquisition of Sonnen-Bassermann, a West German food concern, has been rejected by an antitrust court in West Berlin. The court on Friday upheld a ruling last March by West Germany's Federal Cartel Office, which rejected the acquisition on the ground that it would give Pillsbury an anti-competitive share - about 35 percent - of the West German packaged-food market.

headline: Ziff Said to Seek Sale of Division
abstract: The Ziff Corporation is putting its Financial Information Services Group up for sale, a source close to the negotiations said yesterday. The sale, which would be handled by Kidder, Peabody & Company, the investment house, could bring as much as $50 million, according to a source close to the company.

headline: IN QUOTES
abstract: ''You will watch the damnedest array of filibusters you can ever imagine on every single issue. Oil and gas, real estate - go through the whole stack, because our rules allow that.''      Senator Alan K. Simpson   Republican of Wyoming on tax bill's Senate prospects

headline: Stocks End Mixed; Volume Climbs
abstract: The stock market ended mixed yesterday after a wave of selling of hospital-management issues erased a strong advance.   The Dow Jones industrial average ended 7.28 points lower at 1,333.67, but advancing stocks edged ahead of declining issues by 778 to 755.   Volume on the New York Stock Exchange climbed to 147.3 million shares, from 130.2 million the day before. This was the highest turnover since July 17, when 159.9 million shares changed hands.

headline: ADDING CLASS TO PRE-MIXED DRINKS
abstract: A LOT of soul searching went on last year at the Chicago headquarters of the James B. Beam Distilling Company. The question was, would putting the 190-year-old distiller's flagship brand, Jim Beam bourbon, into a canned, pre-mixed cocktail do violence to the product's image?   The answer, finally, was no, and ''Jim Beam and Cola'' was born. ''We did a lot of research to make ourselves feel better about it,'' said G. Lane Barnett, vice president of marketing and advertising. ''What really prompted us to do it was the trend toward lighter, sweeter-tasting, lower-alcohol beverages,'' such as light beer and wine coolers, Mr. Barnett said. ''We're chumming for new drinkers.''

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 26, 1985
abstract: The Economy    The President's advisers may ask him to support the tax bill as a vehicle for introducing the issue of tax revision in the Senate. Administration officials said the President could make such an endorsement even though he and House Republicans object to many provisions of the bill. In the Senate, according to White House officials supporting this strategy, the Republican leadership may be able to produce a bill closer to the President's original plan. [Page D1.]  Big businesses expressed opposition to the bill, saying it could stifle capital spending and weaken the economy. [D1.]  Middle-class taxpayers would fare somewhat better under the Ways and Means package than under the plan proposed by President Reagan. [D27.]      Companies    Executives of National Gypsum offered to buy the supplier of building products for about $1.1 billion in cash and securities. Traders valued the deal at about $50 a share. Gypsum shares climbed $2.75 in heavy trading, to $46.75. [D1.]

headline: Stocks Plunge In Singapore
abstract: Prices plunged in frantic selling on the Singapore and Kuala Lumpur stock exchanges today as trading reopened after a three-day halt.

headline: 40 SALVADOR SOLDIERS KILLED BY REBELS
abstract: Leftist rebels killed at least 40 Salvadoran soldiers and wounded 68 in a lightning raid before dawn today on the main training base for Government recruits near this coastal town.   The raid was the most damaging guerrilla action against Government forces this year and one of the few large attacks in the last year and a half. It suggested that the guerrillas still have the ability to carry out well-planned hit-and-run actions at a time when their military fortunes have otherwise seemed to be slipping.   Despite warnings of possible rebel attack, security at the base appears to have been lax. Guerrilla squads penetrated the perimeter and dropped grenades into barracks of sleeping troops, according to three different accounts by soldiers who said they had fought off attackers. From about 100 yards away, other rebels fired 90-millimeter recoilless rifle rounds, RPG-7 rockets and mortars point-blank into the tin-sheeted barracks. #5 U.S. Advisers at Base Five American military advisers were at the base during the attack, according to James Williams, a spokesman for the United States Embassy. None of the Americans were hurt, he said, adding that he ''believed'' the advisers had not taken part in the fighting, but that he could not confirm that they had not.

headline: A SOVIET ARMS IDEA INTERESTS THE U.S.
abstract: The Reagan Administration's senior arms control adviser expressed interest today in a recent Soviet proposal for an interim agreement on medium-range missiles that would freeze American and Soviet missiles in Europe and Asia.   Paul H. Nitze, who advises President Reagan and Secretary of State George P. Shultz, repeated the United States' overall criticism of the proposals outlined by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, in Paris earlier this month and later amplified at the Geneva arms control negotiations.   But Mr. Nitze noted that the Soviet Union had offered to separate the medium-range talks from the two other parts of the Geneva negotiations, on strategic, or long-range, weapons, and on space-based defenses.      U.S. Sought to Separate Issues    The United States has long sought to separate the issues because Moscow was linking progress in the strategic and medium-range talks to an end of the American space-based program.

headline: District Banking Bill Vetoed
abstract: District of Columbia Mayor Marion Barry Jr. today vetoed a bill that would have cleared the way for banks in the nation's capital to merge with banks in 11 states.   ''I take this extraordinary action because the bill does not include provisions that are essential to maximize the benefits of interstate banking for individual and business consumers of banking services and underserved neighborhoods in the District of Columbia,'' Mr. Barry said in a letter to the chairman of the City Council, David Clarke.

headline: A.T.&T. Seeks Rate Changes
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company today proposed increasing rates for private business circuits by $290 million a year, effective Jan. 2, and said it would soon lower the price of international phone calls by $150 million a year.   The private-line change, which is subject to approval by the Federal Communications Commission, would amount to a 7 percent increase in a business customer's total monthly bill for long-distance private lines.

headline: A NEW CHIEF PUSHES TO KEEP HIS COMPANY INDEPENDENT
abstract: AS a Navy flier in the 1950's, Joseph J. Kroger's idea of fun was to fly up to Manhattan at night on practice runs from his base in Atlantic City, swoop in low along the Hudson River and make forbidden passes under the George Washington Bridge.   Now, at age 51, Mr. Kroger gets his kicks driving fast cars, including his Porsche 911 and his BMW 745. He only recently sold his Honda 750 motorcycle ''because I finally came to the conclusion that somebody was going to kill me on it.''   Then again, Mr. Kroger may no longer need a motorcycle to provide the sort of daredevil risks on which he seems to thrive. As the new president and chief operating officer of the Sperry Corporation, he is involved in about as uncertain an undertaking as corporate America can offer. Sperry, a pioneer manufacturer of mainframe computers in the postwar years, is embroiled in a catch-up effort to find new electronic products that will restore its competitiveness and assure its survival as an independent company.

headline: GENEVA CEREMONY LIVE ON SOVIET TV
abstract: Soviet television broke into normal programming at noon today for a live broadcast from Geneva of the joint appearance of President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev.   The broadcast, which was unusual for a television system that generally avoids anything unpredictable or spontaneous, showed Mr. Reagan commenting, through a Russian voice-over translation, on his meetings with Mr. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.   The broadcast included the signing of a new cultural exchange agreement by Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the Soviet Foreign Minister.

headline: G.M. AND FIAT HOLD TALKS ON VENTURE
abstract: The General Motors Corporation and Fiat S.p.A., the big Italian auto company, are conducting negotiations on a possible combined venture, a spokesman for G.M. said today. He added that the talks, however, did not involve joint production of automobiles.   ''There have been discussions between G.M. and Fiat regarding possible business arrangements in non-automotive areas,'' said Jack R. Harned, a G.M. spokesman. The company declined to specify the areas, but there was speculation in the auto industry that the two companies might pool technology in the production of automated manufacturing equipment.

headline: Request for Delay In MGM/UA Deal
abstract: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. announced that it had asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to delay the processing of the three registration statements that Turner filed in connection with its acquisition of the MGM/UA Entertainment Company. The S.E.C. deferral was requested so that Turner could reflect a transaction with Viacom International Inc. in amended filings.   As previously announced, negotiations had begun on Viacom's possible acquisition of a 50 percent interest in one or more of the assets and businesses of MGM to be acquired by Turner in the MGM/UA merger.

headline: Coffee Rises Sharply On Earthquake Rumor
abstract: Coffee futures prices soared yesterday on a false rumor that an earthquake in Colombia had damaged growing areas there.   The contract for delivery in March shot up 17 cents a pound on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York, before dropping a few cents on profit taking.

headline: ITALIAN COALITION FALLS APART OVER THE ACHILLE LAURO AFFAIR
abstract: The five-party coalition of Prime Minister Bettino Craxi collapsed Wednesday night, and Mr. Craxi was expected to resign today.   The small Republican Party led by Defense Minister Giovanni Spadolini withdrew from the coalition to protest the Government's handling of the hijacking of the cruise liner Achille Lauro and the release of a Palestinian leader sought by the United States.   Mr. Spadolini announced Wednesday afternoon that he and the two other Republicans in the Cabinet had submitted their resignations to Mr. Craxi, a Socialist.      Move Touches Off Meetings    Mr. Spadolini's announcement set off a storm of reaction and late-night meetings among the coalition partners. Besides the Republicans and the Socialists, the Cabinet consists of the Christian Democrats, Italy's largest party, and the small Liberal and Social Democratic Parties. In theory, the Government would command a small majority in Parliament without the Republicans, but it seemed unlikely that the coalition could carry on.

headline: AND LOOK WHAT BEFELL PINIES ON WAY TO WORK
abstract: Traffic traps and security snarls have been among the most noted aspects of the United Nations commemorative session, and today even rank and connections did not spare some people.   At 9:30 this morning, a security check at the 42d Street staff entrance caused a line of about 150 employees waiting to enter. Spotted in the middle of the crowd, his identification tag dangling from his lapel, was Robert G. Muller, the Assistant Secretary General in charge of preparations for the 40th anniversary.   A similar fate befell the President of the General Assembly, Jaime de Pinies. Just before 9 o'clock this morning policemen stopped his car at the corner of 46th Street and Second Avenue and informed the driver that he could not proceed. Mr. de Pinies, who according to an aide was ''in good humor,'' got out of the car and said to the officers, ''No President, no show.''

headline: Spot Silver Prices Jump On Rports of Hunt Sale
abstract: Silver prices jumped a sharp 5.5 percent yesterday on reports that the Hunt family of Texas had completed selling about 59 million ounces of the silver it acquired on a speculative binge in the late 1970's.   On the Commodity Exchange, or Comex, the spot price of silver rose 33.5 cents an ounce, to $6.385, in moderately active trading. That was the biggest one-day move on the silver market since March 19, according to the exchange. In sympathy, gold prices also bounced higher, gaining $5.70 an ounce on the Comex, to $329.90.

headline: A Chevron Sale
abstract: The Chevron Corporation said it had agreed to sell its interest in the Bluebell-Altamont oil-producing fields in eastern Utah for $360 million to Proven Properties Inc. of Houston. Chevron said in May that it was soliciting bids in its continuing effort to pay off the long-term debt incurred in the acquisition of the Gulf Corporation last year. The Pennzoil Company owns 49 percent of Proven Properties.

headline: Pretoria Debt Action
abstract: The Government may try to extend a four-month freeze on foreign debt repayments to international banks at scheduled talks on Wednesday, bankers said today. South Africa imposed the moratorium unilaterally in September when foreign lenders refused more credit because of the political unrest over the policy of apartheid.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    * Citicorp sold $50 million of 91-day commercial paper at an average rate of 7.827 percent, up from 7.799 percent last week, and $50 million of 182-day paper at an average rate of 7.731 percent, up from 7.695 percent.    * General Motors Acceptance Corp. is issuing 75 billion lire of 13 1/4 percent Eurobonds due in 1990 at par through underwriters led by Bank of America International.    * International Harvester Co. is offering $150 million (up from $100 million) of 14 1/2 percent senior sinking fund debentures due in 2001 at 100 through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers; the debentures are rated B-3 by Moody's and B by S.&P. Also offered are 100,000 units for International Harvester Credit, a subsidiary, with each unit priced at $1,000 and consisting of one 11.95 percent senior subordinated debenture due in 1995 and 40 seven-year warrants to buy Harvester common at $2.25 a share; the units are rated B-3 by Moody's and CCC by S.&P.    * J. P. Morgan & Co. is issuing $200 million of 12-year floating-rate notes at a price of 100.10 through Morgan Guaranty Ltd.; interest is set at five-hundredths percentage point above the three-month London interbank offered rate.

headline: SOVIET BLOC MEETS IN BULGARIA TODAY
abstract: Mikhail S. Gorbachev and other Soviet leaders left today for a Warsaw Pact meeting in Sofia, Bulgaria, the Government press agency Tass said.         The meeting of the seven-nation pact's Political Consultative Committee is expected to endorse Soviet arms proposals in advance of Mr. Gorbachev's meeting with President Reagan in Geneva next month.

headline: Inquiry Over, Hughes Says
abstract: The Hughes Aircraft Company said today that a Federal grand jury had dropped its investigation into charges that the company had paid a $1 million bribe to a Saudi Arabian businessman in order to win a $1.8 billion contract with the Royal Saudi Air Force in 1981.   The United States Attorney's office informed the company today that the investigation had been dropped, Michael Murphy, a Hughes spokesman, said.

headline: U.S. Officials in Hanoi Seeking Missing Soldiers
abstract: American military officials arrived in Hanoi today to discuss the fate of American servicemen listed as missing in action in Vietnam and to excavate the crash site of a B-52 bomber in the first such joint effort of the United States and Vietnam.   The excavation at the site of the crash in 1972 will begin Monday, but will be preceded by talks aimed at locating other areas where remains of Americans may be found.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM SHULTZ REMARKS ON AID TO REBELS
abstract: Following are excerpts from Secretary of State George P. Shultz's speech today to the Pilgrims Society here:   I want to address an issue that has been on my mind for some time, on which we and our European friends have occasionally had tactical differences. And that is the relation between power and diplomacy.   Negotiated solutions require two things. First, we, or the friends we support, must be willing to negotiate a fair solution. Whether we speak of Israel, or our friends in Central America, or in Africa, or Southwest or Southeast Asia, we or our friends must pursue negotiation and compromise in good faith and with dedication. Such an attitude strengthens moderates on the other side, helps defuse radicalism and offers hope for a solution.

headline: Arco Note Sale Of $350 Million
abstract: The Atlantic Richfield Company yesterday began offering $350 million of notes, divided into maturities of four years and 10 years, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.   A $200 million Arco issue of non-callable 9 3/4 percent notes due in 1989 was offered at a price of 99, to yield 9.825 percent, while $150 million of 10 1/2 percent notes due in 1995 was priced at 99 1/4, to yield 10.622 percent. The 10-year issue is not callable for seven years.   Both issues are rated Aa-3 by Moody's and AA- by S.&P.

headline: POLISH AIDE SAYS TURNOUT WAS 78%
abstract: A Government spokesman said today that election figures from Sunday indicated that voters had ''boycotted the boycott'' called for by the Solidarity opposition.   Lech Walesa, the Solidarity founder, disputed both the Government's data and the interpretation.   The Government spokesman, Jerzy Urban, said that incomplete returns showed that 78 percent of the 26 million eligible voters had cast ballots, a slight increase over the 75 percent participation in local elections last year.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Nov. 11, 1985.                           MONDAY Amer Broadcast'g         Meredith Crop Fischbach Corp           Pitney-Bowes Gifford-Hill & Co                      TUESDAY AMF Inc                  McDermott Intl Cleveland-Cliffs Inc     Mickelberry Corp Hammermill Paper         RepublicBank Corp Household Intl Inc       Robertson (HH) Co Intl Paper Co            Sears Roebuck & Co Inter North Inc          Staley Contl Inc Kellogg Co               Triton Energy Kerr-McGee Corp          Tyco Labs                     WEDNESDAY Advest Group             Marion Laboratories                          North American Coal Colt CBS Inc                  Industries Quaker Oats              Esselte Business Sys USG Corp                 Gerber Products Unifirst Corp                     THURSDAY Cooper Tire & Rubber     Maytag Co First City Bncrptn       TX Sabine Corp First Fidelity Bncrptn   Singer Co Manhattan Industries     Stop & Shop Cos MAPCO Inc                      FRIDAY Barnes Group             Global Marine Inc Chelsea Industries       K N Energy Clark Equipment          Revco D S Inc Control Data             Reynolds Metals Dominion Res-VA          Texas Utilities Donaldson Co             Wel-Mart Stores

headline: BRITAIN CONFIRMS ITS PLAN TO QUIT A 'HARMFULLY POLITICALIZED UNESCO
abstract: Britain, which 40 years ago was one of the key founders of Unesco, will withdraw from the 160-member organization at the end of this year, the Government told the House of Commons today.   Timothy Raison, the Overseas Aid Minister, made the announcement, charging that the agency, the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, is inefficient and badly managed and has been ''harmfully politicized.'' It ''has been used to attack those very values which it was designed to uphold, '' he said.      Gave Notice a Year Ago   Last December, the British served notice, as required by law, of their intention to withdraw from Unesco, complaining about what they viewed as an anti-Western stance. They also complained that Unesco spends 70 percent of its budget at its Paris headquarters, rather than in the field. But until today, the British had left open the possibility they would change their minds if Unesco made major changes.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: * Biotechnica Diagnostics, Cambridge, Mass., a subsidiary of Biotechnica International Inc., has named Richard L. Dalton president.

headline: Midwest Energy
abstract: The Midwest Energy Company, an electric and gas company based in Sioux City,  Iowa, said that it had agreed to acquire the Donovan Companies of St. Paul for $33 a share, or about $50 million. Donovan is the parent of the North Central Public Service Company, a gas utility serving about 60,000 customers in suburban Minneapolis and in Iowa, and the Southern Gas Company, a natural gas utility serving 4,900 customers on Florida's Gulf Coast.

headline: 4 Journalists Are Held By South Africa Police
abstract: Four journalists, including a correspondent for The New York Times and two members of a CBS News television crew, were held by the police today for three and a half hours.   The Times correspondent, Sheila Rule, said the journalists were sitting in a parked car at a teachers' college in Bellville, a mixed-race suburb, when they were taken into custody.

headline: KOHL MEETS WITH JEWISH LEADERS
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany shared a kosher lunch yesterday with a group of American Jewish leaders and held what was described as a ''soul-baring'' discussion about lingering ill feelings from President Reagan's visit to a German military cemetery in May.   Participants said the meeting, held in New York, had been sought by Mr. Kohl and was the first such exchange of views since the uproar over the visit to the Bitburg cemetery, which has some graves of Nazi Waffen SS soldiers.   ''The victors and the vanquished cannot have a reconciliation without the victims,'' Israel Singer, secretary general of the World Jewish Congress, said he told Mr. Kohl at the private lunch.   He said he had also told the West German leader that ''we should have had this meeting before Bitburg.''

headline: Home Resale Pace Eases
abstract: Sales of existing homes dropped 1.7 percent in September, but the annual rate of sales still remained close to the best pace set since late 1979, according to a real estate trade group.   The National Association of Realtors said on Friday that existing single-family homes were sold at an annual pace of 3.44 million units last month, down slightly from the 3.5-million-unit level in August, when sales had risen 11.5 percent.

headline: Insulation Contractor Takes On Lilco Leaders
abstract: John Matthews has run for public office on Long Island four times since 1970 and has been defeated every time. Just this month, he lost his second bid to become Nassau County executive.   Now, the 47-year-old president and owner of the Island Insulation Corporation, a contracting company in Hempstead, is in the middle of another campaign - a bitter proxy fight to oust the management of the troubled Long Island Lighting Company.

headline: Exiled Seychelles Leader Is Shot Dead in London
abstract: Gerard Hoareau, exiled opposition leader from the African island nation of the Seychelles, was shot and killed today by an unidentified gunman on the doorstep of his London home, the police said.   Mr. Hoareau's supporters said the Seychelles Government was responsible for the shooting.

headline: A TURK IN PAPAL TRIAL IS DEAD
abstract: A Turk who was being tried in absentia in the Rome trial of eight men accused of conspiring to kill Pope John Paul II died here today of a heart attack, the Anatolia news agency reported.   The dispatch said that the man, Bekir Celenk, had suffered a heart attack at the Mamak military prison and died on the way to the Gulhane hospital.

headline: ON THE LOTS: a bumper crop of used cars
abstract: LAST month, Ray and Judy Broudeaux bought a 1981 silver blue Buick Park Avenue. The two-door sedan is the first used car the couple ever purchased. They needed a larger car because their son is growing up, and ''the price was right,'' said Mr. Broudeaux.   Like the Broudeaux, more and more people are finding the prices of today's used cars too good to pass up. The boom in new car sales in the past few months has resulted in a pile-up of used cars on dealers' lots. That has pushed down prices by 20 percent or more, and generated a medley of new and unusual incentives, as sellers compete to clear their overflowing lots. As a result, shopping around is more profitable than ever. The buyer's market creates opportunities to play one dealer against the other: Confident bargainers hold out for lower prices, larger cash rebates or longer warranties.

headline: IN MALAYASIA, THE TIN CAPITAL, CRISIS IS WORRISOME
abstract: Tin is more than a commodity to this prosperous-looking Southeast Asian city. It is the metal that built Kuala Lumpur.   More than a century ago, Chinese miners poled their way upstream from the Malacca Strait to this mostly uninhabited, mountain-fringed valley to dig at the magic spots chosen by legendary black-clad Malay diviners.   They found ore. And, though wracked by malaria spread by the mosquitoes that thrived in the water-filled pits, the miners prevailed. By 1883, Malaysia had become the world's largest producer of tin, a title it has retained ever since.

headline: U.S. AND MOSCOW ARE SAID TO AGREE ON FUTURE TALKS
abstract: High-ranking American and Soviet officials were reported tonight to have agreed in principle that President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev should hold a second summit meeting after their two days of talks that start Tuesday.   According to a ranking White House official, President Reagan will conclude the Geneva conference with an invitation to the Soviet leader to visit the United States ''to see the American people and learn what makes us tick.''   Mr. Reagan was said to be leaning toward an invitation for a meeting in 1987 in Washington, though State Department officials were known to be urging him to ask for a meeting next year.      Gorbachev Arrives    Mr. Gorbachev arrived today and said the ''first and foremost'' issue in his meetings with President Reagan was halting the arms race ''and its extension to new spheres.''

headline: WHERE H-BOMBS FELL, SPANIARDS STILL WORRY
abstract: Antonia Flores remembers the day her brother saw fire falling from the sky.   It was nearly 20 years ago - Jan. 17, 1966, at 10:16 A.M., villagers say with precision - and Miss Flores was 6 years old. She was playing in a field when her brother looked up and screamed that pieces of fire were falling.   The two frightened children made it as far as their backyard before stumbling among some cows. The pieces did not hit any people or houses - a miracle, the villagers say. Miss Flores remembers how, minutes later, she played curiously with a broken metal cylinder that had hit the ground.

headline: Israeli Minister Wants Sharon Out of Cabinet
abstract: The Minister of Police, Haim Bar-Lev, said today that he would ask Prime Minister Shimon Peres to dismiss Ariel Sharon from the Government for ''consistent breaches of collective responsibility, bad manners and disloyalty.''   The reference was to Mr. Sharon's public criticism of the Prime Minister before and during Mr. Peres's trip to the United States.

headline: Business and the Law;   Golden Chutes Under Attack
abstract: AFTER long accepting golden parachutes, state courts are beginning to frown upon them. Thus, when the board of the Beatrice Companies voted last month to award $24 million in golden parachutes to six corporate executives, many shareholders rushed into court to try to shoot those parachutes down. They were encouraged by recent actions in other state courts.   In 18 lawsuits, Beatrice shareholders assert, among other things, that it was a violation of fiduciary duty and a waste of corporate assets to lavish such parachutes upon Beatrice's top managers. They point out, for example, that William W. Granger Jr., chairman of Chicago-based Beatrice for just four months, is to receive a $7 million parachute once Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the investment firm, completes its acquisition of the food and consumer-goods company.

headline: TUNISIA'S LEADER BITTER AT THE U.S.
abstract: The Israeli air strike near here, and the initial United States reaction to it, stirred bitter criticism from the President of this north African Arab nation.   Tunisia's President, Habib Bourguiba, expressed ''regret and astonishment'' today at the initial White House response to the Israeli air strike Tuesday against the headquarters near here of the Palestine Liberation Organization. As many as 67 people may have died in the attack.   Mr. Bourguiba spoke before the White House issued a new statement today in which it backed away from its original comment on the raid, which it said appeared to be ''a legitimate response'' against ''terrorist attacks.'' The White House said today that the Israeli raid was ''understandable as an expression of self-defense,'' but said that the bombing ''cannot be condoned.''

headline: CORPORCRACY
abstract: To the Editor:   In ''The Forces Behind White Collar Layoffs'' (Forum, Oct. 13), Mark Green and John Berry rightfully argue that many American companies are afflicted with corpocracy. However, they fail to consider the issues of manpower planning and management development.

headline: TAX PANEL SAID TO LEAN TOWARD A 40% TOP RATE
abstract: A solid majority of the members of the House Ways and Means Committee expressed support today for legislation that would place a 40 percent top tax rate on individuals, according to people who were present at the debate.   President Reagan supports a maximum rate of 35 percent, and Administration officials have said he is adamant against raising it. The highest rate now is 50 percent.   The committee, in its second day-long closed session to draft a tax-revision bill, did not take any votes today. But committee members said afterward that the sentiment for a higher top rate than the President had proposed became apparent after a long discussion of the issue.

headline: Ganges Pact to Be Signed
abstract: Irrigation Minister Anisul Islam Mahmud of Bangladesh left today for New Delhi to sign a three-year agreement on sharing waters of the Ganges River, starting next January. He told reporters before leaving that in three days of talks with Irrigation Minister B. Shankaranand of India, starting Monday, he would also discuss a possible joint study of the river.

headline: Allied-Signal Unit
abstract: Charter Power Systems Inc. has agreed to buy the assets of Allied-Signal Inc.'s C&D Power Systems unit, a maker of storage batteries and chargers for industrial use.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;Rio Algom Chairman Confident About Future
abstract: October began on a promising note for George R. Albino, chairman and chief executive of Rio Algom Ltd., the Canadian mining company that early this month started production at the only mine in North America whose main product is tin.          But the promise faded last week when the 22-nation International Tin Council  announced it could no longer afford to maintain its huge price support program, and the price of the metal plummeted nearly 20 percent.

headline: U.S. WORRIES ABOUT SECURITY OF 2 BASES IN PHILIPPINES
abstract: The scene was disturbingly familiar: United States marines in battle gear with camouflage blacking on their faces, moving along a jungle trail and carrying M-16 rifles.   It was a routine patrol within the perimeter of this vast base, with no enemy and no war. But the symbolism did not escape the soldiers themselves.   ''Charlie's out there somewhere,'' one of them joked, using the terminology of the Vietnam War.      A Growing Issue   With increasing anxiety in Washington about the stability of the Philippine Government, and plans under way to invest $1.3 billion to upgrade America's two big bases here, the long-term security of the installations has become a growing issue.

headline: S.E.C. CHARGES SAVIN IN ACCOUNTING VIOLATION
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged the Savin Corporation with violating generally accepted principles in its accounting of research and development spending. The S.E.C. said the violations let the company understate its losses by $49 million between 1981 and 1984.   Accounting treatment of research and development costs has been the subject of continued debate among high-technology companies, which have complained that there are not enough tax breaks to stimulate higher levels of research. So the S.E.C. action against Savin, an office products company, is especially significant to them.

headline: NEW DAM ON BORNEO DISPLACES MORE THAN WATER
abstract: The helicopter swings around for a better view of Sarawak's first big hydroelectric project: there is the dam that catches a valley of water, the dramatic spillway, the bright new building with its humming turbines.   But there is something else on the horizon, almost too small to notice at first glance. It is a little knot of mourners gathered at the water's edge, waiting for this alien lake to give them back the bodies of its first victims, their sons and fathers.   The people are Ibans, the longhouse-dwellers of Sarawak, a Malaysian state on the north coast of the island of Borneo. The remainder of Malaysia is on the Malay Peninsula.

headline: SYRIA REPORTS ACCORD AMONG LEBANESE
abstract: Three of the most powerful Lebanese militias agreed today to a Syrian-sponsored plan aimed at ending the 10-year-old civil war that has claimed more than 100,000 lives, Syrian officials said.   Dozens of previous agreements between Lebanese Christian and Moslem leaders have collapsed in the last decade. But Syria, the main power broker in Lebanon, has said it is determined to pacify its unruly neighbor.   Even sources among the Christians - traditionally the group most hostile to Syrian intervention - said conditions now appear favorable for an end to Lebanon's fighting. But the Christian sources said differences remain over the pace of political changes demanded by Moslems.
